description:
I had been craving for sushi since quite a few weeks and being vegetarian I have visited shizen and chaya a couple of times now. I went to tataki on a Friday evening. First of all, the place is in a very good location on California street. Looks tiny from outside, but long from inside. We just had a 15 minute wait and they dont take reservations on Friday and Saturday evenings. The place is quite clean, not smelly at all( I have experienced a few Japanese places that smell a lot, I mean seafood smell!!). I loved the EDMish and house music there.

About the food - real good miso soup, dumplings in the appetizer and the sushi. All the vegetarian options were great!! They were uniquely made with good combo of veggies like beet and asparagus. I loved their sake too and it is served in a quite decent quantity. 

Overall, I appreciate this place and would come here often as it is quite nearby to my house.
author: Foram C.

description:
Great spot for a cheap and simple but delicious meal at happy hour. Happy hour is every day form 5-7, and has tons of food and drink specials. Service was great - our server was super helpful as we asked lots of questions. He also was all for the happy hour specials, not luring ya to choose the more expensive wines and allowing us to taste before selecting. 

On the happy hour specials I recommend: garlic edamame, Arctic char roll, albacore tuna roll. The fried tofu was just as expected  - aka totally fine if that's what you're in the mood for but nothing particularly special. But hey, $4... We also got the striped bass and katsuo tuna sashimi pieces. The bass was delicious but the tuna was disgusting... stay away. 

Off the happy hour menu we had the seaweed salad (standard, delicious) and the extinguisher roll (amazing, but spicy!). The roll also comes with a flaming mound of salt which is fun.
author: Samara C.

description:
My girlfriend and I were across the street drinking when we realized we needed dinner. We walked in on Wednesday, October 10th around 8pm and easily grabbed a table. Another friend joined shortly after, so we asked for a table for three.

*agedashi: fried tofu served with spicy daikon, scallions, fresh ginger, shredded nori, mushroom ponzu ($8)
*brussels sprouts: sea salt, garlic oil, wasabi miso & spicy agave glaze ($9)
*pork gyoza: crispy ground pork and vegetable dumplings, served with garlic shoyu ($9)
*karaage: marinated chicken, breaded and fried in the traditional Japanese style ($9)
*shiro maguro toro: pole-caught wild albacore belly, N Pacific ($15 sashimi)
*kampachi toro: farmed amberjack belly, Hawaii ($18 sashimi)
*uni: wild diver-caught urchin, CA ($14 nigiri) x2
*shishito pepper: grilled shishito pepper with Hawaiian sea salt and shredded red pepper ($8)
*pork belly: slow cooked pork belly, bourbon miso glaze ($12)
*kikusui junmai ginjo: light & dry, aroma of fresh cantaloupe ($56 bottle)
*kikusui nigori: dry & intense, white flowers & steamed rice ($18)
*cabernet sauvignon: 2014 louis martini, sonoma, california ($14 glass) x2

We all just called out a few apps we wanted and I picked the sushi. I adore uni, so I had to get an order. It was nice and creamy. The two toros were good, though I'm a fan of otoro, so I like my fish fatty. I like it to melt in my mouth. The shishitos were blistered nicely, the karaage crunchy, and the gyoza fulfilled my dumpling craving. The agedashi was plated nicely. Though they had the sauce on the side. Helped keep the tofu crispy, but the flavor didn't seep into the pieces. I wasn't a huge fan of the brussels as I thought the sauce didn't have enough contrast. It was just kinda savory and a touch sweet. Maybe some citrus would have helped? Our drinks were fine. We enjoyed our sake and wine.

Our server was sweet. He was attentive even though I could tell he was busy. We ordered in rounds: drinks, some food, some more food, and then some more drinks, so I know he had a lot on his plate. Plus we were here past closing and they didn't rush us. Much appreciated.

Cute sushi spot for the neighborhood. I've been meaning to try Tataki for a while, so I'm glad I finally did.
author: Elena N.

description:
HH is pretty fantastic - an assortment of rolls, nigiri, hot sake, cocktails, beer and wine for $5. Take a look at their regular menu to compare prices and see what you can get that's the biggest bang for your buck.

We got the cruchy spicy tuna, albacore and avo, katsuo nigiri (tuna), and Nasu Agebetashi, which is an eggplant dish that is filled with yummy umami flavor. Followed this all with a margarita, sangria and hot sake, as well as their specialty Tataki roll. Lots of good specialty rolls on the menu, it was super hard picking only one.

We loved our nigiri and Tataki roll for the freshness of fish. I had never had seared fish on a sushi roll, but it added a nice level of warmth that I thoroughly enjoyed. Their HH rolls are basic but good, and I would suggest trying 2 of them and then getting one of their regular rolls as well.

HH is a busy time, especially for drinks. We got all of our food relatively quickly but our drinks didn't come until some time afterward. The bartender personally delivered them and mentioned that he was quite busy. Our waitress seemed a little frazzled as well, but still took the time to describe all of the nigiri to us. 

Pro tip: if you're wondering what artic char is like we were, she described it as tasting and looking like salmon, but not salmon.
author: Allie L.

description:
Not a bad place! 

PROS: 
+ HH every day until 7pm?! Includes $5 nigiri that were ok quality, and garlic edamame. Great price, especially for SF! 
+ Tataki ramen - 3.5 stars - not bad, milky tonkatsu + shoyu broth and thick firm noodles. (Disclaimer: I have high standards for ramen so 3.5 is good)
+ atmosphere - trendy
+ good service 
+ not crowded on a Saturday night. Walked in and only waited 15 mins 

CONS:
- didn't like how they didn't have chili oil or the Japanese chili pepper, only sriracha, red pepper flakes, or the spicy miso paste. Every authentic Japanese restaurant should have chili oil or Japanese chili pepper :( 


OVERALL: I guess the food didn't "wow" me for 4 stars, but it's a good HH place, food is affordable and decent, and nice atmosphere and service.
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Tataki has great food and a great ambience to match. The BF and I came in on a weekday around 6:30 pm and we were seated within a few minutes. We ordered some small plates and 3 specialty rolls to share, which was way more food than the two of us needed. 

Agedashi tofu -- 5/5
Really good. I especially enjoyed the different globs of crushed daikon, spicy daikon, and ginger that came with the dish. 

Kampachi tataki -- 4.5/5
The taste was a 5. Even though there was jalapeno on top, it somehow didn't overpower the dish whatsoever, instead adding a pleasant background heat (it wasn't too spicy whatsoever). Loved the sauce too. I'm docking half a star for the less polished presentation. The avocado was cut in irregular chunks and overall the dish looked pretty plain compared to everything else we got.

Golden State roll -- 5/5
The contrast of the sweet/tart apple and savory fish was so good. I always try to get a specialty roll with fresher, more citrus-y flavors and this fit the bill perfectly.

Ratatouille roll -- 5/5
Delicious vegetarian option. The fried eggplant was super crispy and definitely didn't taste "healthy" lol.

Tataki roll -- 5/5
My favorite roll of the night! It was beautiful to look at, with a rainbow of tobiko on top. Of course, it also tasted yummy, fresh and light but still hearty and filling.
author: Rebecca X.

description:
WOW! I had such a great experience at Tataki Sushi! I cannot believe I did not discover it sooner. 

What we ordered:
-Tataki
-Nigiri
-Namagaki (BOMB)
-Extinguisher 
-Islander

The extinguisher was my favorite! It was so tasty and had such a nice presentation. Everything else was also very fresh and delicious. 

TIP! snag a seat at the bar! That way, you can watch the sushi being made right in front of you...and possibly get your food first too. Hehe.
author: Mary L.

description:
I love this place. Accidentally discovered it the first time I visited SF and have been craving it since. Of course I came back the next time I was in town. 
I am not big on raw fish and our server was very knowledgeable about the menu and helped me pick out a good starter roll for picky eaters like me. I got the double double which is delicious ! Also the pork gyoza  the best I've ever had.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Good ambiance, not too loud, not too crowded. Fast service, good drinks.

Rolls, appetizers and nigiri portion sizes on the small sizes. Overall food was good though, would give them 3.5*s

Note: they do not serve eel in any form
author: Tom P.

description:
Got takeout sushi from this place and I must say, this place is pretty good for takeout sushi. Rolls were delicious and presentation was very nice as well. Fish quality was pretty decent, definitely fresh. Beautiful cuts of fish. We ordered three nigiri pieces and two rolls. The nigiri pieces were nicely prepared however had a bit too much wasabi which unfortunately masked the flavor of the fish. Rolls, on the other hand, were delicious. We ordered the Extinguisher roll and the Kraken roll. Both were beautifully prepared and equally delicious. 

Definitely really good for takeout. I can only imagine how it's like when dining in. Definitely on my list to try dine in.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Local, sustainable, excellent flavor fish. They have a secret.. a $5 happy hour menu 5p-7p everyday attached here. 

Also try the kabocha pumpkin miso soup... so creamy for being dairy free!
author: Syrah A.

description: I must admit that I can be a basic b*ch when it comes to food. By that I mean, I am content with California rolls and tempura. Came to Tataki for happy hour with my SO and we enjoyed handrolls and cut rolls for $5. It was a solid meal and I highly recommend coming here during this time. Otherwise, you will be paying $7-$10 for a cut roll. It's definitely a good deal! Also, I'd like to mention that Tataki offers the happy hour everyday from 5-7pm. That's rare because not too many spots offer happy hour on the weekends.
author: Briana H.

description:
A great spot for vegetarian sushi options. I went during their daily happy hour and even on a Sunday, the place was packed. I ordered the sweet potato tempura roll and veggie tempura roll - both were excellent. We also tried the agedashi tofu, which was surprisingly good. I'm usually not a fan of soft tofu, but this was very well made with a light crispy layer on the outside. 

For drinks we ordered the kin-san-gria and the Matsushima mule - the sangria was great, the mule was a little too sour. Overall, it's a great happy hour stop. I'll be back to try their veggie specialty rolls next time.
author: Apoorva A.

description:
Really wanted to love this place since the place looks so nice and all the reviews... it was just okay for me

Kampachi Tataki - slices are super thin, dish came out luke warm -  not cool. Although there were jalapeno ponzu and jalapeno slices, did not taste the burn

Spicy tuna roll - maki sized rolls, tuna wasnt bad
author: Christina T.

description:
Im use to crazy sushis with all kinds of weird toppings that explode in my mouth. Don't get me wrong I love sashimi so it's you want that great place for it. Got a mule in their happy hour and nigori sake. Also garlic edamame was sooo tasty. 
I was expecting explosion in my mouth sushi so I ended up getting ramen. It's was very very strong in pork flavor and it was tasty. Just depends what you like
author: Suley Z.

description: As soon as we came in, the hostess quickly sat us down. She was very friendly. Next thing I saw r two glasses of water shown up on our table while I was reading their Happy Hour menu. It says "everything $5" so we ordered everything from this Happy Hour menu. To my surprise, everything is so fresh and delicious for just $5. Will definitely come back again!
author: Amy B.

description:
I love the sustainable aspect of this place. I love sushi and I liked how unique the dishes were. I couldn't tell you what we had because I couldn't even pronounce the names :) 

The only reason they don't they don't eat 5 stars is that they don't want to accept American Express. Not something you expect eating at a super cute nice place. They technically can accept it but avoid it and that's a bit frustrating when you want to take business clients there. Sadly I only come here for business trips so I won't be back. I would evaluate if not accepting is worth missing out on business.
author: Pamela B.

description:
Came here for a friend's departure to NYC.  He actually suggested the place, as he and his girl came here often.  So, this was the first time.  As first impression went, this place was on point.

We had the baked mussels and friend calamari.  Both were well done and well presented.  Had to say, though, they added a little too much salt to the starters.

Their fish quality was pretty decent, definitely fresh.  The fish odor was none.  The textures were firm.  The fish was cut beautifully.  We ordered the 3-4 plate of sashimi with the various fish pieces and two rolls. 

Rolls also were delicious. We ordered the Extinguisher roll and the Kraken roll. Both were beautifully prepared and equally delicious. 

We also had 3 sakes: one was the hot house sake, and the other two were recommended to us.  Without of a doubt, the two that were recommended were my favorite sakes.  Ask the servers, they know exactly what's good.  They know them pretty well.  Just wished I remember their names, but I saw them at a store I would pick them up for home.  Very smooth sakes, earthy, fruity, and tasty.

Rating
Food:  4
Service:  4
Ambience:  3  (It is a little too dark for me)
Price:  4  (Food is expensive; but that's SF)
Overall:  4

Would definitely come back to this place.
author: James S.

description:
Pristine fish and sustainable too. 

But you pay the price. Hello, Pac Heights!

I don't like the high prices and I constantly whine forking over $24 for 8 pieces of sashimi, but I'm a glutton for punishment and at the end of every meal at Tataki, I actually don't mind emptying my wallet here. It is worth it.

Tataki prides itself on providing its patrons with sustainable seafood. They closely follow Monterey Aquarium's seafood watch list. The reason being is to educate the public to refrain from consuming fishes that have been overfished or species that are in danger of being put on the endanger list. So, don't go looking for yellowfin tuna here nor the ever popular unagi. DO get to know your substitutes and feel better that you're helping the ocean replenish life. I've gone to love Arctic char (rich orange color similar to salmon and has soft texture), pole caught Albacore and Mackerel Pike. Whichever choice you make, you'll be sure to have fresh sashimi this side of town.

If you're not up for raw fish, appetizers such as the nasu agebitashi (grilled eggplant), seaweed salad or garlic edamame will whet your appetite. And thanks to foggy SF weather, you can always opt for their hot piping bowl of Tataki ramen ($16). With bouncy thin noodles, some Chasu, menma, nori and an egg, you're in it for a full meal. The complex broth is made up of pork, chicken and veggies simmered overnight, my only complaint is, they are really stingy with the broth. I always need MORE broth!

Since dinner here is always a spendy one (even for just a neighborhood resto), I usually take advantage of HH from Sunday - Thursday, 5 - 630pm. While only a few rolls are on the menu, this is such a steal that I'm a happy camper. Don't forget that $5 Kin-sangria for happy hour! it's a delicate blend of beer, sake and wine to create the perfect pairing for their light tasting dishes. 

I feel good supporting this sushi place and for what they stand for. It's my little way of giving back for the ocean's bounty that I enjoy whenever I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Janice C.

description:
Yum!  Small, lovely sushi restaurant within walking distance of UCSF.  Promotes
Sustainable fish. Terrific sushi with the best salmon skin hand rolls, my fave. Also loved the seaweed salad. Sushi is beautifully presented with fresh flowers or veggies sculpted like flowers. Contrasting colors are so appealing. Service could use tweaking. Server got one of our dishes wrong, we had to ask for wasabi & ginger, and we had to work to order more sushi. By the time we left at 6:00, the restaurant was full & there were people waiting to be seated. I'd definitely return.
author: Sherry S.

description: Came here during happy hour! We got margaritas, crunchy California and crunchy spicy tuna roll, albacore and avocado and the vegetable tempura. All were delicious and fresh! My favorite was the spicy tuna roll. I loved the service and it had a nice chill atmosphere. They had a lot of choices which I'll have to try sometime like ramen and other small plate dishes. The happy hour specials were from $4 to 5 bucks for drinks and food! Great deal!
author: Natalie M.

description:
The bartender is awesome ! Service , food, drinks ! Everything was great :) so glad I found them on yelp ! 
I ordered the double double and IPA of course :)
author: Emanuela A.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of Tataki. 

I've ordered takeaway a few times - so I can't speak to the restaurant setting - but I don't think the sushi is worth the high price. The Spicy Tuna Roll is mushy and you can barely discern the tuna from the 'spicy mix'. Additionally, I usually like to order Salmon Nigiri and they don't list Salmon on their nigiri menu. If you do order it, they charge you $5 per nigiri and give you King Salmon - which isn't significantly better than other Salmon Nigiri in SF. Given these reasons, I'd likely go elsewhere for sushi in Pac Heights and get exactly what I want/save some money!
author: Katie C.

description:
Tucked away in Pacific Heights, lies this dim Japanese restaurant.  

Nigori milky-like sake was ordered up and it was a chill drink to relieve the Friday weekday flow!

I felt like scallops so I ordered up the Tataki Hotate.  It was great!  

Extinguisher was an eye ogler.  They have many rolls and selections of nigiri to order from.  They have ramen and izakaya dishes as well.

Attentive staff. 

Enjoyable dining!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
The ambiance in here was cute and our waiter was so nice!  I liked how they have gluten-free + a bunch of vegetarian options.  There was crispiness to the gyoza which I personally like and the sushi ordered had a little kick to it (also had apples inside --- pretty interesting).
Ordered: pork gyoza ($8), golden state roll ($16)
author: Mikayla M.

description: Great part of town, and welcoming entry way. Was seated right away (Monday evening) and was given water quickly. Ordered cocktails and pork gyoza to start. Good quality meat! I myself ordered the extinguisher and my date, the green flash. Both excellent! Highly recommend.
author: Lacey J.

description:
My friend and I were craving sushi for dinner, and decided to try Tataki. It's located in the lovely Pac Heights neighborhood. We didn't drive there, but it's located pretty close to the residential area neighboring Pac Heights, so I imagine one would be able to find parking if they ventured a few blocks away from the busy streets. It's also located a few blocks away from Salt&Straw if you're looking for a dessert place afterwards :) The interior of Tataki is lovely and has such a nice ambiance. There is a separate bar seating in one area, and on the other side is the sushi bar. And of course there is plenty of table seating. We tried to make reservations the night before, but Tataki does not take reservations on Friday and Saturday. Thankfully, we came at a good time (6:30ish) and were seated immediately. 

We ended up ordering 3 rolls for the 2 of us and ate it all :P We ordered the extinguisher, which came with a fun small flame in the beginning. It was a tad spicy with the spicy albacore and spicy aioli, but it was still delicious :) The second roll was the tataki. It had a mix of seared fish with a sweet citrus shoyu sauce. The sauce combined well with the sauce, and I liked the variety of fish on it. I would definitely recommend both rolls! Our third roll, golden state, wasn't the best choice. The spicy scallop sounded enticing, but the scallop was tiny, and the roll was a little too saturated in sauce. If we could do a retake, I would probably want to try the kingfisher, which has their seasonal variety of fish. 

Service was okay. It was a pretty busy restaurant, so I understand service can be a bit slower. Often times, we had to wave down our server since she didn't drop by often. But when she did see us waving her down, she was quick to come and help us with whatever we needed. Pricing is a bit more on the pricey side for rolls (ranged from $15-17), but I suppose that's the going rate in San Francisco. I heard happy hour is great, and would definitely want to drop by during happy hour next time.
author: Jackie C.

description:
And the birthday dinner! Surrounded by my favorite kind of food and my favorite people. This was pretty low-key but such a sweet and simple place. Garlic edamame, ramen, and sushi. I can never go wrong discovering another Japanese restaurant and Tataki was no different. 

Lights were low, flavor was full, and service was fast. Laughs circulated and dishes were swapped and the night smoothly ended with a surprising flaming dessert. 

When in SF and unplanned, always Yelp. You'll always come across some great little or big finds. Thanks for the birthday dinner Tataki, you were very tasty.
author: Julienne D.

description:
Saw this cute little place on yelp and thought it was perfect for date night. They have a bar, dining area, and sushi bar area. We were seated right away without a reservation on a Saturday around 6pm. The restaurant did start getting more packed within the next hour. We ordered two rolls- the kraken & extinguisher, 12 piece sashimi plate, and the Kin-Sangria and some type of cucumber cocktail. I was not wowed with anything we ordered. The presentation for everything was beautiful but the quality and taste wasn't up to par. The sushi rolls were the skinniest rolls I've ever seen and lacked flavor other than a kick from the jalapenos and sriracha. The sashimi platter was ok. One of the selections, I believe it was the tuna, wasn't very fresh. The cocktail drinks were watered down. My glass was literally 75% ice. You can definitely find much better sushi and drinks for the same price in SF. 

Also, while the busgirl (not our server) was clearing our table, she stacked the plates very high and dropped the whole soy sauce dipping bowl onto my boyfriend's jacket. She apologized, and we didn't make a big deal about it. I felt that she should've compensated one of our drinks or something, but nope. 
.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend and had a good time. Service was decent. Food was average though prices were definitely on the high side. 

There's probably better sushi around for the same/ lower prices. But if you're all about the atmosphere, then this place would probably do.
author: Christina N.

description: What a treat my friend had in store for me!  We started with the garlic soybeans then proceeded to order their special of the day: a fly iwana specialty roll and a chawanmushi with uni, mushroom, and other ingredients.  Great food, service, and comfortably close surroundings!
author: Hayami M.

description: Such a great find, especially if you're vegan or are with other people who want actual sushi. this is Shizen's sister restaurant and it is adorable. A great place to come if you can't get a reservation at Shizen (the case with us) because they have a lot of similar menu items. Definitely would recommend and will be coming back next time we come to SF!
author: Caitlyn H.

description:
If you are ever craving good sushi in San Francisco, you should count your blessings because this city is a gold mine for amazing rolls and fresh raw fish. Whether you are looking for quick and affordable bites (woot Sushiritto), a full course experience (Tekka), or even something in between (omfg Ebisu), SF is dynamite... or should I say dynamite roll?! 

And the most recent place I've fallen in love with is Tataki. 

Tataki is a little sushi bar tucked in the peaceful neighborhood that is SF's Lower Pacific Heights (used to be in other locations like Glen Park). A few weeks ago, my friends and I were looking for a very quick sushi bite in the city. Usually, dinners (even early ones) take forever in San Francisco. And sushi is out of the question if you want to be out in under an hour. But luckily, we struck a gem with Tataki because we got seated immediately and left in under 45 minutes. 

How?? Porque?? Tai sao??? The beauty about Tataki is its location. Unlike most sushi restaurants in the city that are situated in overly popular neighborhoods (such as Akiko's in Union Square), Tataki was NEVER too crowded during the two times that I came. I came with my girlfriend the second time around 7pm on a Sundate (yes Sundate) and though it was busy, we again got seated immediately. 

More specifically, Tataki is located on California Street near the corner of Divisadero. You'd think parking would be bad, but there's usually plenty of parking throughout the day at Lower Pac Heights. It's because the area is more residential than anything else. Bless, maybe I'll move here instead of the busier Sunset/Mission. Both times we went, we found parking in less than 5 minutes. 

The first thing you will notice when you walk into Tataki is that the ambiance is A+. The lighting is dim at night, seating is pretty spacious for couples, and there's CANDLELIGHT in the evening! Personally, I feel like the best times to go are either 1. at night when you are on a date or 2. before 6pm during Happy Hour because some of their rolls are discounted. 

Overall, service is super speedy at this restaurant and food comes out fast. In terms of their menu, they have a good number of combo plates, sushi rolls, sashimi/nigiri, as well as appetizers and drinks. AND THEY EVEN HAVE RAMEN~ differentfood for everyone! Speaking of which, let me point out the ones that I've ordered during my two visits. ...

-Fire Extinguisher (10/10). Usually, sushi with fire is more of a gimmick than anything else - meaning that the sushi is overpriced and you're paying for the fire. Tataki's Fire Extinguisher is definitely not that. One bite of this sushi and I instantly went to heaven. The albacore on this sushi is so fresh and the spices on this roll and a perfect addition for anyone who loves spicy food. Omg I love the habanero masago and the spicy aioli sauce. The fire is an awesome thing to witness too. I definitely think it's worth $14. 

-Golden State (10/10). If you read the ingredients to me before I came to Tataki, I wouldn't have ordered this roll. I mean apple reduction, really? But seriously, this roll is BOMB! The apple adds an amazing to the spicy scallop and seared albacore. Again this is worth the price of $15

-Green Flash (10/10). Green Flash is definitely an interesting roll to order. It's made up of fresh albacore (once again), crab meat, and some chips among other things. If you like some crisp in your sushi, this roll is worth getting. It's $14, definitely worth the price.

-Karage (8/10). I wasn't expecting much for Karage since places can be a hit or miss, but I thought the one at Tataki wasn't bad! It was a bit too much on the breaking (needed more meat, but it was still delicious and I loved the two sauces they had (spicy Sriracha and a mayo one). This is definitely worth $8. 

Overall, even though the food was amazing at Tataki, I have to say the best part besides the atmosphere is their mission; this place prides itself on sustainability and I LOVE IT! I have to give Tataki an "omg, id travel 2 hours for this." With great food, lots of variety, and awesome culture, I'd say Tataki is one of the better sushi restaurants in San Francisco.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Uhm hell yes! After a long day of exploring San Francisco, I decided to move way from the central action of the city to Tataki. While it is more in a slow, calmer part of the city, this restaurant is worth visiting.

Where to begin! Let's see from the moment you walk in, you are greeted with a smile. The modern look of the restaurant prepares you for what you are able to receive - a modern twist on traditional sushi rolls that does not dare compromise the quality of flavors. With extremely fresh fish and a very knowledgable waitress, we were taken on a true culinary adventure.

We decided to get the sashimi platter and an assortment of rolls. In addition, we decided to do 2 sake flights (Yes, two!) The sashimi platter was beautifully presented and as beautifully as it was presented, it tasted even better. There was not a single piece of sashimi that we did not like or felt was less quality than the other. Each of rolls were artistically presented. And then to top it off with the sake, we were left in a day dream. I still dream about returning. My favorite part was the bill. I thought that this experience would come at a bank breaking price, but no it was quite affordable for what we purchased.

So leave the main sushi places of central San Francisco and come out towards Tataki! You will not regret it. I will be sure to upload pictures soon!
author: Tar R.

description:
I like that it's sustainably farmed fish. It's great that places are taking care to make sure we can have good sushi for years to come. 

We started with the garlic edamame which was great. Served hot with a lot of sauteed garlic. It paired nicely with a couple of cold Sapporo's on draft. 

Next was the Double Double roll, philadelphia roll and shrimp tempura roll. All were quite good. My friend always orders the philly roll, it's his favorite. After this we tried a couple different nigiri as well as the extinguisher roll. The extinguisher was good, but not really a must have. It made for a good picture. The star of the night was the amberjack nigiri. We ended up eating 3 orders of it because we liked it so much. It's not cheap, but I will certainly come back to have more of their good sustainably raised sushi.
author: John W.

description: Good menu selection , sushi not very high end but reasonably priced. Loved the Ramen bowl, Happy Hour pricing is good! Will go back.
author: Michael G.

description: Best happy hour sushi in SF. Sustainable, clean and fresh! I moved to Marin and still go to SF just to hit up Tataki HH!
author: L V.

description:
An awesome night of sushi, tataki will now be my go to sushi spot.

I'll be returning for tataki for two main reasons. The first is their mission of sustainability. As someone who cares a whole lot about the environment, it's often tough to eat sushi when I know the problematic role that fish farming and over catching play in our environmental struggle. Yet all of the menu has been sustainably sourced, which is a major feat, and the prices don't even show it!

The second reason is because it's a great sushi place for the gluten free diner. The menu already indicates what is gluten free and what can be made gluten free, and there are plenty of options (definitely not most of the specialty rolls, which is a bummer, but alas). There is also gluten free soy sauce for the table which is always nice.

All this only matters because the food was awesome as well. We got the seaweed salad and the seaweed and cucumber salad, and while both were great, order the regular seaweed salad for a more traditional set with better flavor. We also ordered avocado rolls (super small), butternut squash miso soup which was AMAZING, and a variety of specialty roles that were all awesome. We got a variety plate of sashimi (chef's choice) and honestly felt like the rolls were far tastier. Also had a most delicious mint strawberry lemonade from the bar tender.
author: Tule H.

description: Phenomenal sushi. LOVED the sake flight. The flaming roll literally on fire was cool. The service was quick and friendly and I really loved the atmosphere, including the music. You know it's good when you want to Shazam the music the restaurant is playing! The lights were perfectly dim and I told my friend that it's the perfect place for a girls night or a romantic date. Definitely will be coming back
author: Elizabeth G.

description: This is a good place to go. I super recommended this to u guys cuz I really satisfy their services and the fish is so freshhhhh but the nigiri is quite bit tiny...
author: Jessica C.

description: Good food, friendly staff, matsushima Mule is tasty. Happy hour is super affordable. The islander role is fantastic, filet mignon with pineapple is a  great combo. Kabocha miso soup is great as well. And Zach is always happy to make the meal as awesome as possible. Keep it up!
author: G L.

description: I have been to Tataki more than a dozen times. You can never go wrong with the happy hour deal they offer. $5 nigiri ( scallop, albacore, arctic char, yellowtail, katsuo skipjack ) $5 temakis and makis. And $5 Agedashi tofu, Fried squid and eggplant. Service is excellent, and you can always find a table during happy hour!
author: Mario M.

description: We love this place. The sushi is delicious, the happy hour is yummy (and vegetarian friendly!) and we love how inclusive this place is. There's something for everyone. The prices are very reasonable as well. I LOVE that they take reservations (I never want to wait 2 hours for a table at Shizen). The service here is impeccable as well, something that can be hard to find at a sushi place. Overall, very happy to discover this great sushi place.
author: Hannah S.

description:
I come here for the happy hour, plain and simple. My go to order is:

Fried calamari
Eggplant starter
Artic char cut roll
Spicy tuna cut roll
Crunchy Cali cut roll

And maybe a couple more of the happy hour rolls to top it all off.

Beers start at $4 and the servers are nice and helpful! The new location is way bigger than the previous one so much less of a wait time.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Stopped by for a quick bite to eat and was really impressed! The eggplant had really good flavor, light and slightly tangy. LOVED the gyoza, it had a delicate wrapper and the flavor of the pork stood out...the sauce was good too. Got one roll which was delicious. We'll definitely be back to try more!
author: Chanel H.

description:
We love this place for a date night. We spend a great deal of money here, because we always end up making a night out of it rather than a quick meal as they have a good selection of sake and beers and cocktails (tho i usually just stick with the sakes) and a great dining atmosphere to catch up and socialize. their sushi rolls are all delicious! I also enjoy their standard ramen for a soup dish. the rice to fish ratios are on point! and in true san francisco fashion, they have a focus on sustainable dining. Great atmosphere, there's usually a short wait, but totally worth it!

However, my Uni experiences haven't been impressive. but i might be super picky.
author: Felicia C.

description:
Service was great for the 31 December. 
We took a reservation and our table was ready when we came. 
The food is delicious and well display. 
Easy to find and we park on the street.
author: Naj A.

description:
Just rating this restaurant based on food alone, I'd give it 4 stars. But the experience, as a whole was definitely 5 stars... Or maybe I was just having a good day. 

2 great things about this place - #1 They introduced to me to this fish called Arctic Char. It might be my favorite fish ever. #2 Their house ramen has a very unique flavor. Just worth it to go in for the ramen alone. 

Other than that, the Sea Dragon roll was good overall but had a unique after taste that is hard to describe and I was not a big fan of that. The sashimi plate we had was also pretty nice considering I'm not a big sashimi guy. All in all, a nice ambience that ties the food together and makes you feel warm and fuzzy when you leave. Will go again!
author: Ganesh K.

description:
I can't say no to decently priced omakase!

They have a 5 and 8, and 10 piece option, ranging from $16 to $38 what a steal!  The nigiri were pretty sizable, so the 10 pieces plus an appetizer was more than enough for me.  The selection of fish may not be as extensive as other restaurants, but that's countered by the fact that all their fish is sustainable!  (That's why you're seeing albacore instead of bluefin on the menu.)

As the sister restaurant of Shizen, they offer a lot of the popular vegan rolls from that location.  They have different names, but are essentially the same rolls.  This makes it a great option if you've got a mixed party of some who want to eat veggie and some who just want an authentic sushi experience.

Tips and Tricks
-If you're going vegan, Purple Rain!
-Decent happy hour
-No wait if you go close to opening
author: Jessica L.

description: Amazing sushi and even better service. Zack was super friendly and new all about the sushi and sake. Relatively good pricing especially given that all the fish is sustainable.
author: Dean C.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in SF! They have gluten free ramen which was very tasty. The green tea cheesecake is so delicious!! I recommend this place highly!
author: Summer R.

description: Yum yum yum!!!! Just thinking about tataki gets me excited.  I'm a huge sushi fan, so it's not a surprise I wouldn't like a sushi restaurant. Their sushi is super high end and they have a really good happy hour deal. They have many vegan options (they're the only sushi place I've been to that makes a vegan California roll, and a really good one for that matter!) they just have a lot of choices, and it's also a very welcoming environment.
author: Arja K.

description: We came here to celebrate Father's Day. We came very hungry and we ordered a lot. Every roll was better than the last! Food is amazing. They even brought one roll called the extinguisher that has fire burning. Very nice ambience and the staff is super friendly. It is a shame we do not live close by otherwise we would be here every week.
author: Gerardo G.

description:
Yummy! We ordered the Tataki Roll which was good. My friend ordered the Yuba Salad and it was just arugula but overall sushi was pretty good. 

Service was okay. Had to wait a while for the waitress to come by and take our order after we ordered drinks and appetizers, but overall good experience.
author: Angel D.

description: The fish is good but honestly, I dont get the hype. Particularly annoying is trying to get takeout. They are too busy to answer the phone but when you go in to order, they fail to tell you that it will take 45 minutes to make the 2 rolls you order? hmmmm
author: Hope T.

description:
I hadn't been to Tataki since 2009 and was enticed by the Yelp reviews stating, "it has a great happy hour". Armed with a hungry stomach, I met a friend there and was ready to roll. Sushi roll that is. 

We were able to snag a couple sushi bar seats as we arrived around 5:30, so the place wasn't too crowded yet. The happy hour menu is actually pretty good. It's much more limited than most in the city but, the trade off is the quality of fish. Everything they serve here is sustainable so, you don't have to feel guilty about eating overfished fish. 

I ordered the following: 

- Ikura - decent roe but, generally I love it when they are cured in house. These were not...
- Spicy tuna hand roll - I have to say the nori was excellent
- Five piece nigiri (chefs choice) - It's only $16 bucks and great value for the types of fish they are serving up. A little heavy handed on the rice but, overall a solid effort. 
- Oysters - they serve them two ways and they are dressed up. You end up tasting more of the dressings (yuzu, ponzu) but, they were clean nonetheless. 

I'll definitely be back for another happy hour.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Oof! My wife and I enjoy sushi, despite being vegetarian. We were excited to try this place since they had a lot of vegetarian options on the menu. 
We got the spicy edamame, the avocado roll, the vegan California roll and the spicy tofuna. 
We each felt something was a little "off" as we ate; the texture was just a little too soft. 
It's now been over 12 hours and we've been struggling with ... a variety of gastro-intestinal issues. 
Normally you'd think the non-fish options would be safe, but these definitely did a number on us. Definitely won't be back!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Wow, this was our first time here and the staff is friendly and pleasant. The chefs make beautiful presentations and the quality of fish is delightful!   All of the fish was smooth and buttery and full of great flavor! 
We had the sashimi deluxe and Tataki roll!  We will be back again.
author: D R.

description:
This is 5 stars because of the options.  It has man vegetarian and vegan sushi rolls!!! I've never seen this option before. This is what I loved because I don't really eat much meat.  Also, the veggie ones tasted good. It wasn't yucky tasking rolls!!! :D Thus, very good and I recommend this place - it is unique.

Only downsides are the space is small (like all SF locations) so we had to wait for more than half an hour to sit with a larger group of about 7 people. We also didn't get the normal free stuff that comes with the meal that I'm used to getting at Japanese places like the salad or miso soup. I was a little disappointed in this because the prices were pretty high, but it was only including the roll!  I would go back, but only if I was hosting people or needed a treat. A bit to steep in pricing for me.

Environment wise, it was nice and clean. Nothing like fine dine, but also not fast food. A restaurant that is in the middle that has good service. A recommend checking out, especially for vegetarians.
author: Okapi C.

description:
I really wish Yelp would let us rate using half stars, because I think Tataki is a solid 3.5. 

After seeing the photos on Yelp, I was dyyying to try this place out. I came on a Friday night around 7:45pm and we were seated right away. I was so excited to order the kin-sangria ($8) which is a mix of lychee, strawberry, Riesling, and sake - literally all my favorite things in one drink! But it was okay, I wish it was a bit sweeter. 

FOOD: 

Hotate Tataki Plate ($15): I looove seared scallops so I had to order this! The scallops were delicious but they were VERY small and there was only 6 pieces. 4/5 

Tataki Roll ($15): The good and bad thing about this roll is that they do not skimp on the avocado. There was so much it was the only thing I could taste. Couldn't really taste the seared fish on top or anything other than avocado, tbh. Way overpriced for what it is. 2/5

Nigiri Sampler ($16): 5 pieces of chef's choice nigiri. On Yelp I saw someone else post the 9 piece nigiri combo saying that it was only $22. Nope! It's now $30. In addition to the sampler, we also ordered the iwana, kampachi, king salmon, and amaebi. All the fish was very fresh, but there was just too much rice. 3.5/5 

Overall, the restaurant is pretty and a great place for date night, but for the price you're paying, you can definitely get better sushi - nigiri especially, elsewhere. Judging from other reviews, I'm guessing maybe the sushi rolls would've been a better option.
author: Cecille W.

description: We ordered different plates, including nigiri, rolls, and the izakaya plates. I'd say come here if you want to order a bunch of rolls and izakaya plates. We were told what the special of the day was (albacore belly, but seared). This gave me kind of a warning flag (who sears toro of any kind..? Unless you're trying to mask the quality of the fish you're serving...whatever). The overall experience was good. I enjoyed the izakaya plates the most, and considering that this is a "sushi" restaurant it was slightly underwhelming. I'd give it like a 3.7! Good eats, good service, but strengths lie in non-sushi offers.
author: David Y.

description: Is it the best sushi place I've ever been to? No. Is it amazing? No. But, it's really delicious and fresh. Their Uni was absolutely amazing. It was the best Uni I've ever tried. I tried a bunch of their rolls, and they weren't special. Overall, it was an okay experience.
author: Anna I.

description: This is really a good sushi place. They have delicious special rolls and lots of variety of food in their menu. We had a tonkatsu ramen and 2 different special rolls. The tonkatsu ramen is pretty good but the sliced pork is really fatty. I think they need to give more ramen and more lean meat (I prefer less fatty meat). I love the sushi. We got the golden state and tataki roll. I'll give the tonkatsu ramen 3.79 star, golden state roll 4.35 star and tataki roll 4.23 star.
author: Cheryl E.

description: Amazing Toro & amazing sushi/sashimi all around. Seriously my go-to place now (& probably forever)
author: K B.

description: I've read about this sushi bar as one that uses sustainable fish, not that I'm that eco-conscious. We started off with the garlic edamame and spicy edamame (happy hour). Both were flavorful, but we enjoyed the spicy one more. I ordered the sashimi deluxe. Yes, all 20 pieces for myself! The fish was fresh. I don't remember the different fishes, but I know I didn't like the ones with skin. Keep this place in mind, if you're looking for a place with a variety of fish.
author: Helen H.

description: Excellent service, fresh sushi and sashimi, and great ambiance. We liked the happy hour selection, Too!
author: Susie K.

description:
Came right at opening on Sunday evening and left very full and very content. 

Began our meal with a few choices from the happy hour menu: garlic edamame and fried calamari. The edamame came steaming hot and was definitely lived up to its garlic name. The smell was divine and the garlic taste was very present, but not overwhelming. The soy reduction definitely helped with that and also gave the pods a nice sweet undertone. As for the fried calamari, they were nothing to write home about. That said, I did like that they were not too heavily battered.

For our entrees, we opted to share three plates: hotate (scallop tataki), the tataki roll, and the arctic char/avocado roll. The hotate was definitely divine. The scallop was soft and picked up excellent flavor from the sliced lemon "bed" and brinier masago. The tataki roll was pretty good in my opinion, though I wasn't a fan of it being served drenched in the shoyu already. It definitely took away from the flavor of the fish. The arctic char roll did make up for this though as it was the only dish where you had that nice, buttery soft texture from fresh fish. 

Each dish was presented beautifully and made this meal intimate, yet modern and chic enough to be a nice place to catch up with friends. On occasion, the lights would change intensity though....which was a little annoying.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
One of the best happy hours in the city. They recently extended it to 7:00pm too, and added weekends. Everything on the HH menu is 5 bucks. Including pretty tasty cocktails. 

Went with a group of 4 and ordered a TON of food and drinks for a pretty fair price. The vegetable tempura roll and spicy tuna are classics, but above average here imo. Also the agedashi tofu and roasted eggplant are pretty amazing. They also have a lot of Nigiri choices for the same $5 price tag, cant go wrong with 5 dollar Hotate. 

Great food, very attentive service, and fair prices, will definitely be back for the happy hour.
author: Giff D.

description: This is a good place for vegans who want sushi.  We were a party of 7, 2 of which were kids and one had a shellfish allergy.  We had to wait for 20 mins to get a table.  It was past 8 pm.  After we got seated the place cleared up a bit by 9.  The sushi was very good but the rolls were not very big.  They don't give out free miso soup or edamame.  Nothing was free.  I must say the ratatouille was extraordinary.  It was eggplant and that was the best of all the special rolls we got.
author: Sally C.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants in the area for sure. The food is so fresh. I will def be back!
author: Jillian S.

description:
Great sushi and appetizers. We had the fried chicken which came with two great sweet and spicy sauces and the oysters. Be sure to get the extinguisher roll. 

My only few complaints about this place that is preventing me to give it a perfect score is that the staff was not too knowledgable about the type of sashimi and fish on the menu and the ambiance/architectural layout of the place is a bit inefficient.
author: Christina G.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Saturday with two friends. We were seated pretty quickly. 

I like that Tataki cares about sustainability and I really wanted to love this place. At first glance, the prices seem "low" for SF standards. However, once you get your food, you realize it's because everything is smaller. None of our orders was amazing and the quality of the fish was questionable. I'm no expert in sushi grade fish, but what I was served was kind of bland and had a weird texture. One of my friends doesn't eat seafood and liked the seafood-less rolls.

It's a small restaurant and the service is efficient. I didn't love the food, so I won't be back.
author: Nelya T.

description: My husband and I stumbled on this place looking for sushi in our neighborhood.  It did not disappoint.  We are basically regulars and come almost every week. You can basically close your eyes and pick anything on the menu.  Love Tataki.
author: Catherine T.

description:
UPDATE: I did receive a message of apology from the owner after posting my review. Unfortunately I am not able to go back and give them a second chance, but it was nice that they took the time to respond to me.


My husband & I visited while on vacation to celebrate our 5th anniversary. He loves sushi and I'm vegetarian, so I was excited about all the vegetarian options on the menu. Unfortunately our server sort of ruined our experience.

The food was really good, but it was a little tough to enjoy it because our server seemed annoyed with us. I had to tell him (on his second visit to our table) that it was our anniversary and we'd never visited the restaurant before. He then told me they're known for being sustainable (which I had already read in the menu), and... that's it. Nothing about the different menu options, no welcome, no what are you celebrating... bummer.

So my husband ordered what he wanted, was then told they were out of three of the items he wanted, and then I asked for recommendations. The server recommended all the vegetarian sushi rolls. I mean I can read. I know what my options are. If you don't have any specific recommendations, that's fine, but make something up or be honest. Don't recommend everything your restaurant has, that sort of defeats the point! 

Anyway, it went on like that. Not a great dining experience. The food was good, and the bartender(?) who delivered our drinks was super friendly. Wish he'd been our server! Oh well. Maybe worth another try if we were local, but as we were just visiting for a few days, it ended up being a low point of our trip.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I had a great time here. We live a couple miles away and have been serious about the place.

Had great service by Vivian tonight. We were indecisive about what we wanted and ordered 1 by 1 slowly.

She was attentive, relaxed, & courteous.

Quality service. I'm glad we were her table. Great suggestions.

Even helped us get something that wasn't on the menu anymore!
author: jessica c.

description:
Awesome sushi! 

Came here on a Friday night with my boyfriend, and we were sure in for a treat! We ordered 3 rolls here - all FRESH & TASTY! I love how each roll we ordered had a unique flavor and beautiful presentation. We sat at the sushi bar - which was fun to watch the sushi masters in action. It does get crowded here so make a reservation prior or expect to wait. Not to worry though, as there are many cool bars nearby for a drink before and/or after. 

**Recommended rolls: Tataki roll, Islander, & Sea Dragon
author: Kayli G.

description: Delicious!! A little disorganized getting to a table but once you sit down food and drinks arrive alarmingly fast. The sushi was top notch - beautiful presentation, interesting combinations, and very yummy.
author: Lauren G.

description: We came here for happy hour on a Wednesday night and our experience was fantastic. After sipping on my delicious strawberry-mint lemonade, I asked our server about a spicy crab roll because I didn't see it on the menu. She spoke with the kitchen and they offered to come up with something. A few moments later, she returned with a custom sushi roll just for me - a twist of a Philadelphia roll but with crab and spicy mayo. The service here is exceptional and the happy hour prices are the best in the city!
author: Candy S.

description: Food is good service good but me thinks set up inside is way to basic and cheaply put together. Not trying to be a snot here but to be the #3 sushi restaurant in San Francisco on Yelp you need to have some sort of ambiance right? 1 star on the interior and table set up. Invest a little $  Tataki and you'll move to 4 stars :)
author: Matt T.

description:
Don't come here expecting to get any plain rice or Salmon teriyaki or any grilled salmon dish.  But if no one in your party is picky, there is plenty or sushi that is tasty.  
Our friends brought us here and like this place because of the sustainable fish.  That is a really great aspect of Tataki.  I ordered the Golden State and then, from the happy hour menu Hotate nigiri and garlic edamame.  I loved the quality of the fish.  Everything was super fresh.  The rolls weren't huge, but well balanced.  Nice sized nigiri.  Garlic edamame was a big hit.  We also got brussel  sprouts, but asked for them without pepper and they looked well seasoned, but needed salt.  My 9 year old is not a fan of sushi(doesn't like sushi rice because of the vinegar or most of the fish).  To make it even more fun, poor kid can eat wheat.  So her go-to dish at Japanese restaurants is grilled salmon (aka Salmon teriyaki without the sauce).  Well, they didn't have that here.  What?  No Salmon teriyaki at a Japanese restaurant?  So we tried the waitress's recommendation of a some sort of grilled fish from the small plates menu.  I thought it was tender and tasty, but my kid didn't like it.  To make matters worse, the veggies that came with it were soaked in some sort of vinegary sauce or marinade.  AND...the cherry on top...there was no plain rice in the entire restaurant.  I've eaten at many Japanese restaurants and never have come across one where there's no plain rice.   
If it was just me, I would totally go back for the sushi--especially the Golden State roll, but, next time I'll have to bring food for the kids or just leave them at home.
author: Zoya R.

description:
Went here on our last night in town. Didn't have to wait, was seated immediately. Nice ambience with dim lighting. 

What we ordered:

Garlic edamame: typical (3/5)

Sashimi starter: fresh, fish cut thick and scallops were  on point (4/5)

Islander roll: topped with thinly sliced prime rib and pineapple - different but surprisingly good. (4/5)

UNI: fresh (5/5)

Service was great, prices okay and ambience was cool.
author: Tuyet N.

description:
Tataki has quick service, delicious sushi, and good prices. It's a comfortable environment and they normally have availability. Make sure to get the spicy edamame as an appetizer. They also have a lot of good vegetarian/vegan sushi options and ramen.

They have a great Happy Hour. Normally, I get Tataki as take-out because I live close by, and I have never been disappointed. 

Standout rolls are: golden state, double double, extinguisher, and tataki.
author: Lauren A.

description: Solid place for sushi at reasonable prices. I'll usually order takeout from here as well. Recently I learned about their happy prices on roll which are just $5. They also have tonkatsu ramen surprisingly and it's above average. Good broth and chewy noodles -- but I wouldn't say it's top tier. The place is pretty big and feels like a nice hang out spot with friends.
author: Young Y.

description:
Excellent sushi and their garlic edamame is awesome!

Highly recommend the faux unagi- it's truly something else (not eel at all)

The rolls are fun and delicious, fresh fish and lively atmosphere.
author: Alison L.

description:
Awesome sushi place! Went with here with my roommate and absolutely loved it. 

Food:
-Tekka Roll. (6 pieces). Albacore tuna. The rolls were small so if you're hungry be prepared to order more! $6.
-Extinguisher Roll: spicy albacore, spicy aioli, cucumber, oh yeah and fire. They bring your plate out with a mound of salt that's on fire! Tastes delicious (it is on the spicier side) and worth it for presentation alone. $14
-Miso soup : Tasty, not too salty. Not a huge bowl. It is a starter, after all. $3. 

Drinks:
-We for the Junmai sake flight! Good to share among two people and to sample their different varieties. I believe this was around $15. 

Atmosphere:
-Dimly lit with string lights and a gorgeous wooden interior. Service was fast and friendly. Great date spot! 

Definitely will come back.
author: Naveena S.

description: This was our go-to place when we briefly lived in the city. Though the portions are very small, the quality is good and consistent. Staff and service are unpretentious and attentive. Overall, great experience!
author: Linda C.

description:
GUYS. I THINK I JUST FOUND MY FAVORITE SUSHI SPOT IN SF (not $$$$, of course). LIKE YOU SERIOUSLY NEED TO GET YOUR ASS HERE RN. 

So I've been on the hunt for a spot with the perfect balance of quality and value and I think Tataki is THE ONE. Okay, so it might not be the most authentic Japanese and more on the fusion side, but hear me out.. 

$22 for 9 pieces of chef's choice nigiri. SO RIDICULOUS. So it's not labeled as an "omakase" exactly, but I think it's pretty damn close to an omakase you would get at somewhere like Amami. 9 pieces of nigiri for $22! I repeat, $22. THAT'S SUCH A STEAL. 

Another reason why I love Tataki: they only serve sustainable fish. You won't find your usual salmon, tuna or yellowtail here. That shit is hella basic AF anyway. Come to Tataki to step yo fish game up:

1. Kodai (tai snapper)
2. Kampachi (amberjack)
3. Katsuo (skipjack tuna)
4. Suzuki (striped bass) - BOMB, pulled a DJ Khaled and got anotha one
5. Faux-nagi (black cod)
6. Hotate (scallop)
7. Saba (mackerel)
8. Iwana (artic char) - BOMB BOMB, got another one of these. Imagine salmon but better
9. Shiro maguro (albacore)

All of these are on the menu, so you could order them all individually by pairs if you wanted but why would you.. 

My only gripe is that they are a bit heavy on the rice but whatever, I'll live. 

I am so, so, so happy I found you, Tataki. I will never let you go.
author: Laverne N.

description: The Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen was legit so good! The pork in the soup was just divine and I ate every bite. I also got sushi and thought it was okay... it was cut giant chunks.
author: Tina L.

description:
I have been a fan of Tataki since moving to Pac Heights a few months ago. This has been a regular spot for my girlfriend and I, but the service today was terrible!

- The waiter got one of the items wrong. I ordered a Tataki ramen, but he brought out a Tataki sushi plate. We had to correct him and the ramen eventually came out.
- When my girlfriend's sashimi came out, she asked the waitress for some ginger.  The ginger never arrived.
- Finally, our order of Arctic Char was taking forever, so my girlfriend inquired about it with the waiter. The waiter then goes over to the table next to us and quietly says that they accidentally got a double order of Arctic Char. The waiter takes their plate back to the kitchen and comes back a few seconds later and gives us a plate of Arctic Char. Then he gives the other table their plate of Arctic Char back with a half dozen pieces missing. The waiter obviously had our order replated from the table next to us. We pointed this out to the waiter immediately and he did not seem to understand how disgusting this was. The original plate of Arctic Char was sitting on the other table for 5-10 minutes. I don't know if the other guests ate from that plate, but it doesn't really matter. We asked the waiter to take away our plate and cancel the order, which he did without any argument.

I don't know how the waiter thought his actions were appropriate.  The waiter had no sense of health standards or customer service. Not only did the waiter try to pass off other people's sushi onto us, but he obviously inconvenienced the other table by taking away their plate of Arctic Char during their meal.
author: Mark K.

description:
Meh.

The Extinguisher ($15) has a mushy center. The overall taste is ... not great. I don't know what it is, but something was off. 

The shrimp tempura roll ($11) was a surprising fail, because how do you f*** that up? Boggles the mind.

The pork gyoza ($8) was fine.

You can't order ramen to go.

As for service, I was seriously inconveniencing the hostess with my take-out order and/or existence (lol), but there was a friendly waitress who came by so it's a wash.
author: Crystal M.

description:
This place is a few blocks from my apartment, so I feel like I have to like it. 

All in all, it's a modern, hipster place. Staff is friendly, place is clean, food is good. 
Sashimi Deluxe is great- fish is fresh, plating is nice. Extinguisher is plated nicely, but wished there was more spice... or something. Double-double was great- had good textures and flavors. Tataki is good, but looking back on it, nothing really stood out about it.
author: Mandi W.

description: Really amazing happy hour deals on high quality nigiri and cocktails for $5..happy hour is 5-7pm everyday. Great choice for early dinner.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Fantastic Japanese restaurant. 

The atmosphere is decidedly intimate and modern, with a space that felt close but not suffocating. 

The garlic edamame was leagues beyond what I expected for an appetizer--so savory that I found myself licking my fingers clean (good thing I wasn't with a date). 

The rolls were excellently crafted and the fish was obviously fresh, with subtle and refreshing flavor. 

I also ordered a bowl of the ramen which was fantastic--and I know ramen. The noodles were rich and abundant in a delicious broth that was heavy on the flavor without the salt. 

It was pricey (about $60 for two people) but nevertheless a very desirable date spot with a wine bar across the street, perfect  for a nightcap.
author: Spencer L.

description: The tataki was pretty good and it was clear that some level of creativity and care went into it. However, everything else on the menu was mediocre at best and low-effort across the board with the typical "white people" Japanese food consisting of deep fried calamari and unimpressive rolls. If it had stopped at that it would've been ok and I'd still give a 3 star, but the uni that I had ordered was the dealbreaker: it was spoiled and had a very noticeable and unpleasant sour rancour. Simply put, the quality control at this restaurant is poor, where it should have been the number one priority.
author: Frank P.

description:
Tataki was on my radar for awhile and what I thought was going to be a slow night (a Tuesday night during the holiday week) turned out to be a good night still for Tataki.  We waited about 10-15 minutes for a table, though was quoted about 20 minutes or so originally.  There's always things you like and dislike with everything, so here's mine on Tataki.  

Like:
What they're all about..sustainable seafood.  
How they moved two doors down into a larger space.
Friendly and helpful waitstaff
The chicken karaage - perfectly fried and served with a lemony aioli and a spicier one.
Butabara - Small little pork belly "sliders."  They're open faced on a sweet roll.  Tender flavorful belly and the roll was reminiscent of King's Hawaiian rolls.
The pincho tataki plate.  This was albacore tuna with a light garlic ponzu sauce.  Very light but fresh.  The fish was seared very lightly and so tender!  

Average: 
The tempura roll

Dislike:
There was a little bit of a wait, but luckily we got called up a little sooner than expected.
The acoustics in here - minimal decor, hardwood floors = very loud.
One of the special rolls we got was extremely fishy - not sure if the albacore was that fresh then..I can't quite remember the roll's name but it was fried, I think it was the double double?  It had an orange sauce with it.
The portions are on the smaller side and pricey.

I'm glad I finally tried to Tataki, but not sure if I would be back unless it was for a happy hour, since the prices are kind of up there while the portions are lighter.  The quality is here though.
author: Cat C.

description:
I heard about this sushi restaurant while watching a documentary which discussed the proliferation of sushi restaurants, and  how  exploding sushi demand in almost every country of the world has led to a heavy hit to the oceans blue fin tuna community. 

So although this place does sushi, and they do it well, they tend to serve what is at the time the most sustainable fish in their sushi. A pretty admirable business model.


Up for booze? Boom:  wine, sake, and Sapporo!

Can I just go off and then it about their happy hour? 4 dollar booze, $4 sushi rolls, and $3 seaweed salad? Whaaaaat?  

I am NOT a vegetarian, but boy do they have a vegetarian menu, vegetarian options for dayyyyys! 
And it's very fresh. It tastes wonderful, all of it. Fish, vegetarian. Whatever.

The staff is also incredibly knowledgeable and friendly. I feel like every time I had a drink go empty, they were right there to offer another one. And it seemed genuine, not contrived.

The room is well, well lit. It reminds me of the sunset. Real bulbs, none of that fluorescent lighting carp.

And there is a sushi bar on one side of the restaurant, & a bar bar on the other end. I think it was a full bar, but I'm not quite sure. There's lots of seating, even when it got busy, it seems to flow in a way where people weren't waiting for outrageous times.

These people really know what they're doing. The prices are a little high, a little. But then again, their menu is always changing to sustainable needs, and I think that's respectable and probably requires a bit more labor and change than a business is generally accustomed to. So well done. 

Lots of originality, lots of fun, will definitely be back!
author: Dave K.

description: Gotta love a place that, according to yelp, closes in 30+ minutes and the door is still open yet the little pretentious sushi dar has the need to be a prick about telling us the place has already had its last call.
author: Nick W.

description: Yum! Cute little place that's rather inconspicuous but the food is great. Nice chill vibe - great date night place. We got some sushi and some ramen and both were delicious. Given that this place is walking distance from my place we will definitely be back!
author: Liv T.

description:
Casual, intimate, conversation starter = Tataki. Dim lit rooms with bright accented furnishings, sustainable utensils and overall a laid back vibe. A great place to have dinner with friends or to bring your out of town guests to. 

This spot is trendy, food comes out with beautiful presentation and they have numerous options on sake! Our server was down to earth, sadly didn't catch his name.

 I ordered their tonkatsu ramen ($12), broth was delicious and I was definitely a fan of their menma(bamboo shoots)! I wasn't feeling so great that night so their house ramen keep me content and full. Only thing bad thing I had to say was that the chashu had a weird taste to it and it was too salty for me. 

So if you're looking for a good place to take your out of town guests or to take someone to a place that has pizazz, look no further ! 


OTHER INFO:
- street parking (usual SF parking) 
- semi-casual attire 
- environmentally friendly 
- not great for really big parties
author: Grace Anne D.

description:
I wouldn't put this in the traditional Japanese sushi bar catagory.  This is definitely an Asian fusion restaurant.  I liked the decor. It's fresh, clean and hip.  It's great for going out.  The sushi is just average.  

Now, don't get me wrong, they have fresh fish, however the portions are light and the flavors are just super strong.  We tried some of the rolls, and the sauces and flavors were so strong that I couldn't even tell the actual flavors of the fish.  In fact, it would've been difficult to tell if the fish was even fresh with all the added flavors.  

The one roll that I liked in particular was the Extinguisher.  It was spicy and strong, but I could still taste the tuna. 

Be prepared to spend money. I don't think the portions were that big and it was a bit expensive for the portion size.  Overall, it's just a meh.
author: Shirley C.

description:
This place is awesome, I have been coming here for years. Glad they expanded/moved to a bigger spot. Still the restaurant is tiny. 

The atmosphere is awesome, lots of great comfy bar spots --perfect for eating directly at the bar. They don't take reservations so if you have a big group, be prepared to wait a bit and definitely come early! 

Love the Sashimi Deluxe platter --nice fresh fish.  The speciality rolls are awesome. One is fancier and tastier than the next.  

Service: was good, our waiter was super energetic but a bit spacey.  Overall the staff was friendly and did there best to accommodate our party. 

Awesome spot for sushi, great for a date or with a group of small friends.
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
I had such high hopes for this restaurant because of yelp's ratings. There's no way that it's 4/5 stars with 1000+ reviews and could be this shitty with their customer service.

Me and my friend came on a Monday night, as servers who work at sushi restaurants ourselves, we know when we taste bad fish. 

For an appetizer we ordered the hotate tataki which was super sweet and tasted pretty good. We ordered the kingfisher roll next and maybe because the fish was drowned in yuzu sauce we didn't taste anything bad. We actually thought it was pretty tasty.

We wanted to try their chef choice 12 piece sashimi. It was so nice of them to give us an extra 3 pieces of fish for free. But now we know why it was free. It looked amazing at first but once we started picking at the fish, there were several pieces that had discoloration or it just looked off. Either way, me and my friend didn't want to knock anything till we tried it. First piece of fish we ate was the Tai snapper, it tasted rubbery and bland. We thought it was meh. She tried a piece of the tuna and said it didn't have any taste and tasted like it was too frozen. At that moment I should've known better than to try it myself. I chewed half of it and spat it back out. Tried a piece of the medai and did the same. Sorry but the sashimi platter was unappetizing and gross. 

A girl server came by and asked if we wanted a box for the sashimi since we left more than half the order untouched. I told her what we thought of the fish and she said ok, took the plate away and gave us the check with the sashimi platter still on the bill. I'm sorry what? I'm not asking for free fish because it's honestly whatever to us at this point we just wanted them to acknowledge that their fish that night was bad. I put my card down and once again I told her again that the fish was not good and I spat 2 pieces out and I honestly wouldn't want to pay for something that's giving me stomach pains already. She said oh ok I'll talk with the manager. She comes back and said oh we gave you 20% off the platter and that it's beyond her power.  Our original bill was $78 she comes back with the bill being $70. 

At this point it's not about the fucking money... you as an establishment put out bad fish and expected your customers to pay for it. I'm sure the other stuff on the menu doesn't taste bad but man. I'm sooo disappointed with their customer service.


UPDATE: my stomach is hurting so bad I knew the price for the fish was too good to be true. 

STAY AWAY FROM THE SASHIMI.
author: Julie H.

description:
Really cute Pac Heights sushi spot. Not your typical rolls, but still fresh flavors. All their rolls were good, but their nigiri stood out to me. My favorite was the white fish (can't remember the specific name since their fish aren't the typical sake, hamachi, etc.), and their uni was amazing! I've only had uni at one other restaurant in the city (Roka Akor) which was as good. 

Cost is very normal for a sushi restaurant in SF. Not cheap, not overly expensive at all. Great for a date night or casual catch up night with friends. We were seated immediately on a Wednesday night at 7pm. Highly recommend!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I've been going to Tataki for a few years now (starting when they were in their old location just down the block) and I've loved their sushi. I've had so many different items off the menu and I've been pleased with all of them. 

More recently, however, I visited the restaurant for dinner with some friends. I ordered fresh salmon nigiri and a fried chicken dish. It all tasted delicious while I was there, but a few hours after I went home, I felt seriously sick. I ended up in the emergency room that night with a case of food poisoning. Definitely a disappointment since I LOVED going to Tataki, but ever since that incident, it's not the same to me anymore. 

It may have been an unlucky day or something, so I think first-timers should still give it a shot and see for themselves. Clearly, they have great Yelp ratings so I'm not the only fan. But I'll be staying away for a little while. 

Great things to order: kaiso salad, green dragon roll, salt and pepper squid!
author: Natalie Q.

description:
Some of the best sushi in San Francisco + the bay area.

My girlfriend and I went ham on the menu since there was no wait / I have not dined here prior.

Gyoza -- So damn good. Handmade and perfectly cooked.

Sashimi  -- Chef's favorite. 6 pieces, standard variety. All served at perfect temperature and tasted super fresh.

Mushroom Miso Soup -- Meh, I would stick to the standard next tiem.

Extinguisher roll -- Okay. Overpowered by spice. Spicy tuna had a gummy consistency, wasn't a fan.

Tataki roll -- Incredible roll. 5 thinly thinly cut slices of fish slightly charged for something truly special. 

All the above with out drinks clocked in at a reasonable $59. Service was excellent. 

Highly recommend.
author: Peter T.

description:
Excellent sushi. Sustainability focus means expanding our comfort levels to try new species but  we were pleasantly surprised that Arctic Char was a  suitable replacement for Salmon. As a fan of Saba I was thrilled at the tenderness and freshness of the pieces I was served. Miso soup was as expected and spicy edamame is very spicy but delicious. 

Very casual neighborhood atmosphere.
author: Arlo G.

description:
Tataki just moved into a bigger space (two houses further down the street!) but the quality remains the same. Tataki offers fresh sushi creations (traditional and experimental), plenty of starters and full-on entrees. Plenty of seating PLUS an everyday-Happy Hour from 5pm to 6.30pm - a WINNER!

+ freshness and taste - starters (green beans, edamame) and rolls (spicy tuna, dragon) as well as entree (ramen) were great
+ friendly and fast service
+ generous happy hour
+ sushi bar

- prices - remember you're in PacHeights, expect to pay a couple of bucks more
- parking - street only

Definitely a top sushi spot in PacHeights!
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Interesting specialty sushi rolls and they also serve ramen here! The service was super friendly and attentive. The place was packed on a weekend for dinner so there might be a short wait if you go at a popular time.

They had a lot of vegetable rolls on the menu so this would be a good place for vegetarians too. For the appetizer we got the corn on the cob (~$6) which was covered in delicious sauce and butter and an order of calamari (~$8) which came with two amazing creamy sauces. 

We ordered the double double roll - tempura albacore and masago ($13). It was really tasty and I loved the crunchiness of the roll. My boyfriend ordered the tataki ramen ($15). The broth was rich and thick and the pork was super fatty. I would definitely recommend getting the ramen here.
author: Linda X.

description: I took myself on a date here and it was great! The host sat me down right in the middle of two couples at the bar, it was perfect! I ordered everything on the menu. I felt like a little kiddo in the candy store. I ordered the 24-something piece Omakase and the fresh fish selections were absolutely delicious. I also ordered the monkfish liver and of course, topped it off with uni. The waiter didn't even give me that "all this for you ma'am" look. The ambiance was great and the service was excellent. There is typically a wait however, all the times I have been there, the seating was pretty fast (like I said, perks of being single, you get to fit right into the nooks and crannies of the restaurant). They also have gluten-free options because, yes, unfortunately I'm one of those now. I highly recommend!
author: Leena B.

description: We were visiting San Francisco and looking for a good restaurant to eat sushi. We found it here at Tataki. Great service, food was excellent and overall a great experience.
author: Mike C.

description:
Currently writing this review after our dinner at Tataki.. at another restaurant. My friend and I left unsatisfied and still hungry. 

We really wanted to love this place and we had high expectations...

I work at a Japanese restaurant myself, and outside of work, I spend 4-5 days a week eating sashimi. Although I'm no expert at fish, I would say I keep a fair amount of Japanese restaurants in rotation to at least know what's good and what's not. 

The ambiance is great, spacious and modern but casual. All dishes including the Hotate tataki and the Kingfisher roll were good, until we got to the sashimi. We ordered the 12pc sashimi and they were kind enough to give us 3 extra pieces, priced at $34 which was unusually cheap for sashimi. They gave us tai, medai, shima aji, kuromaguro and some type of sake and none of them were good unfortunately. The sashimi was extremely lackluster, bland and lacked texture. I only had 3 pieces before tapping out.

We let our waitress know about their fish and she smiled and brought us the check with the item still on the bill. Maybe she didnt quite understand? We let her know once again that their fish was not fresh and she came back with 20% off of the sashimi. Our original bill was $78 and after the discount it was $70... I havent had a bad experience at a Japanese restaurant in years. Extremely disappointed that the streak had to end tonight. Never coming back, and would not recommend others to come.
