Keep in mind the place was EMPTY. This came from the 'hostess,' the message that was sent to us through our waitress. It was comical but we complied. Sushi was decent but we already started with a poor taste in our mouth. The hostess' ridiculous mandate made for an uncomfortable experience. Will not return. Poor customer service, our waitress apologized for her ridiculousness.
author: N W.

description:
Food is okay. It was quite pricey - Around $170 for 3 people and we did not order that much. Fishes are sustainably caught so its supposedly "healthier" - but it was quite bland to me. Less choices in fish also as they only use sustainably caught seafood.
The corn appetizer was very nice and the fried calamari and chicken karaage were fried very n nicely and came with some special sauces which were nice. I had an okay experience but I probably won't return. Could get cheaper and better quality with more choices of fishes elsewhere.
author: Jane W.

description:
This place have more reviews than other sushi places, so I was always curious to go. Well, the curiosity killed the cat.

The truth is, it is nothing memorable. Non-Japanese chefs = non authentic.
Some of the fish was too watery, it's because of how they thaw frozen fish in a wrong way. Also the rice was mushy. If you wanna make good sushi, you have to nail it on rice.

We had some 2 tataki and 4 kinds of sushi, and 1 roll. The choice of rolls was disappointing. Almost all of them were "spicy", which means they are not using fresh fish, therefore you have to hide it with spice. 

Aji was the best thing out of all. Katsuo and Amberjack were nothing special. Scallop tataki was not bad. White albacore, which is normally hard to mess up, was so watery, I honestly have never had anything like that before.

The best thing in this place was probably the macha cheesecake. Definitely not the fish.

I do give the 3rd star for having somewhat rare fish on the sushi menu, like arctic Char. That's about it.

Very mediocre and a little disappointing.
author: Cartman P.

description:
Sustainable sushi? Delicious + Sustainable sushi?! I'm hooked!
Came here for a friend's birthday, and I didn't really know what to expect. But let me tell you now, I've been wowed and I can't wait to come back! The five of us (girls) tried practically half of the entire menu!

First off, the Sangria was yummy. Real fruits and real sweet--just the way I like it.
Next we had Calamari and Crab Croquettes for starters. Both were done to perfection! Not too fried, but OH SO Delicious!!
We wanted sashimi so we opted for the Sashimi Deluxe platter. It was a gorgeous plate. But not only was it pretty, it had substance! Everything on there was super fresh. A must-have if you love sashimi everything. 
Now for the rolls...I can't remember all of the rolls we ordered and the online-menu doesn't seem to be updated. But I'll do my best: the Extinguisher was on FIRE! Literally! So pretty and tasty. Double Double, Golden State, Green Dragon, among other things were all mouth-watering. I have no complaints and loved absolutely everything I had that night.

The only thing is that the restaurant is a little small, so arrive early...or late!
author: Athena L.

description:
Tataki sushi is by far by second favorite sushi place in the city. (I actually refuse to review my favorite spot in fear that it may contribute to it getting too busy, but anyways back to Tataki).

Tataki is always fresh, always delicious, the waiters are super cool and I'd actually hang out w any of them outside of the restaurant so yeah they're that cool. Only thing that sucks is they do get busy... and by "they do get busy" I really mean avoid this place on Friday/Saturday nights at all costs and good luck getting through the phone lines to make a to go order.

By weeknight dinner, etc. = money!
author: Nolan M.

description: The kin-sangria may be the most refreshing cocktail I have ever had (and I am a dental student, so refreshing means a lot!). It is an excellent mix of sake, riesling, and fresh fruit - come at happy hour for the $5 price. Tataki has a nice list of more simple rolls for $4.50 during happy hour, so we got a few of those and some calamari to get us started, and all the rolls were very nice. In regards to the specialty rolls, we really liked the extinguisher (it is on fire! so its a kodak moment) and the spicy albacore is really good. The pacific sunrise was also good, if you are into mixing sashimi flavors. We also grabbed the sashimi platter, and Tataki's sashimi was fresh as can be and didn't taste like it was in a freezer for a few years before served, so we were very happy with the platter. Overall, great place, but very small, so it gets packed quick.
author: Nikita K.

description:
They are all about sustainable seafood practices at Tataki so I suppose some San Franciscans will feel good about themselves or self-righteous while dining here while others may not care at all.  No matter your reasons for wanting to dine here there is one most would agree upon and that is that the sushi is very good.  

Although we arrived during their daily happy hour period we only partook of a few of their happy hour items, chiefly the alcohol.  We started off our excellent meal with the phenomenal garlic edamame which was covered in minced fried garlic and soy sauce (I can only do edamame like this at home now from on).  As for the fish we ordered the arctic char, uni nigiri, pac sunrise, and the tataki deluxe which came with 20 excellently seared pieces of raw fish accompanied by a number of sauces.  I enjoyed every item we ordered.  Everything was very fresh tasting and each piece of fish was very tender and had that smooth buttery quality.
author: Erich D.

description:
delicious. Came for dinner on a Friday night with some friends. We put our names down at 7:00PM and were seated by 8:00PM...not bad! It was my first time here and I really enjoyed it.

We somehow missed this on the menu, but a lot of people were ordering this flaming sushi roll that made for great presentation. Next time!

What we ate:
edamame - a little mushier than I like, but tasty nonetheless. 
crab croquettes - super yum. Mixed with sweet potato and not overwhelmingly large.
sweet potato tempura roll - The idea was very cute, but it didn't seem to execute as well as I think they intended. The pink rice wrap ended up looking kind of cheap and plastic-like
12 piece sashimi - We really enjoyed this. Ours included scallop with lemon and cucumber, snapper, tuna (super buttery!), and arctic char. An assortment of seaweed was used to decorate the plate and I found those tasty and fun to try
49er roll - yum
spicy roll - good but a bit heavy

I highly recommend the sake sangria. It was delicious. The sake infused lychees and berries were delicious.
author: Alice H.

description:
This was a really lovely sushi spot in a cute, if difficult to park in, area of town my friend Kim brought us to.

It was a small restaurant, and not crowded as we sat down to a late Saturday lunch.

First and foremost, the miso soup, while not filled with ingredients, was really quite good. 

The presentation of all the sushi was beautiful as well.

The super spicy 'Extinguisher roll'  was delicious. It included albacore tuna, avocado, habanero masago (which actually made it spicy), and was topped with spicy aioli (which helped as well)  - yum yum. Habanero!

The spicy tempura roll, a throw back to my early days of sushi, was also flavorful and nice. (It included shrimp tempura, spicy albacore tuna, jalapeno, and masago) - talk about comfort food sushi!

My husband had sashimi which IMO was decent and fresh but not as great or decadent as it could be, which is the reason for taking off what could have been 4 stars. 

Also, my awesome friend Kim had a vegetarian roll which was predominately mushroom, which my husband thought was good but which didn't really impress me...

All in all it was good quality sushi, beautifully presented.
author: Valerie J.

description:
Great sushi with very fresh fish! I've been here multiple times over the past few years as it's only a handful of blocks from my apartment. The restaurant itself is pretty small and there's usually a wait but if you get there right around 5:15 you're normally fine to sneak in and sit down right away. They have a really good happy hour but it ends at 7 which can sometimes be hard to make after work.

All the rolls I've had are really good; double double, mix it up, 49er and golden state are my personal favorites. The sushi is on the pricier side which is why happy hour is clutch.
author: Lizzy U.

description:
Very good find. Thanks fellow yelpers. Went last night at 6:30. There was no wait and I was seated at a table.  Ordered a crunchy tuna roll on the happy hour menu and a cold spinach salad for starters, along with some cold sake.  The food came in just a few minutes. The sake followed.  Honestly I could have stopped here. The roll was huge and tasty. The spinach. Perfect. The sake. A big carafe for $15. I could barely finish it, but I did!
While I was eating the starters, I ordered two rolls, the Pacifico and theTataki.  I much preferred the Pacifico, which was assorted fish wrapped in cucumber. It was very big and filling. The Tataki roll was good, not great. Maybe I was just too full.  It was essentially a vegetable based roll with different seared fish on the top, with four different sauces/spice profiles. Good idea but didn't melt in my mouth like the Pacifico.
Service was both efficient and friendly.  I liked this place alot.
author: David A.

description:
We came here around 8ish on a Friday night, and waited for probably half an hour.  I think you have to get lucky when coming to this place...I think we got there right as a group of people were just seated, so missed out on that shift and had to wait extra long.  But once we were actually seated, the service was quick and the food came quickly too.

Between the two of us, we ordered a plate of croquettes (comes with 4), miso soup, the nigiri sampler, the Tataki roll, the 49er roll, the Mix-it-Up roll, and a Philadelphia roll.  Without a doubt, this was way too much food, which I learned about 2 rolls in.  

I enjoyed each roll, except the Philadelphia.  There was nothing wrong with that roll, I just personally don't love cream cheese and smoked salmon in my sushi, so that's my own fault.  All the other rolls were superb, especially the 49er roll, which has a thinly sliced piece of lemon on top of artic char, with some avocado, cucumbers, and other stuff in the filling.  I felt like all the rolls were thoughtfully made, both in concept as well as in execution.  Quality!  The crab croquettes were delicious too, but I mean, how can you mess up breaded, deep-fried sweet potatoes, right?  Note: they give you 4 sizable croquettes in an order, and I think that's what did me in.  If you plan to eat a lot of rolls, you might want to skip the croquettes, as all those potatoes will surely stuff you up way too quickly.  A mistake I learned as soon as the second roll came.  Oy.

Price-wise, it's a bit pricier, at about $12-13 for the specialty rolls, and $5-7 for simpler things like California or tuna rolls.  

Overall, delicious, healthy-tasting, and beautiful!
author: Vivian C.

description:
I'm currently visiting SF enjoying the finer life of being a pescatarian by hitting up all the spots in the city with fresh fish selections. Tataki's reviews online convinced me to come in and the sustainable fishing practices were the hook, line and sinker.

We started off with the seaweed salad. The portion was deceiving, we first thought we were going to have this two bite taste and it ended up being more filling than it seemed. 

Then the rolls started coming out. Golden state was pure GOLD in the state of my mouth. Minced apples? Who knew. A must have in my book.

Next was the Early Bird, tasty pieces of filet mignon that even I, the non meat eater had to try. It made miso-hot.

I have had kampachi cooked before and they offered it sashimi style so I had to order. The sashimi were generous cuts at the perfect temperature. I was in sushi heaven.

Last was the extinguisher roll. Tasty and a must have for show but I'll go with something else next time. The first two Blew. My. Mind.

All in all get yourself to Tataki. Prawn-tow.
author: Leslie P.

description: TATAKI = DELICIOUS.  Fresh & always fantastic, it's a neighborhood staple for me.  Friendly staff and unique options.  My go to sushi spot in the city.
author: Bridget C.

description: The best Ramen ever! So tasty and fulfilling, indescribable! Warm recommendations for this place. All of my friends are going to be invited to come with me here ! Great thanks for great service!
author: Milena M.

description:
This is the dream place for vegetarians/vegans who love sushi! They have a vegetarian menu which for some reason is not on their website. I tried the Vegan California and the Ratatouille specialty roll. The Ratatouille is AMAZING! It's warm and full of flavor. Definitely recommend for the veggie lovers. My friends also ordered the Extinguisher, which apparently is their most popular dish. It is delivered with a fire burning on a pile of salt. They also have a delicious vegan mochi dessert. 

My only criticism is that the portions aren't that large (which is expected of sushi), just be warned that if you come here with an empty stomach, you should probably order 2 or 3 rolls. 

I will definitely be coming back!
author: Leslie C.

description: My girlfriend went here because it's sustainable and I'm a vegetarian. I was so excited to find this place that has delicious food and wonderful drinks.
author: Nikole D.

description:
I recently tried some vegetarian offerings at Tataki.  Tataki has been on my radar for at least a year now, as it boasts a more creative veg menu than simply shitake maki and spinach-avocado rolls.  Given its small size (and long waits), the inconvenience of parking, and the frustration with traffic during prime-time hours, I haven't been able to find a good time until now.

I ordered a Mixed Green Salad, a Spicy Tofuna Roll (a vegetarian version of the spicy tuna roll), a Ratatouille roll, and the Hot Potato Roll.  

My review is mixed.  The salad was nothing special, and the ginger dressing was so sparse that, amazingly, I found the salad dry.  I wouldn't order again (although I liked the addition of cashews).  The Spicy Tofuna Roll, too, was a bona fide miss.  Skip it.  It was terrible.  There was nothing spicy about it; there was nothing remotely tuna-esque about it either.  It's a total pass and borderline larceny at $7.50.  My favorite, by far, was the Ratatouille Roll.  A little on the sweet side but delicious.  I'd order it again.  The Hot Potato Roll, too, was good, but it got boring after a few pieces.  

Service was rude.  The female server started to clear the plates from me while I was still eating (and chewing).  While I arrived and ate within a half hour of closing time, there were two other tables still in the restaurant when I left, and it wasn't as if everyone was waiting for me to leave.  This left me with a bad taste.  It was terrible, terrible form.

I sat at the sushi bar.  While it appears that Tataki has a commitment to sustainable fishing (even though there really is no such thing on any commercial level) -- and they have the Monterrey Bay Aquarium Fish Watch cards for people to consult and take with them -- the fish didn't appear super fresh in my opinion.  I don't eat fish, so this was immaterial to me and what I ordered.

I'd eat the Ratatouille Roll again.  I may try the Reggae Roll should I ever go back (which is unlikely), as it was the only other specialty roll offered that I didn't order.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything to write home about either.  My three 3-star rating is generous.  It's really 2.5 stars.

Meh.  I can't recommend, but I understand its appeal.  Franchia in NY is a vegan Korean-place with vegetarian sushi.  Franchia's sushi is off-the-hook.  This was anything but.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: Bomb sushi. Used to come here regularly when it was a "neighborhood spot" for me. Highly recommend the flaming sushi "the extinguisher" because it's on fire and also tastes good. The tataki deluxe is amazing sashimi and perfect to share with a group or a hungry 2-top.
author: E F.

description: I absolutely love this neighborhood gem. They have a really great menu, including a lot of interesting / "out there" sushi rolls that turn out to be very flavorful. It's always lively but not too loud, and the service has always been excellent.
author: Sean F.

description:
There is a compromise made, whenever a restaurant offers take out.  A sushi restaurant is no different.  Offering takeout instantly knocks you down from potential Ino and Okoze status, to sushi rock.  You ruin the experience of people in the restaurant when you have brown bags flying out of the restaurant.  Sushi is an interactive experience, meant to be enjoyed through conversation with the chef and other patrons.  If you want takeout, go get Chinese or Thai food.

I get that this place is driven by its sustainable sushi mission and not necessarily about the quality of the fish, presentation, and dining experience.  However, I don't agree with the decision to sauce every piece of fish on the menu.  

I ordered maguro, hamachi, Saba, and aji....and every single piece had sauce on it.  When I see sauce, I think of interior quality fish - hence the need to mask the true flavor of the fish (or you are a sick person who eat sushi but don't like the taste of fish).  Ordering the extinguisher and spicy tuna roll was a mistake.  They sauce was so overpowering, I could have eaten cat food and not even noticed the difference.  The chard is just an exotic name for salmon.  What was even more foolish and disappointing was the calamari, which arrived after the nigiri and rolls.  Mind you, this was on a Thursday night and not on a random Tuesday or Sunday night.  Also wanted to note that our bill came out to $70 with a tip.

There was a zagat sign that said "sushi snob worthy."  I question zagat's ability to judge sushi restaurants.  Tataki isn't "worthy" but I do support its mission in raising awareness for our overfished oceans.  Hence the three stars.
author: Kelvin W.

description:
Meh. 

First of all I fully support neighborhood type of restaurant. But Tataki was just below average in very aspect. First off the service was not good. A previous review mentioned where the waiter won't refill your water until your ask him, I had the same experience. His attitude wasn't particularly friendly either. 

The sushi was below average for the price. I recommend sushi lovers go to either Umami in Cow Hollow (they might look expensive but for the quality you get it's really good value), or Sushi Bistro in the Richmond. Spending $80+ for 2 people for dinner at Tataki is not worth it
author: Kelvin Y.

description: Drove 15 min out of my way to eat here because Yelp hours said the place was open from 11am to 10pm. Got here at 2:35pm and place was "closed". Door was open I asked if they were open, worker told me "we are closed" in a rude way. Told him he should update his Yelp hours and he just ignored me. Never coming back here again.
author: Rafaella D.

description: Good sushi and fair pricing. We got the crunchy tuna, artic char and avocado, extinguisher (If you enjoy spicey- you will like this), the tataki roll, and kin sangria. All the rolls were good and the happy hour pricing allowed us to enjoy more items like the sake that we wouldn't usually have purchased. The new building has a beautiful interior design and the service we quick and efficient. I would recommend this to others.
author: Sarah W.

description: Very nice Tataki deluxe combo and exterminator flaming sushi for me. Waited for an hour and a half before going into the place. Worth the wait!
author: Yuzhou C.

description: Amazing service and great food with creative drinks. Bartender is truly a mixologist and doesn't show limitations with it being beer and wine only! The sashimi was super fresh with generous portions and the rolls were packed with flavor. Definitely going back again soon!
author: Paige L.

description:
The sushi here was above average, but the rolls were just mediocre. Also, the service was very slow. The restaurant was very cramped.

I got the extinguisher roll, which came out with fire on the plate! Fun, but I didn't love the roll. I don't believe the menu said it had cucumber in it, which it did. I love avocado in my sushi, but not cucumber.

I recommend just ordering sushi, as the pieces were large and extremely fresh.
author: Nikki A.

description: It's a good idea to get here for dinner right when it opens in the evening because it fills up quickly!  Love the happy hour menu!  We had miso soup and edamame along with happy hour spicy tuna and sweet potato rolls - tasty, reasonably priced!  We also had the fried calamari which was decently tasty and the sashimi platter of 12 pieces (3 each of 4 kinds) - the sashimi was fresh and very tasty, plus they give you lots of garnish vegetables that were also tasty and healthy.  Beer was $2.50 for a Sapporo.  Service was friendly -- I could not ask for more!  And this place is conveniently located off of two Muni lines, the 1 and 24.  I can't wait to come back very soon!
author: Maile N.

description: Awesome Sushi! I haven't seen so many vegetarian Sushi options at any other restaurant. Everything was super yummy! My husband who never eats tofu or beets, found those very flavorful. Of course my friends mentioned their meat based sushis are amazing too. They have great gluten free selection as well. Definitely visiting again!!
author: Bay Area H.

description: I started with a sake flight, then the eggplant appetizer was pretty good.  Ramen was good- although a little lacking in quantity, I liked how they cooked the pork.  Waiter seemed informed about what I thought was a pretty wide selection of foods.  I'm still not sure how I feel about the whole Arctic char "substitute for sustainability" thing at a sushi place vs tuna/salmon, but it tasted good.  I'd definitely return.
author: Charles C.

description:
I live a few blocks away from Tataki and have been here a few times for my sushi cravings. 

The place is very intimate and seats only just a couple of tables in the entire restaurant. I would recommend coming here for a date! ;) 

In terms of sushi, their fish is fresh with decent prices. If it's your first time try the Tataki,  Extinguisher Roll (see photo), and Sashimi Regular (see photo).
author: Jennifer L.

description: Really enjoyed the vegetarian sushi (mixed veg and sweet potato). The service was great, everyone was very friendly!
author: Nina J.

description: I liked almost everything about this place. Good ambiance, tasty sushi, and good service.
author: Sara K.

description:
Great food, very attentive service. The pork belly buns were the best thing I've eaten in months, and the sushi rolls were high quality. 

They don't serve eel as it's not sustainably fished, but their "faux-nagi" is made with another fish but tastes very similar to the real deal. I will be going back for sure.
author: John S.

description: This review will be short and simple and only based on their ramen. Omg it is amazing! I live 3 blocks from here and can't stop ordering the ramen. Trust me as a chef and avid restaurant visitor your mind will be blown away! No joke just try it once it is so flavorful and the noddles are just perfect. Great job guys on your new location and new servers too. Everything is way better than the old place!
author: Alejandro S.

description: Very tasty sushi and great presentation. We ended up paying $140 for a party of 2 but we enjoyed our dinner. They have good selection of sushi's and the recommended items by our waiter were tasty and great. We'll probably go back to this place in near future. A little bit pricy but the quality was OK compared to price.
author: Reza F.

description:
I can't believe I've never written a review for my favorite sushi place!

Tataki does AMAZING, mind-blowing vegetarian and vegan sushi as well as great sustainable sushi. Anyone who lives in the bay knows these are all buzzwords in our vernacular, and anyone who knows me understands how much delicious vegetarian sushi means to me. Because, let's face it: cucumber roles are boring. Favorites include ratatouille (tempura eggplant, pepper, zucchini, carrot; garlic) and 
reggae (asparagus, cucumber, avocado, tomato, pumpkin).

If you can't make it to the original spot on California & Divis, they have two other locations (Tataki Canyon in Glen Park & Tataki South in Noe Valley). AND I'm pleased to say I caught wind of a brand-spanking-new creation from these folks that should open the week of Thursday, 1.8 - Shizen. Shizen is a fully vegan sushi bar and izakaya.
author: Amber K.

description:
Not sure what to make of this place ... It's not a newly opened restaurant and so one would not expect it to be run as such. 1) calling them is useless - I believe they just take their phone off the hook ... Busy signal for the last 1/2 hour 2) physically present at their restaurant - takes them while to even acknowledge me. It is a small restaurant. There are 4 people standing behind the sushi counter ... 2 sushi maker & 2 waiters/everything else. They told me - give us a sec ...I figured I'll give them a minute or 2 ... 5 min ... 7 min .... Almost 9 minute before anyone remembered that I'm
Standing there waiting waiting waiting ... 3 people passed me to go to the bathroom ...finally one of the sushi guy asked if I wanted to order ... YES ! 

Tataki roll - excellent
Futomaki - very good
Cucumber roll - very good
Avocado roll - very good 
Seafood salad - way overdressed w/soy .. Too salty
Ocean salad - good

We'll go back b/c it's conveniently located in the neighborhood and the sushi is pretty fresh as long as we can mentally prepare ourselves that this place is S.....l......o.....w     And service it a 'C-'
author: Jay S.

description:
I have been eating at Tataki for years.  In the past, I would have leaned towards a four star rating.  But, now I find it difficult to push for a three star rating. 

The fish is sustainable and I really like their efforts.  The fish is fresh, but the level does very upon visits.  We live in San Francisco and well they ought to be more consistent.

The location is great for me because it is on the way home from my gym and close to the yoga studio.  However, it is a rather small place that can be challenging at times.  The real turn off is the attitude change in service and blasting music.  The servers are too busy chatting it up with one another to, well get you water, tea, or take your order, at times.  They also have an unwelcoming approach.  

In addition, you can't hear what anyone is saying over the music, including the sushi chef who is clearly annoyed he has to repeat himself...ummm maybe if you turned down the music I would not have to ask again.  This is really uninviting and I hope they take the snobbery down a notch and refocus on sustainability and kindness.
author: Kiki I.

description: Awesome new location and friendlier staff it seems that the last small location. The nigiri platter is a perfect dinner. Really long lines and not tons of seatings so only good for dates and two tops.
author: Kate M.

description:
After living in San Francisco for about a year, and checking out many of the sushi restaurants around Japantown and the Lower Pacific Heights area, I would say Tataki is my personal favorite.

Since the rolls have been covered in great detail already here (tl;dr they're tasty, with good presentation, but not cheap), I am instead going to highlight my favorite order: The Nigiri Enthusiast - 9 pieces of chef-chosen nigiri for 20 bucks, and it's never let me down. Something about the rice at this place is amazing, and keeps me coming back.

As has been said before here - be aware of the no-reservations policy and the sometimes substantial wait-times for parties size 2+. If you are a party of 2, try to sit at the sushi bar!
author: Jack H.

description:
I had been here a bunch of times when my boyfriend lived in the neighborhood around 2 years ago and finally came back this past weekend with some friends that were visiting in town.  We were able to put our name in for a table for 6 and head next door to Wild Hare to grab a cocktail before sitting down for dinner (the wait was ~30 min, which was perfect!). I love the sustainable seafood initiative and know that the fish will always be super fresh and tender.  

We ordered the garlic edamame to start and wwoowwww the smell & texture of the added garlic crunch to the edamame is brilliant!  So good! I ordered the seaweed salad (on the smaller side for the price), the tuna tataki (at the recommendation of the waiter), and the shitake mushroom roll (you know for...vegetables..).  The tataki was great & melted in your mouth.  I also tried a piece of the fried sweet potato roll (forget the name) but that was really really yummy & a great choice for any vegetarians in the group!  I docked one star for the waiter being very...blah (literally the only way I can think of describing him) which is unfortunate but my past experiences had been wonderful in terms of the staff.  

All in all, great place for sushi & worth the wait!
author: Raina D.

description:
My group of 12  wanted two tables merged together but the busboy would not honor this so we sat together at the bar area. It is too bad we couldn't sit together in a circle, oh well. This was our last meal before we headed out to the airport.

The service was amazing though. We ordered the Fried Calamari as an appetizer and it was so delicious! The sauce (spicy mayo) was on point. The Extinguisher roll was also quite the show with a little bit of fire on the side.
The sashimi deluxe was a bit overpriced for only 20 pieces... one of the tuna pieces also went bad. I have an eye and taste for poorly controlled food pieces; however, everything else was fresh!


I would come here again for their amazing service next time I am in town. :)
author: Neon H.

description: What a relief! A sustainably sourced sushi restaurant (for dad) with extensive vegetarian options (for mom) that is delicious? Yessssss
author: M. M.

description: There are many Japanese sushi restaurants in San Francisco. I thought this one would be a little fancier at this location, but it wasn't. It has the same type of rolls you can find at most places. I had the extinguisher roll. It was good, but not amazing.
author: Denise C.

description:
A friend brought me here for sushi one night, as it's his favorite sushi haunt and right down the street from him. 

First off, I noticed their claim and - coming from CT - questioned that they're the first sustainable sushi restaurant in the US. Miya's in New Haven has been doing the sustainable sushi thing well before 2009, and I asked them about this. Miya's answer was simply that they've been using sustainable seafood in their sushi for a while, but choose not to use the "sustainable" label. Respect. So, in reality - Tataki might have an unwilling contender to that claim. That said, I won't compare it to Miya's as they are very different in execution. Tataki is certainly more traditional. 

The rolls we shared were excellent and very flavorful. Nothing terribly unexpected, but everything seemed well-balanced and flavorful. 

The sashimi was good, though not great. It could have been more fresh. I've become a stickler for sashimi/sushi at every sushi restaurant I go to, and I've learned to appreciate what truly "fresh" means. This wasn't quite there. 

Service was so-so. Friendly enough, but not super attentive and our tea and water remained empty for quite some time until we finally asked to have them refilled. On the plus side, I didn't hate eating sushi accompanied by a full Tame Impala album. 

All in all, this would normally have been a 3 star review for me - but it gets an extra star for sustainability efforts.
author: Robert K.

description: Not what I had hoped from San Francisco sushi, Yelpers!  We came here because of the four star average and had to wait awhile.  I was fine waiting, but when we actually got seated, we had like 2 inches of clearance from other diners (dislike) and we didn't get drinks or edamame that we had ordered until forever later.  The service was slow and spacey (what'd you order again?  what are you missing?) and the garlic edamame was not good.  Our rolls were okay, but again, I had expected better.  I would not recommend this to out of towners.
author: Laura C.

description:
After an evening of hanging out with my friends at Tataki, we left the joint still feeling hungry and jipped. We showed up early but Tataki has the "we only sit whole parties" sign at the front. This is more of a place for couples who have greens to fork out. 

Tataki has 2 other locations; Tataki South (Noe Valley) and Tataki Canyon (Glen Park). This one happens to be the main location. Personally, I feel that Tataki South had better vibes than this place. 

ATMOSPHERE N F O O D: 
This location was dimly lit, service was MEH, and the food well...the rolls fell apart really quickly. The main spectacle here are the "tataki" items which is pretty much lightly seared sashimi grade fish in a pool of sauce. Yes, you read that right. 
A P O O L of sauce. For someone such as myself who has been eating fish almost all my life, I could really tell if the slice of fish was fresh or not. The Kurodai (sea bream) was definitely not fresh because there was this fishy aftertaste to it that bombed out the sauce too. UGH. 

The Tataki roll at least wasn't as disappointing in terms of freshness. However, when I picked up a piece with my pro Asian chopstick skills, it fell apart as if it were a cake crumble. Like W T F... It wasn't that busy here, but how do you FxxK up a roll that's so simple looking?! Ah well.

S E R V I C E:
Manager, who was a white guy with a pony tail attended our table infrequently. He refilled our water glasses only when we asked him and only came around when one of our orders were ready. In some way, it almost felt as if we were being rushed to order, eat and get scooted out. When we were leaving, there were hella couples outside waiting and mean mugging at us. Hipsters...
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Safe seafood sushi
Fresh
Popular
I'm not taking a star off because it's a long wait to get in.
WAP friendly restaurant!
Plus yUM!
author: Mary P.

description:
We ordered takeout/delivery from Tataki using Postmates on Saturday around 5:30pm.  The food/sushi we received was fresh and delicious, but the order was incomplete and took too long.  Our poor delivery person went to check on the food multiple times and kept getting turned away because it wasn't ready.  It took them over an hour to prepare the food and the order was incomplete when it arrived (one out of four rolls and two out of ten pieces were missing - this was not a massive order).
I may try it in person because it was so tasty, but I'll certainly never try for carry out again.  
If they're not able to accommodate Postmates correctly and quickly they shouldn't participate in the service.
author: Ellen H.

description:
I met up with a friend here last night for dinner. We just missed the happy hour (5-7) but it looked like they had some good specials. Next time! The restaurant is small and can get very crowded very quickly. There is no space to wait inside so bring a coat.

I ordered an Asahi beer and the mix-it-up roll which was good. The sushi had a nice spice kick to it and the fish tasted fresh. I would definitely order it again. The pieces were fairly large and there were 8 of them. My friend ordered the avocado roll, sweet potato roll, and a miso soup. 

Our food was brought out as it was ready. So she got her miso and avocado roll first. A few minutes went by and I got my roll. Then a while went by and asked our waiter about the sweet potato roll. Apparently it takes longer because it's a tempura. But we were basically done by the time that came out. So I would say SHARE. That way no one is left waiting for their food.

When our bill came out, they had forgotten to include our drinks which we pointed out. The guy was appreciative and only charged us the happy hour rate for the beers. 

Overall I was happy with the food, service and atmosphere. Would return.
author: Rachel E.

description:
We beat the dinner rush which was a good thing. That place is small. Small and a very cool, modern, cozy ambience. We were seated right away and were rubbing elbows with the couple next to us. No worries, we were just hungry.

Straight to the food, we ordered two rolls, each of eight pieces: The Extinguisher roll, which is the spiciest on the menu, and the Golden State. I liked the Extinguisher much better than the Golden State, only because it had more pizazz in flavor. The Golden State was good, but there was no "Wow" in it for me. The Extinguisher came with siracha sauce on the side and I dipped my roll in it (it didn't need it) but I LOOVE being hot. For those who love presentation, the Extinguisher roll was served to us with flames on the platter. I was easily amused.

We also ordered a Philly roll, which had salmon, cream cheese and cucumber (?). That was good, but I wasn't really in the mood for cheese. Our calamari was delicious and not too battered.

Our salads, one was the Ocean salad, the other was the Seaweed salad. The seaweed was predictable and the Ocean salad tasted just like the Ocean, with algae and all. I didn't like it too much. 

The service was prompt, friendly and helpful. Though...I think he forgot my order of toro sashimi. It was ok because I was full enough. Good thing he didn't charge us for it.
author: Sharon B.

description: Best sushi I ever had. The tataki roll just melts in your mouth. 10/10 would eat again
author: Kenny T.

description:
Best sushi I've had thus far in the city. Have tried Pabu, Zushi puzzle, ozumo and tataki beats all of them by a mile. Such a cozy environment, every roll is so fresh and tasty. Love the mix-it-up, extinguisher, spicy tempura and double double.

49er roll is pretty overrated though. The most underwhelming of all the roles tried here
author: Kunal J.

description:
So, why don't I just let you know a few of the good & bad things about this place:

+ I still can't wrap my mind about the fact that the service at this place is bad. I mean, the waiter/server has some sort of an attitude problem. 

+ Okayyyyy, the food took forever to arrive. And nobody filled my empty water glass until the end of the meal. I was thirsty.  Rude.

+ Literally though, I like the whole guilt-free and sustainable idea and the whole separate vegge menu but the food was mediocre and a bit pricier than other places.

I will not be back soon.
author: J M.

description:
Im a fan. Had the saba, the artic char, spicy tuna rolls, the scallops. Everything was delicious. Pretty good selection and nothing had that freezer burn taste that some sushi spots tend to have. 

Very small spot but cool none the less. I guess Ill have to come back for this happy hour that everyone is raving about.
author: Brian R.

description: Tataki is the best!! It's so delicious and convenient with a great ambiance. Happy hour is a very good deal and the lunch specials they had at their old location were too good to pass up (soon they promised me they will have lunch at their new location too). The rolls and service are top notch. We love the 49er roll (recently renamed but I forget the new name - maybe Golden State?) and the nigiri is always fresh and delish. You can't go wrong. Tony and JD are the best. They take great care of us every time. We live just a few blocks away and we truly feel like this is our go-to neighborhood place. The only suggestion I have is to open back up for lunch asap!
author: Megan V.

description: I have no idea how so many people can speak so highly of a restaurant with such poor service. Granted the food may be excellent but if you can't serve people who are getting to go orders quickly then don't allow to go orders from your restaurant. We placed an order with them for pick up and when we showed up to get the food 30 minutes later they told us that the order had still not been placed with the kitchen and that we would have to wait 30 to 40 minutes for our food to be ready. They refused to give our food any kind of priority even though it was their mistake that the order had not been placed with the kitchen initially. Do not order from this restaurant unless you have nothing to do for the rest of the day. Quality food is everywhere in the city, I don't need to wait painfully with terrible service at a restaurant that can't get their orders straight to get a good meal.
author: Ben J.

description:
Yummy guilt-free, sustainable sushi!

Calamari appetizer was good.  But, you can't really mess this up unless you use unfresh calamari.

I really enjoyed their happy hour crunchy california roll and crunchy spicy tuna roll, especially because the spicy tuna was actually spicy!  I did find it odd though that they had the tempura bits to make those crunchy rolls, but no tempura to make a side order of vegetable tempura.

Scallop Tataki was my favorite of the night.  The citrus aioli was just the right amount to not overwhelm the fresh taste of the seared scallops.

The Extinguisher was flashy, but not as spicy as the spicy tuna.  I thought it would've been just as spicy if not spicier than the spicy tuna given the habanero masago and "spicy aioli."

Spicy Tempura was also yum!  But, it might be because I am in love with anything spicy tuna that is actually spicy.

I struggled between giving Tataki 3 or 4 stars, and in the end, opted for 4 because the service was good, and even though I probably won't make it out here much again since it's a bit out of my way.
author: Christina L.

description: The rolls here are unique and the food tasted fresh. The night was overall an enjoyable experience. We were celebrating a birthday and kinda went all out. The service was good enough to keep the meal running smoothly. We went through a few bottles of the unfiltered sake which I liked more than the Sauvignon Blanc that was also ordered. I posted pictures of the sushi but we also got the garlic edamame (yum!) and the seaweed salad to get us started.
author: Jacqueline O.

description:
Eating at Tataki is like doing your weekly Yoga. You are mindful of your body and what you put in your mouth while being conscious of how that piece of tuna is going to affect the fish population of the world. Mind blowing...
Anyway, the quality of fish is very good and Tataki tout the importance of serving you sustainable fish so you don't have to feel so bad about poisoning yourself with that bio-accumulated, mercury laden piece of fish that is slowly deteriorating your CNS. Ha, just kidding. 

But yes, Tataki is good. Good food with good principle.
author: Taffany H.

description: This place came recommended by a friend, so we trekked out from Berkeley on a lovely Tuesday. Arrived during Happy Hour (5-6:30) and started with delicious calamari. We had standard spicy tuna, and a few fancy rolls. The super star dish was the black cod. I don't know how I have never had black cod before but it is now one of my favorite meals. Great service, excellent food, and if you circle the block 65 times you should be able to find a parking spot.
author: Cyndi C.

description:
Went with the Nigiri Enthusiast which is basically omakase (chef's picks of sushi of the day), for $20, it deserves 5 stars for value. Fish is sustainable, so they don't have items like blue fin tuna, which is cool and I respect them for doing that (even though I love toro). Also had their cold spinach salad which was tasty! 

+ Great customer service, fun and attentive servers.

+ The restaurant is small and intimate but not obnoxiously so. 

Generally, this place deserves at least 4 stars for the value and environment/experience.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Really liked this spot.  The sashimi was fish was excellent (great shiro maguro) and the rolls were well done.  The garlic edamame was unique and very flavorful.  Staff was attentive, friendly, & helpful.

Worth noting: My roommate was a bit bummed that they didn't have bbq eel or hamachi kama, but I guess that's the catch for a sustainable sushi spot.
author: Kunal K.

description:
Dear Tataki. 

You let me down...

Cold miso soup served after main dishes. Buzz kill. 

Wishing you improvement, 

Zoey
author: Zoey S.

description: It was about 15 minutes before my boyfriend and I got seated. It's pretty small inside but I liked our seats by the window. The service was a but slow especially when I asked if they had fresh wasabi and the waitress said she would check, she never checked -.- we ordered the sashimi regular with 12 pieces for $22. The tuna was a melt-in-my-mouth! But everything else was ok. We tried their special: albacore toro which was pretty good too. We ordered a Divisderoll because the name was so clever but it wasn't anything special. Finally, the fire extinguisher was my favorite. Hint of spicy, aesthetically pleasing and was delicious. Never got our teas refilled and wasn't full. Rolls were small which was disappointing since there's such high reviews here. Probably won't be back but maybe for happy hour.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Tataki is as good as people say - and definitely as crowded and expensive so get there early and be prepared to drop some money. You might as well if you're there.

The sashimi is incredibly fresh and delicious. Its like butter on your palette - but better. They have a great happy hour menu with some good deals on rolls, but don't just stick to that, go for their specialty rolls. They have a good mix of spicy rolls (they're not that spicy) and sweeter rolls. 

I have to say Tataki is worth the hype, its one of the best sushi places I've been to. And I will be back.
author: Analisa S.

description: Best sushi I've found in SF and as you might expect - it's got an Eco friendly premium. 4 stars because it's way too small to handle the demand and is a little pricey. That said, everything tastes great and is extremely fresh. The service is friendly and they do pretty well on to go packaging.
author: Ash R.

description:
First thing out of the airport, and we track down sushi.  Priorities, people!

Good sashimi.  Albacore, striped bass, and amberjack were the 9-piece lunch special.  They were co-ed fresh, firm, and perky.  The flavors work well for a summer lunch particularly with the thin slice of lemon.  The rolls use a grade down, but are ok.  No pink in the ginger, thankfully.  Miso wasn't too strong but was pretty nice after a butt-squishing flight.  The salad dressing could use a bit more kick, but we're ginger-holics.

Sushi without the side dish of guilt is much appreciated.  Made us miss this bay area.  Plenty of metered parking nearby on a Friday lunch.
author: Jason R.

description:
A couple of weeks ago my fiancée and I were looking for a new sushi place to try for dinner.  We searched online for sustainable sushi restaurants and came across Tataki.  It had good reviews online so we decided to get there early since they didn't take reservations.  We were one of the first people to sit down around 5pm on a Saturday.  Our order was:

1) Kurodai
2) Arctic Char with Avocado Roll
3) and the now infamous Nigiri Enthusiast in our eyes

We enjoyed the first 2 dishes and were ready to devour the nigiri.  I went to pick up the first piece of nigiri with my chopsticks and it slipped out and fell onto it's side.  That's when I noticed a black spot on the underside of the fish that was hanging off the rice.  I looked closer and my eye's opened wide.  There was a small black fly smashed into the fish.  Scarred for life!  

The waitress took the plate back and we could see the sushi chef say "oh sh*!".   Caught off guard by the whole situation we didn't know what to do.   Looking back now we probably would have been more aggressive in expressing our disgust at the whole situation.  In return we got a bowl of edamame...

Had the fly incident not happened I would've given Tataki 4 stars.  But now I can never go back.
author: Felix C.

description:
One of the best happy hour deals in San Francisco. Two people can have enough to eat/drink here under $40 including tip during their happy hour (daily 5:30-7p).

Its a small place (although I read they are moving to a HUGE location 2 doors down... you heard it here first!) so large groups won't do well.

The calamari is excellent, so is their seaweed salad and the spicy tuna roll. House Sake is I think $3 on happy hour... thats a steal.

Go there while the happy hour lasts... the new location will be pricey (much higher rent I  guess). I sure hope they keep their happy hour!
author: Sumit C.

description:
I love how you can scarf down all the sushi you want and Tataki ensures the fish you're eating is sustainably caught... oh how I love guilt free gluttony. Of course all of this wouldn't matter one fin if the sushi wasn't good, but as it turns out they have some of the best nigiri and rolls in the City. 

The space itself is attractive (ok for a small group of friends -4 or less- or a date) and service is good too. Yes it's annoying they don't take reservations and this has prevented me from coming more often, but my last visit reminded me how it's worth the hassle.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Impressive.

We ordered the Sashimi Deluxe, really 'cause I'd seen a picture here on Yelp and was curious about the sauce and seasoning parings for each of the fish. Verdict? Genius.  Fresh, flavorful, great presentation. Great tastes you can appreciate.

Mindful and friendly service.

Tables around us had plates on fire - salt with rum tossed on top, lit on fire. Cool to look at.

Small place, but cozy, not uncomfortable.
author: Emmeline A.

description:
This little sushi bar nestled in Lower Pac Heights was a great find.  A very intimate (small) restaurant with competitive prices and excellent, fresh, sushi.  My girlfriend and I were big fans of the professional service, the presentation of the cut rolls, and of course their taste.  

Ordered the California and Spicy Tuna rolls to start which were sprinkled with delicate amounts tempura and the perfect rice:fish ratio.  Next came the Extinguisher roll which had awesome presentation and the perfect kick with the side of sriracha and habanero masago.   To cool down we ordered the 49er roll; this last foray had a creamy slice of avocado on top and a refreshing citrus sensation which I thought was a great twist.

Those four cut rolls with two glasses of hot tea came out to only $37 (we did just make happy hour which discounted the first two rolls).  Overall a great dining experience.  Will definitely be back!
author: Chris C.

description:
Are people rating this place high only because the fish is sustainable, and because there is a good vegetarian selection?  wtf.

I ordered the 9 piece nigiri platter and the Divisaderoll.

My checklist for good sushi:
[x] properly seasoned rice (rice wine vinegar + sugar)
[x] tasty and/or unique sauces/flavors in rolls
[  ] fresh fish

See that?  The fish just wasn't fresh.  Ick!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I don't have words for how much I love Tataki and their Happy Hour specials.

Whenever I come here, I never fail to get the calamari ($5 during happy hour) and the Crunchy Spicy Tuna Roll. I've also tried the Arctic Char with Avocado and Crunchy California Rolls; of these, my favorites would definitely still be the Crunchy Spicy Tuna and the California Rolls. I guess I'm not big on arctic char. I still really want to try the Extinguisher Roll, so I'll have to come back sometime for that!

I'd also recommend the Kin-san-gria for $5 during Happy Hour - it's so, so good (especially if you like sweet drinks), though be careful when you eat the lychee at the end: it pretty much just tastes like alcohol!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Situation: I came here for lunch with a friend yesterday. The restaurant is really small - we actually missed it the first time we walked past it. 

Order: We both got the lunch special sashimi plate, which came with a nice sized salad with sweet miso dressing. The sashimi was really fresh, with nicely sliced portions. We loved the arctic char, albacore, and scallops.  Having read the reviews, we also got one of the arctic char/avocado rolls and were not disappointed. We liked it so much that we ordered another one before we left. 

Service: Everyone was very nice and attentive. We did notice that the food was a little slow in coming out...It might've been a combination of the fact that they only had one sushi chef and we were starving ;-)

Price: $20 each. not bad. we'll be back.
author: Janet Z.

description:
Out of all the sushi places in SF I've tried, Tataki may be my favorite. There's nothing special about its interior and its location is a little random, but the food is solid. I often go places where there's only one roll I leave craving. At Tataki, I left loving every single one we ordered. We got crunchy spicy tuna, the extinguisher, and green dragon all of which were delicious and rich. Both the extinguisher and green dragon were heartily topped with avocado (clearly, tataki knows the way to a girl's heart) and were extremely flavorful. 

Service was speedy and attentive. While we didn't necessarily leave BLOWN AWAY as we had expected, we were definitely extremely satisfied and found Tataki to be better than most of our options in the Marina. Definitely try to go on the early side as this place was packed by 6pm and they do not take reservations.
author: Rachel L.

description: Went here for Happy Hour with three friends, ordered two rounds of beers, two rounds of sake and near 60 pieces of sushi, and the grand total after tip was around $25/person. Steal of a deal if you get there and order before 6:30pm. The sushi itself was just so-so.
author: Eric M.

description:
Deciding to try Tataki after being tasked with the responsibility of finding a place for dinner, our grouped headed up the street from Utoepia, not expecting the hour wait that lay ahead. The two Asians in the group were getting fairly hangry towards the end, with myself convinced that the food would not be worth the wait (those who know me know that I usually will only wait up to 20 minutes for food).

Finally being seated, we decide on getting the garlic edamame, poke, scallop tataki, extinguisher and golden gate rolls, kin-sangria and a glass of umeshu, only realizing as we noticed the fauxnagi on the menu that Tataki focused on serving dishes using sustainable ingredients. The garlic edamame (garlic-y and vinegared), and the golden gate rolls were both excellent. The poke was served three ways (sweet, savory-sweet, and savory), with the savory-sweet style with the vinegared seaweed being tasty, but the other two presentations, the tataki, and the extinguisher roll (which is lit on fire when served) were good, but much less noteworthy. The kin-sangria also failed to impress, being, for the most part, underwhelming and bland.

So, while their food is not bad, and wait-aside, would warrant a 3.5 stars from me, the lack of reservations, coupled with long waits (the space is tiny and only has ~10 tables, with most being two-seaters), knocks them down to a flat 3 stars. Showing up earlier for dinner, especially on Mondays and Tuesdays, supposedly greatly increases the chances of being seated more quickly. Prices are, admittedly, a bit higher than usual, with our total bill after tip coming out to $100 (~$70 without alcohol) - we were, however, comfortably full at the end of our meal. Do note that they have a restriction of a two credit card max per table, so be sure to bring cash if you're splitting!
author: Johnny W.

description: Had a great experience! Sushi was great the only thing I would comment on is the small roll choice during lunch. However it was my birthday and they brought out a beautiful complementary dessert! And sake shots! Great time! And great service! The sushi was fresh and tastes awesome!
author: Allie S.

description:
First off location: Great place and decent parking around for free rather than paying for the meter right in front. 

Size of restaurant: Small- maybe around 8 tables for only 2-4 people each. As well as a bar table in front of the sushi chef area. 

Lunch menu: I came here for lunch and the menu is less than spectacular. It doesn't have many options and the chef apparently makes the choice for what sashimi or nigiri he/she wants to give you. My GF wanted to get maguro(tuna) but we couldn't choose just maguro specifically. (Most likely the chef chooses the sashimi that is getting old).

What I got: I ordered the roll/nigiri lunch combo which is a total of 8 pieces of sushi. The nigiri wasn't the freshest and smelled pretty fishy to me. The California rolls were nicer than many other places but it's just California rolls...

Overall this place is just alright, and I am still in search for the best sushi restaurant in SF.
author: Tj C.

description:
I'm still wavering between 4 and 5 stars for this place. This it the first sushi restaurant I've been to that has an entire vegetarian menu!!! 

The sweet potato croquettes were SOO good. I think I liked that better than any of the rolls we ordered!

I ordered the spicy tofuna roll because it was on the 7X7 list of vegetarian things to eat before you die, but of the 3 rolls I tried, the spicy tofuna was actually my least favorite! It was a little too mushy for me, but I guess they were trying to recreate the texture of real tuna. 

The sweet potato tempura roll and the Veggie Philly were both amazing. 

This is a small restaurant, so be prepared to wait and try to keep the group to 4 or fewer people.
author: Shilpa Y.

description: I never write reviews but this dinner was horrible! I had high expectations based on all the reviews on yelp but the food do not taste fresh nor cooked to order. The tempura was definitely not hot. On my way out i noticed the change of owners notice on the window and that explained everything. Definitely not coming back.
author: Zeid A.

description:
Loooove Tataki! Small and intimate dining area with cool lighting that changes colors to make the dining experience even more fun.

Creative rolls with tasty ingredients go really with the fresh fish. My favorite roll was the Russian Roulette. AA grade sushi with a shot of sake for the person who by chance picks one the potentially lethal aka spicy piece of the roll. Fun game to play while eating because it had us on the edge of our seats who would get the spicy piece + sake shot. I was secretly hoping it would be me (and it was) the entire time because I love spicy food. Sake shot is a bonus.

Great selection of sake - super yummy and well priced. 

Next time, we will try more from their sake selection. I especially want to try their Tataki plates!
author: Veronica T.

description:
Sustainable sushi: excellent ethos but an otherwise poor dining experience. The long wait and poor service overshadowed the food, and the food was average at best.

My friend and I ordered 3 rolls: 49er, Golden State, and Pacific Sunrise. Two of the rolls (Pacific Sunrise, 49er) were misses because of the lack of texture and flavor. The Golden State was fresh, but underwhelming. 

Aside from the food, the overall experience of the restaurant was subpar. Guests are seated side by side with tables just inches apart, and most of the tables line the wall anyway, further closing off space. Our server was dismissive and unattentive from the beginning to end of our meal, and normally I wouldn't note customer service (since that can be a one-off experience) but it was disappointing for a restaurant of this recognition and caliber. Considering the prices and the hype, I expected much more.

There are not a large number of signature roll options here, so I'm disappointed that the 3 we selected were neither particularly creative nor tasty inventions. Two points for an ethical stand on traditional cuisine, but a point back for lackluster execution. This experience left me wanting more.
author: Jennie W.

description:
Sustainable, and delicious sushi...sign me up!  Well, actually, when entering Tataki, you must sign yourself up on the list.  There is almost always a wait, which is fine, although I don't recommend going there with a party any larger than 4. 

Favorites:
* the pacific sunrise roll: cucumber wrap with 4 different types of fish and garlic ponzu sauce (no rice)
* the 49er roll: masago, avocado, topped with arctic char and lemon
* the early bird roll: asparagus, avocado, topped with seared filet mignon and pineapple (great way to add variety in the meal)  
* arctic char sashimi/nigiri
* striped bass sashimi/nigiri

Overall, I have had a good experience at Tataki every time!


Other Notes:
- While dining, you might see a roll come out that is on fire, that is the extinguisher roll.  It looks really cool and all, but it's definitely not one of their better rolls.  Unless you want to take some cool pictures, I don't recommend.
- Tataki has a great selection for those who are vegan/vegetarian!
author: Juliana K.

description:
This place was decent.  A little pretentious considering they dont serve salmon or unagi bc "They're not sustainable" blah blah. I just wanted some standard sushi and it was alright but I'd rather go somewhere where I can get what I want.
Also, better come early bc the place is so small it feels up ultra fast.
I would go here again if there wasnt a better place open.
author: Nicole H.

description: As advertised. Happy hour is good and in a good location. Perfect for out of town folks too.
author: Adam G.

description: Love their double double roll! I'm glad they moved into a bigger place but I must say-- be careful when ordering take out- the online menu is completely wrong with price and now that they've moved some of the rolls are not offered.
author: Bridget L.

description: Hostess thinks she can be rude with a smile and it's ok. Placed a carry out order and came to pick it up at the time that was given. She said it was going to be another 10-15 min. I was like oh wow. She then told me "I think I told you on the phone it would be 30-40 min on the phone and this guy placed his order 5 min before you and his is just ready". Really lady??  Being rude with a smile is still rude. She also pointed out that the restaurant was at full capacity. That's fine but that has nothing to do with your carry out estimate being wrong. She should have just apologized and said it would be ready in 10-15 min instead of scolding me for showing up at the time we were given.
author: Kim K.

description:
If you're looking to disregard all of the successful components of a nice restaurant, simply to consume sustainable product, visit Tataki! 

Where did all of these 5-star reviews come from? Service was awful, sushi was mediocre, ambience was loud.
author: Valerie T.

description:
I am a fan of their food only, NOT their prices. For $$, I really expected affordable fulfilling sushi. But I do have to applaud them on their fish, simply fresh and delicious. 

We ordered: 

kurodai (6 pieces) - seared black sea bream, avocado, jalapeno-ponzu sauce, masago

tataki - 5 varieties of seared fish, cucumber, avocado, tobiko, sweet sauce

extinguisher - albacore tuna, avocado, habanero masago, spicy aioli

49er - masago, avocado roll topped with arctic char and lemon

golden state - spicy scallop, minced apple, seared albacore tuna, avocado, yuzu tobiko

Both the kuroda and tataki were delicious but were not special. I wish I read the menu more closely because I would not have ordered the kurodai if I had read seared. And the tataki had four different kinds of tobiko and not 5 varieties of seared fish. The extinguisher was cool since there was a side of fire but the roll was average. My two favorite were the 49er and golden state. The 49er was refreshing and the artic char was excellent. I actually thought it was salmon until my girlfriend corrected me. And the golden state was so simple but so good. My only problem with the rolls, is the lack of rice. Rice = full and I was not full. Too bad my wallet could not handle paying for more rolls.

What I recommend: 

-- an dish with arctic char
-- golden state
-- 49er
author: Andrew W.

description: The sushi was pretty good here, especially for $10 at lunch, but didn't blow me away. Avocado was kind of skimpy in my Arctic char/avocado roll. I had striped bass, albacore, and Arctic char sushi, as well. The fish was fresh and the rice was solidly prepared: well-seasoned and didn't fall apart. I've had better sushi but I do like Tataki's commitment to sustainable fish. Also, house salad was well-dressed with classic sushi restaurant gingery dressing.
author: Natasha G.

description:
Food Quality : 7
Food Presentation : 10
The Wait : very long
Food portions : small
Price : $$$

This place is just above average. They spend way too much time on presentation. Took an hour for our order to be delivered. The delicious factor is just average. For the portion they give you this place is consider $$$
author: Baldwin W.

description: The Ambiance was cold and the hour was very sub-par. No good drinks and the HH rolls were soggy. Regular rolls were okay, but pretty small and over-priced. The spicy edamame was drenched in some odd-tasting sauce. It wasn't the worst sushi, but definitely not the best in the city. My quest for good sushi continues.
author: Payal A.

description: Solid sushi at solid price points. The lunch deals are very good. Service is slow and not very attentive but it's not all that bad
author: Sai S.

description:
I was brought here on a dinner date with one of my gfs and came in expecting a standard sushi experience. 

What I got instead was much more than expected. 

This small sushi bar is one of the first sustainable sushi restaurants in the U.S and their mission is to serve only responsibly sourced and environmentally friendly seafood. This is totally commendable because when you eat here, you know you are supporting that cause to sustain the biodiversity and health of the oceans. This cause does not affect the quality of food you receive. 

That being said, the fish are soooo unbelievably fresh tasting. My friend and I shared a regular sashimi platter - an assortment of salmon, scallop, artic char, striped bass, and albacore (i believe). Super fresh and melted in your mouth like butter! The rolls I got were yummy as well (I think it was green dragon roll and extinguisher roll). 

For dessert, we had green tea cheesecake. 

Pretty amazing meal! Would definitely go back to get the largest platter of sashimi as that was what won me over.
author: Doris C.

description:
Came in for a quick lunch and enjoyed a delicious chirashi bowl w extra ginger + seaweed salad! 

Beautifully cut and deliciously fresh sashimi over well made sushi rice! 

Small, casual and fantastic place for sushi. Sustainable fish rules! 

Definitely my new neighborhood spot for sushi :)
author: Shanna N.

description:
Oh. My. God. Yum. The happy hour albacore/avocado roll melted in my mouth. I was dancing in my seat to the freshest/tastiest sushi of my life and somehow ALL of my favorite Beatles songs... 

Tiny place, great service, love that the sushi rolls are actually an edible size instead of so big it's embarrassing to eat it in public, and it's all sustainable. So so good!
author: Jessica S.

description: Super good, very original. Went for happy hour got the calamari which was delicious, golden state roll, mix-it-up roll, both very good. Nice atmosphere too, A+
author: Grant M.

description:
Been back here so many times that I've pretty much eaten everything on their menu.  This is my favorite sushi joint in SF so far.  Never fails and always fresh.  

Get the sashimi deluxe; 20 pieces of melt in your mouth fresh fish.  I could die happy after eating this.  Some other favorite rolls are early bird, ratatouille roll, rainbow, spicy tuna and so much more my tummy is yearning for. 

GO and be merry.  The staff is also great and plays awesome music :D
author: Nho C.

description:
+ sustainable sushi
+ renting out the back room for a birthday party 
+ beer and sake 
+ being right next to j line
author: M C.

description: It's good, but not great. There are certainly better sushi spots around the city that are better quality for the same price. A lot of what you're paying for here is the sustainability concept. The extinguisher is by far the best roll, their seaweed salad never disappoints but their salmon sashimi always tastes a bit off - not sure what it is. In a city full of impressive, high quality, creative sushi joints outside of Tokyo, this place comes in at a solid B.
author: Kristy M.

description:
Love love love Tataki! This is my go-to sushi spot in the city. Very small and intimate! They do not take reservations, only walk-in's. My advice, go put your name on the list and go to the bar next door to get a great craft beer while you wait! 

My favorite thing on the menu is the tataki deluxe (chef's choice of seared fish with a variety great dipping sauces). You can taste the freshness of the fish in every bite. The stand out fish is the iwana. 

Go get loose on some Sake and have some incredible fish!
author: Sarah M.

description: Horrible! Small rolls, no flavor, mixed drinks were weak and nasty. If u know good sushi do not go here. The reviews are not accurate!!! SF must. It know good sushi.
author: Lindsey D.

description: Cute ambience. Nice little happy hour which is very affordable. Clean and new appearance
author: Ron M.

description:
Any place that will wrap my sushi in cucumber is already winning!

This was the first place I went to after landing in SF for the first time and it did not disappoint. The food is fresh and they advertise sustainable fishing practices --awesome! 

Paleo friendly. Always delicious. Favorite spot in the city.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
This place is a favorite for Friday night dates with my boyfriend. The ambiance is very intimate and quiet. 

They don't have a lot of the rolls I normally enjoy at sushi restaurants BUT, their fish is always extremely fresh and light which definitely makes up for their lack of variety. 

Their sake selection is also great. 

Tataki is not exactly a destination restaurant, but it serves up a quality meal for neighborhood locals.
author: Casey M.

description: Their rolls are the bomb. The extinguisher role is by far one of the best rolls I have ever had.
author: Ashwin G.

description: Hands down best service, best sushi and just a lovely atmosphere. We had the extinguisher roll which comes with a flame burning on the plate...amazing! We will definitely be dining here again.
author: Danielle W.

description: This is not one of those spots you come to and expect to have over the top friendly service. However what they lack in service, they make up for with their incredibly fresh seafood.  The roll options are very simple and limited. It was a bit of a struggle to order hand rolls the way that we wanted, but eventually they did make it and they were delicious! If you want a local, neighborhood joint kind of place, this is it. The sushi is great, and that's really all you need here, and sake!
author: Sasha R.

description:
Tataki has one of the best happy hours in the city (for those looking for drinks AND food!). Even though I have been here for dinner, I am rating it purely for the happy hour experience.

Every time I come here for happy hour, I order the arctic char and avocado roll...well, 3 orders of it. :X The taste of arctic char is VERY similar to salmon (sake) but it is sustainable. Yay! I am helping the environment AND making my belly happy!

The obligatory spicy tuna roll comes with crispy panko on top which, if no one was looking, I would totally lick off the plate. 

Good prices for beers; the kinsangria is one-of-a-kind and refreshing!

Service is hit or miss...I would rate this place lower for service but Yelp is meant to review food...right?

Words of wisdom - Come early for happy hour (5:30-7pm)! The line gets long VERY quickly. Also, every person in your party must be present before being seated. 

Find me there some time...with 4 arctic char rolls :)
author: Christine L.

description: Really quaint place and super nice service with awesome food. We had a little wait but they brought us out a little taster of wine while we waited. No reservations but worth a wait! Everything we had was great and beautifully presented. They didn't have salmon as its not normally sustainable but suggested some alternatives that were great. Someone next to us had a flaming roll - literally a little fire on the plate, so cool!! Looking forward to coming back.
author: Kelly C.

description:
If you're looking for a solid sushi joint in Pacific Heights...Tataki will do the trick. Being so close to Japantown, it's hard to find a place that serve the best Uni or Nigori, but also a couple of solid standard rolls.

Tataki is that happy medium. It's affordable, has a great Happy Hour (until 7) and serves the most authentic Sushi offerings along with a good selection of specialty rolls. It's a quaint space, so this isn't the best place for a large group, but definitely a solid choice for a party of 2-4. 

When craving Sushi within walking distance, I'll definitely come back to Tataki.

The Extinguisher Roll is delicious and an order of Edamame gets you a generous portion.
author: Mandy A.

description:
I love when sushi restaurants create their own spin on traditional sushi rolls. Tataki did not disappoint! We ordered the 12-piece nigiri plate (among other dishes).  Though the server was unable to predict what kinds of fish the chef would select, everything was very fresh, tasty, and innovative.

Service was good.  The berry sangria was delicious. The restaurant itself is small, so be prepared to wait, unless you can make a reservation.  I can't wait to return and try new rolls!
author: Viviana L.

description:
5 stars: Arctic Char with Avocado, Uni
4 stars: Crunchy Spicy Tuna Roll
3 stars: Sweet Potato Tempura, Deep Fried Calamari, Kin Sangria, Golden State Roll

Overall, 4 stars because the 5 star items were delicious.
author: Crystal W.

description:
I really can't say enough about how much I love San Francisco. I feel like every visit is an opportunity to find my next favorite restaurant. Now, with there being so many sushi restaurants it's hard to narrow down just one, especially when you're staying in the heart of Japan Town.
Let me tell you, Tataki is worth the wait. If you don't have to wait, you're lucky, we did. If you do, go next door and grab a drink. Trust me. This fish is not your everyday sushi fish. The freshness is second to none. The uni is unbelievable and this is coming from and anti uni eater. (until Tataki).  Everything we had was good, the rolls, sushi, nigiri, sake, all of it. 

Now, the cons.
It's small. There isn't a whole bunch of seating so there will likely be a bit of a wait. They are busy. Real busy. Service is on the slower side. Don't expect to be in and out. Enjoy it.
author: Kayci S.

description:
Definitely yelp-overrated. Two stars as the quality of the food isn't great. But you know, major props to those who rate Tataki 5 stars for guilt-free, sustainable eating. With many countries fishing huge schools of fish out of the ocean, I wanted to check out this place to see what guilt-free sushi would be like.

However, as a person who enjoys fatty, delicious ocean-bred wild sashimi, I was very underwhelmed the taste, quality and texture of the fish here. Wild ocean fish clearly eat a very different diet from the more local farm fish or freshwater fish, and the addage "You are what you eat" applies here. 

I tried the Extinguisher, Tataki, Hotate, and various nigiri, along with their cooked hot foods and overall felt empty in both my stomach and wallet. 

On the plus side, I enjoyed the decor and the service was responsive, although they were a little overwhelmed and not always check in on us enough.
author: Lars B.

description: Service is 100% better. Food is amazing... I love their tataki! So happy this place is in my hood.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
I live in the area but last night was the first time trying Tataki and I will definitely return.  

The two of us ordered the double-double roll which my boyfriend loved.  My favorite was the 49er roll - the fresh lemon was perfect with the arctic char.  

We also ordered a couple items from their happy hour menu but they weren't too impressive.  The crispy tuna roll was tasty but had a brown sauce on it that I couldn't exactly identify.  And we had their calamari but it was so dry and chewy that we didn't even finish it.

All in all, we enjoyed our meal.
author: Nicole T.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday back in January. After searching for a good sushi place in SF this was the one I decided on and we were not disappointed. 

Parking sucked, but it's San Francisco. We went on a Thursday night around 7:30pm and only had to wait 5 minutes for a table. The inside is not that big and does not sit very many people, so I'd imagine that on a weekend night this place gets pretty packed. I'm not a fan of the decor. I hate pretentious looking sushi places and this place fits into that category, but you can't deny good food when you taste it.

We ordered:
- One bottle of Nigori Sake ($10)
- Tataki Deluxe ($30)
- Extinguisher Roll ($13)
- Golden State Roll ($15)

I was kind of afraid that all the hype was only because of the sustainable sushi, but I was happy to find that it wasn't. The menu is small, but I think their selection is great. The Tataki Deluxe was by far our favorite thing we ordered.The Deluxe came with Kanpachi served with jalapeno ponzu sauce, Arctic Char served with yuzu citrus sauce, Albacore served with garlic sauce, Skipjack Tuna served with garlic sauce, and Yellowfin Tuna served with tataki sauce. Every piece of fish was fresh, tender, and melted in our mouths. Even though it's kind of pricey, it's totally worth every penny. For $30 you get a little taste of everything and it is delicious. The other two rolls were really good too. I preferred the Extinguisher Roll over the Golden State. The Extinguisher had a good spicy kick to it, but not so spicy that it'd kill your palette. 

In the end Tataki lived up to our expectation. Try it out for yourself and see.
author: Eifeh S.

description:
I don't know if it's really expensive or my low wages are just making me touchier about it but tataki makes some solid rolls and apetizers. Especially the poke salad, which as an avid poke fanatic (sort of sounds like i'm really in to pokemon which i guess i still am) it's not really poke like you'd get in hawaii but it's pretty creative and tasty.

Pass on the fancy edamame. It's one of the rare things i've eaten that I will declare as being much too salty.
author: Misha T.

description: We came into tataki at random just trying to find a good new sushi place. It was amazing! The fish was incredibly fresh, the rolls were unique without being overbearing, and the ambiance was exactly what you wanted from a little sushi place. The waiters were very nice and helpful the whole time. definitely one of my favorite sushi places in the city.
