author: Lily C.

description: A cute, neighborhood sushi place with fresh fish and great specials pre-7pm.  We shared 3 rolls and an ocean salad (highly recommended -- a nice combination of seaweed and veggies) and received a bill for $20.  In San Francisco, that's pretty incredible, especially for this quality.  I'll definitely be back, and will try some of their nigiri.
author: Trent W.

description:
Rush hour.

It's OK to be stuck with Armin: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kkR5c6n48Os

It's less OK to be made not to feel welcome.

First things first: This location is better than Noe Valley: http://www.yelp.com/biz/tataki-south-san-francisco#hrid:iblgwcmHgH6Q3xvwO-V4hQ

Certainly appreciate the dedication to sustainability.

Vegan California roll (bean curd, vegan mayo) and reggae roll (asparagus tempura, cucumber, tomato and shredded pumpkin) were both inventive and good.

Skipjack tuna with sweet mustard sounded promising. Not impressed with the bland cuts of fish and the sauce lacked both sweetness and mustard.

Mixed veggie roll was the best. Simple. Not fussy.

Sake sangria lived up to the hype. Smooth and full of fruit. Perfect.

Liked the compact space. Tables are at a premium, the atmosphere is buzzing and a fine selection of EDM sets the mood.

All overshadowed by service that felt rushed and indifferent. Not asked once how we liked our meal, just present to remind us to order and clear plates.

Prices this high need a purpose (sustainability) but also quality and genuine warmth from the staff. Got some. Not all.
author: Jason B.

description:
I just came back from an atrocious dining experience here tonight (9/24/2012). 

I've had a great experience dining at this establishment in the past. Its a shame because the food here is excellent and it pains me that this awful experience might be enough for me to NEVER come back here again. 

I came here with my mom who was visiting from out of town and we were promptly seated. We ordered the Tataki Deluxe and two rolls. 5 minutes later, two other customers right next to us were seated and ordered a few rolls. I had the reasonable expectation that we would get our food since we came first. Not only did the customers next to us get their food before us, they were almost done with their food while we were still waiting. 

I don't think its unreasonable for me to expect our food to come before other customers who  come in after us, but the waiter was not upfront from the beginning on how long it would take for the Tataki Deluxe to work on. They could of served us the other two rolls before serving us the Tataki Deluxe so we could at least have something to much on. On top of us waiting hungrily for our food, the waiter did nothing to rectify the situation. He coldly told us "well....you'll just have to wait..." and walked off completely apathetic.

My mom and I left that night without ever getting our food. We ended up going to the another restaurant down the street.I felt completely bummed, since I wanted to show her the best of what my neighborhood had to offer. Its unfortunate, I come to this place to eat alot. Again, the food here is great and this is the first time I've had an issue with the service, but after tonight and the way I was treated by the waiter working there tonight, I don't feel like I could ever come back. 

I wrote this review in hopes that someone from Tataki actually reads this. Here are some pointers for the future:

1) Make expectations clear from the beginning for your customers. Again, I don't mind waiting longer for food if it takes awhile to prep, I would of been completely fine with that if you had been upfront from the beginning.

2) Attitude - At least try to be sympathetic towards your customers and attempt to rectify the situation. Our waiter was cold, disengaged, and apathetic.
author: CJ P.

description:
wow. ridiculous. The host was super rude too! 

On a Friday night, we came with a party of 5, and waited for over 1 hour and was still not seated...We arrived at 8:30pm.

Big parties here are not recommended!

I just don't understand why they can't push the tables together and accommodate us. There are only 2 booth for parties of 6 max, i think.

All the couples and pairs, who showed up after us, were all seated, while our group was out there waiting.

Eh, maybe my anger settles, I will give this place another try, but be forewarn--BIG parties stay away!!
author: Jen H.

description:
I'm always on the hunt for the best sushi places in SF and so far this one takes the cake. 

Super tiny place, though they generally get you seated pretty quickly, with creative sushi rolls and fantastic presentation. 

Don't recommend going with a group larger than 4, gets a little cramped.
author: Nadine H.

description:
Nope not really a fan. I came here with my bff and bf since she was coming from out of town I thought we'd all try something new.
In my opinion the food was more pricey for the quality of food that was given. I would have hoped for more food for the price. Plus the taste of the sushi was just alright. Dont think I will return
author: Natasha I.

description: We love walking to Tataki on a late afternoon and have a delicious sushi. Our favorite is definitely the Tataki roll and the seared Tataki special. We enjoy very much their selection, even more knowing that they care about sustainability. The staff is nice and very responsive. The atmosphere is somber and comfortable. It is kids friendly though younger kids might have have enough space to move around.
author: Marielle C.

description: Every time we come here it has been mind blowingly delicious. I was somewhat skeptical when ordering sushi with fish I have never heard of before. But don't be afraid everything they are serving up taste amazing! This is how sushi should be prepared. Fresh, sustainable, and guilt free.
author: Rachel J.

description:
I ate here for the first time a few days ago. It was the best vegan sushi I've ever had! The place was fairly small but my table got seated fairly quickly and the service was good. 

We ordered the vegan reggae roll, hot potato, avocado, sweet potato tempura, and cucumber rolls. The sweet potato tempura rolls weren't very good but the stand outs were the reggae and hot potato rolls. The non vegans at the table enjoyed their sushi as well. The only complaint is that the miso soup wasn't hot and was overpriced.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Great Sushi with unique plates and good flavor .... very small place so if a reservation is not made you might be waiting for some time ...
 
My girl and I got lucky when we arrived and were seated almost immediately ... it was some time ago so most of what we ordered I forgot .. I do remember the extinguisher ( sushi with a cool salt flame burning ) seaweed salad .. ok fun texture ...  sashimi, crab coquettes, and some other rolls ... 

From what I remember everything was great .. I will definitely go back again ...
author: Anthony S.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots in the city. The servers change frequently and I'm afraid there are internal management issues. It is a hit and miss on the service part most of the times but the sushi is to kill for! Why four stars if the service can be shoddy? Well, I haven not had a horrible, wretched waiter and I can overlook some problems if the overall experience is great particularly taste-wise if it's a restaurant. There's something wrong in management so just fix that so your employees stay loyal and stick around for at least one straight year.
author: Pocho G.

description:
WOW.

Expensive.
author: Jess C.

description: Initially refused to seat us because the waiter was training someone at the register. When he walked towards us, we asked if we could just sit at the bar; turned down again because "someone could be waiting outside". Kinda ridiculous. Burger place next door was amazing and had great service!
author: Richard R.

description:
Not worth the price. Small rolls with some seared albacore for $13? I regret eating here.

If prices were lower I would give 4 stars.

I liked how they emphasize sustainability in fishing and will give 3 stars for that
author: Ken N.

description:
Tataki is the first sustainable sushi restaurant in the US and probably the WORLD!

Loved the sweet shrimp with the fried shrimp heads...my fav. I also really enjoyed the thai snapper with lemon and sea salt. Scott, my fiance liked the toro.

My fiance and I know fresh fish and quality sushi and Tataki was really good. I'm still searching for the best sushi in SF, but this is on the top of my list so far.
author: Ally V.

description:
Hello...was it the ten-hours in the car or the...10 hrs. n da kar...THIS PLACE, for us, DESERVES 5+1 STARS (you'll learn later that we loaned the extra 1 star to this trip's stay at Kabuki - who is our go to in SF, if not with fam...)..

Dude, not sure if it was because it was Sunday at 6:05pm but Tataki had fast service and no shit, the best sushi I've ever had...Didn't even matter that it is sustainable...didn't even know it was until I read Yelp - but no lie you can eat the entire Happy Hour Menu - and you can hook up the Pacific Roll (no rice sushi whaaat?)  - which we did for less than $55...with two bottles of Large Sapporo...and they have cucumber water...?!

The wait staff was attentive and the place, though tiny and not like I expected the place to be from the reviews - not way Japanese style...was downright perfect man.  Straight up we had a great time...it made the cave we were staying in kicked up a notch without the garlic after taste.  

And the food is beautiful...literally artistic...ok, sorry art is to me a movement against a previous creative movement - it was straight designed dude.  The tofu had hearts...and if you can sit next to the window (the seat for two)...it is the best.

I loved the place...
author: Fourty F.

description:
Checked out Tataki with some friends for a little Monday night sushi. The deal with Tataki is they are a sustainable sushi place, so some of your typical go to sushi choices might not appear on this menu. The flip side of that is you'll also stumble across some offerings you might not find on other sushi menus such as atlantic char and sea bream. I tried  the pacific sunrise, kurodai tataki, and the extinguisher (which comes out on fire!). Everything was very good, I was especially impressed by the extinguisher which was legitimately spicy. It was by far the spiciest sushi i've had at any sushi place and I really enjoyed it. All of my friends also mentioned that anything made to be spicy was not holding back. If I went back I think I'd hit up only spicy selections, they were that good!

I'd also like to mention that they have one of the most extensive vegetarian menus of any sushi place I've been to. Could be a good place to compromise with a vegetarian friend of yours if you have a craving for fish (and they might even let you off the hook because it's sustainable).
author: Stephen S.

description:
Decent place for sushi, but definitely won't be coming back. The service was unbelievably slow. The two groups that came after us were served before us and the waiter never came back to refill my water. The sushi was...interesting? We got the tataki roll, 49er roll, and the double double. The tataki roll was drenched in ponzu, which was not something I've ever seen before. The 49er roll was filled with masago instead of having it as a topping. I wish they stated that the masago would be the filling. The double double was cut in this diagonal shape making it hard to eat. Also, the double double was so spicy that it left an uncomfortable burning sensation that spread throughout my lungs and stomach. If you're into fusion sushi, then this is the place for you. But for me, coming from Japan and used to authentic and traditional Japanese sushi, this was not the place for me. Also, the chefs weren't Japanese, the sushi they offered were lacking in diversity (some due to their use of sustainable seafood), and ultimately, I couldn't get past their interesting but strange concoctions. 

Also, when we called in to ask what the wait was for two people, they said that they had one table open. We stated that we'd be over there right away and whoever was on the other line said "good luck." We thought this was a very strange response. Also, in the middle of our meal, we were debating on getting more sushi. We decided to and then the waiter asked us if we really wanted more sushi... another response that we weren't used to hearing at restaurants. Just a strange experience in general.
author: Hana K.

description:
The concept of sustainable sushi is definitely grandeur and admirable. 

We ordered the Arctic Char and Avocado and the Sashimi Regular. Both were not bad, but not amazing. I would normally give this place three stars, but minus a star for service. 

Also, I don't think I'll be back.
author: Audrey N.

description: I wasn't blown away, and service is just ok.  The menu is limited and the only roll I really liked was the one that was on fire.  The rest was just ok... need more creative and tru sushi options.
author: ThuZ W.

description: Came here for happy hour and ordered the artic char with avocado, crunchy spicy tuna roll, and calamari! Everything tasted so fresh and of course I had to order some uni..and man.. their uni was so creamy and i was in HEAVEN. We also had the chef's choice nigiri and it did not disappoint. The fish is very high quality and you are paying for what you get. One of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Sushi with a conscience??? Tasty!!! This cozy restaurant has introduced me to all sorts of new fish I had never even heard of before, all tasty and all sustainably fished to maintain our oceans and seas. That itself wins points! They don't take reservations and with only a handful of tables, be prepared to wait but service is fast and the wait is not unbearable especially if you grab a drink next door. 

The best deal here is its happy hour where rolls, sangria and beer are cheap and all super tasty otherwise normal prices are a little more than average. This is a restaurant that serves fresh nigiri, sashimi and as the name suggests ... tataki samplers but don't come here if you have a non raw fish lover, pretty much everything on the menu is raw or lightly seared.
author: Ro L.

description:
Great neighborhood spot and happy hour specials until 7pm!  
We came on a Friday evening and we waited about 30 mins and still able to get seated in time to order the specials.  It's a small restaurant and more ideal for parties of 2, 3, or 4.  We lucked out and sat at the sushi bar.  I like that all the fish they serve is sustainable.  Everything is super fresh.  We shared the sashimi deluxe, 2 handrolls, and a few nigiri items.  So we tried scallop, amaebi, artic char, spicy tuna, fresh salmon, and a few other white fishes.  

Service was really good and fast considering how busy it was.  They definitely do a good job at turning tables.  All in all with 2 large beers it came out to $86 without tip.  A little expensive but worth the splurge.
author: Meredith K.

description: I came for an early dinner with my 2-year-old, not wanting to cook dinner while his dad was on a business trip. They were very accommodating, seating us by the sushi bar so he could watch, patiently cleaning up his spilled water, and giving him special chop sticks tied together with a rubber band. The food was good, and my son ate everything, although I didn't choose anything too exotic. Since it was happy hour, we both ate for $20, including a generous tip
author: Jamaro B.

description:
While my cousin and I were trying to decide which sushi joint to eat at, Tataki came up on our list!  We were first-time triers at this restaurant, and overall it was a great experience!  

Here were some key points noted during the eating experience:

- The Mackerel, which was made to cook dry with sea salt, shockingly tasted so good!  Natural and simple, yet tasty!

-The Golden State Roll, which had scallops in it, wasn't very pleasing; it tasted plain and not flavorful.

-The Tuna Roll was perfectly spicy and delicious.

-The California Rolls were also tasty, with the crab meat all minced.

The waiter was kind, helpful, and knew what he was doing.
author: Tina R.

description:
love this place! food was amazing. sushi very fresh. very good service! 
A+
author: Diana F.

description:
For the money, there's almost no better sushi spot than Tataki. 

I started kicking myself for not having written about Tataki's amazing happy hour deals earlier. If you're like me and enjoy getting rolls, there are 5-6 different rolls available (i.e. spicy crunchy tuna, arctic char and avocado) for under $5. Thirsty? Sip on a 20-ounce Sapporo for only $4.50. Great deals! 

Above all, I loved the sweet potato roll. Unique and delicious. 

If you're heading to Tataki, know that happy hour ends at 7 PM. The restaurant is quite tiny, so get there early to avoid crowds, especially if you have a party of four or more. 

And as has been mentioned by the myriad other positive reviews, Tataki is a sustainable sushi spot, so ask your waiter to give you some free schoolin' on how you can be a more socially conscious sushi-eater. 

Chow down!
author: Tom A.

description: Tataki is a great sushi place! I little on the expensive side, but they do practice sustainability and the fish is very fresh! The house hot sake isn't that strong, so I would suggest the cold sake, but the rolls are great, especially the spicy tempura roll with jalapenos.
author: Eric M.

description:
My wife and I live in San Francisco and are on a constant quest for finding the best sushi. Most range from just ok to really good. Tataki definitely rises to the top. Seafood salad was so good and the albacore sashimi melts in your mouth. 

We came just after lunch so we were seated right away. I have to assume dinner time is much busier so planning ahead is probably a good idea. 

We will definitely be back for more.
author: Joseph H.

description:
My family & I had just left the hospital (new addition to the family) & were kinda hungry. We all agreed on Japanese food, so I Yelp'd a Japanese restaurant nearby. Tataki happened to be the one who chose because it had good reviews. 

If it wasn't for 'Tataki' in bright lights, we probably wouldn't have found the place. We walked in. Fairly small place, but really intimate. The lighting is a ilttle darker than usual. We had to write our party on the clipboard. They won't sit you if your whole party isn't there. It was full when we got there. But luckily, a party of 4 was leaving. We were a part of 4 adults & 1 baby (in a stroller). We had to make minor adjustments, but we all fit at the table. After taking a couple minutes to look at the menu, here's what we ordered:

Crab Croquette - This was REALLY GOOD! :) It's like crab cakes. Definitely worth a try. 

Shrimp Tempura Roll - Yummy roll. You can't go wrong with shrimp tempura.

Philadelphia Roll - I don't really do raw sushi, but this roll wasn't bad. My brother's girlfriend enjoyed this roll a lot. 

Double Double - SPICY, but yummy! One of their specialty rolls, so there were 8 pieces. 

Green Dragon (x2) - YUMMMM!!!!!!! We ordered this a little bit into our meal already. It was SOOOOO GOOD that we ordered 2 of them! Haha. Definitely would get this roll again. 

We all really enjoyed the food at Tataki. 

-1 star for not bringing our 3 miso soups AND charging us for it.
author: Jessica A.

description:
Im a huge foodie and a hard critic when it comes to judging restaurants. I judge it from the service to the food to the presentation and of course the atmosphere. This place got  5 stars in each category. Everything was just amazing. 

We ordered:

Sashimi Regular Platter:
it was YUUUMMMY! The fish just melted in my mouth. It  was chef's choice and he chose the salmon, scallops, I think hamachi and one other one. It didnt have that nasty fishy taste, wasnt slimy, and the cuts were just perfect. 

Extinguisher Roll:  
Also very good. The fire on the plate was really cool and added a nice touch to it. The roll wasnt too spicy like everyone complained it was. I also liked that the pieces werent huge so it was easy to put in my mouth in one bite without having me look ridiculous. 

Tataki Roll:
Very yummy. Also smaller pieces. The fish was seared perfectly. 

Saki: 
Im not sure what kind it was, but it was that white one. For $13 there was a good amount in there. My friend and I probably got about 6 shots each. 

Green Tea Cheesecake:
It was nothing special. It was good, but can't say I was amazed and would want it again. 


Definitely coming here again. Worth the price!
author: G O.

description: Good fish -- though I wish salmon were on their sustainable menu. Good, friendly service. Seems like they've been reading yelp and are adjusting attitudes accordingly.
author: Rudolph R.

description:
Their special house rolls are fabulous. And the vegetarian options are really good. Sweet potato roll very imaginative. My favorite - the Extinguisher.
Best Sushi we've had in SF for a while, better than Godzilla a block or two away.
author: David G.

description:
While waiting for my food and reading a rave review of Tataki, for some reason in Italian, I lamented how sad this place is. Seems that the only thing going for it these days is a tired marketing campaign about their sustainable fish.

Sure, you could say they blew it when we waited 60 minutes for a table on a Monday night. To be fair, we gave up counter seats at minute 30 because our friend wasn't there yet.

Or maybe it was when the waitstaff never expressed thanks for waiting, or kept us informed how much longer it'd be.

Leaving our vacated table unbussed for 10 minutes only heightened our anticipation.

Then again it could be when they forgot our edamame or my friend's bowl of rice.

Hmm, luke warm, tough-to-chew fish surely didn't help.

Making my fiancée wait 20 minutes lonely for her food was almost as boss as ticking off another 30 minutes for our last course.

Nope, it was the FREAKIN' indifference and "we could care less" vibe of the place that made our dinner suck so hard.

1.5 * stars
author: Brady K.

description:
After waiting ~45 minutes on a Tuesday night, we were sat at the table by the window, which is exactly what I was hoping for.  The restaurant is charmingly cozy, and I loved that they were playing the Hot Chip DJ Kicks album.  

We ordered the seaweed salad.  I've yet to try a seaweed salad that wasn't essentially like every other seaweed salad. Which, honestly, is fine by me. The baked mussels were delicious.

The sashimi was relatively fresh, but nothing particularly exciting.  We did love the Early Bird roll with seared filet mignon and pineapple, by far the most creative roll on their short list.
author: Nicole J.

description:
This is an excellent sushi place to go to. The sashimi is fresh and the crunchy rolls are fantastic. I am a fan of the hand rolls. 

The best time to go to Tataki is during the Happy Hour. ;0) The food is cheap at the happy hour and is still excellent as always. 

The seaweed can get a little chewy when you eat the sushi and one in a while it falls a part.

The calamari is a must try. Yay calamari!!!!

I would go back, but during the HAPPY HOUR!!! :)
author: Jessica E.

description:
I tried this place with a friend a few days ago.  I loved the kurodai tataki since the subtly seared sea bream paired with the spicy pepper resulted in an amazing flavour.  The arctic char/avocado roll and Pacific Sunrise roll were really refreshing.  I love saba and they have three different types on the nigiri menu.  Also, they are a sustainable sushi establishment which gets a +1 in my book, but keep in mind this means that some types of seafood will not be served here.

The staff was very friendly and the location had decent parking.  The place is rather small, albeit cozy, so if you go during prime time be prepared to wait.  I think everyone was still full from Super Bowl snacks since there wasn't a huge wait when we arrived.
author: Derek Z.

description:
Some of the best sushi I have ever had, and so cool that they do sustainable sushi. I went here with my boyfriend and we had such a fantastic time. The decor and vibe is very intimate and chic and the sushi is simply divine. 

 Our favorite was the double double roll which is lightly fried and smothered in this amazing sauce that is to die for. I also really enjoyed the Reggae roll which is a vegetarian delight with tempura asparagus, cucumber, tomatoes and a trio of fabulous sauces on the side. 

Overall Tataki is one of my new favorites and I highly recommend it.
author: Sabrina G.

description: A great spot for a good quality sushi with special attitude to sell only the type of fish that has been fished politically correct without damaging other fishes... Aka no hamachi and salmon on the menu.
author: Diana R.

description: The sushi is fresh and delicious, the staff is friendly, and the neighborhood is really cute. I know they are environmentally friendly, which I can appreciate, but to not have fresh crab at a sushi restaurant is crazy to me. Imitation is not good.
author: Ashley F.

description:
Tataki was the 1st of a 2-part dinner during our gut-busting weekend in San Francisco. It was a stone's throw away from my friend's place, located in the nice Pacific Heights neighborhood. We caught last call for Happy Hour, which was really lucky since this place is a teeeeeny place with a lot of eager customers. The happy hour prices are ridiculously good, but I glanced at the regular menu and I thought those prices were decent too. But, deals! Why would you say no to deals? I got an arctic char cut roll and a California hand roll, with a side of their lovely kin-san-gria, which had lovely slices of fruit in it, like lychee. 

But the rolls made me realize how good Bay area people have it when it comes to great seafood and sushi. The arctic char cut roll was phenomenal; the fish was so fresh and firm, and the rest of the components perfectly complemented the great quality fish. I typically think of California roll as simple and lame, but the crunchy CA roll at Tataki was something else. This is not your convenience store sushi. I definitely would love to come back here for a more proper, sit-down dinner when I'm back in San Fran...that is, if I'm not too busy stuffing my face with sushi from Bay Area's greatest hits.
author: Mariel L.

description:
I gave you a second chance Tataki and you blew it. You do not get a 3rd date.

Nigiri/sashimi - nothing to salivate over, definitely had cuts of fish that were 4x better.
Rolls - very unimpressive

Upon leaving this restaurant my mind starts to question why I like sushi until I remember that other places know how to do it right. As my friends and I departed, I saw people walking towards Tataki and I felt like telling them to turn around and check out some other place. Run! Run for the sake of good sushi!
author: Rachel R.

description:
I came here early on a Saturday night and scored a seat for 2 at the sushi bar. It was my first time and it did not disappoint. Some highlights:

- Super fresh sushi
- Great, attentive, but not overbearing service
- Decent selection of beers and nigori sake

It's a little on the pricey side for sushi in SF, but it's damn worth it. Give it a try.
author: Yum N.

description: Happy hour was great! $2.50 Sapporo and good prices for sushi. It's a pretty popular restaurant, so don't wait til the end of happy hour to show up!
author: Michelle P.

description:
I work nearby now so I decided to give this place another try and went for lunch. Their lunch specials is slightly pricey. $10 for a sushi combo with a 6-piece roll of simple sushi along with 4 piece nigiri or additional $4 for 7-piece nigiri. I ordered a philidelphia roll and the CA roll/4piece nigiri combo. Turned out to be $15 lunch... :/ The pieces are slightly small and their Philly roll just wasn't raw salmon. It was smoked-salmon with cream cheese.... is it normally like that cuz I always had raw salmon in my rolls. *shrug

All in all, I did have a satisfying lunch. Better than Godzilla, IMO. Way better. It's definitely not a daily lunch to splurge on~
author: Rosanne L.

description:
Its a small busy restaurant and kind of hard to find parking, at least that night that I was there. We ended up sitting at the bar. I wish that the seats at the bar had a little backing so I could at least hang my jacket or my bag. 

Itwas a little hard to flag down a server to take our order since they were so busy. After we placed our order, the food came quickly and the chefs even just passed the rolls and sashimi to us over the bar. 

I really liked the Tataki roll since it had different seared fish. The sashimi was fresh and I love the idea that Tataki is sustainable sushi. Very impressed. We had several rolls, scallops, and sashimi. The rolls weren't exceptionally good, but all the fish were very fresh. My favorite of the night was the scallops.
author: Jay L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Tataki for his birthday dinner on a Monday afternoon/early evening.  The place is a bit small but the high ceilings, large windows, and light colors kept it from feeling cramped.  We had about a 15 min wait but were able to check out the menu and decide what to order.

I am a big fan of sangria so when I saw the kin-san-gria on the happy hour menu, I was intrigued!  It was light and refreshing and served in a fluted glass.  Fun for something different!

Highlight of the night: the garlic edamame.  My boyfriend is constantly in search of good garlic edamame and this place did not disappoint!  The fried calamari was pretty standard and we were in the mood for rolls so we tried the extinguisher, arctic char and avocado, spicy tuna, and the golden state roll.  My favorite was the golden state roll mostly because it was so unusual.  I had never had apple in a roll but it was actually really tasty.

We will definitely be back!
author: Heather K.

description:
Okay, first of all, this rating is going to discuss the service my group got more than the sushi we ate, because the service really was what made our experience worth only 2 stars.

We had been planning a sushi night in the city for about a week, and after much research on here I selected Tataki for our evening. They don't take reservations, so unless you plan on being there waiting for the place to open, expect a LONG wait for a table. 

We were planning on dinner here, then drinks and dessert at The Bubble Lounge after. We never got to The Bubble Lounge, because we waited an hour and a half for a table here. And that wouldn't have been such a big deal if the host/waiter had told us honestly that it was going to be that long. He told us it would be 30-45 minutes when we got there at about 7:45. Okay, no biggie, we're looking at getting seated at about 8:15-8:30. Not 9:15 which is when we finally got seated. 

After we got seated, we weren't offered any sot of compensation for our extended wait by our waiter. He didn't even bring us water for another 5-10 minutes. (I suggest he look up "service" in the dictionary.) When he finally came with the water, we were completely ready to order. Another few minutes, and we had our beverages, and a few minutes after that we had our sushi.

All in all, the food was good. Nothing too special - the sushi is fresh, and the portions are fairly standard for the price. The soy sauce on the table was a little salty, and we kept trying to flag down our waiter to tell him that, but he kept going past us. Lucky for us, one of the sushi chefs (Ken) heard us talking about it, and personally brought us low-sodium soy sauce. He also talked to my husband for a minute, found out he like spicy foods, and comped us one of their signature rolls, the Extinguisher. Like I said, the best service we got all night was from him.

One thing I need to say - I've never eaten somewhere where the server can have long hair not pulled back from their face. Our server had shoulder-length hair that was just hanging down. I'm fairly certain that's a health code violation. But I digress.

Overall, this place is NOT worth an hour and a half wait. If you're planning an evening in the city that includes sushi, pick somewhere that takes reservations so you don't waste your whole evening in the cold waiting for a table.
author: Amy E.

description: Went for happy hour and got the crunchy spicy tuna roll and the Philadelphia rolls. They were very very good, I recommend this place to everyone! :)
author: Max G.

description:
Still fabulously delicious and I'm still in love with it, but I wanted to add a note here that they definitely don't have high chairs for children. 

I came here a week ago with a couple of friends and their tot, and had expressed some apprehension as it is a small place and seems ill-suited to young children. (I looked for any specific comments amongst the reviews and found none, however, which is why I felt compelled to add this note.) They came to a solution of nabbing a corner for us and thus confining the tiny one to his seat, which worked well enough as he's a fairly well-behaved child, but if you're planning to bring a kid along for dinner who actually needs a high chair to sit up or keep them from roaming? No dice here. Even so, the staff was courteous and fairly accommodating about the tiny guest in the corner, so all's well that ends :)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Always drive by Tataki and one night we decided to give it a try, the place is small so expect a bit of a wait. 

The thing that makes this place stand out is the fact they care a lot about the fish they are serving...sustainable as I've seen others put it. What I also noticed is that they are good at what they do. A lot better than most places in the city. 

The main thing about this place is their "tataki"...pretty much seared fish marinated with a sauce afterwards, which is pretty simple. Here at Tataki they do it a little bit differently. They serve a variety of fishes served in that manner, seared with a sauce/vinegar and some garnish. We had two different ones..the kurodai and the char. I preferred the char much more with the yuzu sauce.

Just for kicks we had the extinguisher roll, that comes with a nice little fire on the side. Just salt that has alcohol lit up next to your sushi. The roll was good and I enjoyed it. I've always enjoyed eating rolls with avocado and such. Its an american thing hahaha, because my mom prefers just eating sashimi/nigiri.

Their nigiri/sashimi were fresh and we stuck with the chef specials instead. And they laid out a nice display of fish for us. 

I think we had 2 bottles of sake and a couple beers, I don't remember exactly but my face was heating up. By the time we finished everything, we noticed the rest of restaurant was empty...we were the last ones! I felt so bad, but they didn't rush us and allowed us to take our time. But of course, we finished our bottle quick so we wouldn't hold them back from closing up.

Overall, Tataki was a good call. Though we had a bit of a wait, but that was already expected. Food and service was good, I would come back again.
author: phillip w.

description:
Pretty good sushi, a solid fresh choice with a decent selection of saki. This is our go-to neighborhood spot for sushi as it's consistently fresh and I've never had to wait long. 

The service is friendly but there's definitely room for improvement. The atmosphere is lacking, very tiny and tight quarters but not uncomfortable. No fancy decor, it's a bit vague. Prices are decent for sushi in the city.
author: Meredith M.

description:
We love this place.  The fish is fresh and sustainable.

We have tried:
- calamari (really good)
- sashimi appetizer (thick pieces with skin still on in some places - hard to chew)
- tataki roll (my favorite!)
- shrimp tempura (I think they use panko for the crust?)

All was really spectacular quality!  I wish they'd only cut the sashimi a little thinner and make sure to remove the skin, so that I can chew it.  None the less, I will return for sure!
author: Jade F.

description:
Great happy hour!!!

People literally just wait a the door until they open for happy hour!!

The food is great, drinks are on special also. The place is small, but its great.
This is a sustainable resto. as well.

really good, recommended.
author: Ash R.

description:
Our first experience with sustainable sushi and it was a great one. The artic char (like salmon), amaebi (w/ the fried shrimp heads), and tobiko were fresh. The Early Bird (asparagus and avocado) wrapped in filet mignon and pineapple slices - YUM! The albacore tataki was also really good and it went really well with the garlic sauce. We loved the garlic sauce so much, we started dipping our sushi in there. We didn't try as many items as we wanted our first time so we must come back to try more!

Small place + no reservations taken = Long wait
author: Tina T.

description: The sashimi platter is always fantastic, as are the oysters, Arctic char, and 49er roll (though you do have to watch out for seeds in the lemon slices). Tataki is the go-to neighborhood sushi spot for my boyfriend and I. Their quality is consistent and priced right. Highly recommend.
author: Julia H.

description:
A vegetarian-sushi-lover's dream!

The place is always packed so it can be a wait to get in on weekends, but I try to get here before happy hour ends and usually end up seated in 10 minutes, or so.

Their creative approach to making sushi that is vegetarian friendly make this a spot that never bores me. I come here at least once a month, because it's conveniently located on Divisadero and is a quick walk from my place.

My go to order is the crunchy veggie tempura roll, and a cold Sapporo in their chilled glasses (+1)! Their seaweed salad is also good, as is the garlic edamame. 

Their sustainable approach to Sushi also gets major points (even though I don't eat fish), as does their effort to promote awareness about their sourcing practices and what sustainable fishing practices should be.
author: A S.

description: Despite being a few blocks away, I haven't actually sat down to eat here. For one, it's super tiny. And for two the wait is really long. Nonetheless it's still my go to spot to pick up. I usually call on my way home from work and the roll is ready in about 15 minutues for pick up. The extinguisher roll is my favorite. Always fresh and delicious. The prices seem to be in line with other places in San Francisco. If you're looking good sushi to pick up some dinner, I highly recommend it.
author: Michele V.

description:
This was by far one of my favorite sushi dining experiences! Although the place itself is quite small, the service is outstanding! My boyfriend took me here for an anniversary dinner and it did not disappoint. Well priced wine and appetizers to start. 
The ocean salad was incredibly fresh and delicious. My favorite roll of the night was definitely the Extinguisher. Just melts in your mouth! If you like sushi, eat here!
author: Viki P.

description:
I love this place! 

I'm pretty much a regular here and have had consistantly great experiences almost every time. The garlic edamame is so delicious - a must try. We tend to order the sashimi most of the time along with the Extingisher roll and the seaweed salad - all of which are delicious.

Service is usually good as well. I have however experienced one evening at the sushi bar in which the service was subpar. I'm thinking our waiter was having a bad night as he tossed our menus down on the bar and almost hit my friend with them - the sushi saved the evening though and we were able to leave with happy bellies.
author: Leanne S.

description:
3.25 stars...

I went here for my birthday, and though I enjoyed the food, i was not blown away by it.  I was impressed by the conviction of the restaurant to create a sustainable sushi environment, though the fish seemed to lack something...i'll call it flavor.  Perhaps that's why other fish are overfished and these particular ones are not.

The star of the show was by far the Arctic Char.  Never heard of it before, but I left there a big fan.  The Arctic Char and Avocado roll was very good, and the Tataki Deluxe provided more slices of Arctic Char along with Katsuo, Kurodai, Scallop, and Albacore.  Each type of fish came with a special dipping sauce that enhanced the flavor of the fish, and at times, really provided the only flavor in that particular bite of fish.

I agree that dining at a place like this greatly enhances your knowledge and sensibility of our ecosystem, sustainability, and all that great tree hugger stuff, and i enjoyed my awareness being raised on the issue of sustainability.  That being said, i would find it hard-pressed to make it back there on that premise knowing that the times that i do dine out, i'd really like to enjoy and savor the meal, even if it means making the environment second fiddle for 1.5 hours.  Call me insensitive or whatever, but i am not about to forego my mild sushi addiction to eat other raw fish that just doesn't measure up.

Happy Eating!
author: Bradley H.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for a few months.  I kept seeing the bookmark on my Yelp but never made it out here until I met up with a girl friend who lives in the area.

We walked in around 6:55pm and the place was full but definitely not packed.  We opted to sit at the bar since service always seems faster there.  I looked at the menu and noticed that HH ended at 7pm.  I quickly looked up smiled big, and asked the sushi chef if it was too late to order off the HH menu.  :D  He said go ahead and we got the deep fried spicy tuna roll, the artic char, and the fried calamari.  We added the Tataki salad, and 6 piece sashimi to the order along with two iced teas.  

I think this was the first time I've had artic char.  It looked a little like salmon but it tasted like...fish?  haha.  The deep fried spicy tuna roll was yummy but it wasn't spicy at all!  The tataki on the tataki salad was sooo good, and probably my favorite.  The salad itself was crammed onto this little bowl and it was nearly impossible to eat from it.  It was almost like a never ending bowl of greens.  The calamari was good but the leggy pieces were extra scary and some of them, I swore still had heads and eyes.  Pass...  Sashimi was ok, I only ate 2 or my share of pieces.  I also ordered a tataki roll, to go for my BF.  Before he got home, I secretly ate one and it was delicious.  I loved the presentation of this restaurant!

The whole bill, including tax/tip came up to about $65.  I don't know if I would come back.  The concept is great but I think I want traditional sushi when I have a craving for sushi.  I didn't even come here because they're sustainable, I came here because I love TATAKI!!!
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Yelp reviews set high expectations for Tataki. My 3 stars encompasses the entire experience. I think the problem with sushi places, or a good majority of the restaurants in SF is that you can't make reservations. And I hate waiting. Not a good combo, especially when you're hungry, cold, tired and, because it's SF, cold again. 

We waited a little over an hour for two people on a Saturday night. By the time we got in, it was 9:30. The entire space consists of tables of two that maybe seats 20 total, and a sushi counter that seats four. We sat at the counter and ordered: albacore tataki, divisaderoll, double-double, golden state, and 49-er. The albacore was awesome, but the rolls were just okay, but I have to admit, the quality of the fish was very good. My fave out of the rolls was the 49-er because I love that thinly sliced lemon on top. Mmm-mmm-MMM!

Service was decent and pleasant enough. The sushi chefs were nice as well. Once we sat down, the food came out at a decent pace, but the wait was a killer. Especially in sub-zero (30-degree) temperatures. There are two seats outside and like two inside to hide from the elements, but other than that, bring a puffy North Face jacket in the winter and brace yourself for a wait. If you bring a date, she might hate you for the wait. Unless she's totally into you and wants a long wait because she never wants the night to end. Highly unlikely.

Looking at the menu, I would probably come during happy hour for the specials, although for our dinner, for that amount of food, it was only $60. 

And the key to this place is that it's sustainable sushi. So I guess it's not overfished. Personally, I could care less about this, but do appreciate it. Maybe if it weren't sustainable, they'd be caught faster and the wait would be shorter.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description: what a find!!! We were looking for a Japanese restaurant for dinner, and thanks to fellow yelpers, we found this nice restaurant!!!   We were very lucky and only waited 5 minutes or so for a table.  (after we sat down, there was a long line for a table).   we tried oysters (not bad), sashimi deluxe (so yummy!), uni (sea urchin) nigiri (also very yummy!), and some specialty rolls.   The bill at the end was roughly $100, but it was really delicious!!!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I had high expectations going into Tataki, since there are so many Yelp reviews raving about this place. And seriously, how often do you see a 4-star sushi restaurant? 

Here are the rolls we ordered:

49er ($13) - WINNER OF THE NIGHT! Masago-filled with arctic char with a thin slice of lemon on top - zesty, refreshing, delicious. Because this roll isn't drenched with sauce or anything, you can really get a good taste of the arctic char. MUST TRY!

Tataki roll ($13) - Five varieties of fish coupled with a very subtle sweet sauce. Very tasty! 

Mix-it-up ($11) - Spicy albacore, which was interesting because it's not really the albacore that's spicy, but they add Sriracha sauce on the albacore. It was flavorful but wasn't a huge fan of it. 

The restaurant is small and cozy, so it's good for intimate dates. The service was kind of slow though... but the sushi and ambiance made up for it. :)
author: Christine A.

description:
Definitely one of my top sushi go-to's. Vegetarian sushi, though simple in concept, is really damn hard for places to master. Tataki does a really good job with their vegetarian menu (and all my friends like the non-veg stuff as well).

Highly recommend:

Spicy Tofuna Roll (I wish every sushi place had this roll. I envy those of you that eat the spicy tuna)
Ratatouille Roll
Reggae Roll

I wasn't a big fan of the Cold Tofu starter, pretty bland. I can't remember what my non-veg friends had but it was some of the specialty rolls and they loved them. 

Don't go here with a big group though, it's tiny. And call in advance as there can be a bit of a wait so make sure you are willing to wait.
author: Raina B.

description:
Tataki is always packed, which isn't a huge feat given the size of the restaurant. We managed to get the last empty table during "happy hour" one evening.

We had "happy hour" items for $5 each;  Calamari appetizer (pretty good), Crunchy Spicy Tuna roll, and Crunchy California roll (both pretty good). We also got one each of the Tamago Nigiri (pretty good), and some weird roll with filet mignon (not great, but I was curious).

Our waiter was nice, but the vibe was really snobby. The host seemed like he thought we were taking up space that a more refined patron would surely need soon.  My husband summed up the experience saying "Don't get too snotty - you're just acceptable fusion sushi."

We may come back for "happy hour" and cheap appetizers and sushi, but I would never take Japanese guests here.
author: Karen C.

description: The co-owner of this restaurant is in a sushi documentary on netflix.  he sounds idiotic.  He says he wants to save the fishees and yet he owns a sushi restaurant.  he says it's better to eat wild fish than farmed fish.  how is that sustainability?
author: Cary C.

description:
My frequent trips to SF are ruining the sushi back home in Chicago. It's just so much fresher and tastier in SF...sigh.  When in SF I can usually be found devouring several rolls at Ryoko, but decided to try a new place this time. Hello Tataki!

The yelp reviews warned me of a long wait so a friend and I showed up earlyish (7pm on a Wed night) and put our name in.  I asked a waiter to give us an estimate for the amount of time we'd be waiting and he said 25-45 minutes. Hmmm....what kind of an estimate is that? We weren't sure if we had enough time for a drink next door, but decided to take our chances and enjoy a glass of wine at Solstice.

40 minutes later (and a bit tipsy from wine) we were seated at Tataki and ready to get our sushi on.  We started with some edaname and sake...and ordering the following sushi:
* Golden State
* Extinguisher
* 49er
* Sweet potato roll

All were fab, but we agreed the Golden State was the favorite: spicy scallop with minced apple topped with albacore tuna, avocado and 24k gold flakes. Mmmmm. The 49er was a close 2nd- loving the arctic char craze in SF. It ended up being way more sushi than I expected, but we didn't seem to have much trouble polishing it off.

Looks like I've found yet another raw fish winner in SF!
author: Andrea R.

description:
My girlfriend and I decided to make this our first sushi stop on the basis of the other reviews we had seen on Yelp prior to coming out to San Francisco. First things first - you don't want to come here too late. Space is a bit tight, and even though we showed up at 6:30, we still had to wait outside for about 15-20 minutes before getting seated. There's no waiting space inside either, so if it's a cool night, make sure to come with something warm to wear! Prior to arriving, we didn't really look at the menu closely...so we were a bit shocked to take a look once we got seated and see no bluefin tuna, salmon, eel, or many of our favorites that are staples of our sushi-eating experiences.

Nevertheless, the food was absolutely superb. We got the tataki deluxe, which is a fabulous sampling of different types of tuna tataki paired off with different dipping sauces. I don't remember them individually, but each pair was unique in its taste, and all of them were very delicious. The toro, even though it wasn't the traditional kind, was fantastic as well; it just fell apart in our mouth when we ate it, and we had to order a couple more pieces before we headed out. The dragon roll was also very good as well. Despite using cod as a substitute for eel, it was still very savory, and you couldn't tell too much of a difference in the taste. My only suggestion would be to add a little more of a marinade or sauce to the cod, but otherwise it was fantastic.

The restaurant has a nice cozy atmosphere to it, and the service, even when completely packed, was very good and was quick to get our food served. It's a unique sushi restaurant due to its sustainability initiative, but I was amazed at how much I liked the meal despite omitting many fish that other restaurants would not be able to have a menu without. A definite must-visit when I am in town again.
author: Asuka N.

description:
It's an inconvenient truth, but I'm admittedly pretty green when it comes to the green, eco-friendly way of life that's been seeping it's way into mainstream society. By no means am I throwing Burger King wrappers on the street or dumping battery acid into storm drains... but when it comes to saving the environment, I'm slightly behind the curve as I do my best to evolve into a full on hippie. 

I barely drive (opting for public transportation), I compost, I only drink tap water, I try to use tote bags when I'm at the grocery store, etc.... Now, I can carve another environmentally friendly tactic into my belt: sustainable sushi.

Before last night, I actually had no idea anything like this existed. Sure, I understand the detrimental effects of netting, fish farming and the like... but call me ignorant, as I had no idea some of my favorite sea creatures were technically on the 'avoid' list of terrible seafood choices. Some of those include unagi, king crab, toro and more. Most of these little critters are over-fished to meet demand, so it's destroying the underwater eco-system. It's a shame more seafood joints don't take an active role in educating their patrons about these hidden issues, but I'm stoked that Tataki not only takes the time to pull back the curtain, but they've built their entire business practice on serving nothing but sustainable sushi.

Monterey Bay Aquarium has these nifty little handouts as a go-to guide on the good/bad seafood choices, and Tataki only serves stuff from the 'best choices' and 'good alternatives' section of the pamphlet. Sure, it limits their menu just a tad, but it's nice to have the peace of mind that you're not destroying an entire underwater population with every hand roll that swims into your belly.

With that limited and often fluctuating menu, they do a good job of ensuring you're getting a pretty quality meal. Their specialty rolls are dope (with my favorite being the extinguisher... whoa!) and they have day-to-day local specials based on whatever goods get plucked out of the San Francisco Bay that day. 

While everything I tried on the roll side was fantastic, I thought the miso soup and the ocean salad were Shit-tay with a capital S (as you can see). The miso was pretty bland, and the ocean salad just tasted like I was swallowing a mouthful of sea water with odd-textured seaweed. Not exactly the most appetizing way to begin a meal, so it's a good thing the sushi delivered a come-from-behind win. On my next visit, I'll likely skip the apps and go straight to the fishies.

Apparently, Tataki is the only truly sustainable sushi joint in North America... so despite their shortcomings in the starters department, what they're doing is remarkable and well deserving of five stars (in my opinion). 

It's a pretty small joint, so seating is at a premium. Expect to wait a 45 minutes to an hour for a table. But, it's totally worth it.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Really good sushi! Very creative and love the flaming roll! It's pretty cozy inside and always a wait. It's worth it though. Worth the slight priciness.
author: Cindy C.

description: So this place has been consistently great over all the times I've gone there. But the last visit was different. Perhaps it was a bad day for the sushi chefs or maybe I was not getting it, but the food was just not good. Our order of Saba had a pure raw garlic puree on top that just destroyed the delicate flavors of the fish. Our two rolls also had a funny flavor that both my friend and I noticed but couldn't figure out. Our waiter without notice no longer served our table but was taken over by the other waiter. We didn't quite know what happened, we never Said anything about the food or any complaints. It was a little starnge, and it took us a while to figure that out. I'm hoping it was just a one time thing
author: Matt A.

description:
I almost feel bad giving it three stars because it has such a fantastic star rating. However, my taste buds beg to differ. 

I heard about this place a while ago but never really solidly put it in my mind. Then a few months ago, I went to the academy of sciences night events on Thursdays and they were there doing a demonstration on sustainable sushi. They gave a great shpeal on how they use many different types of fish to substitute for the non-sustainable fish that they don't offer (i.e. salmon, unagi) and I had a taste and it was actually not bad. I had it in my mind to try this place, plus the bf REALLY loves sushi ... lol

Came here last night with no reservations, surprised to have gotten a seat at their only window spot and it was nice. The inside is REALLY tiny and has about 10 tables and can seat maybeeee 20 people so this is not a good place for a group. It's a little difficult to find because it's so small and parking is just horrific near California and Diviserario (sp???) regardless. They have happy hour between 5 pm - 7 pm every day and we got there around 6:15 so took advantage of their happy hour specials.

They make a killer sangria and it's only $5 during their happy hour (normally $7.50). They had about five rolls on their happy hour menu which was **ok** ... their notable for the fact that the rolls had a lot of fish in it instead of small tiny rolls like I expected for happy hour. Otherwise, their normal rolls are creative and there is a lot of attention to detail, such as the olive looking sauce drip on top of their "extinguisher" roll ... but for the most part I thought the sushi here was only ok. Nothing was spectacular even the special tartare they recommended as a starter was only alright. Creative ideas, but maybe not so well executed?

I did not have a bad time, but with all the other sushi offerings, perhaps non-sustainable and/or similar places in the area that are, I don't see why I'd come here for mediocre sushi and a lot of "sustainability tax" (i.e. the rolls were pricey, if we did not get happy hour rolls, it would have been probably $80-90+ for two people). I think this is a cool place to come, try and decide for yourself, unfortunately I decided it was only worth 3 stars for me.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Sustainable sushi... how awesome is that?!  Very conscious, very cool.  

I'm vegetarian and tried the Vegan Cali roll which was okay, very different from what I've had but I enjoyed it.  

I also had the Reggae roll which was SO good!  Probably the best Veg. roll I've had, so GOOD!!!  Mind-blowing deliciousness.  Mmm...

The rolls are a lil pricey for its size, but SO GOOD since I may not be able to have it very often.  Its a small lil place that seems to get busy quick.  We came in around 6:30 and was there in time for their happy hour 4-7pm everyday.  Some rolls are about $5 during happy hour...

***Update.  A year later... I am still comparing other sushi places to this and Tataki still wins it all when I think of their Reggae roll.  OMG... drool.  I need to go to SF soon to eat this yummy roll and feel an ounce of food happiness again!!! 

4.5!  Cos the veg. cali roll was... aight.
author: Mypang T.

description: I had dinner with a friend at Tataki. The Rolls were great. I recommend The Extinguisher, The Tataki, and Tempura. Also had some great Saki. Getting seated is tricky due to very limited spacing. Make sure to have everyone in your party with you at seating time otherwise you'll be passed up. The service is great.
author: Matt W.

description:
I have been searching for really great sushi since moving back to SF and I think I have found the place.  I suppose almost 400 people agree, so it's not exactly a secret, but after having fantastic sushi for years in NYC, LA and even Chicago, I have found sushi in SF to be just OK until now.  So what matters to me: Texture, Temperature and Taste.  None are more important than the other but all three = freshness.  I ordered the sashimi deluxe dinner and a couple of roles.  The sashimi came out just right.  The fish was cold and a bit firm when first biting, but then melt in your mouth afterwards.  The fish was full of flavor and each was very distinct from one another.  Just about perfect.  

I also ordered the faux nagi, which was quite spectacular.  The dish exists as a replacement for the non-sustainable unagi, but I think surpasses the original.  They put a nice char on the fish and use a similar sauce, but the meat is far more tender and leaves a much cleaner aftertaste than the original unagi.   

For bonus points, the prices are very reasonable and they claim to be the only sustainable sushi bar in North America.  What does that mean:  they choose fish that are abundant, line caught or farmed in sustainable ways and do not contain all of that mercury and crap that you aren't supposed to eat.  So, your wallet, body and conscience can feel good about eating at this place.  

I so wanted to give this place 5 stars, but there is room for improvement.  I didn't think the rolls were all that great.  The higher priced specialty rolls did not come with very much fish and they used so much sauce accompaniments, that it was hard to find the taste of the fish.  If you are going to jam that much stuff in a roll and add sauce to boot, you really need to bring more fish, otherwise it gets lost.  For the cost of two rolls, you can just about get another sashimi platter, a much better investment in my book.
author: Scott C.

description: My husband and I want to try a new sushi place around our neighborhood.  We came across this place on yelp and it have pretty good reviews. So why not give this place a try. This place is very tiny and packed with people. We have to write our own name on the waiting list. We waited for 50 mins before we got a seat at the sushi bar.  We ordered a hot tea, saki and Sapporo beer to start off. While we look at the menu we decided to order the sashimi regular, tataki roll and extinguisher. Service was little slow but understandable since the restaurant is packed and only have two sushi chef and two waiter/waitress. After we have some drinks the sashimi arrived. The salmon to me looks awfully dark, darker than I ever have for sashimi. Anyway we went ahead to try it and sure enough, it definitely tasted fishy.  Usually salmon should have a fresh sweet buttery flavor that would melt in your mouth. But this one tasted fishy. We have to turn it back. The waitress apologized and ask the chef to replace with something else. They came back with a snapper which tasted good. They put some ginger sauce on top. Maybe they were afraid we will complain again.  The next roll was the tataki roll with seared fish and a sauce was glazed over the sushi. I felt it was too soggy. The rice little wet and I don't taste the seared.  The extinguisher was on the hot side. Overwhelmed with hot sauce that I don't taste the freshness of the fish. Overalls my opinion with this place is that they try too hard to make the food fancy. Which caused the taste for the freshness of sushi. Almost all the fish I have there is covered or topped with sauce. The salmon they didn't cover with sauce was fishy. Really make me wonder if they want to hide the quality of the fish. On top of that the waitress came back and told us saying that the chef just want you to know the fish was fresh cut today. Really?? Makes me wonder.
author: Becky K.

description:
In our recently acquired early bird dining style, the mister and I arrived at Tataki even before the doors opened.  We bought a coffee across the street and waited, watching the restaurant like a couple of creepers.  And because we were feeling so creepy, we decided to wait for other customers to go in before we headed over.

Anyway, Tataki is a small restaurant with about 28 seats, so the early bird thing most likely paid off in this instance since it sounds like the wait here at dinner time can be quite long, especially on a Saturday night.  Cool thing about this place is that there's happy hour everyday until 7pm.  We ordered the arctic char/avocado roll, a Kin-san-gria for me and a small hot sake for him from the hh menu.  I couldn't taste the alcohol in the Kin-san-gria; it was good!  About halfway through our meal, the phantom alcohol hit me, so I'm glad I only had one.  We then ordered the garlic edamame, pacific sunrise roll, uni nigiri and the tataki deluxe.  We tore through the edamame like no one's business; the soy sauce and slight lemony tang along with the loads of garlic was so yummy.  Both the rolls we ordered were pretty good too; not the best I've had but I liked them.  The uni was sweet and creamy; it was definitely good quality uni.

The best thing at Tataki is--you've guessed it--the tataki!  The tataki deluxe came with 20 delicious, delicately arranged pieces of various fish along with dipping sauces to match.  The fish and sauces paired together wonderfully!  Good thing I dined with the mister (well, it's always a good thing) because I was definitely not minding my manners as I double dipped my fish after each bite to get more of the sauce on each piece.  The next time I come here, I'd forego the rolls and stick to the tataki, sashimi and nigiri.
author: Thi D.

description: I was prepared to wait for a while, but we arrived at 7pm on a Friday night and waited maybe 10 minutes for a table. Our meal was fantastic. Loved the three different preparations of albacore poke. Also enjoyed the bincho (albacore) and hotate (scallops) specials and the tataki and golden state rolls. Just order a little of everything! You won't be disappointed. Their fish was fresh and just melted in your mouth.
author: Sophia B.

description: I have no idea about the food there but the service is REALLY BAD. We waited there for half hour with patience but the waitress was so rude that all five of us agreed to leave. We were so disturbed by her behavior that we left for another place although we were starving!
author: Yenchu L.

description:
Sat night. 9pm. Open table for 2. And my gf and I are told we can't sit there because they have to plan for the other groups??! Yea... No. (And this was after we waited 15 mins for one of the two hipster servers to notice we were waiting.)

As far as the food goes, eh. I've had better, I've had worse.

They'd have gotten 3 stars had it not been for some shitty attitude from one of the servers.

(This was my second time - and I'm not really shocked to see the service hasn't improved)
author: David H.

description:
A two star rating might seem harsh, but given the description "Meh. I've experienced better." it describes my experience completely. I'm indifferent to the whole sustainability thing, so it was the great rating that drew me in. We came for dinner during happy hour so we ordered the calamari, california roll and some other roll I can't remember the name of off the happy hour menu and then the double-double roll and I want to say the 49er roll off the regular menu. The fact that I can't remember the names of the rolls is another indication of how mediocre I thought the food was. Everything was edible but it lacked flavor and the food just looked....drab. By the end of the meal we wished we had ordered another california roll off the happy hour menu because it was literally the best tasting roll we had that night. 

We had high hopes for this place but sadly they didn't deliver. The highlight of the night were the two married guys sitting at the table next to us (by the next table i mean less than a feet away, which was too close for comfort but whatever) that ordered too much sake and shared a couple shots with us.
author: Queena T.

description:
MK and I came here starving late last night (a little after 9pm) and there was a wait, but open tables and an open bar area. -1/2 star
After we were seated, service was slow and it stayed that way. 
I sat literally right in front of the cash register and the two guys working that night were so difficult to grab the attention of. My water glass stayed empty all night long. (definite bad thing when you accidentally take in a huge bite of wasabi and start crying) Speaking of wasabi, I had to wait 15 minutes for just wasabi and salt. And the wasabi is pre-plated, too! -1 star

And my first roll came before out appetizers were out. -1/2 star

I can't judge the fish quality since I grabbed 2 vegetarian rolls.
But I gotta say, I was a little frustrated that they couldn't customize MK's order. (He doesn't eat rice.) The server was such a pain to him. -1 star

By the end of the night, our tab ran up roughly $70 for 2 rolls, 2 appetizers, 2 drinks, and 3 hand rolls which is about average imo.

By the way, they say hand rolls are only during happy hour... it's not. MK grabbed 3.

Redeeming factor: a nice ambience. +1 star.
Total: 3 stars.
author: Angie M.

description:
First visit to Tataki, totally stoked about guilt-free seafood, but wondering whether that means my favorite fish will be off the plate (I'm looking at you, salmon). 

Fears unfounded, the meal was delicious and thanks to a sustainable gem called "arctic char", I can savor the taste of pink-fleshed fatty cold water fish without contributing to overfishing. Also, daaang, I might actually like the taste of arctic char a little better.

Everything we ordered was fresh and artfully presented. Prices were a touch higher than my default sushi spot, which is reasonable given the extra cost of sourcing ingredients. Like others, we had to wait for a seat, but a spot at the counter opened up shortly. 

Thanks for the introduction to my new favorite fish, Tataki. I'll be back!
author: Monica S.

description:
3.75
one of the better sushi restaurants in sf.
it's fusion-ish if  you like that.
the rolls are pretty good.
the extinguisher is not spicy at all.
the rice is a tad sweet but it's not mushy which is a definite plus.

their traditional mochi is similar to korean rice cake with bean powder.
the green tea cheesecake was pretty delish.
author: Heejin L.

description: I stopped by here while on a break from work on a Wednesday evening and had the rainbow roll with miso soup and ice tea. Everything was wonderful and I plan on returning soon! The menu was diverse so there should be plenty of things to try in the future. Great place for a date or small group of friends.
author: Nate B.

description: These guys/gals are trying to do a good thing for the world and educate me. So they get extra points. The venue was clean, the fish was fresh and tasted good. Hard to get full flavors from a farm raised fish, but they field a quality product. Keep up the good fight guys!
author: Marko I.

description: The best sushi I've ever had. We're new to the city and a friend took us here saying it was his favorite. We're absolutely hooked.
author: Scott P.

description:
Tataki has an excellent selection of lunch specials. I have never eaten in but I regularly get food to go. It is a little pricey because there is a high guilt free surcharge apparently so a lunch special make it accessible.

With the lunch special you get a choice of either miso soup or salad. The  soup is too salty and the salad is gross and brown with disgusting dressing.
author: Melissa B.

description: Look no further for the best sushi rolls in town! I love love love their house rolls, can't get enough of them. My favorite so far: Golden Gate. Innovative taste, interesting texture and addictive. The fact that they support sustainable fishing is the cherry on top of the pie.
author: Patricia D.

description:
I found this place to be extremely unique. The sushi had the fish on the outside of the roll and there was generous amounts of  red caviar on all the rolls we ordered.  

I also noticed that the sushi was warm.. either slightly seared or served on warm rice.. and had some sort of marinade on it like soy sauce or something of that nature.  Not exactly what I'm used to as I prefer my sushi chilled. Taste-wise the sushi was also somewhat banal and I didn't really get a "kick" out of anything I had here.. not even the 49-er ;)  lol

Lastly, their wasabi was slightly discolored.. brownish. Perhaps it was organic or sustainable.. either way I didn't like this but accepted it figuring it was normal.

We went (2 ppl) on a Wednesday evening at 7:30PM and the wait was 5 mins. By 8:00 there were empty seats. We ordered between the 2 of us the half bottle of unpasteurized sake and another small sake, edamame, 3 rolls (49er, golden state, and something else I forgot, and the green tea cheese cake). 

Oh, last remark about this place: Lots of rice in the rolls and so you don't need to order too much to be full. I left extremely satisfied and with tip for 2 it came up to $110 :p

Don't forget to ask for water! They make you ask for it here..
author: Kathy S.

description:
Wow, some of the best sushi I ever had! 
Had to wait in a line for a table in around 15 minutes, but definetly worth it! 
Ended up in the bar with my sister, so we could see how the cheff worked, and that's amazing. The sushi tasted soo good, and the service was really nice - would love to visit Tataki again, next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Emilie L.

description: In terms of sushi - this may be my favorite of all time.  Their vegetarian options are TO DIE FOR, their spicy tuna tempura is delish and the nigiri was incredible.  I can't WAIT to go back!!!
author: Emily Y.

description:
After eating at Tataki, I realized why there are *not* many places, if there are any others at all in San Francisco, that serve sustainable sushi -- It's simply not as good.  I mean don't get me wrong, god (whoever that is for you) bless there souls for being ecovironmentally conscious, but it's simply a niche, and a valiant attempt at differentiating.

And somehow, I guess it's working because I have no idea how the food here on its own can average 4 stars.  I came here on a Monday night, so there were no crowds or a long wait to sway my judgement here (unlike some other low-star reviews, this review is completely even-tempered, unbiased, and all about the food ;-) )

- We had the baked mussels to start. They were a little gritty, not very hot, and parts of it stuck to the shell (not in a good way.)
- Then seaweed salad; ok, it was seaweed salad.
- Then we each had the 9 piece nigiri.  Nothing memorable except me thinking "I wish this was the smooth, melt in your mouth fish like 7/10 sushi places in SF can do because the fish is just that great out here and all you have to do is slice it ... ".  But then I remembered, "oh yeah, this is sustainable fish :-/  ", so I just ate and thought about my future children and mustered a smile.
- then the extinguisher roll.  There was really nothing memorable about this at all except fire on the plate.  Plus the roll was tiny.  Am I really going to pay $12 for fire?
- we had some other roll too, but for the life of me, I can't remember what it was like. 

So if you've been craving really good sushi, and are scouring yelp looking for a place with great, fresh, fish, I would recommend you bypass Tataki and go for something ... less sustainable.

On the other hand, if you've just over-pumped the gas in your car and some of it leaked out, run over a squirrel, or otherwise maimed a breathing being (trees/plants count) and are looking for something to make you feel a little better about your part in the environment, then perhaps Tataki is the place for you tonight.

Cheers, and happy fishing.

(Btw, I would have really liked to have given this a 2.5 star review based on the food, but had to go whole numbers; the wait staff unfortunately tipped it lower.)
author: Jenny X.

description: Very fresh sushi. The quality of the food is so good and tasty. Probably one of the best Japanese We've tried in SF. Highly recommended.
author: Laia B.

description: Food looked awesome, but table was dirty, waitstaff catatonic, and club music pulsing like some happy hour gay bar. I'll try take out and report back.
author: Siobhán K C.

description:
The service was quick. I love the decor of the restaurant, everything had a wood theme. Cozy place too meaning not big and limited space.

ORDERED:
extinguisher (albacore tuna, avocado, habanero masago, spicy aioli) - awesomely displayed dish. Includes fire :)

golden state (spicy scallop, minced apple,seared albacore tuna, avocado, yuzu tobiko) -  really enjoyed the minced apple in the roll.

early bird (asparagus, avocado roll topped with seared filet mignon and pineapple) - beef was done perfectly tender. the hint of pineapple tied all the flavors together.
author: Jess H.

description:
I needed a quick bite this afternoon close to the Mt. Zion campus of UCSF. After reviewing a couple of entries on my Yelp app, I decided I was in the mood for sushi. And after reading the fantastic reviews of this establishment, I was convinced to walk on over to Tataki. 

The building is small and unassuming with limited, yet comfortable seating. My order was taken quickly and pleasantly. There is a menu of lunch specials which I would recommend if you're in the mood for a little variety. I ordered a spicy tuna roll and the chef selection of 4 nigiri. The meal came with a salad or miso soup for $10.  For the price I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of all the ingredients, especially the nigiri. I'm not saying it was the best sushi I have ever ordered, but for a quick Tuesday lunch it hit just the right spot. 

After I finished my plate was quickly cleared and the check brought. Remember the $15 credit card minimum if you're usually one not to carry cash. I would definitely recommend visiting this place, especially since they purchase fish that are sustainably farmed. The 4 stars come from the combination of service, flavor, and sustainable farming.
author: Calvin G.

description: My wife and I tried this place out with a visiting friend. Next thing we know, 7 sushi rolls have been delightfully devoured with three bottles of sake. Our last roll was the 'Double-Double' served on a fan-shaped place and delivering a full on mouthgasm!
author: Wendell A.

description: I've gone out today sushi plenty of times and I've got to say that so far Tataki is hands down the best sushi place in SF. What more is there to say? (I have dreams about eating there, that's how good it is.)
author: Angelica R.

description: Best sushi in the City.  Hands down. Service was excellent. Atmosphere was on point. Loved how they moved to the bigger space cause I can finally now get in (cause I refuse to wait in lines). But I'm so glad they did.  Fresh fish. Creative menu.  Flavor explosions!  And for San Francisco, very reasonable prices. Will be coming back here every time I crave sushi. Which is probably once a week!
author: Brian C.

description:
ATTN sushi lovers: eating here is the best decision you will ever make... and it's good for the planet. How can you say no to that?

Let me begin by saying I'm a total sushi snob.  I live for Sushi.  Before discovering Tataki, I was a complete newb when it came to sustainable sushi.  I discovered it with a DJ friend who had just met one of the owners, a true crusader for the sustainable seafood movement.  After meeting him,  learning all about sustainability and more responsible choices, I was inspired to follow in the same pursuit and be more conscious of what I ate from then on.  

Everything they serve is either Best Choice or Good Alternative on the Monterey Bay Seafood Watch Guide so you won't find normal Sushi items such as Hamachi, Toro or Unagi, all in the Avoid category either for inhumane catching methods, being overfished or harmful to eat.  Some of the alternatives they offer taste and look exactly like, or even better than, the other stuff, you can't even tell the difference and you won't miss it - I promise.  The fish I've had there has always been fresh, juicy and delicious. I love the poke sampler, a sweet, savory and spicy trio; my favorite is the spicy, it's fantastic.  Also try the tataki roll and extinguisher roll, the flame on the plate adds extra pizazz! And if you're feeling ace, order the "V.I.P. roll", it's not even on the menu! Did I mention everything is delicious?

I'm really glad I discovered this place and the movement.  Now I'll never eat farmed, overfished or inhumanely caught fish.  I know this sounds really tree-hugging-hippie, but I swear... all the cool kids are doing it :)
author: Connie W.

description:
