So I tend to not eat sushi very often as I'm not very good at knowing what I should or should not order. I always go with others who are foodies and let them take care of everything. 

Well a friend of mine from Minneapolis came into the city and was craving sushi. He had heard sushi was so much better out of the midwest (duh!). Well I didn't want to disappoint him, so I asked around and this place came highly recommended with reasonable prices. 

The wait wasn't long. It's a small, cute place. So it never feels packed and cramped. We asked our server for recommendations as we both had never been there before. He recommended the Extinguisher and Golden State. 

In the end we order both of those plus the 49er, edamame and 2 seaweed salads. 

Everything was prepared perfectly and arrived at our table perfectly spaced out. We had just finished our salads when our server arrived with the Golden State and 49er. My favorite was the 49er. I loved all the flavors and textures, especially the little lemon slice on the top! The seaweed salad was such a great size with big but subtle flavors. Wouldn't have changed a thing about it! I personally didn't care much for the Extinguisher as it was too spicy for my tastes. My friend LOVED the spice though! 

I would highly recommend this restaurant and will start eating more sushi now that i've finally found a great place to go!
author: Jee Mee H.

description:
Extremely impressive, albeit tiny, sushi spot tucked in a pacific heights neighborhood.  Their vegetarian menu is awesome, especially for someone who isn't a huge fan of fish.  Their sushi was equally fresh, delicious, and beautifully presented. They accommodated our huge party of 10 at the last minute on a really busy night.  Unlike other places, they didn't turn us down.  Everything we ordered was fantastic. 

A very clean, conscientious restaurant with great options for veggie lovers and sushi lovers a like.  We'll definitely go back!
author: Karen C.

description:
Wish I could give this place a negative number of stars. Went there on off night (a Wednesday) and ended up with food poisoning. The throw-up-all night-and-miss-work type of food poisoning. My friend did not have it as bad as me, although she did feel nauseous. We ordered the uni (special of the night), tempura roll, miso soup and bincho. Im guessing it was the uni, since it was mid-week and most likely had been left over from the weekend. 

Never again will I go here, or any sushi restaurant midweek for that matter.
author: Naveen G.

description:
The sushi here is delicious! I usually get my food to go, since they're always so busy.

Only four stars because sometimes the wait staff comes off as a bit pretentious or otherwise just not hospitable--however this is a minor detractor. Overall, I love Tataki!
author: Matthew J M.

description: This is by far the most delicious and flavorful Japanese food I've had in the Bay Area. Being a vegetarian it's hard to find a variety of veg rolls besides the usual avocado or mix veg rolls. This place has quite a lot of options and their Gyoza and garlic edamame were to die for! Definitely recommend it for a date or with friends.
author: Namrata P.

description:
Tasty down to the very last bite. The restaurant is really intimate, not ideal on a busy night with a large group, but doable.

Because we went with such a large group, we were able to order quite a few things. 

1.) Crab Croquette
2.) Ocean Salad
3.) Tataki Roll
4.) Extinguisher
5.) Golden State
6.) Green Dragon
7.) Philadelphia Roll

The quality of the fish is amazing, melt in your mouth freshness and can we say "A+" for the presentation. Don't forget to read the articles on the wall about Tuna and other fish.
author: Lisa G.

description:
Went here about 3 weeks ago with my girlfriend. We were really hungry looking for a sushi place and waited until 6pm on a Sunday for the place to open.

Luckily enough we were able to sit and order immediately. We started with Miso soups which were great as expected. We shared an order each of the Rainbow, Shrimp Tempura and Dragon Roll. Now the rolls we ate here stood out immediately as we started chewing. We had been eating at various sushi places frequently. Tataki's fish is simply fresher than fish at any other sushi place. Its texture is more natural and its taste perfect. Especially the Shrimp Tempura roll...It came with some sort of shiny-red crumbled batter which was excellent. 

After dessert we paid less than 50 dollars with a generous tip.

I have been relying on yelp extensively to find places to go, so I decided it was my turn to give feedback. I'll go as far as to say that Tataki is the best sushi I hade in SF so far.
author: Bulent K.

description: A really great restaurant . The seafood salad is a good way to start out your meal , it's a few pieces of chef's choice with seaweed. Very delicious . I had a few specialty rolls and they were fresh and delicious. Get here early though , the place isn't big , and it gets super hot inside if it's a full house.
author: Lauren V.

description: This place is seriously delicious! Everything I've had here has been exceptional. The Arctic char and avocado is flavorful and the fish/rice/avo ratio is just right for each piece. The scallop and toro are to die for-- incredibly fresh and hearty (in the best way possible for sushi). Even the lowly California roll is quite the masterpiece here. If you like wasabi, man oh man are you in for a treat! I believe it's prepared fresh here and compliments all of the rolls and nigiri perfectly.
author: A L.

description: The service may never be what I enjoyed for the first 2.5 years. It's not bad, just not familiar. Happy the food is back to very good. Like that it's local. I wish all the fish were.
author: Dave B.

description: Got the Spicy tempura roll and it was not fresh. The albacore tuna was mushy and clearly was old. Came here because of the Yelp reviews but was very disappointed. Will not be returning.
author: Samantha M.

description:
Another great visit to Tataki last night w my friend Liz!

We ordered the "mix-it-up" and Philadelphia rolls - both very good. 

I also tried the handline caught local Albacore - FANTASTIC! (so fresh & melted in my mouth, like all their ngiri does) ;)

And best of all, we had an AMAZING cocktail - "Kin-San-gria": house sangria w Riesling, sake & fresh fruits. It was so good, we each had 2!
author: Sally M.

description:
So far, I have not found a better place for sushi in San Francisco.

Excellent fish and an extensive, delicious vegan/vegetarian menu.
Lovely presentations.
Cozy and pleasant environment.
Knowledgeable, kind staff.
Prices are good for the quality of the experience.
author: Vanessa N.

description:
Let me keep it simple: The sushi here really is buttery-melt-in-your-mouth-fresh-and-delectable, and may be my favorite sushi in all of San Francisco, but both times I have been here each person at my table including myself has spent over $30, and left still feeling hungry. 

The problem is: the sushi is so good that you crave more. You want to order more. You do order more. You spend a lot of money, and still feel unsatisfied.

Last night I ate here and it was amazing:
-Sashimi sampler (6 pieces, 3 types of different fish, all delicious)
-Salmon sashimi special
-Scallop tataki
-Divisaderoll
-Two house hot sakes

I wanted more but we had already racked up quite a bill.

So, we did the next best thing: we left and went to Safeway and bought brie cheese, sourdough baguette, and wine...and went home and devoured that.

But, still, I think it's worth it. 

Come here if you are a sushi snob, an environmental fish activist (it's all sustainable), if you want to go big, and/or if you aren't starving.
author: Jamie J.

description: We went here last week on a weeknight and still waited nearly 40 minutes for a table, but it was worth it. The place is tiny so waiting for a table is almost inevitable. We ordered the sashimi deluxe and the fire extinguisher. The fire extinguisher was impressive with the fire on the plate, but the taste didn't quite live up to the presentation. The sashimi was superb, very fresh and clean. I would definitely come back, but only on a weeknight since I can't imagine waiting for a table on a weekend here.
author: Le D.

description:
Before I get into details, this is what you must know: small place, no reservations,  good service, great food and definitely a place to visit more than once, I will surely be back.

Now, on the specifics, came here with 3 more friends, ordered bunch of stuff to share: edamame, fried calamari,  tataki deluxe, tataki, extinguisher, early bird, green dragon and all four of us agreed, it was fresh and delicious. Same goes for deserts, they were great, cheesecake, mochi and whatever the third one was (something with rice) but mochi was my favorite but my firends loved the cheesecake.

The only reason why I am not giving it 5 stars is because I could find some issues with service, our table wasn't cleaned during service (there was a lot of spilled soy sauce on it) and we really werent' offfered water but eventually we asked for it towards the end. With all that being said, I didn;t mind it too much. Our server was very pleasant and helpfull and most importnantly, food was great. 

I will be back, fo sho, cause i need me some mo, of that sweet tataki my ninjas!
author: Voodoo S.

description:
Con: Not so happy! Ate here at happy hour on a Thursday. Got there at 5:00 and waited for the 5:30 opening.
Pro: Sat in the front window with a good view of the street and no crowding. 
Con: Ordered beer and sake and a couple of hand fools cause my partner is diabetic and NEEDED food. Waitress said they didn't have the ghost sake I liked. Ordered a more expensive and larger bottle. 
Con: Waitress brought the beer and sake and promptly dropped the beer on the table, broke a sake glass and covered everything with beer and glass shards.Maintained our cool and waited while she alone cleaned it all up. She took away all the tableware and glassware and came back to make sure the table was clean.
Con: she was the only waitress and took forever to bring back our drinks, table war, water and glasses.Food took even longer!
Pro: I have funky teeth and if the nori isn't fresh I can't bite it. Nori and all fish was wonderfully fresh!
Con: I asked when we sat down if they had Uni. Said yes. When waitress brought us our two orders she said it as the last. What? This was 5:35!
Con: all orders on the happy hour menu came with canned wasabi. Orders off the menu came with fresh ground wasabi. Turns out it's an option if you ask.
Con: free water without ice.
Con: very warm room!
Con: when I asked about a different sake to try she brought me ghost sake! WTF!
Pro: fish was tasty and amazing!
Con: no comping of anything for the spilled beer and glass all over us.
Management DID NOT SEEM TO CARE!
Con: no itemized bill showing taxes and other fees!
Result NO TIP AND VERY UNSATISFACTORY EXPERIENCE,
author: Carol m.

description:
I love that Tataki is trying to make sustainable sushi work.  I came here, wanting, hoping, to love it and to think, 'hey, you CAN eat fabulous sushi and not totally lay ruin to the oceans!'  I hoped I would think, 'man, I wish there was a sustainable sushi place in my neighborhood!'

One problem: their sushi was not fabulous.

Oh, it was passable.  It was really fresh (I am coming to find that in San Francisco, most all fish is really fresh, and that's to be expected, considering its location) and I didn't think it would make me sick or anything.  But, well, I ordered the chef's choice of nigiri thinking that he would choose selections of fish that complemented one another, that had different tastes, that showcased the variety of his restaurant.  He didn't.  Three of the four selections were as bland of fish as I've ever eaten.  The waitress didn't even bother telling us what they were until we asked (she did, however, tell another couple as we craned our necks to overhear).  One of the four selections was absolutely fantastic - buttery and almost citrusy in its sweetness.  Too bad I don't know which one it is so I can't plug it!

We also got three rolls and the arctic char with avocado was, as promised by the previous reviews, the best.  Like a salmon-avocado with a kick.  The pieces were big and juicy, almost too big to fit in my mouth in one bite.

We also got Tataki's version of a rainbow roll, the Tataki roll, in which the chef seared the variety of fish on the outside with a blowtorch and topped the whole thing off with four kinds of caviar.  It looked beautiful and was fun to watch the guy prepare but... eh.  It was pretty good, but nothing phenomenal, and it had a blowtorch aftertaste.

The one roll I didn't even finish was their spicy tuna roll.  Spicy tuna mix wrapped in crab and topped with habanero and avocado... sounds good, right?  Not if the whole thing tastes like fake crab!  I asked before we ordered the roll - is this real or fake crab? - and she told me it was half and half.  Well, half and half doesn't matter if it tastes like the cheapest crab salad from King Soopers.  Really.

Normally I would give this level of food and experience two stars, but for being sustainable and trying to do their part, I'm giving three - but begrudgingly, since no sushi in San Francisco should ever be worse than most of the sushi in Boulder, CO!
author: Hannah E.

description: This place is whatever.  Waited 40 minutes for very sub-par, quite bland sushi.  You have to order a lot to be filled and I just don't think the wait is worth it.  On to the next....
author: Alex G.

description:
A place to go when you have time and in the neighborhood.

They are somewhat small (~30 seats) and do not take reservations.

With that said, the food is good especially if you like spicy rolls.
author: Francis M.

description:
I came here with a girlfriend recently and it was amazing. I am a huge fan of sushi and often disappointed by sushi places, and this one definitely did not disappoint! The firecracker roll comes with a little, well, fire on the plate, which is strangely exciting given the darkness of the room! I also got an artic char roll which was wonderful, I'd never had it before and it does taste like tuna with the look of salmon - weird.

My girlfriend ordered two vegetarian options and really enjoyed both.

I am into the vibe of this place - though it is tiny and there is often a wait so come early and not with a big group - as well as their sustainable approach. The one thing I am docking a star for is service - it took me about ten tries to get the waiter's attention every time I wanted water, which was often given my heavy hand with wasabi.

I'll be back!
author: Courtney A.

description:
SF's take on sushi: small restaurant, incredibly tasty, sustainable fish with a twist of originality. 

Food: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars
Ambiance: 3.5 stars
Price: $$

Food: 4
Fish was fresh, with great plating/presentation and attention to detail. Everything was great, without being too much. What you would expect for sushi. Selection is not as large (don't expect Yellow Tail), but once you read about fish sustainability, you won't be wanting it anyway. Not a fan of the tataki roll, but personal preference. Rainbow was exceptional, tobiko really good. Edemame had a hint of butter which made them incredibly tasty. 

Service: 4 
You sign in and might have to wait because of the size, but they are good at giving you a heads up and inviting you to grab a drink next door while you are waiting. Waiter was good, a little dry but really efficient. Rolls are served as they are ready, which is good and bad. Don't expect a large plate with everything on it, so if you like to end with a last bite of (name your roll here), you'll have to save it. Our last rolls came a little too late and had lost our eating momentum (and it was the Tataki which we didn't like as much, so dinner didn't end on the strongest note)

Ambiance: 3.5
wood chopsticks, small place, nice tables. Not your typical japanese place, in a positive way. No carpet, decent decoration on the walls, a little too bright for the size.

All in all, great date night, fun place for 2/4 people especially on a slow night like Monday.
author: Etienne D.

description:
I was eager to try Tataki after learning that it is one of the few sustainable sushi joints in the city. My wish finally came true when my friend and I stopped by here early this evening. We arrived right at opening time which was good since the restaurant is tiny. Although the restaurant itself is small, the decor is very clean, hip and modern.

We got down to business and ordered the sashimi deluxe with a side order of sushi rice. We also ordered the seafood salad as a starter. The sashimi was out of this world. Extremely fresh and melt in your mouth tender! Mmmmmm!!! The sushi rice was delicious with just the right amount of seasoning in it.

Since I've been pining to eat here, we decided to be gluttons and ordered the uni and shiro maguro nigiri. Well, we didn't stop there and also ordered the crab croquettes. It was the perfect ending to our meal with bits of tender crab encased in batter-fried goodness. Oh my!

Any restaurant that serves delicious food and is conscientious of the environment gets five stars in my book! Extra kudos for the Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch pamphlet they leave on each table! It's a great way to educate their diners about sustainable seafood.

Service is also fast and helpful when you're in dilemma about what to order. I will definitely come back and make this my regular sushi spot whenever I'm in the city.
author: Bernadette A.

description: Delicious and creative sushi. Good location and happy to get in with happy hours.
author: Francis R.

description: I really like this spot. It's small with intimate lighting and really fresh fish. I found this place from the Yelp reviews, so they didn't disappoint. I really suggest the muscles as a starter, the Nigiri Aji (so fresh), the 49er roll, and the cheesecake for dessert. I always ask the staff what they suggest to get and they like the notion of trust that comes from the customer, so they give good ideas. They don't take reservations, and it can get busy, but you'll def enjoy some fresh fish that is worth your while if you wait.
author: Mimi K.

description:
Love the arctic char roll and the double double roll - original and so delicious!

Extra star for serving sustainable fish in all their dishes while keeping prices similar to other sushi restaurants in SF.

They also have lunch specials and a happy hour if you want to spend less $.
author: Ali G.

description:
Awesome rolls - try practically anything with char - its really good!  Interesting sushi - considering the whole sustainable fish story for the restaurant - they have no salmon - but soo many varieties.  

I just went there again most recently 2 days ago - and the wait was suprisingly not too bad and the food great.  Try the double-double, extinguisher (make sure you dip in the salt) and tataki roll.  It was very filling and I think we actually ordered a bit too much - which happens very easily w/ sushi.  

There was one veggie person in our party - who also (I think) had an excellent time and comes to Tataki fairly often.  So it works for veggies (non-seafood) peeps as well.  

This will go into sushi circulation!  Price wise - it worked out to about $40/pp (w/ drinks).  Its a small place - but tables turnover fairly fast - dont leave if you are waiting - the wait is not too bad!
author: Bhavin M.

description: Amazing!!! the sushi is so delicious...i wish i was able to try all the menu! it's not just about the fresh fish and seafood they're using but also the way they serve the food and the integration of all ingredients is genius! also, it's a sweet small place, very intimate and romantic and with good service. been there twice and will go again!
author: Michal E.

description:
A friend and I scored a table here without having to endure a super long wait on a weeknight. It's a super small space and so expect a wait outside. Yes, it's that cramped!

I'll be the first to admit, I'm a total Sashimi fanatic and was a bit skeptical about Tataki given their limited menu but the inquisitive side of me motivated me to check em out. Welp, based on the 4 star rating I'm giving Tataki, you can say I'm a fan!

The limited menu items they had didn't stop them from churning out some creative & tasty dishes which is the reason I'm such a fan. They were all very tasty and well executed. I'd definitely support this movement!
author: Soozie H.

description: Tataki has to be the best and freshest sushi in the pac heights area. I love that they open up a bit before dinner gets going, when you can typically walk in without an wait. It's a small space so be prepared to be scrunched in next to someone but all the rolls are awesome!
author: Kaego R.

description:
Boy, what a wait. We arrived here shortly after 8 pm. We waited until about 8:45. The restaurant is on the smaller side; it can probably fit about 30 people via tables and about 5 at the counter. The allure of this place is that it promotes sustainability, so that means no blue fin tuna. 

The staff is very nice and knowledgeable. Water was refilled every second. 

Here's what I had: 

2 pieces of uni ($8) - wild diver-caught urchin, U.S :  fresh, had a lot of flavor. 
2 pieces of hotate ($6) -  suspension-farmed scallop, Japan : soft like a pilow 
2 pieces of Iwana ($5)  - closed-farmed arctic char, Iceland : tasted somewhat like mackeral, but I liked how soft it was.
2 pieces of  Saba ($4.5) - wild Atlantic mackerel, Norway: tasted like Spanish mackerel 

Total damage per person is around $30, it varies depending on what you get. I think 9 nigiri pieces is usually enough to feed the average person. 

The fish on the west coast seems to be a lot drier than that of the east coast. It is like someone patted the uni and the hotate dry with a paper towel. It doesn't really affect the taste that much, it is just something I noticed. 

Overall, not a bad deal for sustainable, fresh, and rather inexpensive quality sushi. If you are trying to kill a craving for some great sushi but don't want to break the bank, this is a great place to try.
author: Stacy T.

description: Cozy little space, we sat at the bar and we're able to watch the chefs prepare food, which was cool.  The calamari we got was a little on the chewy side, but the seasoning and sauce were great.  All the rolls and sashimi that we got were tasty and had nice presentation.  Definitely  not a place for large groups, but for four people or less it works.  The service was surprisingly fast, we were in and out without any waiting around.  Prices were decent too, especially if you hit their happy hour (before 7).  Overall it was a solid place for dinner.
author: Angus R.

description:
My family and I just came back from having dinner at Tataki. How we found the place is all due to my sister's fiance. They love to Yelp and be very adventurous.  They like to try and checkout new restaurants using Yelp.  I think we all have to agree, we all highly recommend this restaurant.  

I was a bit skeptical because my mom is not into sushi.  To my surprise, they did have somehting just for everyone.  We had the following:

Crab Croquette - My parents seemed to like this. It was ok. It had just the right amount of spices.
Baked Sanma - This is baked mackerel. It was a little salty but I squeezed some lemon and it was perfect.
Ahi Tuna Poke - Definitel reeommend this one.
Fried Calamari - A little on the salty side, but if you squeeze lemon it's not so salty
Tataki Deluxe - definitely recomend this dish.
Extinguisher - If you like hot, THIS IS the dish for you.
Early Bird - I like the pineapple taste and definitely recommend this dish.

The restaurant is small but the place is clean specially the restroom.
Last but not least, service was great and price was reasonable.

I defitnitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Nerissa D.

description: Great lunch spot near kaiser hospital. Small on the inside. Great service. They have chefs choice lunch specials. 10$ 2 rolls and Comes with a REAL mixed green salad or miso soup. The sushi was amazingly great!! Spicy tuna was not crazy with sauce either. I'll be coming back when working in the area again!!
author: Jenny H.

description:
This is my go to neighborhood sushi spot. That being said, I would absolutely cab it across the city and wait as long as necessary for a table. I LOVE that everything is from sustainable sources.

The Faux-nagi, a take on unagi with black cod, melts in the mouth with tons of flavor. I always get the sashimi platter. The arctic char tastes like sea-butter and the Japanese scallops are amazing. I could easily eat the deluxe sashimi platter (20 pieces) by myself, yeah its that good! The specialty rolls are awesome too.
author: Mike G.

description: Not that bad. We enjoyed the 49ers roll, but were pretty disappointed with the extinguisher, (no, spice did not cover the extremely bad fish taste..) although the roll looked entertaining.. Overall, nothing to stand out, plus space is kinda cramped.. Gave stars for nice service.
author: Alice G.

description: I have to put emphasis on how truly great their deep fried calamari is. It is AMAZING, and ultimately the BEST calamari dish I've ever had. It was fresh and just as crispy and the taste hinted w/ a bit of lemon was just orgasmic in the mouth. Just wanted to put emphasis on the calamari as if I were underlining it, adding bold to it and capitalizing it. Yes, if you have not tried the calamari here you are definitely missing out. Also, sushi is SO fresh, even if the portions are small, this is quality of quantity we are talking here.
author: Sam K.

description: Some of the best sushi I've had in the city. Wife and I went in late December. I can't believe we've never seen this place. We ordered the seaweed salad to start. I can usually determine the how the sushi is going to be based on the freshness of the seaweed salad. The $$$ was fresh and plentiful .  The entrees we ordered were the, golden state roll , the mix it up roll and the double-double roll. All were fantastic, but the best was probably the double-double which was a good level of spice but not overkill. We'll go here again. A great gem.
author: Mike T.

description: I am so lucky to be living walking distance from one of the few sustainable sushi restaurants in the city, especially when they offer weekly happy hours until 7pm!  I personally enjoy their regular sushi menu over the happy hour menu (just because the selection for HH is limited), but for my bank account's sake, hey I will take it ;)  Some of my favorite rolls: extinguisher (comes with fire, literally), golden state & green dragon.
author: Lindsey O.

description: I've always wanted to try this place since I live down the street and always see a line out the door of people waiting. I went on a Sunday evening and ended up ordering to go since the wait was too long, and wasn't that impressed with the rolls that I got. The sushi seemed to be quickly made, with the rice not evenly spread around the seaweed and their takeout actually wasn't much faster than eating there would have been.
author: Jing L.

description:
This is a fantastic sushi place!  I have enjoyed eating sushi for a long time, and this is one of my top three sushi places I've ever tried!


Pros:
- Happy hour runs until 7.  There are many delicious rolls on the happy hour menu, and they are very reasonably priced!

- The quality of the fish at this place is fantastic! It is both flavorful and sustainable (good on the taste buds and the conscience).  

- The rolls are creative (won't find them anywhere else) and delicious! 

- The ambiance is intimate and cozy.  


Cons: 
- Limited seating
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
Hands down best sushi joint in the city. If you gave Tataki a low rating, you are a liar!! Ha. I said it. 

If you go, make sure Elliot takes care of you. He knows his fish and will guide you along one of the best meals you will ever have in SF. Per Elliot's recommendations we tried the golden gate roll, kurodai tataki (seared sea bream, avocado, and a jalapeno ponzu sauce...holy shit was this good), a 12 piece sashimi plate which included scallops, striped bass, arctic char, and tuna (every piece melted in our mouths; unbelievably fresh and each uniquely flavorful and delicious), and the tuna tataki salad. Not a bad bite. I really don't have enough superlatives to don Tataki with, but seriously... do yourself a favor and go!
author: Bruce S.

description:
Pro: The sustainable concept is interesting and good for the environment.

Cons: The arctic char, supposedly the replacement for salmon, is tasteless.  All sushi rolls are small and has little fish in them.  Lots of vegetarian rolls but nothing much to satisfy a sashimi's lover.
Will not come back.
author: De S.

description:
So many great restaurants in San Francisco, particularly so many sushi restaurants, and yet I can't go anywhere else.  Because I came to Tataki, I fell in love with Tataki, and now I have no interest in trying any other sushi.  Period.  It's THAT good.  

My first visit to Tataki was really eye-opening because it didn't taste like any other sushi I'd ever had before.  It actually made me question the quality of all the other fish I've eaten before.  Seriously, Tataki made me get all introspective and pensive and shit.  

You know what happens when you eat sushi made with sustainable seafood?  You end up eating things you've never eaten before.  All those old reliable rolls you used to love?  Tuna, salmon, etc?  Forget them, because at Tataki you'll be eating things like mackerel and char instead.  And they taste a million times better.  

Swoon.  I love Tataki.
author: Julie H.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here to celebrate six months together--our halfiversary! Happy hour is every night until 7pm. We were there in time to get $4 large Sapporos.

We ordered: arctic char (5 pieces; $4.50 during happy hour), the extinguisher (8 pieces; $13; albacore tuna, avocado, habanero masago, spicy aioli, and a small fire on the plate), and the nigiri sampler (5 pieces; $11; chef's choice). The extinguisher had a cool presentation and was a good level of spicy. The nigiri sampler was good but I wish I had gone with the nigiri enthusiast, which has 9 pieces.

GET THE ARCTIC CHAR. I cannot stress this enough. The next time we come here (and oh yes we're coming back), we're going to get 4 orders of the arctic char and devour furiously.
author: Alleliah N.

description: One of those small restaurants with character. Getting a table was difficult but it was worth it. Sushi was one of the best I ever had. Sashimi platter was THE BEST I ever had. I Dont know when I will be in the city for this again but I certainly enjoyed my visit and hope to visit again some day. Take your date/partner here...you are welcome ;)
author: Kay Y.

description: They do not take reservations and will not seat you until everyone in your party has arrived. Very small place, but worth the wait. Amazing sushi... My favorite was the mix-it-up roll. As were were finishing, we saw another table get the roll with a flaming plate. Next time we are in town, we will have to try the extinguisher roll.
author: Becky P.

description:
Happy hour, 5-7 everyday - it's amazing.

Sweet potato roll.

However, make sure your whole party is there - they will not seat you otherwise.
author: Matthew F.

description:
OH MAN, the Char Carpaccio is AMAZING.  It just melts in your mouth and citrus sauce goes perfectly with it.  Don't leave without getting it.

One thing we especially enjoyed was our sake.  And the name escapes me, but I had an unfiltered, sweet, slightly effervescent sake.  If you like sweet wines and champagne, you should give it shot.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I would have rated this place 4 stars, but they were out of beef carpaccio last night and until I taste that raw, still mooing goodness they'll have to settle for 3. Oh, and they ran out of Oysters, too. :(

BUT! I will say that their diviserderoll with kampachi and tobiko was actually quite nice. Crunchy tobiko, good flavours, and I didn't look like an idiot trying to shove a giant piece of sushi in my mouth, because they were cut into small, managable pieces. 

Then we ordered baked mussels, miso soup, and the Spicy Tempura roll. The baked mussels were in some sort of delectable cheese concoction, and since it was Jon's first time eating them I was able to breathe again when he said he liked them. Unless he was lying, and in that case I'm just going to go die now. 

They weren't lying about the Spicy Tempura roll. It was topped with a fire-roasted slice of jalapeno, and hot damn they were right. But I had gone with the roll as sort of a backup. Thank goodness for sparkling sake and water. 

No dessert, but the service was excellent, even if the girl was a little too into trying to clear everyones tables as quickly as possible. That would have been nice if we were passing through periods of awkward silence, but we weren't, so it was just kinda weird.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Really delicious, fresh, light food. My favorites: garlic edamame and seaweed and cucumber salad.   I assign stars based on food.
That said, the service is in differenta and the atmosphere is cramped and not particularly attractive. 
Very clean restroom, though.
author: I R.

description:
We have become regulars at this quaint place and enjoy each visit. Elliott does a great job of working to seat and serve the masses as this place definitely has an impressive following. 

Be prepared for at least a 20 minute wait but know the sashimi and arctic char and avocado roll are worth the wait.
author: Jen F.

description:
My girlfriend's eyes lit up as she looked to another table--the plate was on FIRE! We had already ordered. "What is that?!?", she exclaimed. Wanting to cross my fingers, I retorted with, "Extinguisher...?".

Our order at this new & not-so-reasonably priced Sushi joint in Pacific Heights consisted of their Asian-fusion style Beef Carpaccio, an Artic-Char roll...and of course, the Extinguisher roll. 

Edamame was complimentary with our order, I always like that...and the beef Carpaccio appetizer was perfect for sharing--I hate onions but actually enjoyed the mildly onion flavored sauce.

The sushi was SUPER fresh, and being a fan of anything hot & spicy the Extinguisher roll delivered. At first you don't realize how hot it is, but there's this residual, "OMG MY MOUTH IS ON FIRE I NEED WATER OH WAIT ITS NOT HELPING EAT SOYBEAN DRINK WINE AHHH IT'S GOING AWAY MUCH BETTER".

Then of course, you have another one.
( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/8RnqktI7A5mY1_NdR1j7nQ/l )

Our server had also mentioned the Nigiri special for the evening, Alaskan Salmon. It was probably some of the freshest, smoothest & tastiest I've had.

I would visit Tataki again, but my biggest suggestion to them is to create some sort of Happy Hour special. Solstice is next door with booming business & if they are going to compete then it would be a good idea for them to have more reasonable pricing.
author: matt m.

description:
Sashami-averse.... 

That said, this place still gets my approval! I was going through my quasi-vegetarian phase when I ate here so my options were pretty limited when it can to ordering. While scanning the menu, I saw the Ratoutouille roll. Ordered it and it was AMAZING! Had the calamari as well and it was delicious.

Place is fairly small, ~30 seats. I'd suggest arriving early to get a table.
author: Annie L.

description: Adorable little sushi place.  When we went the wait time wasn't terrible (which is oh so nice) and the veggie options were delish.
author: Amala N.

description: Sustainable. Sushi. What does that mean? Basically, its the free range chicken, grass fed/roaming beef of the sea. Does it matter? Debatable. Does it taste better. Your damn right, and that is what matters. The sashimi deluxe here was incredible. Fresh as I've had just about anywhere. The sunrise roll is equally fresh and light and clean, not to mention the arctic char sashimi which was also excellent. We also had the tataki salad which was wonderful and large, then finished with the matcha cheesecake. The food  here is excellent and worth the wait as the place is tiny even for SF. Be warned, service can be a bit slow since its constantly jammed and small but its sushi...relax, stay a while.
author: Z P.

description:
Good sushi. Everything is sustainable here so be prepared to try some new fish and it is absolutely delicious.

The arctic char was really good as well as a bunch of other fish that I couldn't get the name of.  We ordered the nigiri platter and got no explanation on what everything was which was disappointing.  It was all very fresh, unfortunately they only gave us one nigiri of each kind so my date and I couldn't try the same fish together.  The interior is small and cozy with 4 spots available at the sushi bar. The chefs were helpful but I felt bad after asking them what every fish was that i got so I spared them and shut up after a while.

It can get busy (at least on weekends) so be prepared to wait.  Service was good except for the lack of explanation and the puddle of soy sauce that was originally on my stool. That was easily taken care of by switching stools with the one next to me but the couple trying to sit down a minute later weren't too happy.

It's a little on the pricey side but Tataki should definitely be included in your sushi bar rotation, and if you don't have a rotation yet get one!
author: Ryan J.

description:
(See pics)

Arrived around 7pm and it's not busy but got very packed around 8:30pm!

I don't usually rate places 5 stars, but apparently I got lucky and found 2 great places back to back!!

Thanks to Yelp for this little joint, I would not have found it if it's not for the great reviews!

The miso soup was very good, thick soy and lots of seaweed and tofu, my like! The Tataki Deluxe, for only 28 bucks, you get 18 pieces of sashimi-- albacore totally melted in your mouth, kampachi with that little jalapeno on top, firm edge soft center tuna, arctic char carpaccio with the compliment of capers, skipjack that gave your taste bud all the detailed textures it yearns for, and all with their special pairing sauces! 

Uni Nigiri was from Santa Barbara and was fresh attractive beige colour and vibrant! Ikura Nigiri was soft and gently popped in your mouth like small fireworks.

The Extinguisher was almost like a fancy show, that they put sugar on the side, light up a fire that was burning when they served it. Beautiful and eye-catching, the blood red habanero infused tobiko on kampachi avocado roll was inventive and delicious.

They also have an excellent selection of cold sake. We first had the Otokoyama as it's always a great choice. Then moved onto the vanilla flavour Sho Chiku Premium. Both were perfect complementary to the sushi.

They had 2 kinds of not so common desserts-- coffee jello with Kahlua cream sauce and whipped cream, definitely made my tongue dance! The green tea cheesecake was solid, creamy but not too heavy, and with slices of strawberry "garnish" which balanced the taste and made the experience unforgettable!

And all these were ONLY 100 bucks. You just can't beat the excellent quality and perfect upbeat ambiance!

Their use of wooden plates and reusable chopsticks, as well as their promoting environmentally friendliness definitely made them stand out from many other sushi places I have been to.

And even the bathroom had its own character, the round lighted mirror made an interesting reflection in your pupils.
author: T L.

description:
Yay! Finally a neighborhood sushi joint! 

Highlight: The Rolls!!

The presentation: Perfection.

The food: 
- Delicious: Ratataouille Roll, Tataki Roll, Reggae Roll
- Only OK: Extinguisher Roll (although great presentation), Ice Cream Mochi

Will definitely be returning!

Other notes:
- 4 of us went with a baby, and the music is just perfectly loud that we could all hear one another talk, but we couldn't hear the baby cry.
- 2 of the 4 of us were vegan / vegetarians - and the menu options were plentiful and tasty! Highly recommend!
author: Helen D.

description: a little pricey on the specialty rolls but like the new place
author: John S.

description: It's my first time is San Francisco, so getting some good sushi is a priority. The divisaderoll was incredibly fresh and delicious and the shrimp tempura roll was done perfectly. The experience here was simply wonderful. Fantastic food, wine and sake.
author: Heather T.

description:
Tataki is B Y FAR the best sushi spot I've been to in the city.  I'm actually a vegetarian so I'll start with that:  the vegetarian menu is amazing.  I've been to a few veggie sushi spots in the mission which were decent... but the most interesting roll I've had at one of those places was an avocado tempura roll.  Tataki has a full veggie menu with really awesome choices like a veggie philly roll (bean curd serves as the protein), hot potato roll (some sort of sweet potato in an amazing sauce), asparagus tempura roll topped with shaved pumpkin, etc. I'm not doing it justice so you'll have to go check out the menu yourself.  

My fish eating friends have all loved the regular sushi menu as well.  Apparently the fish is sustainable and extremely fresh.  Everyone I've come with has come back multiple times after our visit.

My only qualm is the space is a little small.  If you have a group of 5 or more, I probably wouldn't come here.  But, even with the lack of space, they've managed to decorate well enough to make the place feel inviting.   

Finally, the service is awesome.  I've had a different waiter/waitress each time and they've always been super friendly and on point.  

I can rave more but I'll stop at that.  Definitely would recommend checking it out.
author: Zena B.

description: Challenge with this spot is getting a table.. Its a great place to eat but when you have to wait 30 mins in their cramped entry way or outside in the california street wind tunnel the experience is diminished.
author: Benjamin N.

description:
Tuesday night. I came here as a party of 4 for a friend's birthday. I wish I got here earlier.  Probably got here around 6:25pm, parked by 6:30 (got lucky with parking), and waited about 40 minutes to get seated. This place is SMALL. I wouldn't recommend coming with a large party unless you come super early or super late.

To start off, the service was only average. For such a small place, I would've expected more attentive service. There was only one waiter and a lady who filled up water. We were served non-iced water with a slice of cucumber inside. Friends got some beer. Wanted to get the sangria but missed the happy hour after waiting so long, so... forget it.

The portions here are small. If we didn't order a platter of sashimi deluxe, I don't think we would've been full. The rolls had "6 pieces" or so, but they are so bite-sized! I guess being sustainable is more costly... ): but I didn't taste that much of a difference in the fish than other japanese restaurants of this pricing.

We started out with the garlic edamame appetizer. It was okay... kinda sour, which was weird. Don't recall finishing the dish. 

We ordered:

Rainbow roll: YUM! I liked how they didn't throw in the shrimp as the orange color (like other places), but it was all fish (and avocados) on the top! I'm not a fan of california roll, so it was kinda nice to have a small roll with little imitation crab (: 

Divisaderoll: I liked it cause it was just albacore, avocado, and masago (I don't like all those extra cucumbers and stuff in my sushi).

Tataki roll: Very interesting! Wasn't a big fan of the sweet sauce, but the fish was seared just the right amount and the assorted tobiko was good presentation.

Golden State roll: Not my favorite. I thought it would be better, but the apple was weird.

49er roll: I liked this! I'm kind of a fan of lemon complimenting fish on sushi because of the kick of flavor, but the strong hint of lemon may be a way to hide other flavors, like "not fresh" fish

Sashimi deluxe: I wish I knew what everything on here was. There was the deliiciouuss sweet shrimp, the salmon was FRESH, there was skipjack tuna (weirdly dry? and flavorless), scallops, albacore tuna, artic char (tastes and looks similar to salmon), and some dirt tasting sashimi... seriously i was like wtf is this? i ate a mouthful of dirt (it was wrapped all fancy)

California roll and spicy tuna roll: Both pretty basic rolls, but they did throw on some crunchy stuff on top to make it "special". 

I did appreciate how they did not throw everything on the table at once. They brought things out as we finished another dish, so we never had a cramp table from too many dishes presented at once.

All together with a sapporo and an asahi beer, the meal was $160 (+t&t).
Don't feel like I'd come here again if I just wanted to get some sushi.
author: Adorable T.

description:
Surprisingly delicious and interesting rolls, excellent quality fish, AND they only serve sustainable sushi!  Have I stumbled upon sushi heaven?! It was surprisingly affordable (for sushi) and the staff was friendly and fairly quick. 

We had the sashimi taster, the mix-it-up roll, and a kampachi roll. All were delicious, but the mix-it-up roll is perhaps the best roll I've had in awhile. 

Tataki is now tied with Kazu Sushi for my second favorite sushi place (Zushi you're still number one but Tataki and Kazu are closing the gap).
author: Dani D.

description:
this is the place for you if youre a fan of overpriced japanese food.  

not much of a sashimi selection...nothing too special or unique on the chef's menu as well...

there are some speciality rolls if youre into that kinda of food...

and there are some tasty looking soup/noodle dishes as well

ordered up 3 items including 2 appetizers and a sashimi platter...nothing else off the menu really appealed to me.

staff is nice tho...and at least they use the white ginger instead of that pink stuff that many bunk japanese places use...also, the cuts of sashimi are generous.
author: Kyu L.

description:
Being a sushi fan, I am always in the mood to try new things. I had never  been to tataki before, but reading the reviews on yelp persuaded me to try it. Since a lot of people wrote that this place can get quite busy, I arrived at 5:40 (just about the time that they open). It was quite chilly that night so I asked to wait inside. It was clear that they were not prepared to seat me yet, but I didn't mind. I just wanted to stand somewhere that I wouldn't get icicles on the tip of my nose. 

As I was finally allowed inside, I was shocked to see that the waiters were wearing street clothes, and eating their dinners. We sat at the sushi bar and saw that the case was pretty clean. However, the selection of fish was very limited. I ordered salmon sashimi, which ended up tasting fishy, so I didn't finish it. I normally eat A TON of sushi when I go out, but this was not the case.

The ambiance was quite strange too. The music was playing on a loop, which got annoying. As the waitresses came to take our orders, it was clear that it was still her "dinner time". 

I won't be going back to tataki anytime soon.
author: Samantha R.

description: Their specialty rolls are so yummy.  I love this place.
author: PO W.

description:
I've had this place before, and thought it was good.  This trip however, may be my last.  
We ordered several things both to start and for our main meal.  There was a mixup with part of the food order, and the hot tea I ordered never came.  The seafood salad was not nearly as good as last time I was there one piece was especially disgusting... I know they use rotating menues of sustainable fish, so hopefully this is just a blip in good service and food.  
On a positive note, the albacore nigiri and char/avocado roll were good.  
So yes, Meh.  I've experienced better.
author: Rob B.

description: To say I don't eat sushi often is an understatement. But I was glad I had it this time. Cool little place! Get there good and early so you won't have to wait long. Great crab croquets, by the way!
author: Dan B.

description:
Guilt-free sashimi, AMAZING-- for the mind And body! This was a first for me, I walked out of there feeling like I just donated to charity (which I did last week ;)).

Real quick--
**Place is small, don't plan to throw a party here (unless you can arrange to rent the whole place out). I counted... 26 seats, including the bar. Also, you will not be seated unless all guests are present. 
**Waiter was par. We arrived an hour prior to closing. Got seated 40 minutes later. It was very obvious that we were delaying him for his evening ahead. He was not rude, just very apathetic.
**Artic char, what is it you say? It's most similar to salmon a.k.a. sake. But it tasted... better! Could have been a conscience thing but I really liked it. Was fresh enough and thick enough.

Because the venue is quite petite, we waited a while for seats. However, being that it was my first time there, I used the time to read the articles on their wall. I learned a lot! Each table has a small information card that tells you about different sashimi pieces and its' source.

After my dinner here tonight, I am going to (try my very, very best to) stop ordering (Oh-)Toro, (Fat Belly) Bluefin Tuna at other restaurants (they don't serve it at all here, it's being fished to extinction). I always felt bad, as I chewed its' yummy, tainted, goodness. I never knew there were ethical choices for Japanese food until now; I'm so glad I found this place through Yelp!

The service has room for improvement, and it is there that Tataki falls short of what would have been a 5-star review.

I love the business ethics (and most of items of food)! Most because: my oyster on the half shell was room temperature-- my expectation was for it to feel chilled on the palate. The Pacific Sunrise specialty roll was also room temperature; it has 4 types of raw fish in it, kind of 0_o when it's anything but chilled.

Again, love the business ethics and the prices are reasonable!
author: Tammy H.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written about this place yet. Definitely one of the better sushi places in the city. 

Downside.. small place, long waits

Upside..great sushi. Most of their rolls are decent to amazing. If you're looking for a place where you know you're gonna enjoy the sushi, this is the place to go.
author: Shreya C.

description: Great place but they don't take reservations or let you go on the waiting list over the phone... Would recommend if you're going at an off time.
author: Robert C.

description: Everything I've had here is flavorful and fresh, the chef's choice of sashimi is unbeatable.
author: Katie M.

description:
I'm giving Tataki 5 stars because I was not left wanting AT ALL after my experience here.

Girlfriend and I were promptly seated at the bar. The chefs could not have been nicer, and the host was very hospitable and accommodating.

The best part about this place - SPICY TOFUNA ROLL!

All of the applicable menu items are labeled veggie or vegan (can't help but love places that do that), and there are plenty of both. The ambiance is fantastic. Great lighting and seating with some hip hop playing in the speakers that just fits for some reason.

Make it a point to check this place out if you ever get the chance. Well worth it.
author: Dalton C.

description:
As an interested PacHeights sushi-goer, i considered it my civic duty to stake out Tataki for days before their opening last night -- and was very much satisfied with the experience. the mood was serene, the food was excellent, the staff was cute, and the music was straight elevator music (not like, "lame music", but like, "i think OTIS Elevator actually gets kickbacks from sales of this CD"). but it was fine. in a sick way, it became kinda catchy and we bopped in our seats despite ourselves. a great, quiet spot.

the night began by receiving the strangest appetizer i've ever experienced in a sushi bar: an amuse-bouche of corn chips and ceviche. which, non-sequitur as it was, was actually great, if surprising.

we ordered:

miso, mixed salad, some otokoyamas (which came in rad black stoneware bottles)
the chef's sashimi selection was magnificent. very fresh and surprisingly, honestly, HEARTY sashimi.
a kamachi tataki was the only disappointment of the evening. stunningly bland save for a light ponzu sauce.
the extinguisher roll (spicy tuna, avocado, jalapeno tobiko) and
the spicy tempura roll were perfect partners.

nice to see annie's have some company for quiet dining after work next to the 1 California stop.

peep the photos, thanks to bill and his leica for remembering to document at the end of the meal!
author: John M.

description:
Love sushi...we were planning on heading to Sushi Ran but a women who we met in Mill Valley that lives in Salslito suggest we go here instead.  

This place is Michelin recommended and what.... sustainable sushi that sold responsibly sourced, environmentally friendly seafood. Yes there is such a thing so we had to check this place out in Pacific Heights.

We started off with oysters...miagi.  Then I ordered Uni.    We almost ordered the sashimi deluxe but instead ordered the Tataki deluxe.  I think its the same thing but the Tataki is Chefs choice of seared fish, 20 pieces, but  a selection of dipping sauce for each fish $32.  My hubby is Mr. sauce guy so he enjoyed all the different varieties he got to dip his sashimi in.  The portions a good size and cut well.  We washed this down with Kin-san-gria $5 which is house sangria made with Riesling, Sake and fresh fruits like strawberries, blueberries and leche.  

I enjoyed this place and will have to come back cause it made me feel guilt free.  Will have to try some of their rolls as they were very popular.  One of the rolls were on fire when it was served to you...pretty cool.  Do not go here with a big group...max would be four to go with.  Really a cute small place but worth the try.
author: Emmy D.

description:
Japanese? Burger next door? or Italian across the street? It's almost 5:30pm on a Friday and my friend and I finally decided on Japanese.

I've never been to any of these restaurant before, but my friend told me that she once had sushi take-out from this Japanese place and they tasted pretty good. So at 5:30pm, the door opened and we were the first customers to walk so there was no wait. Since it was still early, I didn't feel very hungry and we started out with one salad and two specials. But then It took us 2 more orders to finally satisfy ourselves.

1st order: Ocean salad, Iwana (arctic char) & Kurodai (seared black sea bream): Surprisingly good!!...alright, I need more food.

2nd order: Let's try the roll, 1 order of Extinguisher: Yums...now let's just try one new thing:

3rd order: Pacific Sunrise (what do you mean rolls with no rice?): Not bad, I liked it a lot. But my friend thought the texture of the cucumber was weird.

Everything came pretty quickly. Although we ended up ordering a few more dishes, overall it still felt like a pretty light meal. Well, I did make the effort to try to keep it light, but also because everything was nicely plated, tasted very fresh and wasn't excessively flavored/sauced. A very nice way to end a stressful Friday.

The only thing I didn't enjoy a lot about was the crowdedness and the tight space. It probably took 10-15 minute before all the restaurant became completely full and a line started forming outside of the door. And do expect an average/slightly above average level of noise. However, I'll definitely go back to try more things on the menu!
author: Lily X.

description:
Pros:
Decent sushi in the neighborhood. 

Cons:
Highly overrated.  Some of the fish came out clearly not very fresh, which is disappointing for a place that makes you wait outside for a table.  Additional note: no reservations taken. 

Fun:
There is a dish that is on fire that is probably worth trying.
author: Mike G.

description: I just discovered this gem just a few blocks from my usual hotel when I'm in Laurel Heights, and I'll never go elsewhere for sushi in this neighborhood. Excellent happy hour prices, friendly people, and "blood-, sweat- and tear-free" sushi...?  It doesn't get better than that!
author: Jennifer D K.

description:
Tataki is my favorite sushi restaurant. Not only is it 100% sustainable, it's vegetarian-friendly, and its sushi rolls are superb. Apparently lots of people think so because this place is CROWDED with LONG LINES. Walking by on Sat night, there were more people waiting outside than eating inside. Wisely we came back on Sun night at 9. Every seat was taken, but we were seated promptly (dishes come out quickly).

The stand-outs are the specialty rolls (had the ratatouille and 49er). The flavors are synergistically combined and balanced, ingredients very fresh, not too much rice... The regular rolls (futomaki, arctic char/avocado) were excellent as well. 

Tataki is one of the few sushi restaurants that's vegetarian and vegan friendly. I'd even take my veg friends who're not into raw fish here just for the veg specialty rolls. 

One of the things that make Tataki stand out from the numerous sushi places in the city: Tataki takes sustainability as its core design. Considering that sushi restaurants typically serve unsustainably farmed salmon and overfished tuna, Tataki is a much-needed trendsetter (http://www.montereybayaquarium.org/cr/SeafoodWatch/web/sfw_factsheet.aspx?fid=60, http://www.sustainablesushi.net/). In fact Tataki is part of Monterey Bay Seafood Watch Restaurant Program http://www.montereybayaquarium.org/cr/seafoodwatch/web/sfw_restaurant_program.aspx 

Service is friendly and helpful enough however this place is badly in need of 50% more waitstaff (with more experience) and a hostess to manage the crowds. Better still OPEN ANOTHER TATAKI in my neighborhood (9th/Irving). Yes there's Koo and Ebisu already but Tataki is better and more exciting.

Food: 4.5 stars (rolls are 5 stars)
Service: 2.5 (too crowded, not enough waitstaff to be attentive)
Ambiance: 4 (again too crowded to be relaxing, 5 stars during not crowded hours)
+ 1 star for sustainability
author: Yvonne C.

description:
Best sushi I have had in SF.  Wonderful taste bud roller coasters.  If you come past 630, especially on a weekend, expect to wait a long time.  People should really stop complaining about the wait, it is obvious this is a small restaurant with a loyal following.

The 49er roll, with melt in your mouth arctic char, and a pop of lemon was by far the best.  The Extinguisher roll was a lot of fun and very tasty as well.  

Can't wait to go back.
author: Green M.

description:
I wanted to love this place, but there were just enough dings to knock it down a star. This is a good place for a date that can stand waiting outside and being in a small, cozy Japanese sushi place.

Firstly, this place is about sustainable sushi. This is a very good thing and I can eat my raw fish with little to no guilt. The wait can be pretty daunting. We came at 7:45pm on a Wednesday and the wait was still 30 min in the cold. We sat at the bar as we didn't want to wait longer for a table.

My foodie partner cannot eat certain kinds of fish, and we asked questions about the fish in one of the dishes and they were very accommodating in changing the fish in the dish to tuna.

The server was very helpful but after our order it took 10 minutes to get our drinks and first plate. That may not seem like a lot, but we asked and as it turns out the server totally forgot. He apologized and things went smoothly after that. Nevertheless, it was 8:30 before my first bite and I was famished.

The fish was, in a word, phenomenal. Kurodai tataki (5/5), 49er roll (4/5), sashimi taster (5/5). Every bite just melted in my mouth. The presentation was simple, elegant, and effective. Overall, the cost is a bit steep but it's what to expect for high quality sushi. A great place for a date, for sure.
author: Dave K.

description:
I love this place. This is my absolute favorite sushi place. Plus it is awesome knowing its sustainable.

I recommend going on Monday nights -- smaller crowds. Because believe me, it can get super crowded. But the food is amazing. Try the sea change salad. And the fauxnagi.
author: Jina A.

description:
I went to Tataki for the first time last night (Monday evening) for Happy Hour, and I went home very happy :) Its small and there aren't loads of seats, but its worth trying out.

Only reason they didn't get 5 stars: I got there early to get a table for my friend and I, and was informed that they only seat full parties. I'd called ahead and specifically asked about the wait and about coming early, and was told it was fine. So I asked another person and whether it was okay if I ordered and she was really cool about it and let me sit...

The sushi is awesome, both vegetarian and fish. And the hot sake for the HH price is amazing as well (~4 shots for $3.50). The divisadero roll seemed really fresh and was super tasty. 

All in all, a great place to eat! Definitely will be back :)
author: Jen G.

description:
Kind of a sub-par experience.

Big selling point on sustainable seafood, but the long waits, snobby service, and mediocre flavors are turn offs.  Was expecting a lot more from this place.
author: boston U.

description:
We loved this place! During our honeymoon we were searching for a great sushi bar and after reading all the great reviews we decided to try Tataki!!!
Even though it was cold and we had to wait 15 minutes outside for a table it was all worth it!!! We had great appetizer including the croquette, and they the rolls were the best. And we finished the night with their delicious dessert kinako mochi.
author: Fernanda D.

description:
IS IT POSSIBLE TO GIVE THIS PLACE 10 STARS???

Seriously. In my top 2 of sushi places ever.

Seeing as how I'm vegetarian, I am very picky about what constitutes good sushi for me, but I also went with a meat-eater ;) and she gave it a thumbs up as well, so there's something for everyone--the mark of awesome sushi eating!

Firstly: do not go if you are in a hurry on any evening--this place was packed on a Thursday night at 8pm! We waited about an hour to get in, as there is literally only about 8 tables and bar seating to squeeze everyone in. But the menu is amazing and just the smell of it was enough to force us to wait to be seated. The real problem with seating is that the waitresses fill it on a whoever-fits-first priority, so even though there were three of us in my party waiting an hour, a two-person party was seated quicker, because a two-seater opened up first.

The place is lovely once you're inside. Very cozy and romantic, and the sushi chefs were very nice! They talked to us a bit and made sure our meals were good.

I ordered the vegetarian sushi plate, which came with a whole range of weird things I'd never eaten before (I did upload a pic also!), including avocado rolls, weird orange crunchy rolls, inari, a teriyaki mushroom roll, and veggie rolls. There were about 10 different options on the plate, and most of them were really fantastic. I don't care for mushrooms, but my girlfriend ate that one and said they were good.

I also tried the veggie-option appetizer...which I can't recall what it's named, but it was SO GOOD. There were these root-type things that were fried I think and coated in a sweet and semi-spicy sauce. My gf and I are them all LOL

Our friend tried the hot potato roll and after giving me one bite had to order a second one because I was drooling all over her plate. It is VERY spicy with the sauce on the plate, but you don't have to dip it. It was filled with a sweet potato and other awesome things. Our friend also tried the cold tofu entree; I didn't get the chance to ask her if it was good because it disappeared before I could!!

My gf ordered a California roll and the house roll (Tataki Roll) and both were phenomenal, she said. Our friend also got a miso soup, which was fab (NOT veggie though, because of the fish flakes for the broth).

We spent about $75 here for three people, which I don't think is TOO bad. My stomach says the price was well worth it. I will eat here again ANY day!!
author: Snarky R.

description:
This place deserves a wow.

As a last minute choice for a late dinner my expectations were exceeded.  The sushi was amazing, but what was really special was the service. I don't usually care about service, but the host, waitress and sushi chefs last night were all incredibly and genuinely friendly. It wasn't that fake attentiveness at some places, these people just really care.

Other things I loved: cucumber water, funny sign about reserving the right to refuse service to anyone (especially when it involves sake bombs), flaming sushi plate, perfect rolls, intimate setting, quick service

Food: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars
Ambiance: 5 stars

I have not had a five star experience in a while, so this was an awesome find. I love this place. I want to go back again soon.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Fresh, clean and well-presented rolls and tataki. A bit on the pricey side, but I suppose it's to be expected in SF. Their menu is limited to appetizers, rolls, tataki, drinks, and nigiri. Alas, they don't have a chirashi offering.
author: Thomas C.

description: This was our first 2010 sushi experience in San Fran...we randomly drove by this place & decided it looked cool enough from the outside & not eerie empty on a random weekday evening....so we checked it out. This T-I-N-Y place was hoppin,'  I had to pull my elbows in every time the waiter walked by. I assume our inappropriate sex conversation was  probably heard in the kitchen, BUT no one seemed to notice and that was fantastic! The sushi was average per my standards, but my friend absolutely loved everything we split....An extra plus for me was the cucumber in my water (LUV THAT!) and they had anchor steam on the menu (yay!). Well, I would probably visit here again.
author: Barbara D.

description:
Tataki's rolls are super small and super expensive. For that reason, when eating here, you are forced you to go big or go home. 

There's no question that the sushi is above average. Problem is, I do not want to "go big" at a restaurant that is simply above average. The emphasis here is on sustainability, not on taste. Or service. Or value.

If money were no object, I could see this being a more viable option. But if money were no object, Tataki certainly would not be very high on my list.
author: Rob M.

description:
Great place! For someone allergic to both shellfish and gluten, I'm usually a little wary of sushi, and pretty skeptical that there will be no "specialty rolls" that are safe to eat. I'm glad Tataki proved me wrong.

They have organic gluten-free soy sauce, a vegetarian menu, and some pretty sweet shellfish-free specialty rolls. I had the 49er. It was delicious.

The overall restaurant is a little small and pretty loud, but the service was good and the place was clean... and I didn't get sick. So, I'm now a fan of Tataki.
author: Deirdre P.

description:
seriously. Woo Hoo. As Good As It Gets. All words capitalized. really.

I'm a huge fan of Sushi. Gone to my fair shares of establishments. make it at home. the works. None compare to what they are accomplishing at Tataki Sushi. 

They have a FULLY SUSTAINABLE menu! Do you 'tards know what this means??!!??!!

It means the ocean as a whole, populations, habitats, fishing practices, the whole friggin economy(!!!) is not harmed in this fishery practice.

This makes for an entirely enjoyable menu. all of it. I order ANYTHING there, and feel good about it, because I'm NOT eating nearly endangered Bluefin tuna, or shrimp from farms in third worlds with enormous amounts of waste, or the utterly repulsing FARMED salmon.

Am I all hauty-taughty? I don't know - but I know seafood, and I may have been either brainwashed, or educated (really - it's the same thing) from the Monterey Bay Aquarium to only eat sustainable seafood. 

This is, by far, my most favorite Sushi restaurant I have EVER been to. Hands down. seriously. As. Good. As. It. Gets. 

seriously - try it, and cuss me out if you believe differently.
author: sarah m.

description:
For all the hype of Tataki being an advocate for sustainable and uncommon  fish, our visit was disappointing. All their rolls (while tasty) were lathered in sauces, so the fish in them was lost underneath.
It reminded me of sushi joints in Mexico, where the not-so-fresh fish is disguised with tons of other stuff (sweet, spicy, creamy, etc.). Sad, as I know they do work hard on obtaining fresh and sustainable sourced products. Not quite what their fish deserved.
One of the dishes even came with a flaming pile of sugar on the side, and although it was dramatic, did not deliver on the fish expectation front.
The place felt gimmicky.
The food was OK, but I would much rather go to a different place for my sushi, as I like the fish to speak for itself.
author: Rebeca R.

description:
Having just moved into the neighborhood, I was somewhat at a loss on where to take a friend of mine who wanted to stop by for a bit. Luckily I found Tataki on Yelp. We came here for happy hour so I admittedly did not get to sample a wide variety of their offerings, but what I did taste left me wanting more. The arctic char roll and the crunchy spicy tuna rolls were delish. I must say, I wasn't too impressed with their sake sangria thing. Stick to the cheap beer. 

As other reviewers have noted, this place is tiiiiiiiinnnyyyy. We got there fairly early so there were only a couple of diners when we were first seated, but halfway through it filled up quickly. I may as well have been sitting on my neighbor's lap. And I think I may have freaked a fellow diner out when I got up to go to the restroom and brushed against the small of her back a little too long. Sorry! I wasn't trying to get fresh.. I just had to pee. Speaking of the bathroom, it's really cool. The mirror lights brighten  your face like crazy and you look like you're in a music video circa early 2000's. Seriously: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gzjvB68rTIQ That's all I could think of while I was washing my hands.

Anyway, the service was great and the food was tasty, so I definitely see this becoming a regular neighborhood go-to place.
author: Lilia M.

description: A decent sushi place. I personally like larger and fancier rolls.
author: Shivani S.

description:
Poor Service

The waiter forgot the main dish in our order.

After having finished the other food we ordered about 20 minutes before, we press him again (about the 3rd time) for an update on our main dish. He admitted that it was still in the queue to be cooked (this was 1 hour after we arrived). Note that we were the first customers to arrive when the restaurant opened at 5pm and were the first to order (we were even the only customers in the restaurant for a good 5-10 minutes). Why was our order still in the queue 1 hour later?

He couldn't he just admit he forgot to place our order until we reminded him ~40 minutes into our visit?
author: Norman P.

description:
Ummmm..................... This place gave me a very interesting thought. I was there about two weeks ago friday. Me and my friends wanted to have some Japanese food and I remember my friend told me about this place so we all decided to give is a try.

When I first walk into the place it give me the feeling of food may go wrong if we didn't order the right things to eat. But anyhow 1st time got to try want they got for the special of the day rite??? So they have this one roll that put a fire on the plate call extingisher roll is so good i ate almost half of the order. The fish is HELLA fresh and the UNI is hella good.......... yummy yummy yummy............. price is somewhat reasonalbe. Not too expansive but not cheap either. I like the way how they set up the place I was enjoying every moment when i was there.

I usually don't like to eat dessert after dinner but I saw the table next to our want eating some kinda green tea cheese cake so i wanted to try it and guess what? I never had a cheese cake taste so good. Not to sweet and I actually will finish it myself. Your ppl just got to go try it and yelp about it.
author: Peter C.

description: Awesome lunch menu - two rolls, plus soup for $10 - awesome quality and everything is sustainable. They also offer gluten-free soy sauce (if you ask), which is a treat for folks with celiac disease. I've come here consistently for more than two years and the food has always been the same great quality.
author: JD M.

description: I live a few blocks away from Tataki and am glad I've found a good sushi place to frequent.  They believe in sustainable sushi, so they don't serve any eel or other fish that are endangered on the Seafood Watch list.  I'm a huge sushi fan and would say that I don't care, but I think it's admirable and it didn't make my dining experience any less tasty.  I've had the Golden Gate roll (has bits of apple), the Green Dragon roll, Pacific Sunrise roll (I think), the regular sushi sampler, and the really large sushi sampler.  I enjoyed all of it pretty much, I felt the quality was quite decent (especially for the price) and thought their selections were good.  The green tea cheesecake is delicious as well!  There can be a bit of a wait since the place is small.
author: Sophia D.

description:
Bottom line: Concept is admirable, but execution was poor.  I will not be going back, but will look for other sushi restaurants that share the same ideals.

Service:  slow, not enthusiastic... but did all the basics.

Sushi: bland or drowned in sriracha.  For showing so much respect for the fish (i.e. selecting sustainable sources), it was not really a standout for any of the rolls.   rice was overcooked and presentation was sloppy.

Setting: loud music.
author: Jonathan T.

description: I love tataki so much! They have excellent quality fish, and have all environmentally friendly choices. I took one star away because they are so small and don't take reservations, so I've always had to wait at least 30min, esp if you're with more than 2 people. Otherwise all around fantastic!
author: Ashley B.

description:
Interesting experience. Usually I don't write reviews for a place that has hundreds, but due to the type of place and nuances, I was compelled.

1. It's packed! We ate on a Sunday at 5pm when it opened, and by 5:45pm the whole place was full. It's also very small.

2. They don't really have "omakase" - they have a "chef's choice" nigiri/sashimi plate, but nothing crazy fancy like some high end sushi restaurants. The experience is definitely based around the sustainable seafood choices that the restaurant makes.

3. It's pricey! Only two $$ signs? It was me and my cousin (another guy) and we spent almost $120 including tip. We weren't even THAT hungry.  What the heck did I order...

4. The sushi rice is pretty bad.  Not only is it clumpy and doughy, but they give you too much, it almost ruins the nigiri.

5. Ordered uni, and one piece had a bunch of grainy things in it, possibly pieces of the shell itself, and they were good about taking it back and bringing out a new one.  Points.

Good service, OK fish quality, and bad sushi rice. So why 4 stars? Well damnit, because I'm not contributing to the overfishing of numerous fish species around the world.  Is that really worth 4 stars? It's worth more actually, since this is just a review website that exists on the internet - while the fish are real things that are disappearing as we speak.  But I digress...  The point is, as consumers, we vote with our wallets, and when we start saying "yes I'll pay more because it's the right thing to do," is when things change.
author: J D.

description:
I just want to go ahead and say that this place still holds a special place in my heart. They consistently deliver a delicious meal and puts  a smile on my face that I thought only my man could do.

The first time I went to Tataki they had just opened and they were great now they have a 'People like us on Yelp Sticker', which in my book means that u've arrived, and they still got it.
author: Brittany D.

description: Tried extinguisher-good, fried calamari was great, and the arctic char was really good too, definitely go during happy hour the prices are low!
author: Misha Z.

description: Our first time at Tataki. Wow. We loved the food at Tataki. The chef's sampler was amazing. The sea urchin was super fresh and delicious. We also tried the Extinguisher and loved it. Can't wait to go back.
author: Kyoko T.

description:
Followed another Yelper's suggestion that happy hour runs til 7 and they'll serve that right up til then and they were right. I arrived with my husband at 6:30 and we were seated right away (although we were lucky, it is a tiny place- I think 5 tables for 2, 2 tables for 4, and a few seats at the sushi bar). What we ordered at 6:50 was charged at the happy hour price, but when we ordered another of the exact same roll at 7:10 was charged at full price. I actually did like how transparent that rule was. So definitely try to get there at 6:30 if you want a deal, and order all you might possibly want!

Really recommend the sake-fruit-white wine sangria. Maybe this is naive of me but I swear it tasted like Japan! All the flavors you could want in one cocktail (at $4 during happy hour). The rolls were quite good, and as vegetarians we frequently eat the same sushi from a limited selection so the creativity here was fun. You will definitely have an opportunity to try a kind of sushi you haven't had before if you're up for adventure (regardless of veg/not)!

I will be back. Why 4 stars? I found the host/server (only one person) a little too hipster-snotty. But that was just a personal preference. You should go!
author: Ashley L.

description:
So it's not even 5pm and I was already craving sushi.  I wanted to try somewhere new, since I have this unending search for the perfect sushi hotspot in the city.  So because of the decent reviews on Yelp and the fact that there was a "happy hour" that some people raved about... I was eager to try this place.  Thankfully my buddy agreed to join my sushi quest.  
Since I was forewarned by other Yelpers regarding the size of the place... yes it's true, it's not much bigger than my apartment. The compact dining area did not dissuade my hope, in fact the the 4 seats-only sushi bar with the few scattered dining tables was a casual yet intimate ambiance... was perfect.  
I prefer sitting at the sushi bar for 2 reasons... to see how fresh the fish is and to get a rapport with the sushi chef.  Unfortunately I didn't feel that the guys behind the bar were overly friendly, obviously busy, but barely got a smile out of either one.  Thankfully our server was friendly & attentive.  So we had the 3 main rolls on the happy hour menu: Artic char, spicy tuna crunch and california crunch.  Just looking at them didn't seem like anything much, but I have to say they were surprisingly really yummy.  We also tried the Extinguisher, which to me was just ok.  I didn't care for the creamy thing on it.  Well overall I think this review should be at least 3.5 stars.  I look forward to coming back to try their other rolls and sashimi.
author: Myra M.
