description: My fiancée and I experienced Tataki a few nights ago and thought it was good. We personally are bigger fans of Domo in Hayes Valley. We ordered the Happy Hour specials which were Crunchy Spicy Tuna and Crunchy Cali Roll. Then proceeded with the Spicy Shrimp Tempura Roll, Tuna Roll and one more I cant remember. All were fresh and yummy but it didn't blow our minds. Still searching for the ultimate sushi in SF.
author: Bri R.

description: Had a spicy crunchy garlic albacore handroll at Off The Grid @ the Presidio & loved every bite of it! Definitely interested in checking out the restaurant someday.
author: Kristine C.

description: My local, sustainable, awesome sushi.  I almost always sit at the bar and let the chef feed me whatever is fresh.  Don't get me wrong, it's not completely mind blowing sushi, but its always fresh and its always eco-friendly.  Their rolls are amazing, and its always top quality.  I go here all the time and fully recommend it!
author: Ryan H.

description:
I'd been wanting to check out Tataki for a while now. I like sushi, but I have to admit I kinda feel bad dining in sushi restaurants since so few offer sustainable options. Needless to say, I was thrilled by the idea of a sushi restaurant selling solely sustainable fare. But I never seemed to have the courage to dine here, since my desire to try other SF hotspots always won out. Well, I finally took the plunge when a group of us were in the city a couple weeks ago and we decided to grab dinner here.

There's a pretty diverse mix of sushi fare on the menu at Tataki. We wound up ordering a lot of food to share. We started off with some appetizers--an order of edamame, two orders of seaweed salad and two orders of the "sea change" jellyfish salad. (Get it? Our oceans will be full of jellyfish if we don't choose smart seafood choices.) The edamame were hot and not too salty. The seaweed salad was crisp and chewy--in a good way, mind you--and very flavorful. The jellyfish salad was, um, unique. I'd never had jellyfish before, so this was an interesting introduction. Flavorwise, it had a nice kick from the daikon radish. But I couldn't get past the texture, a bit like stringy Jell-O. I was glad I tried it, but I'm not sure I'll be rushing to order more jellyfish.

We ordered a plate of sashimi and four or five rolls for our main course. I didn't partake in the sashimi, but I did try a couple of the rolls. I lost track of what was what, but I know we ordered one that arrived on fire! Pretty entertaining, basically getting dinner and a show! We also ordered an off-menu option, the VIP roll, with the "faux nagi"--seared blackcod instead of fried unagi eel--that was pretty good. I was pleased to see so many veggie options on the menu at Tataki too. I ordered the veggie Philly roll (bean curd, cream cheese and avocado) and found it quite tasty. We also tried the Hot Potato roll, with sweet potato tempura inside and topped with "tofuna". The tofuna was, like the jellyfish, an interesting experience--it had paste-like quality to it, honestly. And I'd be remiss if I didn't give the chefs at Tataki points for presentation. All the food we ordered looked like works of art--from the intricate rolls to the jellyfish salad in a martini glass.

We ended dinner with a sampling of desserts--green tea cheesecake, red bean mochi ice cream, hot mochi and coffee jelly. All were mighty tasty, though I have to say the green tea cheesecake was the weakest (pretty standard in comparison to the rest, plus I'm not the biggest cheesecake fan). The mochi ice cream was great, as was the hot mochi, which tasted like peanut butter and graham cracker. The coffee jelly was nice--like Jell-O for grown-ups.

While the food was pretty good--I'd say a solid four stars--our service was phenomenal. Our server was very friendly and very patient with us as we ordered food for the table. She was helpful, giving us some recommendations of her favorites. But most impressive, she handled our large party with grace, even whilst juggling other tables in the packed restaurant. The second server stopped by a few times and likewise, he was great. I rarely bump a restaurant up an entire star because of service, but Tataki's servers easily earned this restaurant a five-star review. 

I'd come back to Tataki in a heartbeat because they were so welcoming here. The food's great, but its really service where Tataki shines.

But just a quick word of warning--Tataki is tiny, like *seriously* tiny, so it was a bit of a wait for our table of seven. Even though we put our name in as soon as we got there, we wound up waiting 40 minutes--maybe even a whole hour?--for our table. It's not exactly a spot that's conducive to large groups. Not only is it hard to get a table, there's just not much room to move around.
author: Raul N.

description:
What can I say about Tataki that hasn't already been said?  I could easily eat dinner here every night of the week.  It's sushi without any guilt.

I tend to only order the sashimi but everything I've had here I have thoroughly enjoyed.  The fish is always fresh, and absolutely delicious.  I even enjoy the prissy rolls here, and I am a traditionalist.

The wait can be horrific and they do not take reservations.  I tend to get here early leave my name and come back after 20-30 minutes have passed.  That's the only problem with this place, it's no secret that it serves amazing food.  Thus the 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Andy G.

description:
From start to finish everything was great. The restaurant is small with a great vibe, probably only 12 tables or so.

We started out with an order of calamari and garlic edamame. Both delicious, the dipping sauce for the calamari in particular was very good , somewhat spicy which I like.

We had a plate of sashimi which was fantastic, who would have thought raw fish could taste so good.

The rolls hit it out of the park we ordered a spicy tuna as a generic roll and three specialty rolls:

Golden state: spicy scallop, minced apple roll, seared albacore tuna, avocado, yuzu tobiko

Extinguisher: albacore tuna, avocado, habenero massago, spicy aioli (probably my favorite of the three)

double-double: tempura-fried spicy albacore roll, masago, green onions, sesame seeds

Washed it all down with some good sake and finished the meal with some mochi balls.

Hidden Gem: The mochi balls are amazing for desert. Seriously, little balls of heaven!
The red bean is the best followed by the mango.
author: Emilio C.

description:
You can't visit San Francisco without trying their sushi restaurants.  We searched on Yelp for the highest rated sushi restaurants and came across Tataki.  There is a reason why they have such high ratings.  The restaurant is small and intimate perhaps with around ten tables.  We were serviced right away.  We asked the waitress to have the chef prepare us whatever came to mind as we are not that big on ordering sushi (nothing fried and little or no rice) from menus.  The first roll that came out was riceless with four different types of raw fish rolled in cucumber covered in a sauce which tasted like ponzu.  It was delicious.  The second roll had smoked albacore with some sort of yellow roe on top.  Delicious as well.  The third roll I can't quite remember what it was but it was delicious as well.  For dessert, we ordered two different mochi desserts.  I wasn't too crazy over the first one (hot mochi covered in crumbs that resembled graham cracker).  The mochi kept getting stuck to my teeth and it was hard to chew.  We also had mochi ice cream and that was great.
Everything came out pretty fast and our waitress was very attentive.  Best of all is that they are the only fully sustainable sushi restaurant in all of San Francisco, so you know that what you are consuming is the freshest sushi that can be offered.
author: Leslie S.

description:
Sustainable fish - good concept. 
Tataki restaurant as a whole - just ok. 
Tataki (the actualy Japanese appetizer) - usually awesome and delecious. 
Tataki at Tataki restaurant - average. 

Great concept, but concepts don't make my belly happy.
author: Al L.

description:
I can't get back here fast enough.  This is really a four and a half star review.

My dinner companion was more of a conservative sushi eater, so we shared:
 ---the philadelphia roll (soft, buttery salmon to compliment the buttery cream cheese)
 ---the early bird (I was slightly intrigued and mildly disturbed-- steak "sushi"?  Does that count?  I don't know if it classifies as sushi, but it sure is tasty!), 
 ---and the double double (oh, my, god, melty-melt goodness!).  

Oh, I almost forgot to mention, I inhaled an ocean salad while simultaneously salivating over all the plates heading from the kitchen to nearby tables.

I have to admit, like a parrot distracted by shiny things, I fixate on pretty presentations...but these aesthetically pleasing sushi  arrangements are like diamonds, not rhinestones.

In that vein, the bathroom has a magical mirror and equally ethereal lighting.  Don't give into the delusions--I know I don't look that good, not even after a large bottle of unfiltered sake!  But it sure makes me feel good.

In fact, everything about this place makes me feel good.  The pretty bathroom, the chill music, the friendly and unpretentious staff and chefs, the delicious food, and drum-roll, the environmentally friendly mission.  

Now, if only it weren't so small (about four or five tables- and only four seats at the bar) and so very out-of-the-way for me.  Tataki, save me a table, 'cause I'll be back soon.
author: Brianna H.

description:
We came in at 6:55pm on Friday night and were surprised that they still honored the happy hour menu (this wasn't the case at another sushi restaurant on Polk in Russian Hill).  

We cozied up at the sushi bar and ordered the California and spicy tuna rolls to start ($4.50 from the happy hour menu) and they were mouth-dropping amazing.  Now I know what you're thinking.. really? California rolls... amazing?  YES!  We asked the chef -- and they use a special Japanese mayonaise which is creamy and delicious.

The sushi chef recommended the red snapper which was heavenly - light and buttery and the perfect fish for nigiri style. The seaweed salad stood out because it had 5 different kinds of seaweed plus cucumber. Typical seaweed salads have 1 or maybe 2 kinds. Again, great flavors. The waitress added some complimentary gobo (my request) which was a fun touch to the salad.

We left feeling very satisfied and spent only $50, which I consider a great value for sushi.  I'm not sure about the other Yelp reviews that say this place is not a good value.  I thought it was a fantastic value and this is our new favorite neighborhood sushi restaurant. Perfect for a date night or a small group (max 4 people). Apparently their Tataki South location is better for larger groups.

See you soon Tataki!
author: Ian F.

description:
A very big 5-star review to Tataki! An especially high rating for their happy hour specials. They had several house rolls to choose from, plus cheap beers to sip during that time frame.  I love how tiny the place is. A minimalistic approach to the sushi restaurant setting. It really adds to the sushi devouring experience.  Did I mention that they only serve sustainable seafood here--very cool. You don't come across too many establishments touting that effort for the environment. 

My great company and I had a fabulous time trying their veggie, crunchy California and smoked salmon rolls. All of them were good and the price is right. The wait can be rather long on the weekends, just something to keep in mind.
author: Nichole P.

description:
Classy, always-crowded sustainable sushi joint.

Positives:
-Really, really tasty food. The rolls are all really good and some have fun but not-too-flashy flourishes. Ok, the Extinguisher roll is flashy.
-Cozy, nice look to the place.
-Sustainable.

Negatives:
-Unless you go early on an "off" night, you will have to wait, sometimes for a long time. This place is very popular, and has a lot of small tables crammed into a small room, so it feels somewhat cramped. I always feel like I have to lower my voice, because other diners are basically right on your arm.
-Usually only 2 waitstaff on the floor, even when the place is jammed to the brink. So even when seated you wait a long time to get any food or drinks, and the servers seem a bit stressed out and like they have too much going on to attend to anyone in particular.

The food itself is the main draw here. With how popular and successful it seems to be, I really wish they would open up a few more locations, maybe even a larger one. Then the sustainable sushi thing can spread further, which is the only way it will have any impact!
author: Remi X.

description:
So I've been to Tataki before. And I schlepped over again tonight in the chilly, windy weather because I liked this place so much before. I was anticipating the great sushi but what I wasn't anticipating was the absolutely rude staff, finger wagging waiter and vulture-like guests all huddled around the absurdly small front door galley waiting for 2 and 4 tops like they never had eaten before. Done.  Done. And done with this place. 

I waited for about 30 minutes for a table (over wine at Bistro SF Grill next door - btw, fantastic gourmet burgers, genuine and congenial service and delicious Turkish coffee) because apparently Tataki refuses to take the necessary steps towards making this a more pleasant dining and working experience by either 1) taking reservations along side their walk-ins, 2) allowing people to leave a phone number to call rather than yelling names when you know people aren't there/standing outside, or 3) investing in some vibrating remotes. So instead, patient patrons either hover in a 2x2 front door space, outside in the freezing wind, or are forced to check back to see where their names are on the list. So I went for the most rational option and went next door to have a glass of wine while I waited and decided I would check in every 5-10 minutes. I was right next door after all. 

I checked back 3x in the span of ~30 minutes to see where our names were on the list. At the third check in I was told to wrap up our tab at the cozy place next door as our names were next. No more than 3-4 minutes later we wrapped up our tab next door and popped back over to Tataki. After being ignored for a few minutes, I told the waiter running the list that we were back. Oh, wait. Just kidding. In the 3-4 minutes it took us to pay our tab literally 2 steps away, they called our name and because we didn't answer (duh, because I told you we were next door closing our tab as instructed) the waiter gave away our table. Already an awkward and rude move but  fine. However, when I asked why and got the finger wag in my face and then "you're lucky I didn't just cross your name off the list all together" comment, I figured it was game on. Don't even tell me I'm lucky you didn't do something. YOU'RE lucky half patient people put up with that nonsense on a regular basis to keep YOU employed. Please check the California unemployment report and number of good sushi places in this city before you make comments like that to people potentially paying your rent. I crossed my name off the list myself thank you very much and then went back to the friendly, cozy burger place next door and had a fantastic rest of the evening. 

I'd like to note that in addition to the great food and atmosphere at Bistro SF Grill, the owner brought us two pieces of their the new homemade polenta on the house. Clearly Tataki should take a few lessons from their new neighbors. 

Absolutely no plans to go back to Tataki again.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Totally amazing food. We had the California roll, Green Dragon roll, miso soup, and baked muscles, and they were all excellent.
author: Captain B.

description:
I have never liked the food at a Japanese place this much! I am vegetarian and always have had to settle at Japanese places for really basic rolls, soups, or fried stuff. This place some amazing veggie options and even fake tuna! SO GOOD! And even my meat eating friends agree. The food is stellar! The greentea cheesecake with strawberry sauce is INSANITY!
The con is this place is super tiny and when full, cramped! Needs to be at least twice as large. People pour outa the door and it's usually freezing outside and it really sucks.
author: Unicorn U.

description:
NEVER thought I would get to eat sushi like this again.  And I was a nigiri type of person, so i really really (I mean REALLY) miss sushi, my favorite food :(  But I have moved on to be vegan, and the vegan offering were just SO good.  Just the plain vegan california roll was so good we had to get another one.  I also got an order of nigiri for my bf, it was his reward for being a good vegetarian.  The pieces were seriously huge and he said it was amazing, I can't remember what fish it was but the waitress said it was closest to salmon.

I used to be told I am quite excellent at finding good sushi.  I don't know, maybe its Tataki's good karma that makes everything so good.  But vegan, vegetarian, meatatarian, whatever, I highly recommend this place.  And its a business you can feel good about supporting.  I just love that they won't serve endangered fishies.
author: T R S.

description:
Slowest service, ever.

I mean, it was sustainable, which is great. Nothing more important than that. But honestly, it was painfully slow. And the waiter was confused with the orders, even in a small place like this.

I'd consider going back, but only to save the planet.
author: Forza M.

description: This is the goto spot in the neighborhood for sushi. Every night till 7 is happy hour and their rolls are awesome. You can be ultra satisfied with a massive amount of sushi at a reasonable price. Not only is this a goto spot out of convenience but because the quality of the fish, and toro is tremendous. Yet to come across a better all around sushi spot in SF.
author: Adam H.

description: Really enjoyed Tataki. A sushi place with the sustainable seafood guide on the tables? Cool! We had to send the miso soup back to have it heated up, and the service was friendly but left room for improvement. Still I will definitely be back for well prepared and thoughtfully sourced seafood. Also the music was good.
author: Joby P.

description: Tataki is pretty good. I like that they are a sustainable sushi bar (a sushi restaurant that only sells responsibly sourced, environmentally friendly seafood).  Tataki has a wide selection of rolls for those who enjoy creative sushi rolls vs. pure no frills raw fish.
author: MyGirl L.

description:
I've been here once or twice and it's by far the best place I've been to for sushi, even though I live in the Noe Valley and my guardians have paid for the meal, and they enjoy it, too! The sushi is great, and so are the crab cakes, my favorite.

The first time I came in was because I wanted to have some sushi, haven't had it in awhile and it was close to the chinese restaurant my guardians and I have been eating in ever since I came to San Francisco, which was a year and a month ago... from when I wrote this review. So it was one of the greatest discoveries of my sushi life!

I gave it four stars because the space was small an limited, I feel cramped in the place, sometimes. The music fits the place and they could probably change the songs a bit to a more soothing lounge/house-like music. It's in a great neighborhood, and it's a place where I would take my girlfriend (if I had one) out to for dinner, but I recommend getting there fast due to the small space and the line you'll have to suffer if you don't get there early enough.

The sushi and the appetizers are just incredible, and this is a place I would go to again, and like I said earlier, I would take somebody I WILL be dating to this place on a Friday night if I could.
author: Bryan S.

description:
I have to preface, I was starving. I got there a long while before my date as we stumbled about looking for a place to meet in San Francisco on a weekday. I have to say, it was pretty good. 

We had seaweed salad which was small and tasty. I was surprised by the portions as the prices were extremely high. I don't know about you, but I'm telling you right now this girl can eat.  I felt bad, my date paid for it.

My favorite was the scallop served on top of thin slice of lemon with bits of sembei on top. The combination of those flavors were delightful. 

My date was quite fond of the double double, "a tempura-fried spicy albacore roll." I'm in love with this roll. 

I wish there were more variety of fish but this restaurant specializes in finding sustainable fish and there were pamphlets from the Monterey Bay Aquarium showing which ones are the best and worst.  I also curse them for telling me my beloved saba, yellowtail, and maguro were on the bad list.  Now I can't be blissfully unaware.  Boo!
author: Ashley I.

description:
The idea of Tataki gets 5 stars.
The reality of Tataki gets 2 stars.

I've been here a couple times, and the overall experience does not meet the hype.  Here are some highlights:

- Sashimi quality: The albacore tuna was so mushy it was disintegrating under pressure from my chopsticks- characteristic of fish that has been rethawed.  Every piece of yellowfin tuna was stringy.

- Creativity: The first time I came here I ordered the sashimi regular, which consists of a "chef's choice".  In this case, the selection consisted of the exact same four fish featured on the cheaper sashimi taster plate, just more of it.  If that's what I wanted, I would've asked for 2 orders of the sashimi taster!

- Rolls:  They tasted good, but the ones with cooked ingredients were at room temperature by the time they got to our table.  Also (and I'm not docking stars for this, but it's worth mentioning), they didn't meet the expectations set by their descriptions.  Two examples:
1) The Extinguisher roll was good, but for all the hot ingredients and the flaming salt (!) on the plate, it would barely qualify for "medium" spiciness.  It even came with dollups of extra "hot" sauce on the side, which would have been more appropriate if it actually made the roll spicier.
2) None of us could distinguish the apple flavor in the Golden State roll, let alone the scallop.  Raw scallop is so mild and easily masked by other ingredients that I was surprised to see it in a roll in the first place.
author: Rego S.

description: Good for them for yielding to this sustainable fishing campaign. I was a SF first-timer, and thought to try some Japanese because I'd hoped for some real fresh seafood. Though it tastes really good, it's not spectaculating. Don't hate me, and maybe I'm too early to judge, but I think you can find this quality everywhere in NY. I'll have to admit I was lured into here by those pics of the fire show you get with "the extinguisher." Now I have my own, yippee!
author: Eva G.

description: Was delicious! The spicy foods were not all that spicy so we really loved it. I would recommend the crab croquette, this little cake with vegetables inside.
author: Dian d.

description:
The fish is very fresh and sustainable!  Cool atmosphere!  Shiro maguro sashimi and hotate nigiri were like "butter" in your mouth!  Delicious!  Loved the garlic edamame!  

I forget the name of the roll, but it had filet mignon, pineapple, asparagus and avocado with a mustard sauce and sriracha.....totally rich and yummy!

Great first experience! Try it out!
author: Kristi N.

description:
Everything I ate (and Poppy eats a LOT!) was fabulous.  

The wait wasn't forever.  The hobo named Wolf who wanted to fight or hug was a little creepy but whatever..

baked mussels good.  Sashimi excellent.  Several rolls delicious.  Croquette divine (really fried stuff is always yummy) cant remember what else we ate, even green tea cheesecake was good and I'm not a green tea fan.

good job!
author: Poppy C.

description:
I appreciate that they serve sustainable fishes but that means that everything else is a little pricer than other sushi places.

I came here with three of my cousins and a friend. We waited about 45 minutes for a table at 6:20 on a Monday night. The place is really small, thats why it took us so long to get seated. The long wait made us miss happy hour.
Once we were seated, all of us already knew what we were going to order. It sounded like we ordered a lot of food but once the plates came out, we concluded we needed to order more. I was disappointed when I saw their portions. Each of us probably had three orders to get full.

We ordered: bake mussels, crab croquette, deep fried calamari, fresh oysters, sashimi taster, katsuo tataki, char carpaccio, tataki roll, extinguisher, spicy tempura, and the golden state. We ordered the tataki, extinguisher, and golden state rolls twice. Only cause those were the best rolls.

I probably won't be coming back here again. It's kind of out of the way and overpriced for me.
author: Ashley T.

description: I was actually underwhelmed.  First impressions were how "cute" it was (small), but then a person "thing", if you would, is how dirty the windows were inside & out.  Always think that if you can't keep the building clean, how's the kitchen?  Presentation WAS beautiful - no complaints there, but the fish was rather tasteless and did not appear fresh.  We had calamari (a bit oily), two rolls (meh), edamame (can't ruin that!).  Wouldn't go again, even IF the fish are sustainable!
author: Marie O.

description: GREAT HAPPY HOUR SUSHI DEALS.  Excellent food, extremely high quality of service, well-concocted ambiance (music, lighting, setup).  I just got done eating a few hours ago and already want to go back!
author: Phil S.

description:
4 of us were very lucky to get seated right away at 6:50 PM on Sunday night.  30 minutes later, the restaurant was packed and there was a line.

The food was excellent - great selection of rolls, sashimi, and (important) sake!  I thought that the fish was very fresh and tender and the amount of disguising sauces (referenced in one of the previous reviews) was perfect, so we can taste the fish, not the sauce.

The service was excellent - waiter was very patient taking our orders and recommending variations of their specials.  The food, drinks, as well as the refills came quickly and waiter was attentive enough, juggling multiple tables simultaneously.

The place is cozy, small, and clean - which is important - I wouldn't trust a restaurant with a dirty bathroom, because if the owner (management) cannot sanitize the bathroom, how can I trust them with my food?

The cost...well, be ready to spend close to $50 per person if you order enough sushi/sashimi, as well as sake and beer and not regret it.
author: P F.

description:
Been to Tataki twice... While I liked it I don't consider it to be the best in SF.. What I do like however is the fact that they serve sustainable dishes. Makes me feel better about devouring my sushi... 

Solid 4, minus one for how expensive it is..
author: Monica S.

description: We ordered two rolls, both were very spicy and really good! The rolls are small so make sure you order more than one each (or maybe an appetizer). We ordered miso soup with ours.. I probably could have eaten more. The restaurant is sooo tiny! There is no room to wait inside. Luckily, we got there pretty early on a week night and only had to wait about 15 minutes.
author: Maegan B.

description: I can't say enough about Tataki -- it's quietly claimed a spot as my favorite restaurant in the city.  No bells or whistles.  Just really good food in a really nice but casual setting.  And this all from someone who wasn't eating a whole hell of a lot of sushi a year ago...
author: Laurence W.

description: My boyfriend and I both got SICK right after eating sushi here tonight...and the rolls are pretty small, especially for the price.
author: Yana B.

description: I was excited to try Takaki given the "sustainable sushi" concept.  We started with the garlic edamame, which was a bit heavy and saucy, and the miso soup.  Given the positive reviews, we opted for the extinguisher roll and the artic char.  The artic char had a good flavor, but I felt it was somewhat bland.  I enjoyed the SPICY extinguisher roll, but the mayo-based sauce on top did bring out a somewhat fishy taste.  I wanted to be blown away by Takaki, but it was just okay.  Being guilt-free doesn't necessarily mean tasty.
author: Kim K.

description:
I used to live 2 blocks from this restaurant on California and Scott. So when I was in the neighborhood again, I was looking forward to eating here, because I had heard/read some decent reviews, and in the past there really wasn't that many good sushi places within 8 blocks of here. 

So we came just in time on a weekend night, early enough to beat the crowds. The place is quite small, and it can be a very long wait to get a table, as they do not take reservations. Come on a Friday or Saturday night at 7 pm and you may starve before you eat. Maybe that is why all the reviews are so good, because people were famished?

Yes, they try to offer sustainable seafood. That is admirable in environmentally PC conscious SF. From their website:

"Our Mission at Tataki is simple: to showcase the beauty and delicacy of Japanese cuisine while respecting the sanctity and fragility of our environment. If we are to preserve the art of sushi, we must also safeguard the health and biodiversity of our oceans. With this in mind, we strive everyday to integrate the concept of sustainable dining into our menu options."

This is marvelous and admirable. In fact, they were excited to offer a new seafood that night because it was new to them (did it just get released to the sustainability list?)

But as far as the total restaurant dining experience, I was underwhelmed. I really can't put my finger on it. Maybe I have been in really good sushi-ya in Japan and had too high expectations. Maybe the lack of Japanese service staff didn't make it feel authentic, although our waitress was very good. Maybe it was the slower than expected service. Or cramped tables. I don't know what I would have thougth if I had waited an hour like several people did, watching us through the window, waiting. 

 The Chefs and co-owners are Chinese from Hong Kong, Raymond Ho and Kin Lui, with Casson Trenor, their "sustainability guru". 

We orderd Edamame, which was a lot, and we finished it all well before the next dishes came. We also ordered sake, which they have a decent selection. The sushi was also pretty good, but not exceptional in my book. In fact my dining mate, an Italian American who hasn't had half the sushi experiences I have had, didn't think it was that wonderful either. 

For me, a 5 star Sushi-ya,and I have rated many at that level on Yelp, so it is not that I am stingy or a complete snob,  needs to have a certain "kimochi"....or .feeling about it, a certain je ne c'est quoi, where everything fits together as authentically Japanese, with really good sushi. It doesn't have to have fancy decor, fancy sake, expensive and unique creations, just a certain feeling. Maybe it is a feeling locked in my earlier memories, when my grandparents in Japan owned a sushi restaurant, or my mother's memories as she grew up surrounded by sushi.. 

Tataki is good, you can try it if you can wait your turn to eat. 

But for me, it just doesn't quite excel for me personally. You decide for yourself.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Eeeek! I don't know why I gave such a poor review 3 years ago.  Being pregnant and unable to eat most sushi and raw fish, Tataki was a savior in that they have a great vegetarian menu. My fave is their ratatouille roll. I could eat just that alone. Even after having a baby and being able to eat raw fish, I think I like the ratatouille roll more than most of the other rolls at Tataki.  Another great thing is that they use sustainable fish, so you don't feel so bad about eating fish. Wish more sushi places were like this.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Good happy hour special but didn't really take advantage of it. Yummy Sangria! 

The rolls were great. Sashimi was great and quite fresh and size of each piece was very generous. `

For Rainbow Roll, some other $10+ roll, Phili Roll, Sashimi Sampler (6 pieces), calamari, two oysters, one large beer, and two glasses of sangria, our bill was only $66. Pretty sweet deal.
author: Helen V.

description:
Very, very good.

Shrimp ceviche, ahi tuna poke, crab croquette (best in the city), albacore toro, mixed veggie salad, golden state roll, and the double double roll were all fantastic.  Avoid the fire extinguisher.  The flavor was too hot to enjoy, and I love spicy.

3 adults with alcohol for about $120 + tip.
author: Ryan W.

description:
My boyfriend and I recently visited Tataki- since it was super close to where we live.  The wait to sit down was not long around 7ish on a Wed. night- but it was extremely warm.  The environment was cramped- we both said we felt like we were back in NYC.  The girl that sat behind me flicked her hair on to my head a few times on accident-thats how cramped the place was.  Also, they played hip music that did not go with the ambiance.

We ordered 
2 misos
1 beer
sashimi sampler (6 pieces for $11)
sashimi special (2 pieces for $8)
phili roll
and some spicy roll

The miso was really odd.  Both of us thought it was made from pork- because that is EXACTLY what it tasted like.  My boyfriend could not finish his and I could hardly finish mine.  We asked the waiter and he said it was made from fish stock.  It was honestly the only miso i have ever had that I disliked.

The rest of the meal was good- but we racked up a LARGE bill.  

All of the fish is caught sustainably which is cool.

We will not be returning because of the environment, the gross miso and the high prices.  We def felt like we weren't cool enough to be there.
author: Sherri B.

description:
So far, this is my go-to place for sushi in the city.  The sushi is unbelievingly fresh.  The sashmi is very good and there is no fishy smell or taste.  The rolls are also really good and they have a few creative ones on the menu.  

The atmosphere is also very nice.  The place is small so it may not be the place to go if you have a big party.  Service was great and everyone was extremely friendly.
author: S R.

description:
I think I need to stop having sushi with Veena and Rego (see Deep Sushi review, Sushi Bistro review, and this review. See them!). A pattern appears to be forming. 

As for Tataki, it is small, has a nice initial vibe, then you realize it has music blaring loud enough that people have to bark over it (not very relaxing) and there is an odd smell of burnt arm hair that lingers in the air from chefs/servers who have singed their arm-pubes on the flaming extinguisher roll.

The food? Well, nothing was gastronomically memorable. The menu is very one-note and limmited with their offerings. There were two special nigiri of the day; an uncured mackerel and a "fresh" crab (I think king or snow crab). We had a couple orders of each, but sadly they were really uninspiring. The mackerel was OK but nothing like the rich flavor and delicate texture of a great Aji (which is cured but still is mackerel). The crab was very much frozen at some-point in it's life...so it was "fresh"ly thawed? 

Not the worst sushi experience, not good either. 

Sub-note: 
A pet peeve of mine was hit at this place. I asked for hot tea, and it comes served in a shot-glass sized cup. Which in itself is not a problem. The promblem materilizes later whenl refills of tea never appear. Is an oz of tea supposed to suffice for my entire meal? Do I need to be the annoying customer who has to flag down the server after every sip, begging for a refill?  This is a majorly annoying failure of concept and/or service. Hot tea is something I like to sip during the entirety of my meal. It cleanses the palate, it calms the burn of a spicy offering, it is a huge part of my love for the sushi experience. A shot glass of tea is like some gigantic tease. Tataki, I reject your herbal 30 second lap-dance!! 

OK, me and my dog Peeve are going now....
author: Aaron M.

description: Excellent sushi, with great vegetarian options and sustainable fish choices. It's small and gets packed quickly, but it's worth the crowded space. The lunch menu is smaller, but is also one of the better choices in the neighborhood. When I am in the neighborhood, this is always on the top of my mental list of where to eat.
author: Jacob M.

description:
This may be the best restaurant in Pac Heights (granted I still have not tried SPQR yet).  It's understated, nicely decorated, smells new!, super clean and serves up some wonderful sushi.  The sustainable part isn't bad either ;)  When we got there, there were no tables left (it's a small place) so we sat at the bar and watched the two sushi chefs.  The servers were very nice and attentive.  Sushi was excellent.  The extinguisher roll everyone talks about IS really good.  The jalepenos were super fresh and that totally made the roll.  Of course the real "firey" part of the presentation is cool too - you'll have to order it to find out.

This place is solid and I give it 4 stars, instead of 5, for just a few reasons - it's very small inside, and the menu was smaller than I'd like too.  They only have sushi (sashimi, nigiri, rolls, et al), a few salads and miso soup.  No noodle dishes, tempura or say chicken teriyaki.  Keep this in mind if you try to take you non-sushi loving friends here, you know the ones you have to convince that Japanese restaurants will have something they can eat!  Dang, that sucks when you have to do that.
author: Tracey E.

description: Lunch menu was limited but good food and great service! Will come back for dinner next time ;)
author: Lyn X.

description:
Had been here once prior, and while the hype was significant, the food was... pretty good.  

But we ordered in the other night, picked it up from Tataki and brought it home 2 blocks away... and while some of the rolls were, nice... several others weren't good at all -- very bad in fact.  Might as well have been rolls from a grocery market.  

Their version of tuna, was AWFUL to the taste.  We each (there were four of us -- we got $100 worth of food) tried it, each urging the other to "see' if it was indeed bad... and, yep.  It was indeed BAD.

I hate to say it because we'd had such a nice meal there (in the restaurant) before... but when you spend one hundred bucks, and 25 or 33 or 40% of your rolls are downright BAD -- the whole meal is bad. 

And we won't be trying again, anytime soon.  

I give two stars, not one, because of our previous nice meal.
author: Phil H.

description: I like to think I've seen some stuff in my 24 years of life, but NEVER have I seen avocado draped spicy albacore brought to me whilst fire also populates the plate itself.  Damn.  That's some serious culinary confidence.
author: Michael D.

description: Goldenstate and crab cakes----YUM! Wish I would have ordered more!
author: Claudia Z.

description:
I was in San Francisco for the week on business and my hotel was in the Laurel Heights neighborhood. I was using my Mobile Yelp to help me find a good place for dinner in walking distance and Tataki came up. Sushi always sounds good and we really lack good sushi in Portland. 
We had just missed their Happy Hour that goes until 7pm, but we were seated immediately. The space is small so all the tables are really close together, but comfortable. 
We decided to order the Sashimi Regular (Chef's Choice 12pc) and 2 Rolls: Extinguisher and Golden State. The Sashimi was SO good, Chef's choice included 3pcs each of: suspension-farmed Scallop from Japan, closed-farmed Striped Bass from Colorado, pole-caught Albacore and closed-farmed Arctic Char from Iceland. 
As I've already mentioned, we don't get sushi of this quality in Portland (Bamboo Sushi is the only exception, but it's super expensive). 
The Golden State roll and the Extinguisher roll complimented each other very well. The Golden state was light and refreshing and the Extinguisher had a heavier texture with lots of spice and the Presentation was pretty Awesome with Fire and all! 
Service was great throughout the meal.

I LoVED this place. For the quality you are getting in San Francisco, the price point is very Reasonable. Would love to check them out for HH, but I would definitely love to come back and see if they do Omakase.
author: Windy S.

description:
I don't even know where to start or what to say.. all I know is that this place is hella BOMB! Definitely worth 45+ mins of us driving around in circles looking for parking. TRUST. Be prepared to park somewhere far because chances of you finding a parking close to the restaurant are very slim. 

My boyfriend and I got there at around 8pm on a Thursday night and we had to wait for about 45 minutes for a table. But don't worry, because after eating there, you'd forget that you had to wait for such a long time. Yes, the food is just THAT good. 

A very tiny place, but I love the setting. Dim lights, very romantic. The food is great. I don't eat sashimi. I know, I know.. I'm not a true sushi lover yada yada yada. Whatever, I don't care. All I know is that all of their cooked rolls that I ate that night were BOMB! There were only 2 sushi chefs and 2 waitresses, so we had to wait a little bit to get our food. But it's no biggie. My boyfriend had sashimi and he said that their fish is very fresh, and that's pretty rare. This place left a long lasting impression for me. Too bad it's in San Francisco.. if I could, I'd drive the long 8 hour drive just to come here again. Yes, it's just THAT good.
author: Thao A.

description: Have zero clue why anyone thinks this place is great....if your in college...great if you have any taste palate for food and wine....run. I know sushi well..this place is about sauce so much rice that dont get to experience the true taste of the fish and salt...eewww..no person need extra sodium! Stay away!!!
author: Amavi D.

description: Giving this 1 star based off the horrible service. Waiters were very snooty and we had to remind them multiple times (4-5) that we needed refills and they forgot half of our order... twice. Not worth going back if this is the norm.
author: Jena C.

description:
Sustainability does not give anyone an excuse to compromise on the freshness and quality of fish used for sushi. 

Warning signs to when "let's try a new sushi place" fails:

-when your sushi comes topped with tobiko in four different colors
-when you see more serveware than food (ie. my tataki came served in a pretty, straw basket with a handle causing a game of "where's my fish")
-when staple ingredients like the tuna and albacore are not fresh
-when the wasabi has a muddied green color
-when you are the only asian person eating in a japanese restaurant
-when you leave feeling broke 'cause you've already spent too much & hungry 'cause you don't want to pay anymore for subpar quality fish

$30 after, leaving the restaurant unsatisfied, I am now gaining more satisfaction fulfilling my still-hungry stomach with a bowl of homemade ramen.
author: Mary H.

description:
Need a new happy hour spot? Tataki is my new discovery! From 5:30-7 they have a short list of rolls for only $4.50 and of course a selection of sake. 

As it was my first time, we decided to order one of each plus the calamari and minus the veggie roll due to certain anti-vegetables person. The rolls were served pretty quickly. The ingredients tasted fresh and were filling. My favorite of the bunch was the Artic Char with avocado. 

Anyways, who wouldn't love a restaurant that is making sure to respect all the fishies in the sea with a sustainable food menu without sacrificing great food.

Tip: The place is pretty small so I wouldn't recommend having a large party gathering of over 4 people. It gets crowded so arriving at 5:30 will ensure you a seat and no wait.
author: Nicole L.

description:
SUSTAINABLE SUSHI RESTAURANT! 

each table provides a mini pocket sized list featuring which best seafood is best for us and the oceans. i originally found this list in monterey bay aquarium.

i wish more sushi restaurants provided this.
author: Rosalee C.

description: This is really 4.5 stars. Amazingly fresh sushi, cute and cozy atmosphere, quick service - all in all a great Thursday night out. Other than little brochures about guilt free healthy fish, you wouldn't necessarily know about the whole sustainable thing. Definitely a small place, maybe 10 tables total, but we were seated right away. If you don't want your neighbors hearing your convo don't go here. My only gripe is lack of beer selection. Sapporo was the only one offered in the large bottle and I'm not a huge fan. Hot sake was great, seaweed salad was crunchy and refreshing, and I definitely recommend the rainbow and mix-it-up rolls. Only wish this place was in my neighborhood because I'd definitely be back.
author: Natalie H.

description:
My out-of-town friend wanted some tasty local yums after our girly spa treatments. I was hard-pressed to come up with something more SF than sustainable sushi in Pacific Heights, so off we went.

The place has gotten all kinds of media attention for its fish-friendly mission, which I suspect is the cause for the crowds waiting to get in. All told, it's definitely good, though maybe not mind-blowing. Kabuto in the Richmond (try it now! get there early! etc.) still has my heart on that point.

A be-punked staff of servers in a funky, but modern little spot made it a nice choice for a dinner out. It being August and freezing, we started out with some miso soup and edemame. Standard fare, not bad.

The goods (all good), to split three ways: salmon nigiri, rainbow roll, spicy tuna roll, early bird, and a double-double. I'm kind of wary of cooked rolls, but the latter two were fantastic. Early bird came with asparagus and avocado, wrapped with filet mignon and pineapple slices. Double-double, though not an In-n-Out cheeseburger, was almost as good: tempura and spicy tuna with some secret ingredients.

Didn't have the tataki. I'm actually not a huge fan.

Dessert? Green Tea Cheesecake? Um, yes?

All in all, the meal (no sake this time) set us all back about $35. A decent price for a good bit of good sushi, so I'll probably be back, though probably not now, now now.
author: Tara R.

description:
Tataki is my favorite sushi joint in all of SF.  The attention they give to serving sustainable fish adds a "feel-good" element to the dining experience.  Not to mention, serving sustainable sushi means that the fish is fresh and delectable.  I appreciate the laid back atmosphere, too.  Although this is a fancier (read: slightly more expensive) sushi restaurant than some others in the area there is no pretension whatsoever.  

Tip: Hit this place up on a Sunday right at 5pm when they open or during a weeknight.  Weekend nights can be brutal and almost impossible to get a table without a long wait, and they don't take reservations.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
After an exhaustive, but delicious search for the best sushi in SF over the past year, I think I finally found the spot.

The focus on sustainability and organic fish is a nice commitment to social responsibility, but that's not enough to make me a believer- the sushi itself has to be very good.  At Tataki, it's excellent.  High quality and fresh, both the traditional Nigiri and speciality rolls are all outstanding.  You can't match the freshness of the arctic char nigiri (a more buttery tasting cousin of salmon) or the uniqueness and creativity of some of the specialty rolls (try the extinguisher or mix-it-up rolls).  And I can always appreciate it when it says "spicy" on the menu and it's actually SPICY!
author: Mike B.

description:
My boyfriend and I found this sushi bar on yelp, so we decided to try it out.  
Tataki is a small Japanese restaurant that plays pop / hip hop music. I thought i was at a lounge for awhile.  =) 
We ordered sangria for our drinks,  for appetizer we ordered shrimp ceviche. Main course we had regular sashimi, extinguisher roll, uni nigiri, hotate nigiri and ebi nigiri. 
The sashimis were very fresh and the very nice presentations for each plates.  Ceviche was my least flavor dish thru out the meal. They had this futomati chip underneath the topping. The chips got soften up really fast because of the topping so i felt like was eating a chew cookie. 
Overall, it is a nice dinning place for date night.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I've been doing lots of research on sustainable seafood for a project I'm working on, and vowed not to eat any seafood if I wasn't sure it was sustainably raised or caught.   I was going through serious  withdrawal until  Bingo! I found Tataki, recommended by a few friends in the neighborhood.  

I wasn't disappointed, all the selections were delicious, and honestly, the Artic Char will make Salmon all over jump for joy, cuz' it takes better in my opinion! 

You may pay a bit more for your sushi, and have to wait in line, but in my opinion well worth it.
author: G W.

description:
Everyone has their own measurement guides, and for me, sushi places are based on freshness of the fish/ingredients and "worth-it" price to quality ratio; frills aren't necessary.  So one unplanned weeknight, a friend and I found ourselves at the door of Tataki.  Finally!

But... Well, in my humble opinion, this is more of a concept sushi place than a real sushi place.  I have nothing against sustainable fish/food or green, save the environment efforts.  However, it just seems out of place for sushi.  What can I say?  I like to be able to taste and enjoy the freshness of the catches.
The food is good and well-presented (flaming torches and all!).  But it's on the pricer end and portions are small.
author: Carol K.

description:
This is what sushi should taste like.  Tataki has skillfully removed the guesswork in eating sustainable sushi and at the same time found a way to make it just as, if not more, delicious.  Cool ambiance, great music, warm vibes.  

Standout items include (but not limited to):
Arctic char - if you like salmon, you'll love this.
Amaebi - I'm not sure if I like the body of this spot prawn or the fried head more.
Sardines - Surely this is a completely different species than I've had my whole life out of cans.
Uni - The best I've ever had
Aji - never even seen it on other menus.  Great stuff.
Albacore toro - wow.
Vegetarian CA rolls - Didn't even know that was possible.  Good.
Baked mussels appetizer - Perfect start to the perfect meal.

In no way have I exaggerated the above claims.  It's just that good.
author: MLK R.

description: Delicious fresh sushi! Great ambiance. One of my favorite sushi spots
author: Karen B.

description:
Came here on a weekday after work to meet my friend Kat for drinks and dinner.  We were both having a rough week, so we decided to make our restaurant selection based on drink specials.  We're both big fans of sangria (read: will drink 3 carafes, easy, and become obnoxiously loud and giggly) and Asian, so when we saw sangria made with sake and lychee on Tataki's menu, it was like the mother ship was calling us home.  We may be petite Asian girls, but we drink like WASPs.

I tried the crunchy spicy tuna roll as well as the artic char/avocado roll (even though I'm not yippie enough to know what artic char actually is), which were both incredibly fresh.  This place is pretty tiny though, so be sure to get here early if you don't want to wait for a table.
author: Jen L.

description: Two of us waited for 25 minutes outside, only to have a Marina bro reeking of Aqua Di Gio and his girl wander out of Wild Hare next door, come in late after their name had been announced and crossed off the list, and knowingly cut in front of us to take the last table available. The server just shrugged his shoulders and didn't care, so we left. We've been here before and the food's both unauthentic and mediocre even for that Westernized sushi category, so combined with the lousy service this time we have run out of reasons to return.
author: Austin B.

description:
Delicious and nutritious!  Well maybe not the calamari or any tempura based roll, but I can definitely vouch for the deliciousness factor.

Amazing!  I thought I've had great sushi, but this sushi was fresh, melt in your mouth good. The sashimi was out of this world!  I highly recommend the chef's sampler.  When sauce was used it complimented the fish perfectly (think nigiri).  

Unknowingly I came to Tataki at 5ish on a Saturday and was in luck because it was happy hour! Rolls, appetizer, sake, and drinks are reduced so of course we ordered too much food.  (To note, the sangria with lychee is dericious!)  Normally I finish everything within eye site, but I'm going to blame the protein for once.  After a good 5 minutes debating to attempt to eat two more pieces of spicy tuna roll or admit defeat, I had to walk away.  Today I would not be a fat girl on a rampage.  What a waste of perfectly good fresh fish!  

Portions are large and the overall price is more than reasonable.  Unless you have good restraint, come in sweatpants.
author: Justine D.

description:
I haven't been to a sushi restaurant with as many vegetarian options as this one. They have vegetarian rolls that I haven't seen before, and that were pretty good (even though some of them had mayo and cream cheese in them). The spicy tofuna rolls were good but quite hot for me. 

I would definitely go back here again. The mochi ice cream dessert was really good.
author: Lori L.

description:
Although San Francisco literally has hundreds of sushi restaurants, Tataki is one of the few that has *really* good uni (which is why this was my 2nd dinner here in a month).  Their tataki and nigiri items are fantastic, the calamari is a must, and they have a great sake list (stay away from the Samurai sake though, unless you like the taste of cedar and turpentine). Oh, but go somewhere else for dessert.

And since they serve high quality, sustainable sushi, you can also feel good about eating their food.  It's a very small place and they don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait if you're coming during peak times. 

Tri-Vegetable Sampler: Lotus Root Tempura, Skewered Potato, Spicy Burdock Root - a plethora of tastes and textures. The lotus root tempura is perfectly fried - light and crispy. The soft, smoking hot potatoes are drizzled with a sweet sesame sauce. The burdock root is salty, sweet, spicy, and chewy...almost like Chinese beef jerky. YUM! 

Arctic Char Carpaccio - bright and refreshing. The tart yuzu sauce perk up the buttery, seared arctic char. The many capers overpowered the fish, but just remove a caper from each slice and it's just right. 

Uni and Toro Nigiri - my two favorite kinds of sushi so I'm most particular about these, and Tataki did not disappoint. The uni was sooooo fresh, sooooo sweeet, soooooo creamy...soooo sublime. The toro was remarkably light and melted in my mouth. 

Spicy Tuna Roll - average. We only ordered this because it was on the happy hour list. Their pickled ginger was really good though. 

Sashimi Deluxe - beautifully presented shiro maguro (white tuna), iwana (arctic char), maguro (tuna), hotate (scallop), katsuo (bonito), kodai (snapper). Overall, the sashimi was pretty good - the arctic char and scallops were excellent. The arctic char was so rich and silky that you don't even miss salmon (which is only available a few months). The scallops were plump and sweet. 

Calamari - the best calamari I've had in a long time. The batter was super light and crispy, while the squid was tender and warm. I loved the smoky, black pepper seasoning. 

Chocolate & Strawberry Mochi Ice Cream - hard and grainy mochi. It must not have been fresh and/or frozen too long. I could get better mochi ice cream at Trader Joe's! 

Kinako Mochi - toasted mochi in soybean flour. The texture of this mochi was better than the the ice cream mochi's, but I still wouldn't order this again. It's not sweet and quite bland for a dessert. [Recommendation: Go to Benkyodo if you want incredible mochi]

For pics of each course, go to my personal blog (link under my profile).
author: Karin V.

description:
It was my GF's dinner party, and I was looking for a good Sushi restaurant to satisfy her japanese food craving.  After reading lots of great review on Yelp about this place and how they only use sustainable ingredient that doesn't undermine the ego food chain, I decided to go out of my normal treks and drive down there on a chilly SF Friday night.  

We had a group of 6, but it looks like the place is most suitable for dates as they have small tables of 2 (how could I missed the "good for groups: NO" on yelp! Inexcusable!).  We eventually got seated after 45 minutes of waiting which felt like 2 hours in a windy/rainy SF night.  The place was small so there's no way 6 of us could stand inside so we had to hang out under a nearby bus stop. Once we got seated we wasted no time in ordering the crowd favorites: the extinguisher roll, calamari's, an assortment of nigiris and sashimi's to try party favorite UNI sashimi. The food came after 15 minutes as we were drinking sakes.  Again, this is a date dining place with super small tables and elbow to elbow room.  So naturally a party of 6 celebrating a birthday could be a bit loud and we all stood out for our antics. We were fortunate enough not get called out for being because in 300 sq ft there's really nowhere to take our conversation.  

We devoured our appetizers upon their first impact.  The calamari itself were fresh and the house sauce was excellent, but the portion was too measly for our group of six. Next up were the nigiri's and tataki's... and let's just say that they don't taste as fresh as they sound "on paper".  But what the hell, we were starving after the long wait and having a good time and less about critiquing.  The long anticipated Uni's were up next, but again it was really... pedestrian.  I could name 5 sushi place in SF and Oakland that can easily run off with the best uni award and this place can't even touch them.  

Overall, the experience was okay, but definitely not recommended for a big group.  The food was average.  And yes, whenever you wait for 45 minutes in ANY restaurant, your anticipation level just build up so anything less than stellar would cast a large shadow to your entire experience, so I could be a bit biased and filled with over-anticipation.   As for the whole sustainable sushi movement, I applaud that and I think it's a good cause, but don't EVER associate it with FRESH and TASTY ingredient.  They are two completely different things.
author: Howard L.

description:
Sushi - great.  Sustainable - even greater.  Add a cozy restaurant with attentive service and you've got a winner.

The concept is really interesting but except for the fact that they don't have certain types of fish (for example, they serve "alternative eel" and artic char instead of salmon), one would never know the difference.

The fish is extremely fresh, however, and the rolls are inventive (their Golden State roll includes Gold flakes).  Try the Extinguisher Roll which comes complete with flaming salt, and the 49er Roll (masago and avocado topped with arctic char and a lemon slice).

Restaurant is small so make a reservation lest you get stuck putting your name on the waiting list...  But at least the wait will be worth it.

Last thought, prices are reasonable so you get to go home feeling full, happy to have done something good (or at least not as bad) for the environment, and still have a couple $ in your pocket.
author: David A.

description: I really like this japanese restaurant because the rolls are different and unique compared to other japanese restaurants. The tuna and avocado roll very fresh and it was warmed using a food torch. We ordered the sliced fish in soy sauce and it was very fresh and did not taste like fish. I loved the peanut butter and cinnamon mochi too!! The only downside is the price
author: Rosanna T.

description:
After a long hike at Mt. Tam, we figured we should eat healthy so we decided to try a new sushi restaurant.  My first choice was to check out Sebo after all of the great reviews and the special on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations I really have been wanting to try it out but unfortunately they were closed.  I had heard of Tataki before and it was close by so we decided to check it out.  

We waited about 20 or so minutes to get our table and as we were waiting we were reading about sustainable fishing and the concept of their restaurant.  It was quite interesting to learn that hamachi was similar to sake in that they are heavily farmed and in many cases in "dirty" and questionnable farms so Tataki does not serve hamachi or sake.  They also serve fish in season that are fresh and would have lower levels of mercury, etc. 

We decided to go with the sashimi deluxe platter along with a bunch of nigiri.  The sashimi platter was great since it had so many different types of fish.  I thought overall the fish was really fresh and whether its the sustainable fishing or what not, some things were very memorable.  To name a few, I really enjoyed the shiro maguro (tho strangely the toro shiro maguro wasn't quite as good!), hotate and amaebi was sooo sweet and yummy, aji was very good, ikura was fresh and not too salty, saba was lightly seasoned with seaweed, and the artic char was very good as well.  

The only thing about this place was the service which I thought wasn't so great.  I felt the staff wasn't very friendly, helpful or knowledgeable which made the experience not so grand.  Hopefully it was just that night because in general, I thought the food was good and I'd like to try some more of their dishes.  I would probably give this place a four star if it weren't for this one downfall...
author: Jessica T.

description:
LOVE the happy hour specials.  They have a small selection of drinks, appetizers and selected sushi rolls that are reasonably priced. My friend and ate until we were stuffed and only spent $45 on dinner and drinks!  Make sure you go early so you get a seat for happy hour.  The restaurant is on the smaller side, so if you don't get there before it fills up, you'll be waiting for awhile. 

I always get the Arctic Char and Avocado roll.  The Char is like butter.  It literally melts in your mouth.  A good alternative to Salmon (since the restaurant only serves sustainable fish), it has a slightly more delicate flavor.  The crunchy california and crunchy spicy tuna rolls are good, but nothing too special.  Also, the Hotate (scallops) have a very sweet flavor.  Service is usually pretty good.
author: Nita K.

description:
I came across this quaint, intimate, enjoyable eating establishment while driving hungrily away from a place I thought was open in the Marina on NYE. 

Green Zebra: Local Savings for Sustainable Living, a coupon and guide book for food with an eco twist, offers a 10% savings for the meal, so big plus for friend and I. Easy parking and a block of walking take us into the small, yet not rustic dining area. We sit at the bar in front of two friendly, fashionable Japanese Sushi rollers who smile at us. We smile back. Underground hip hop on the speakers bring a sway and bop to body. Same for the innovative reggae that plays later in the eve. 

We order an initial app of organic edamame, which arrives in front of us in less than two minutes: warm, addictive, perfectly salted (ie, not too much). A vegan fare of three delicious, decadent rolls, await us next. Tataki boasts a separate and admirable vegetarian menu, and about 60 or 70 percent of the items are vegan, or can be made vegan. I like this, a lot.

A Faux Tuna Roll with cucumber, and Vegan Cali roll with bean curd, vegan mayo and avo, arrive in the first 8 minutes after ordering. A few minutes after finishing these rolls, the Reggae Roll appears, looking rastafied, filled with tempura asparagus and topped with shredded seasonal pumpkin, avo and tomato. All are delicious. Six-dollar saki and Mochi dessert (goopy rice cake rolled in seaweed) bring the meal to divine harmony. 

I recommend this place, the best Japanese food I have tried as of yet in San Francisco. Plus, they offer small, paper guides discussing the fish to choose that offer less harm to marine life, and those that have more or less mercury. This is a conscious restaurant that educates and nourishes. Enjoy.
author: Gaya G.

description:
My second-favorite sushi place ever - the boyfriend votes it number one!

We had crab croquettes for appetizers, which were more yam than crab.  They should have been named yam croquettes!  Or even better, COQUETTES!!!  

Actually, I'd rather the sashimi be named after me - the quality was sooooo wonderful - no fishiness at all!  yum. yum. yum.  I could just eat sashimi at Tataki and I'd be a happy girl.
author: Nicole K.

description: Terrible service and lack of fish choices. No salmon. Would give a 0 out of 5 of possible.
author: Dean N.

description: Satisfied with the great quality of our sushi. Small restaurant, but chill in terms of atmosphere. A bit crowded. I would come back.
author: Shang S.

description:
Fresh fish and sustainable fish are offered here as well.  That is a must! 

I've had great experiences with these..

1) Oysters on half shell - very very fresh
2) seared tuna app - seared perfectly. warm on the outside and cold on the inside. nice light sauce. 
3) sashimi platters - again, just a nice variety of generous portions of fresh sashimi including artic char, almaco jack, etc (sustainability my friends)
4) seared scallops

I have a very very sensitive stomach and so I'm usually the first or only person to get sick after eating sushi that is not of freshest quality.  But this place has never ever given me problems all 4 times that I have been there. 

Try it out! It's good stuff.
author: Eileen A.

description:
After a weekend in Napa, we decided to stop by SF just for this place!

I really wanted to try the fresh Uni (I saw pictures of Uni being served right on top of the actual Sea Urchin)!! Unfortunately... they rarely do this and the server actually said she hasn't seen it since she's worked there. 

Although i was a bit disappointed, the Uni we ordered was still amazing. The Tataki (seared fish) was not as good as we were hoping, especially because it's the name of the restaurant, but it was still good. Calamari during happy hour is a must! 

Overall, very good food, decently priced for the quality you get, but it is not as memorable as I hoped it would be. Still deserve 4 stars though.
author: Stephen N.

description:
Good - not amazing, here is the run-down:

Tiny little place, so waiting to seat my party of 6 took a little long but to be expected. I got to order a glass of wine while waiting but couldn't go outside with it so huddled in the corner inside the door.

Finally sit - waitress was not the most pleasent and seemed irritated to be doing her job. First up we ordered some seeweed salads and edamame. Salads went over well - edamame was a bit mushy and overcooked. 

Sushi time - ordered california roll, arctic char/asparagus roll, early bird (had filet mignon). Rolls were all pretty good, the early bird was yummy and different. Others at the table ordered the sashimi which they said most of it was good but didn't like the scallops and the "mix it up" california roll with varios fishies, was told that was pretty good as well. 

I like the idea that the fish is sustainable but it's taste and menu-wise, it wasn't amazing. The service could have been better as well. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here but it's a good sushi spot if you live nearby.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
After a nice relaxing Saturday at Alta park, we ventured down the hill for a bit to eat.  I remember my co-workers talking about this place, so we decided to give it a try.  There were about 7 of us there, so it took a little while to fit all of us into this spot little restaurant, but when we did get in, it was totally worth it!

Happy hour was still running for another 10 min or so, so we all put in as many orders we could before it was over.  Saturday evening happy hour, can't beat that!  The rolls were about $4.5 each, so you can fill up for less than $14.  Unheard of at a sushi joint!  I also had to try something else since the happy hour menu is limited and went with  the Extinguisher Roll.  Not only did it taste great, but it came out with part of the plate on fire!  Didn't expect that, but it was definitely a cool presentation.

The restaurant itself has a cool look to it and the service was really friendly and quick.  I think it is also a nice touch that they are about the sustainable seafood (arctic char instead of salmon).  Good stuff.  I thought it was kind of funny that they had chinese characters in the restroom at this establishment. hehe.

I definitely want to come back!
author: Tom Y.

description:
Just when you think there were almost enough sushi restaurants around, another three pop up....this one for instance.  It's like the new starbucks takeover has retired the green apron and barister and put on a chef hat and sushi knife.  

I was always wondering about this place which sits quietly next to Solace on California.....such a prime location, next to the 1 Bus stop.  I've had my eye on you for a while, just never made the move to come.  Finally my friend got me to go for sushi, and we came here for a nice dinner. 

They've got absolutely some fresh fish.  They even put a book pamphlet out to let people know what fishes to eat and what not for the environment, talk about a green sushi spot.  Sorry, I just eat what's good and leave out what's not.  Fortunately, the ones they suggest and have are all very tasty and fresh.  With so many choices, we had to mix it up with some Sashimi Assortment, California Albacore, and a few other rolls.  It wasn't until much later as I was enjoying my last two bites that I noticed they had a happy hour around 5pm.......*shakes head*.  I'll come back for that one I muttered to myself.
author: Vincent K.

description:
My 100th review.

I wasn't planning to make a big deal out of it but Tataki gives me cause and reason to celebrate! There are lots of Japanese places out there as you know, from purist sushi restaurants to all-you-can-stuff-your-face-with joints. You name it, I've probably been there. But I've never had better sushi experiences than at Tataki. I don't know where to categorize them. They're just ELITE. 

Tataki is beautiful, an intimate spot to enjoy the freshest and most delicious sushi and sashimi. Being that they're sustainable just makes it that much better. Some of my traditional favorites are not served here like salmon and eel but I didn't feel deprived one bit. You might think their selection is limited because they only serve sustainable fish but when you order a Chef's Choice of nigiri or sashimi, you will see soon enough that you can help maintain the fish population and enjoy a delicious Japanese meal. 

The Chef's Choice of nigiris was simply amazing the last time I was here. Do you ever see those plastic sushi displays outside of Japanese restaurants? It looks too perfect because they're fake. Well the plate that came to us was that beautiful but it was real! The fish was rich in various colors and just glistening even in the low light. I was tempted to stuff them all in my mouth immediately but I resisted, took my time and savored each flavor. The scallop was sweet and delightful. The black cod called "faux-nagi" is grilled and seasoned to taste like eel. I don't think it tastes like traditional eel because it's so much better! The "faux-nagi" is light and not as salty as a piece of teriyaki drenched eel. I love the added smoky flavor. The wild atlantic mackerel is well balanced. The tai snapper and almaco jack were also divine. Now I remember why I love nigiris. They are the prime example of the best and freshest. 

The sushi rolls are innovative as they are tasty. One of my favorites is the Golden State Roll. It's fresh scallop with minced apple topped with albacore tuna, avocado, and even some 24k gold flakes. The apple is minimal but brings a sweet crisp flavor to the fish and rich avocado. During their happy hour from 5:30-7pm, my other must have roll, the Arctic Char and Avocado is only $4. The artic char replaces salmon and it is hard to tell the difference. It's the same color and it's still buttery and rich.  

Thank you Tataki. I can only hope that my next milestone review will be as environmentally responsible, delicious and makes me as happy as you! I've found my sushi heaven.

Note: They also serve sustainable uni, sea urchin. Thank goodness! You just can't replace that.
author: Julia T.

description: Amazing food! The specialty sushi rolls are delish. Innovative, beautiful, and flavorful food. Great service and cute little restaurant. For those of you who are true vegetarians (i.e. no seafood), this place is a must-try!
author: Nirali R.

description: Had: the Extingquisher roll, the crab croquette, and the 20pc sashimi deluxe, with a giant Sapporo. All delicious, wallet quite a bit lighter.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Went here for dinner and Happy Hour. Their happy hour menu is pretty limited. The ambiance is pretty casual; the place is small and cozy.

Happy Hour (their rolls are like 5 pieces each):

Ordered the Artic Char Roll: very good, it's pretty much similar to salmon
Spicy Tuna topped with crumbs: very good, had this nice taste to it. It might be due to the teriyaki sauce.
Sangria (don't know the exact name): it's made out of riesling and sake - excellent made me kind of tipsy. I had three of them.

Regular menu:

Baked mussels: very good, had this creamy topping - tasted like mayo and sriracha  
Beef carpaccio: very good, I would ask for ponzu sauce with it. Although I would like the beef to be a little thicker, can't hardly taste the beef.
Salad: very good, had this interesting apple dressing to it mixed with soy sauce.
Golden Gate roll:  Basically it's spicy scallop with minced apple topped with albacore tuna.  The roll is pretty small/thin, with about 8 pieces. I love the scallops in it, but the tuna was a little bit fishy. You can't tell if you're scarfing down the entire piece, but if you separate it like I do you can definitely taste it fish not being so fresh.
Amaebi sashimi: it's really good, tasted fresh

I will give it a four star for now, but have to try the fishes sashimi style.
author: Nhung T.

description:
Let me preface my review by stating how incredibly delicious the food was. Without hyperbole, this is probably the best tasting sushi I've ever had, and I've definitely had my fair share of sushi. The nigiri melted in my mouth, as it was very tender. Unfortunately, three of the six in our party got food poisoning. I'll spare you the details of how that manifested... 

Pluses: 

-Best... Sushi... Ever! 
-Friendly staff 
-They happily accommodated our party of six by putting tables together 

Minuses: 

-By chance, a few of us had very uncomfortable but not extremely serious food poisoning 
-Small venue (a small minus for me) 
-Two credit card maximum for a party of six spending $50 each (they DID end up accommodating us but reminded us of the maximum)
author: Scott W.

description:
The ambiance of Tataki is great, with no wait on an off-night. Service is really good, too. My favorite menu item is the arctic char carpaccio--amazing, mouth-watering, fantastic. It is a must-order.
The sushi selection is generally top-notch with an occasional disappointment along the lines of "this is just meh". Overall, I leave full and happy. The sake selection is great and they will let you do tasters if you are unsure of what to get. I recommend the "Mu"; everyone I bring here loves it because it is so mild and goes with everything. The crab cakes are just okay--I'd skip them in favor of sushi or sashimi here.
The prices are super reasonable for what you get. I always expect the bill to be double what it actually is.
author: Veronica J.

description: This place is awesome. The menu is all sustainably caught fish, and the options are unlike anything you would get at a traditional sushi place. The fish comes from all over, and the menu tells you exactly where and how the fish were caught. Good service too, and cute ambiance. Definitely will be back!
author: Suzie P.

description: Very good quality sushi, which is also sustainable. We ate the edamame (excellent), spicy tuna (buttery) and the shrimp tempura roll. All high quality, fresh and tasty. While the space is small, it has a nice and intimate ambiance. Probably not a great place for a big group over 4-5 people. My only complaint is that the service was just so-so and was a bit inattentive.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Came here with a friend around 7:15pm on a Saturday evening, and we arrived just before a rush of people, meaning we didn't end up waiting more than about 15 minutes to get seated. The restaurant *is* quite tiny, but it's not like we were right on top of the next table or practically sitting side-by-side with strangers, so I was OK with the small size.

We started with orders of miso soup and crab croquettes, both of which were surprisingly yummy. Then on to a spicy tuna roll, a golden state roll, and scallops nigiri. I had never had scallops sushi-style before, but these were just exquisite... they practically melted in your mouth they were so good. Plus, it's all sustainable!! No more worrying about the state of the oceans when you eat your sushi rolls and sashimi.

The sake sangria (can't remember the exact name) is worth a taste, very light and fruity and oh-so-good. And I agree with Borna H. -- the waiters are friendly and very attractive. =) I'll definitely be back for more eco-friendly sushi.
author: Nika S.

description:
Abso--****ing--lutely amazing.

Really.

Sashimi, edamame, calamari, prawn tempura roll, tataki roll. Almost all done to absolute perfection - the calamari was possibly some of the best I have ever eaten. The sashimi was awesome, edamame was not overcooked (hooray!). Prawn tempura roll was a bit of a let down relative to the others - it was only very good, not blow your mind.

I seriously suggest you go here. It's awesome. The chefs are out there preparing the sushi and sashimi in front of you, and there's a nice vibe to the place. The only downer is the wait; you have to sign up, as they don't take reservations. Normally Japanese of this quality is substantially more expensive. This was seriously good, especially on a value for money basis.
author: James A.

description:
Sustainable sushi. Definitely a winner in that department if you're at all concerned about that since it's probably the only place in town like that. I really wish there were half ratings because it was really 3.5 stars. Not just a-ok, but certainly not a spot that I will go out of my way for. 

It's a popular place with crowds at the door on most nights. We went in early to catch the happy hour deals AND also be able to sit down right away. 

We ordered two rolls [arctic char + avocado roll, spicy tuna roll], $5 sangria, the crab croquettes, and the Tataki Deluxe. The rolls were good; I think that arctic char makes a pretty good substitute for salmon. The crab croquettes [four of them - generous portion!] were crispy and tasty.
