Splitting the Tataki Deluxe [20 pieces of seared fish with their respective dipping sauces] between two after ALL those starters was the exact portion to leave you satisfied, but not stuffed. There was a dipping sauce for each type of fish, my least favorite being the wasabi one. I liked the garlic one the most and was cross-dipping all the fish. Oops. 

Definitely worth a try. I'd suggest happy hour because there are fewer people and deals on rolls and drinks. Sustainable fish - it's the way to go! I'd really like to see other sushi places take that on. Service is fine and knowledgeable about the fishes served, so if you want to know, just ask.
author: Tinna H.

description:
A great sushi find!  I love sushi, but probably not the guy to go to for authentic sushi because I love silly rolls.  They also follow an eco-friendly sustainable methodology which is to be admired.

Nonetheless, the rolls here were terrific, and the sashimi super fresh and tasty.  The sashimi sampler had this great sauce on one of the fish, with a bit of bbq-esque flavor...great twist on regular sashimi.  The 49er roll was fine (try the one at drunken fish, it's soooo good there for some reason), and the other one I got was tasty as well.  We got 2 drinks, sashimi starter, 2 rolls, 1 nigiri, 2 vege sushi and 1 vege nigiri...$80.  

I actually love Yuzu sushi (San Mateo) and Drunken Fish in Oakland for rolls simply because of the flavor and taste...but there's a reason I'll be back to Tataki:
they have a huge vegetarian sushi menu and actually try to do something different (i tried her 'spicy tuna' which was tofu and sweet potato and i was blown away)!  So now I can actually go to a place with my girlfriend and make a date out of sushi!  Will def be back there again, and will take guests (but not many because this place is TINY).   

I love the sustainable fish strategy, the vege options, and the tasty rolls...a hit all around!
author: A A.

description: The sushi is SO good but the service is terrible. The wait staff is rude, cold and incompetent.
author: Sandra S.

description:
I like being friends with the environment. But I am allergic to the smug, tree-hugging San Franciscans who blindly subscribe to ideals without really standing for them. Like hipsters who buy Priuses without considering a better-mileaged and cleaner car like the Jetta TDI, because they are only after the satisfaction of owning an egg-shaped advertisement of their "environmentalism."

So when the BF took me here a few months ago, I was already inclined to roll my eyes and bite my thumb at these annoying diners, just as I do with organic food (don't get me started; I am all for top-quality produce that has been well-cared for, but organic does NOT equate to that). The conversation went something like this:

Gloria: Hipsters *grumble* grumble*
Waiter: Here is your food.
Gloria: Holy shit this is some good sushi!
Jack: Laughs, then goes to pick up his organic, sustainable, CSA bundle.
author: Gloria L.

description:
This place is a true gem.

I originally found this restaurant via Yelp, and felt compelled to sing the praises after a handful of delicious meals there. Sushi is one of my favorite foods, but as I've become more aware of all of the horrible fishing practices that threaten both species and the wider ecosystem, there are fewer and fewer things on the menu that I'm comfortable ordering.

It's truly shocking to me that even in such a self-proclaimed eco-conscious city as San Francisco, that it's still almost impossible to find sushi restaurants that are actually mindful of their menu's impact.

Enter Tataki. This place stands apart and hopefully heralds the beginning of a new wave of awareness. Their principles and responsible approach to serving seafood do not get in the way of a delicious meal one bit. On the contrary, it's refreshing to go to a sushi restaurant and see so many unfamiliar items on the menu, but know that each one has been selected in a responsible and eco-conscious way. And most importantly, I have not tasted anything there that hasn't been delicious.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Nice small and cozy. They emphasize sustainable fish, so they don't have yellowfin tuna (Moguro) that you may be used to seeing at other places.

I had one of their lunch specials (roll + 7 nigiri), both were fantastic, all the fish was very delicate, soft and the right temperature. The albacore and avocado roll was extremely good as well.

My friend had the chef's choice sashimi lunch, which she really liked, although it was strange that the salmon was cut into large-ish cubes (perhaps tail end of the cut?) as opposed to long slices as one usually expects, they were soft/tender nonetheless. 

Hand rolls were not on the menu, but my friend asked for a spicy tuna handroll which they were happy to oblige. Otherwise the lunch menu is quite simple, and very fitting for somebody that is into more traditional sushi. If you're looking for lots of crunchy rolls or rolls with tempura fried shrimp in the middle and a slew of various sauces on them, this may not be the place for you.

The service was good, the waitress came around a a little too often while we were eating, thats my only real complaint (though too much is better than too little right?)

Others have written about long waits, we went there around 1-2pm on a Saturday and there was no wait.
author: Alex B.

description:
Here's the good part:

Sushi was great. Really tasty and wonderful texture. I got the Sashimi Regular and I thought the Albacore tasted downright creamy. Very very good.

Bad part:

The hostess could not have been less polite or friendly. I asked her if I could sit at the bar, seeing a spot open. Without even looking up she snaps "no." She ignores me for a while then says, "you can take a seat over there." I reply: "Uh, over where?" Her c'mon-you-bone-head answer: "At the bar." Okay, wtf?
The Sashimi Regular has 12 pieces in it. I ate half then realized I was only given 9 pieces. I told the head chef, who was standing 2 feet from me, and he proceeds to tell me that he did give me 12 pieces, I'm wrong, and implies I'm a liar.

In short, I don't care how good the sushi or that it's a sustainable fishery: I'll never go back.
author: Ross S.

description:
So I went here with my friend Lara, and was happy to see that they supported sustainability and environmental practices.  

Often when I'm eating sushi I try to be smart about the types of fish I eat, but then my greedy side is like: "screw that, all these other fools are going to eat up all the worlds fish so you better get some now while you can!"

So here I could lay those thoughts to rest and so it was that I just ordered whatever sounded good.  The fish was pretty fresh but it's definitely more modern place and not so traditional.  

Service was decent although for a nicer type place i may have expected better service but whatevs.  Anyhow, since I see Tinna H was thinking 3.5 and put down three stars, I'll do a four although I too would say 3.5 if I could...
author: Gene X.

description:
it was nearing lunchtime, and chauncey (my canon 5d) and i decided to stop in tataki for a quick bite.  seeing as how chauncey and co. cost me a pretty penny, cheap eateries rank high on my list of what i blow the rest of my money on.  ...next to 40s and easy men, of course.  

for $10, i got miso soup, the arctic char w/avocado roll, and the assorted 4 piece chef's choice nigiri, which included maguro and kampachi.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/r2jiJk3yivcLkWSSYELGcA?select=rpQFCobM1V9sVmaI68YcYA  ...can't remember the names of the other two pieces, unfortunately.  what i CAN tell you is that all of these fishy bites were fresh and tasty.  my waiter also pointed out the method in catching the mogura.  apparently, they only use one hook, so that they don't catch a dolphin.  ...or a boot.  

the space is cozy, but not cramped.  i was able to get the table by the window, awaiting possible photo opportunities.  my waiter and the chef/co-owner were very cordial and engaging.

i applaud tataki's efforts in using sustainable fish.  chauncey and i will definitely return in the near future.

notes:  
*is there a drink menu?  if there is, i didn't get one.  
*bring cash.  there's a $15 minimum credit card charge.
author: Ting A.

description:
This sustainable sushi restaurant is truly one of a kind and genuinely innovative. Came here for dinner last night with a friend. We started out with the edamame, hot sake and albacore tataki (seared albacore tuna with a garli sauce). Straight from there we both could instantly tell that the quality of the fish is impeccable and incredibly fresh. Their presentation is creative, original.

As for the main course, we decided to share different rolls. My favorite was by far  the Paradise sunset roll: cucumber and tuna rolls, (no rice). It was refreshing, light and really flavorful. We also had the popular extinguisher roll, which was delicious and pretty big for one roll. We also ended up getting a Golden State roll to finishi things off. After all the sake and great food, dessert was out of the question unfortunately.

It would be awesome if they took reservations though...waiting outside in the cold is not ideal, especially for a romantic date (not that I was on one at the time). Just saying.
author: Alyssa G.

description: I went in the evening.  There were a number of people before us, but we were seated rather quickly.  It was very small which wasn't a problem for us at all.  We ordered a plate of sashimi, rainbow roll, tuna roll, and the extinguisher (flame on a plate), and a few more (can't remember).  They forgot to bring out our rainbow roll, and everything was clarified in the end.  Not a problem.  The rolls are small compared to all the other places I've eaten.  We had green tea cheesecake, which is not bad, but I do not recommend.  It was a great experience, trying a new restaurant.  The rolls were good-ok-not bad but wasn't great.  I just didn't love it.  I would not come back, but it was definitely worth a try.  Sashimi were good-not bad but having scallops on the plate with it was pretty strange to me (didn't taste good).
author: Nel L.

description:
Most authentic-tasting sushi I've had in California so far - not kidding. There is a good selection of fish and not so much choice of distracting rolls (which makes it even more authentic.) The taste of the fish was quite surprisingly fresh and couple really well with the taste of the sushi rice. Good tea.
Bottom line - simple, fresh and tasty. This is what good sushi is supposed to be. Of course, it could be cheaper but I suppose that's the price to pay for the allegedly sustainable program the restaurant subscribes to - plus it's SF :-(
Regardless, I'd still bring my cheapskate self here very very soon!
author: Paolo D.

description: I really like the fact that they are sustainable and care about the seafood watch. With that said, they have a  great selection of veg rolls as well as some interesting rolls. Will be back.
author: Parichehr M.

description:
I guess the question one has to ask is, what is more important: being able to brag about sustainability, or being able to brag about how good your food is.

I happen to believe you can have both, but this is not a very good example of that.

Service was lacking (item forgotten). Food was decent (sushi as prepared by Chinese dudes in their 20s). Some people say "quaint" atmosphere, I say... "sticky".

I first heard about this place in an in-flight magazine article. That should be all you need to know. They certainly have their marketing down.
author: Daniel K.

description: good food. I am fan. we get some  rolls and drinks. It is fresh and so delicious. Nice presentation. Service is good and pleasant.
author: Cathy D.

description: Kurosawa sake (very floral).  Make no mistake, "sustainable" is quite compatible with both "fresh" and "tasty". The Arctic Char nigiri is like butter. Tataki made my evening!
author: Max L.

description: Wow! I was in the neighborhood and saw that Tataki was open for lunch. The lunch menu is small but certainly in no way limiting. I had the chef's choice 9pc nigiri with roll special. Delicious! The quality of the fish was incredible.  The sushi rice was fresh and polished. I can not eat soy sauce, so the quality of the sushi rice is very important to me. $14! With that price I was expecting miniature nigiri. Luckily, that was not the case. I  appreciate the use of sustainable fish, and the little chart they have on the table to denote more eco-friendly fish choices.  My server was a friendly young man with glasses, well-informed and succinct. I can't wait to go back for dinner to try the sashimi platter. All of the fish has that wonderful buttery texture that only extremely fresh fish has! I have gone back several times now and have consistently had a wonderful meal.
author: Brigid S.

description:
I hate being broke. You pretty much can't go anywhere or do anything, your friends stop calling you because they always have to pay for you, and anytime you do get money it's like there's a hole in every pocket in every pair of pants you own. 

Tataki is one of those places that makes my heart hurt at the sight and sound of it, because I could never afford it if it weren't for a special occasion. And it kinda was the other day, when boyfriend and I had our 1 year "anniversary" (we don't actually have a date, just, like, a nebulous realm of time that counts as the anniversary) so we walked to Tataki, and we were the first ones there which always makes me feel stupidly special (but you gotta be sly at this place because it fills up QUICK).

Anyway, it was to die for. We ordered way too much, but that's just the way you gotta roll sometimes. Service was attentive, informative, and unintrusive. We ordered the Mix-It-Up roll (the best ever), the Reggae (vegetarian) roll (fresh, light, crunchy, perfect), the extinguisher (dramatic and superb), some arctic char (it sounds like some super ugly fish but it was so creamy and melty and insane) and katsuo nigiri, baked sanma (like fish jerky, but that's how it was supposed to be), and hot sake and beer. And dammit I thought we had ordered everything good off the menu but looking back at the menu there's about a million other things I want to devour, even dessert, which I never order at Japanese restaurants. Possibly best of all is that all the fish they serve is organic and sustainable. Oh god I want to go back RIGHT NOW.
author: Laura M.

description: I haven't been back here in a while, but I remember this place having good quality sushi.  It's a cozy place and definitely worth a try.
author: M. T.

description:
Sustainable sushi. Interesting, yes? 

Go here early on a weekday  (before 7pm) and take advantage of their happy hour. We were 10 mins late but the server was really nice -- he let us order our happy hour drinks & a sushi roll. I had the kin sangria (and I recommend it!). It's made with sake, I think. 

Rolls ordered:

artic char & avocado roll (happy hour)
tataki roll
extinguisher roll
49er roll
double double roll
golden state roll
early bird roll

If I remember correctly, the extinguisher roll was the best. 

As for other dishes, I recommend the beef carpaccio. REALLY good.

At the end, we ate a lot and everything was good. It felt nice to eat sustainable sushi. I mean, I'm doing something nice for the environment, after all. :)

Parking sucks. I'm warning you. I got nauseous from all the circling around the blocks, trying to find decent parking. 

I can see myself coming here often if I lived in the neighborhood. 

Anyhow, damaged done for 4: $116.62 before tips.
author: J T.

description:
I'm happy to say that my first ever yelp review is a 5-star experience.  Met up with 2-friends on their recommendation at Tataki last saturday night around 7pm.  We were lucky not to have the long wait experience that most reviewers seem to have had here...probably because people were still out of town during the after-christmas weekend.  It was also 32-degrees, pouring rain, there was a huge bolt of lightning, a loud thunderclap, and the world pretty much looked like it was about to end.  Sort of a sushi armageddon kind of night....

In fact, I was first to arrive and the waitress said they usually don't sit people until everyone arrives....cue the lightning & thunder.....and she said I should probably sit down and not wait outside.  Great surprise.....cuz most places in any big city have this requirement...but great to see someone free thinking and flexible with the situation.  Sat myself down at a table for 4 and ordered the required edamame and a large sapporo.  The waitress was very good explaining the sake menu, and I ordered a carafe of one called Mu...which was very smooth & good.  My friends showed up 10-minutes later and we started the fish fest.

We must have hit this place on a fish delivery day, because all of the fish we tried was amazingly fresh and good (a sushi chef told me one time to avoid sundays because the fish will definitely not be as fresh).  We ordered the chef's selection sashimi platter (arctic char, striped bass, shiro maguro, yellowtail toro.)  They were out of the saba which is one of my favorites but had the aji instead which was very good.  

Ordered more sapporo and more sake.....

Went on to the rolls.  The hot potato roll was great, as was the extinguisher and the double-double.  I did have a problem with the extinguisher....the sterno soaked white salt that is on fire when the plate arrives.....in hind sight....definitely don't eat that.

Oh yeah....I did not mention the sustainability factor here because other reviews certainly gave enough mention.  But it made the place that much better.  The Monterey Bay Aquarium website has a great sushi section on helping people choose sustainable options.  

All in all this place turned a stormy night into something great.  I'll definitely go back during the next storm.
author: Michael G.

description:
Tataki may just have the best sushi I have tried in a while. After waiting about 20 minutes inside the door we were asked "did you put your name on the list?" LIST?? WHAT LIST? 

Just in case you are a Tataki virgin like me, the list is outside and you must sign your name on it when you arrive. oops!

Small interior, nice waitress, amazing sushi. I recommend the "Mix it Up" (spicy tuna roll topped with crab meat with avocado citrus sauce) and thats coming from someone who doesn't normally like spicy food.

Also, come prepared to hear your neighbors dinner conversation if they talk above a whisper.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I really wanted Tataki to be my new favorite sushi place - so much so, that I was in denial for a long time.  I love love love that it is the only completely sustainable sushi restaurant, but Sushi Zone will forever have my heart. 

I was not impressed by the selection of fish they claim to have.  Although everything we ate was good and fresh, it just didn't taste special.  The rice was bland and the options/flavors were boring.
author: Rebecca S.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in SF.  I've been here several times, and everything is always amazing!  All of the food is simply great quality, well prepared, and to top it all off, it's sustainable!
author: Rob M.

description:
I guess I have to be careful to be rating these places based on experience itself and not on the dates I take there.  Not that there was anything wrong with this girl, she was nice enough.  But the total vacuum where any chemistry would have existed could probably have consumed any positive feelings I could have had for Tataki.  Anyways...

They do not take reservations.  Leaving your number in the notes section of the sign-in list does not help either, as they will not call you.  If I could read, I would have known this.  Smooth move, Guy.

Their food is all sustainably farmed, as we were reminded with every dish that was presented.  I could not taste the difference until they brought out some Faux-nagi, because apparently eels are becoming endangered or something.  Considering unagi is my favorite type of sushi, this was the only thing that bothered me; if they didn't want to become extinct, they shouldn't have made themselves so delicious and easy to catch!  The use or Arctic Char instead of salmon was actually quite nice.  Mind you we dined omakase, so I can't really complain about not getting what I wanted.  The execution of each dish was flawless and beautifully presented.

I recommend trying the sparkling sake, which was unique and delicious.  The mochi deserts are also worth a try.

Decor was very date-friendly, as was the intimate setting.

In the end it was about $110 for the date and I, so it was reasonable, but probably not worth going back to.  Why 4 stars?  It was good, but I've had better sushi and better times, but I'm going to chalk it up to the former and not the cold, bitter, heart-like object in my chest.
author: Zhi Q.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night for the first time and met a friend for dinner during happy hour. I arrived at 6:30 pm before my friend. No one was waiting. There was a table for 2 and a table for 4 available. I told the host 2 and it seemed like he didn't want to seat me because my friend hadn't arrived yet. After telling him she'll be there soon he seated me.

It took the server while to bring me water while I was waiting for my friend. I almost thought he wasn't going to bring me any but eventually he did after I was looking at the menu for several minutes.

When we were ready to order we couldn't get the server's attention because he was too busy chatting with the host and not paying attention to anyone.

We ordered the rainbow roll and divisaeroll from the regular menu and the actic char avocado roll and sweet potato tempura roll from the happy hour menu. My friend had a small Asahi beer from the happy hour menu. The rolls were very fresh and tasty. I liked the sweet potato tempura roll the least and think I'll try the mixed vegetable roll instead next time. I was very impressed with the freshness and the flavor of the rolls. It was my first time eating artic char. It had a salmon like color and was fresh.

The server never checked on us and my water went down to near empty. I was done eating before the server came to refill my water.

We ordered a green tea mochi ice cream for dessert and was impressed by it's presentation. It was 2 mochi's each sliced into 8 pieces total, spread out on a rectangular plate on top of sliced strawberries with chocolate syrup drizzled around. It cost $5 and we enjoyed it. The total bill with tax came out to be $39.15 before tip. We thought the price was reasonable...probably because we ordered some things off the hapy hour menu helped to keep the total reasonable. I would come again if I'm in town.
author: B L.

description:
I'm in SF for one day. What meal do I choose to eat during my short stay? Why, sushi of course! Living in landlocked Denver, I crave me some damn good fresh sushi so a friend took us here.

Sure, I like being all eco-conscious but I'd never been to a sustainable sushi restaurant.  I wasn't sure what to expect out of a sustainable restaurant and all I wanted was some damn good sushi. Well this place definitely delivered!  I'm fairly simple when it comes to sushi, and I pretty much eat the safe rolls like california, shrimp tempura and the occasional tuna roll. All were very tasty, quite filling, and I found my new favorite roll here-be sure to try the double-double and you won't be sorry! 

One of my friends is a vegetarian and I was happy to see they even had a separate veggie/vegan menu as well. 

One minus however, is this place is TINY.  I seemed to have brushed up against all the other tables trying to use the bathroom. Speaking of, the bathroom is also pretty cool looking.
author: Kathleen A.

description:
What? I can have my sushi and eat it too? And feel good that it's all through sustainable catching? I'm so in. 

I've come to Tataki numerous times since 2009. And this place never disappoints. This place is small, and when I come, I'm usually here with a small group and we have always been accommodated. Great service. 

Now if you have never had plum wine, I advise you to get a bottle. This changed my life (no joke) and it's a classic go-to when I'm here. On the menu the Kin-san-gria is also a great choice. Light, but it'll kick you in the ass after a glass. Which are the kind of drinks I like.

Now to the food and sushi. Forget a california roll. Forget tempura. Forget your classic go to's for sushi. Because this place goes above and beyond the call of duty as far as sushi goes, and if you're gonna come here, you might as well indulge in the artistry that is put into making these amazing rolls.
For starters I highly recommend the baked mussels or crab croguette. I dont know what is added (i want to say sweet potato) but it makes a world full of difference. These ain't yo mamas crab cakes! If you like tuna and you're watching your figure, you can have the tuna tataki salad which is surprisingly satisfactory in terms of being full after eating. The spicy sauce gives it an extra kick. I love love love the kurodai tataki which is black sea bream, avocados and jalapeno -ponzu sauce. Are you kidding me? And the presentation (on everything) is what really makes this special. The futomaki rolls are very brunchy (is that a word) in terms of taste- eggs, shitake mushroom and spinach. Delish! And the Early Bird roll? Forget about it! 

It's such a treat to come here and I have loved every experience. And I emphasize experience because that's what it truly is. 

*Note- last time I came we were told max for card splitting is two. I think this might be new since I've never had a problem splitting 3-4 cards when out in a group.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Although I was slow to love this place, it's grown on me. Any place that has something called "faux-nagi" and it can taste better than the real thing is doing something right.

The service is friendly. The chefs are great. The fish is sustainable and yummy and fresh.
author: Erica S.

description:
What's not to love about the smallest, cute, intimate restaurants in the city?! Tataki is another one of those cute stops.

My friend brought me here the other day, and as soon as we walked in, I was pretty shocked by how small the place was. It literally houses maybe at most 12 tables, of course all really close to one another (close enough for me to stare at the couple grabbing each others' forearms from across the table and the little girl who positioned her stuffed doggy on the table while she ate). But of course, this is all part of the sf dining experience!

Firstly, I love that the place makes an effort to choose fish whose populations are sustainable. Their mission is to respect the sanctity of the environment! In a place like San Francisco, I am sure this is well-appreciated.

We ordered the shrimp ceviche, char carpaccio, the tataki roll, and the golden state roll. I'm not a huge fan of asian fusion, so I think it's a bit difficult for me to enjoy sushi that's not plain sashimi or nigiri with a dab of wasabi-soy sauce. 

The char carpaccio came out first, and my friend noted that there was a little informational brochure on the table introducing the fish that they served. Based on taste, I would say that the char has a similar taste to salmon and has a grainy texture towards mackerel, however not as fibrous. Nonetheless, the carpaccio was delicious! They topped each slice with a few capers, which I'm not a huge fan of, but past the capers, the fish itself was lightly flavored and delicate. 

I normally only get ceviche at Latin American restaurants, and this was a bit of a disappointment. They mixed the shrimp with tomato, and the tomato was way too overpowering. They served the ceviche on mini fried rice cakes, and though it was really creative, I was bummed I couldn't taste my shrimp. 

Lastly, the tataki roll and the spicy scallop rolls came out, and I really enjoyed the tataki roll. I can't handle anything too spicy, and the spicy scallop roll was seriously some of the spiciest scallop I've eaten. I was a big fan of the tataki roll - I unconsciously was eating all the pieces until my friend pointed out I was doing so. 

Tataki is really nice, cute for a date, a bit intimate for dinner with friends, but overall good quality and good service. It is a bit on the pricier side (what sushi place in sf isn't?), but I would definitely like to come back and try some of their other rolls.
author: stacy c.

description:
I came here hungry and thirsty on a Saturday evening with a large group.

Naturally, I ended up trying roughly 75% of the menu items.

Fried calamari - some of the best I've ever had.
After that I vaguely remember what we ordered. Some sort of potato-like appetizer that I remember as being delicious and oysters (solid) were also ordered, but this is when the sake bombs began flowing freely. Flowing right to the ol' tummy....

I remember the rolls being really really good, however. Can't quite remember which ones but I remember thinking I have to come here again for happy hour to try the sangria and get some of the appetizers.

Nice innards layout, friendly staff and a kick-ass (i never say this phrase) trippy bathroom. GO TO THE BATHROOM

GJ TATAK, GJ.
author: Victor B.

description:
Why one star?  Particularly when the Sushi is amazing...

We go there somewhat regularly.  
We ordered two bowls of miso soup along with our normal order of Sashimi, Char Carpaccio and whatever is the special of the day sashimi.  

We got two wooden bowls of lukewarm Miso at best.  it was cold when it was colder than the temperature of my mouth.  

I asked the very smiley waitor if we could get some hot soup and he happily obliged, took our bowls, apologized and returned to the kitchen.  

He came back and gave us "new" bowls of soup.  I saw the place I sipped the soup, the piece of seaweed left on the rim...   on my  "new"  bowl of soup.   Hotter?  No way.  f*$king insulting.  

I asked the waitor back and he said the kitchen "fixed it".  My girlfriend asked if that meant they just warmed the same bowls again and he (doing the best he could) just smiled and said yeah.

Yes, they have great sushi, but to be served the same bowls of tepid crap and not given good food is unacceptable.  What's more unacceptable is that the kitchen has become so laissez faire that they obviously don't care about quality service or food, unless it comes from the sushi counter.  

serious serious bummer.
author: Peter L.

description:
for my anal sister, who complains that we aren't doing enough to limit the polar ice caps, and we need to recycle even the air that we breathe's birthday, we decided on going to this place - even though there are about 10 sushi restaurants that are closer to my place, and a lot larger...

after sitting down, and looking at the menu, that talks about how each fish is caught (pole-caught, single hook, etc) we ordered our food... 
me, being the eco-ignoramus, just started ordering off the menu thinking that all this is going to be "over the top granola", (aka. no taste)... boy was i wrong!???! probably one of the better japanese restaurant in SF.  Raymond and his co-owner put together a great menu, with a lot of assortments of fish! great job guys!! and i hope more 'eco-idiots" like me can come around to appreciate what you guys have done!

they don't take reservations, since there's only ~8 tables, and 4-seats at the sushi bar
author: Ken T.

description:
This is our new favorite sushi spot (sorry, Stuart). We weren't instant fans when Tataki first opened, but since moving back to the neighborhood, we figured we'd give it another shot, and I'm truly happy we did. Not only does Tataki practice seafood sustainability, they are an all-around excellent sushi restaurant. I wish more sushi restaurants would take notice and do what Tataki does so well.

Service is always friendly and fast - we love sitting at the sushi bar. The nigiri and sashimi are always fresh and the rolls are inventive and delicious. All of the non-sushi dishes we have tried have been wonderful, especially the crab croquette. We always spend way too much when we eat here, but it's well worth it.

Tataki is small and they do not take reservations so be prepared to wait. There is a sustainable sushi guide you can peruse, or you can head over to Solstice and get a drink while you wait.
author: Lisa C.

description:
You probably haven't heard of it, and it's not featured in all of the latest glossy magazines.  In fact, it sits quietly on California street among its neighbors  without much fanfare.  But Tataki is a sushi restaurant like no other in our city - in fact, they are one of two restaurants in the world doing what they are doing, which is, serving a 100% sustainable menu.

The environment is simple and modern.  The menu is small and tight.  And they may not have the choices that you are used to - no unagi, bluefin tuna, salmon.  Don't worry about it.  You are going to have a fantastic meal, and after digging in, you won't miss those things for a minute.

We started with the seaweed salad and an order of cold Soba noodles.  Perfectly prepared, and tasty - light, but filling.

We shared the 9 pc chef's choice sashimi for our main course - which looked like your typical order of tuna, hamachi, and salmon.  Instead it was maguro (from yellowfin tuna), Iwana (char), and Suzuki (bass).  The fish was AMAZING.  So colorful and tender and fresh - like jewels from the ocean.  We followed that with the chef's recommendation of Kona Kampachi nigiri, which was buttery delicious.

There are many other things to try there - rolls, etc.  But I will be back for that sashimi (and uni, when they have it) - and for the wonderful feeling I had when I left knowing that the food had come from responsible sources.  This is definitely a case of a meal that tastes as good as it feels.

P.S. If you are interested in learning more, pick up a copy of "Sustainable Sushi" by Casson Trenor at the restaurant or from your local book source.
author: Liz S.

description:
I thought about not giving this place a review, considering it already has a over 400! But after my experience ... I just had to!! First and foremost ... You must know that I LOVE sushi and can seriously eat it everyday if it weren't for my paranoia of consuming too much mercury! :)

The restaurant:
- Small and cozy, simple yet well decorated. 
- Sits about 30 - 40 people comfortably. 
- Has a small sushi bar that can sit about 5 people. 
- They don't take reservations but has a list outside. My group of 6 got there around 8:30 and we only had to wait about 5 minutes to get a table.

Service:
- Servers were informative and gave great recommendations.
- Was a little slow at refilling water and had to constantly ask to get our tea re-filled
- Food did not take too long and arrived at the table one at a time.

Food:
- Started with Edamame (cooked just right but had a bit too much salt) and Sweet Potato Croquette (Very Good!!)
- Sashimi Plates: Great variety of fish ... was very surprised with the scallops which I usually don't like. But they served it here with a slice of lemon and it was delicious! Almost tasted sweet!
- Tataki Deluxe: Seared fish with complimentary dipping sauces. YUM!
- Rolls: Good but on the small side.

- The fish was EXCEPTIONAL! FRESH!

NOTE: If going in a group ... they have a 2 card minimum.
author: Hiyasmin D.

description:
There were 7 of us and we came to celebrate someone's 3-0 birthday!  So we were impressed that the seafood here is sustainable and they even have a stainable 'guru' on their website to make sure to provide the freshest and guilt-free sushi you can possible eat.  I also read that they were the only sustainable sushi restaurant on the north coast that in itself was impressive.  

The place was small and quaint nothing too special about the ambience.  So we ordered a lot of sushi since there was quite a few of us so I think I sampled a lot of their sushi personally.  We ordered the chef special and the raw fish was very fresh and smooth tasting.  There were other rolls (including the extinguisher) and nigiri ordered that I don't recall but I was impressed with the fresh taste and enjoyed my food.  We ordered saki as well and it had a nice refreshing taste.  All in all, good for the environment, guilt free and good service. I would definitely go back and recommend the place.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description: I've only been once but this was the best sushi I've had in SF yet. The extinguisher and tataki rolls were my favorite.
author: Rohan S.

description:
Great for dinner, though teeny-tiny, so either come early or be prepared to wait. Sushi was perfectly delicious, in my opinion. Lots of variety, decently priced, very fresh. Also, I appreciate that you can do take-out - either call ahead or order when you get there. I walked in at 6pm on Wednesday night, ordered a large order for 4 people, and was out of there in ten minutes. Just what I needed. I found the service helpful and friendly both times.

Also - gluten free soy sauce. Hello!
author: Anna R.

description:
With sushi spots everywhere, we tend to become used to the average stuff.

Tataki stands out not because of the politically correct products and philosophy, but because the fish was of such high quality. Subtle, fresh, and delicious.

Highly recommended.

My buddy and I spent about $20 each for lunch.
author: J. N.

description:
Yes, I am aware of the yelp code of ethics which implies that writing a review of a place you haven't been to is not entirely kosher. 

HOWEVER - I just heard about Tataki from a radio segment done by the california report (www.californiareport.org) and thus feel justified in giving my five stars.

There are only two places in the world, the report said, that serves sustainable fish and this is one of them! 

The ocean is a beautiful place and overfishing severely threatens the existence of fish populations. We are talking extinction, here! The owner of Tataki allows the consumer to protect the ocean and please their appetite. 

Their menu offers sustainable alternatives to your favorite delicacies. Like eel? Tataki prepares a fish it in a way that tastes like the eel you love. 

I love hearing about good businesses. I will update this review when I go there :)
author: Sari G.

description:
Four stars for Tataki's sustainable trend-setting.  I love Toro.  Without fail, I always ordered it when I dined at a sushi joint.  However, until recently I didn't realize that Blue Fin tuna are endangered.  Overfished to the point of extinction, I now feel irresponsible ordering the highly prized meat from these fish.  The voracity of fishing for these prey, especially for the Japanese sashimi markets, is startling and sad because like many resources we abuse, there is no end in sight.

I came here with a friend on a cool San Francisco evening this winter.  Usually there is a line out the door but since we were only a party of two we were sat at a two-top rather promptly.  I am mostly not a woman of too many details (besides you can get ALL of the details in other posts here no doubt) so I will just say that the sushi was delicious, the sake very pleasing and the service to be warm and frank.  I had a good time.  It has a cozy, neighborly feeling to it with a peppering of some hustle 'n' bustle.  
Try it.
author: Katherine P.

description:
Unfairly, the review's tempered by the hour-plus wait in chilled SF climes. Yes, I knew beforehand the place is about the size of a hotel restroom. The efficient-but-not-oozing-with-love-for-humanity waitress estimated a 30-minute wait. Of course once you've committed to standing outside for 30 but the minutes keep ticking by, you're going to stick it out, goddammit, and wait for those chatty bastards sucking up real estate even though they've licked the wasabi plate clean. 

The two groups (literally) left out in the cold did get consolation calamari once we were seated, albeit a very small portion--really, more of a "sorry you had to wait 20 minutes" size, rather than "lord almighty, you were deranged enough to stand out there on your birthday for more than an hour, here's a bucket of tentacles."

Price reflects the sustainability of it all, some items better than others. For instance: seafood salad underwhelmed and the citrus sauce overwhelmed the mix-it-up roll (spicy tuna with crab), but golden state (scallop, apple, tuna, avocado) and 49er (lemon with atlantic char) were quite good. Green tea cheesecake and kinako mochi made for good, light finishers. 

Definitely worth going if you're in SF and the wait's not crazy (clue: gauge for yourself how many large groups there are, and if they're the oblivious-to-the-hordes-outside sort), but not to cross the bay. (Equivalent for instance would be Uzen in Rockridge, and just avoid the overfished options, and arguably better would be Kirala.)
author: V C.

description: Place had a 45 minute wait and no where to wait but that would be my only complaint. Other than that, the food, service was great.  Had the fried calamari & the tempura roll, both awesome.
author: Nick M.

description:
Too lazy to go into details now, but I had dinner here a few weeks ago and everything was phenomenal.  Some of the freshest sushi/sashimi I've had in the bay area.  Keep in mind that the place is small, so go early if you don't want to wait.

oh yea, I believe that they only serve fish from sustainable farming.  This puts them at 6 stars in my opinion~

Looking forward to going back~
author: J D.

description:
Awesome, awesome, awesome.  Sustainable and tasty...what more could you want in a sushi haven?!?  

You might ask, "why sustainable"  and the answer is that it's a smart and conscious way to maintain the fish supply we all LOVE to eat!  Sadly, I had to say goodbye to my wonderful unagi rolls once I learned eel is not sustainable...tear, tear.  

The service here is great and the sushi chefs know what they're doing.  The small atmosphere makes Tataki a great place for a date or small get together.  And the deserts make a graceful end to your experience here.

Rolls you have to try....

Mix it up
Spicy tempura
Extinguisher

Happy sustainable eats!
author: Danielle V.

description:
This is our favorite neighborhood joint. We love going here for fresh sustainable sushi.
The place is tiny so come at an off hour or be prepared to wait a while.
Our favorite is the tataki roll.
They also have decent happy hour.
author: j d.

description:
A convenient spot to go to for lunch or post-work for those of you working in the medical center row as it is never too crowded during lunch or right after work.  (Though it does seem to fill up quite quickly around 7.)  

I've only been here twice so far and had their chirashi sushi during lunch and their specialty rolls at dinner.  They do have a happy hour special though didn't try anything off that menu.  

The chirashi was good though nothing special.  And of the 4 specialty rolls we ordered - while they were good, the only thing that was really memorable was the Extinguisher roll.

Though not terribly creative, they are fresh and deserve some recognition for the efforts they put into making sure all the seafood they serve are farmed sustainably.
author: Jean A.

description:
3 an 3/4 stars , almost four.

I have a hard time letting go off Sushi Zone, or i mean i have a HARD time going somewhere else for sushi then to the Zone, but sometimes i just force my self to go somewhere else even though i know for sure nothing is as good as Z.

Anyway i went here for lunch on a thursday, very hungover and i was actually happy surprised, the fish was fresh and i enjoyed my meal.
I do have to say that the miso was really bad and the service was...well...lazy, i almost felt like going to sleep just by looking at the server, it was hypnotizing watching him drink his cola, i am sure this dude was hungover too, i hope at least.

So, overall this place was Good.
author: cecilia k.

description:
FRESH is about the only way I can describe their food.  They pride themselves on sustainability--and it shows.

As others have already mentioned, the restaurant is tiny.  Though they don't take reservations, arriving within a half hour of opening on a weeknight didn't incur a wait.

I had the sweet potato croquettes to start, and the spicy tofuna and vegan cali roll.  All were filling and delicious, and the presentation was lovely.  I was also very pleased with the service, our server, patient in answering our questions, and accommodating of my friend, who happens to be extremely picky with his sushi.

I took advantage of one of their happy hour specials--a sake cocktail, which the name of escapes me, but it was your typical frou frou drink, complete with umbrella and all.  It was decent, just good enough for a sake hit.  As usual, there are also rolls that can be had for less at this time, between 5:30-7 p.m..

Price-wise, I can see how a meal here can be expensive, but I think they're on par with comparable sushi joints, if not a tad more.  I'm as frugal as it gets, but somehow didn't mind shelling out $30 for dinner.  You're definitely paying for the quality here.  Sure, I'd rather go to Cha-Ya for their veggie fare, but Tataki's rolls are definitely inventive and give Cha-Ya a run for their money.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Very good sushi at this small, sustainability-minded spot in Pac Heights.  We arrived a little late to a decent-size line but - voilà - there's a wine bar next door and my companions and I whiled away the minutes sipping on the lovely house red.

Back at Tataki, we were seated and attended to by a rather interesting fellow who had both of our female friends more or less ogling, which is neither here nor there; to be honest Nema S. and I thought we was pretty cool, too.

The sushi was really quite good. We ordered a selection of rolls and nigiri and nothing really disappointed; one of the cool things about the sustainability kick is that they had some varieties of fish I hadn't even heard of before, and they were all tasty.  Of particular note - pay attention here - the uni was, I'm pretty sure, the best I've had.  Perfectly balanced flavor, perfect texture...I dunno, I don't think I've had it that good before.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Tataki promotes themselves as a sustainable sushi restaurant. This means only sustainable fish as options for rolls or sushi, plus their menus & furniture is either bamboo or some other form of renewable resource (or so it seems).  They even have guides on what types of fish being caught are sustainable (i.e. unagi isn't sustainable, so they don't serve it).

We had boiled organic soy beans; an extinguisher roll that consists of spicy amberjack topped with avocado, habañero masago, hot sauce (served with a fire); and a double-double tempura & spicy tuna sprinkled with sesame seeds (with secret elements).  Their nigiri combinations are decent as well!

Our server was friendly and ready for any questions we had regarding the food served. The sushi chefs were nice as well.

The overall experience was unique in the world of sushi, thus it was a pleasure bringing my best friend here for his birthday. I look forward to returning here in the future!
author: Rob L.

description:
I have but one criterion when it comes to judging a sushi place - and it is this: 
Do they have a dish that is served lit on fire? 
The answer in Tataki's case is a resounding yes. The "Extinguisher." 
And so, friends, they get five stars. 
But that doesn't help you much, does it? Well, the service was punctual without being pushy (that's alliteration!). The prices weren't "cha-ching!" (that's onomatopoeia!). And, having a deep-seeded love for all things sushi, this was just the place for me (a dangling modifier!). 
I recommend it to sushi lovers everywhere - but more specifically, to those sushi lovers who live in close enough proximity to make this suggestion worthwhile. 
Go. You won't be disappointed.
author: Richard T.

description:
Four of us headed to [url="http://www.tatakisushibar.com/"]Tataki[/url] last evening. This restaurant heralds itself as being 100% sustainable and the offerings are not remotely typical.

Being the only one drinking to start, I began with their version of a sangria; riesling, sake, and fresh fruit (lychee, Asian pears) which was very refreshing and enticing. The other three had bowls of miso.

We started with the Baked Sanma (mackerel pike) on skewers with sea salt. These were thin and crunchy and a great start to the meal.

Next came two tataki specials, the seared albacore with garlic sauce and their version of an Arctic Char which was sliced thin and topped with capers and yuzu citrus sauce. The albacore was stunningly tender and although it was offered with a bit of wasabi, the garlic sauce was preferred. I was all over the Arctic Char which reminded me of one of the better crudo offerings at Ame.

We had a vegetarian in the group so we ordered a number of their veggie offerings (which go WAY beyond your typical cucumber sushi). We had two versions of pumpkin served; a sweet potato roll with mixed vegetable (spinach, egg, gourd, and shiitake mushroom) and the hot potato roll where the sweet potato was tempura and topped with spicy tofuna and sweet sauce. The latter was a bit on the spicy side for me and for some odd reason, reminded me of Mexican food (probably the spice). 

We then also shared a sashimi sampler; tuna, arctic char, amberjack, and albacore. The quality and richness of the fish is remarkable.

It would have been possible to stop there, but we were enjoying the now-ordered chilled sake and the company, so we ordered two more rolls; the Golden State, a spicy scallop with minced apple topped with albacore tuna, avocado, and 24k gold flakes and a Vegetarian roll, the whole of its ingredients I don't quite remember except that it was topped with thin slices of tomato. I was genuinely impressed with the craftsmanship of the Golden State when I saw the avocado; most often a roll which is topped with avocado it is thick slices. But here the avocado was thinly sliced and fanned -- but this is something one would not normally see as it is topped with the apple. So there is a pride in the work that the chefs take which shows in the quality, plus there is the supremely superior quality of the fish.

So, all the food, two bottles of sake and one sangria came to about $45 a person; a fabulous bargain considering the quality and quantity of the food. This is a place best shared with friends. I will go back alone, but probably stick to the tataki and sashimi offerings.
author: Carolyn T.

description: This is a "good" sushi place. High quality fish, casual, small setting and reasonable prices for San Francisco. Limited nigiri menu, OK rolls. Good lunchtime service (not too busy). Would come here again for lunch. Don't expect the moon and you won't be disappointed.
author: Bashir A.

description:
Tataki bucks the bluefin/salmon/krab trifecta of americanized sushi and slings some fresh-like-bleeding cuts of alternative fish onto a plate, sometimes in the company of a large flame. Who knew arctic char was so tasty, and was a beautiful substitute into a Philly Roll? They did, and I'm glad they shared.

The sashimi deluxe sampler was delivered in an elegantly arranged basket, on top of edible filler. My date conquered her fear of scallops in a caramel and air bite of pure silk texture. Sake and Suds (anchor steam for me, sapporo for her) washed everything down.

Downsides: slightly undersalted edamame. Dining room is almost too cozy. A bus somehow knocked down a SF Muni powerline outside and we briefly feared for our lives. 

There's an old Inuit saying, 'The greatest tragedy of our time is that we subsist entirely on souls,' at least here we can guarantee we'll have souls to eat for as long as possible.
author: David C.

description:
Yes, there's this whole hype around Tataki's policy of using only sustainable fishes, which is cool and all, but ultimately, the true test for me is how the sushi taste. Well I'm glad to report that sustainable fishes, in the hands of these two chefs, are not only good for our oceans but also, just plain good! 

Four of us came by on a Thursday night and after a 30-min wait (during which we sipped wine next door), we were seated. My friend who's vegetarian was very impressed with all the vegetarian options and loved the sweet potato roll. The rest of us split some of the fishy things and everything was yummy. Prices are comparable to most mid-range sushi places for nigiri ($4-8) and a bit on the high side for rolls ($11-14). They also have some interesting tataki options - we got a amberjack(?) tataki with avocado in a jalapeno-ponzu sauce - yum! 

Ok, so I'm not a good enough person to stop going to all my other favorite non-sustainable sushi spots. But I'm definitely adding Tataki to my rotation.
author: Angi C.

description: Wavering between a 3 and 4 for this place, but it's really a good bet anytime you are craving sushi. It is small, but we've never had to wait too long. The Special rolls are all really solid. I like the the rolls are a normal size that you can actually fit into your mouth. Delish all around!
author: Charlotte C.

description: These guys are putting the most sustainable fish you can get in SF. The place is small but the food is great. The Servers are always fast and friendly. I don't come here all the time but it's one of my favorite Pac Heights spots
author: Anthony M.

description: Cute and sleek little place tucked into lower pac heights. Ordered the nigiri sampler and it came with uber fresh arctic char, tuna, hamachi, etc... Food is good, but best of all - this is sustainable sushi! Welcome to San Francisco.
author: Mel L.

description: fantastic food, just too loud music. recommend the sprcials, in particular the hotate. the ikura uzura nigiri is out of this world.
author: Magali G.

description:
Hands down the best sushi I've ever tasted. Pricey, but worth every penny.

"One line one fish" is a slogan you'll hear tossed around (for what it's worth). Bottom line is the fish is damn good. Ngiri is a favorite of mine, especially the Northern Pacific fare: Hawaiian and Alaskan species.

Sushi is also spot-on and fairly creative. My favorite is called Extinguisher and be forewarned it's probably the most gimmicky of all the rolls but it's so good. The dots of hot sauce will rock your world.

All in all an excellent experience if you're willing to spend the money. Happy hour offers a nice alternative to the dinner prices and it's usually empty at the beginning.
author: Evan F.

description:
Everytime I'm in San Francisco and I feel like getting sushi, I immediately gravitate toward Tataki. Sustainable sushi? Delicious food? A relatively varied menu? Friendly service? Clean facilities? What's not to love! 

You would think that a sustainable menu would mean that you might get two or three choices --- not true. This menu is well-crafted and has many delicious tasting substitutes. I like that you can take a sustainable sushi guide (courtesy of Monterey Bay Aquarium) for when you don't eat at Tataki. The arctic char seriously melts on your tongue. And I used to turn my nose up at albacore tuna, but it was amazing here. Oyster shooters? Awesome. Baked mussels? Arguably my favorite dish here, actually. One note: although their rolls are good, they aren't really anything super special. I recommend coming here for the sashimi and to support sustainability, of course. 

I truly, truly recommend this place for anyone who love sushi, not just people interested in eco-friendly alternatives. 

Moreover, the sake was good, and they have some wine specially paired for sushi. The dessert is good, but don't expect anything too fancy. I personally like the mochi ice cream. Yum! 

One more thing: the place is kind of small, which adds to a nice homey, personal feeling. But that also means that if you get there too late, there might be a long waiting list. To me, though, it is definitely worth it. Go forth, and enjoy!
author: J. L.

description:
I pass Tataki everyday on my way to and from work in Laurel Heights; I had no idea it was oh so tiny inside! My friend recommended it to me because she had been for Happy Hour and had a good experience. 

After indulging in some Happy Hour wine and sweet potato fries at Solstice (conveniently located next door), my boyfriend and I skipped over to Tataki. When I opened the door, my immediate reaction was: oh! tiny! Luckily, we snagged seats at the bar. I like how their Happy Hour included 3 or 4 rolls and an appetizer, which we opted for: the fried calamari with fresh pepper. It was perfectly done and the not too heavy. 

For my entree, I ordered the ever after roll with filet mignon, pineapple, asparagus, and some sort of hot sauce; they don't mess around! The spicy sauce combined with the sweet pineapple was lovely. My boyfriend ordered a tuna roll and although he would have preferred half the amount of fish eggs on top, he did enjoy it. 

I'd recommend Tataki; be sure to take advantage of their Happy Hour deals.
author: Laura D.

description:
It's a really small place, so if you're going for dinner, get there early if you don't want to wait a litte while. They don't take reservations, but there's a list outside you can put your name on, so we were able to go next door to get a drink while we waited.

The service was phenomenal. That was kind of something we noticed all over San Francisco; everyone was just really nice, but it seemed especially so at Tataki.

We were really hungry so we tried a lot of different things. Pretty much everything we had was amazing, but the Extinguisher and Double-double were some of the best specialty sushi we've ever had.
author: Brandon W.

description:
Being reviewer #430 (unless someone else is writing as I'm thinking...) I have to agree to the 4 stars that brought me to try out a new sushi restaurant (new to me after living here for 10+ years and sticking to the same old same old, TriedNTrue, right by my hood kind'a places.)  Yes, tight - seats 25.  I just got lucky on a Tuesday night at 6:45 I guess and got the window seat.  Then the line started out the door.  Albacore tuna was amazing!  The melt in your mouth kind.  Pacific Sunrise roll was yum as well.   I like too that they're about sustainable fishing.  

Service wasn't the smiliest, but cordial enough.  Worth going back!  Don't forget the Happy Hour!
author: Mag K.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday November 22, 2008 @ 9:30pm After the 7pm Showing of Slumdog Millionaire
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Packed!  Party of Scenesters- Girls in Cashmere & Knee-High Boots & Guys in Fitted Tees & Both in William Rast Jeans. 
Vibe:  Energetic 
Music:  Techno
Decor:  Warm & Intimate.  Great Lighting.  Sleek Tables for Deux & Quatre & Pushed Together for a Communal Table in The Center for Huit
Service:  Very Nice & Efficient.  Awesome Sushi Chefs
Imbibe:  Hot Sake 
Devour:  Omakase.  1.  Seafood Salad  2.  Arctic Wild Salmon Carpaccio w/ Yuzu & Capers  3.  Baked New Zealand Mussels w/ Aioli  4.  Sashimi Taster   5.  Pacific Sunrise  6.  Nigiri Included Aji, Spanish Mackarel, Gindara  7.  Extinguisher Comes w/ Fire Display & Habanaro  8.  Green Tea Cheesecake Compliments of The Chef:)
Note:  All the Sushi Served Here is "Sustainable that is Healthy for Patrons & Even Better for The Oceans"
Total:  $103.08
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Tataki now holds a place in my heart as one of my favorite sushi restaurants in the world. It's amazing! 

The couple of things that went "wrong" during our meal actually made me like the restaurant more! The staff was so friendly and accommodating. They answered all of our questions about the menu very well. After being seated at a 4-person table, we were asked if we could move to a two-seater to allow room for a larger party that had walked in. It wasn't a problem for me, but the restaurant gave a free round of drinks on the house for our "troubles." (We got a bottle of sake that was just excellent!)

We ordered so much food - it's a wonder the place didn't push us out the door at closing! We started with the calamari - as I recall, it was light and crispy, as good calamari should be, and had a special dipping sauce. My other choices were the mackerel and ginger roll (no seaweed, just ginger), and the "Golden Gate" roll, which had scallop, tuna, avocado, and apple. It was seriously one of the best-crafted sushi rolls I have ever had. I tried a bite of an artic char roll as well - too bad more restaurants don't substitute that for salmon!  It is clear that the chefs and servers take a lot of pride in their sushi. Our waitress, once she found out we heard about it on yelp, had nothing but good things to say about the great support they've gotten from the yelp community. 

If and when I return to SF one day, I will definitely be back!
author: Laura W.

description: I love this place - sushi is always fresh & service is friendly.  It's a bit small but if you get stuck waiting, there's a wine bar next door to pass the time.  Oh, and during the week they have happy hour rolls & drink specials that are FANTASTIC (ends at 7pm).
author: Kelly C.

description:
Tataki is definitively a good place for sushi. They have only a few tables so waiting can be long, however, we were promptly seated Wednesday night at 8 pm. 

We ordered their signature Tataki Deluxe plate, which was delicious. Five different slightly seared sashimi slices (4) with 5 different dipping sauce. It was yummy. We also had some nigri sushi that was good, fresh, but slightly lacking true flavor.  What I really appreciated is that all the sushi and sashimi was room temperature and not chilled. We tried some of their rolls, which barely needed any additional soy sauce. The only thing that bothered me is their sushi rice. It was too dense and didn't match with the delicate pieces of raw fish and seafood. Therefore, the nigri and the rolls felt a little heavy.

They claim to be a sustainable eatery, but honestly, a sushi place cannot be truly sustainable. Fish imported from Japan, New Zealand, etc. have an inevitable environmental cost. Decorating the Golden State roll with gold flakes is not planet-friendly either. Fortunately, they're going to discontinue the use of those flakes... but luckily, not the roll itself! It was delicious with all the Californian ingredients: scallops, albacore tuna, avocado, and apple.  

Overall everything tasted good, the ambiance was nice, and service was friendly.
author: Szilvia H.

description:
Great happy hour.

Japanese style "sangria" with strawberries, lychee, and blackberries in it.

"Crunchy" california and spicy tuna rolls (these were not crunchy in the way that I had hoped.)

DELICIOUS garlic edamame.

Can't go wrong with happy hour til 7pm 7 days a week!
author: Lina L.

description:
100% Chinese.
Great Jiveassrolls that I didn't have.
Well, that's all people were here eating.
ugh.....
The place is Japanese version of House of Nanking on Columbus.
There is no Japanese costumer come here.

I felt sick after this place.

As soon as I sat by the counter, I said to myself, I made a mistake.
I just felt it. I don't know why I felt it.
Even though such a nice welcoming by a charming waitress.
Even though Nice clean counter, nice interior, nice chairs and all. 
Reminded me of Domo. The FXXXin' lame "Domo" rat'sAss! 
100% Non Japanese!

So I said to myself, " C'mon Nobu, don't be such a jackAss, don't be so judgmental.'
and I went on to say to myself, " Don't judge Sushi because what the sushi chef is, who he is."
 
But, when the waitress brought a glass of cold water with out me asking.
I said, " Oh, shit."
This place doesn't know that cold water and raw fish doesn't go together in Japan. 
These guys have NEVER had Sushi in Japan. 

So far at the moment,
No Oshi-bori was given.
No nice hot tea was given also.
but Cold water was given
That's  minus 3 down already.
But, small Asahi beer was $2.50 because happy hour!
Yatta!
That's a Great Deal, and nice waitress.
So, 
That's +2 up.

So, I ordered,
Katsuo, 6 bucks.
Aji, 5 bucks.
Saba, 4 bucks.
Maguro, 5 bucks.

Just 4 kind x 2 each = 8 Nigiris for start.

But, after the sushi chef sliced the fish, he turned face back and start making Nigiri !
He turned around! 
This sushi chef was showing his FatAss to his customer when he does Nigiri.
I was like What the FXXX?
WhatTheFXXXIs Goin'On?
Doesn't this chef want to show how to make Nigiri, does he?
He must hide something!
His sushi-rice was behind.
Why? it shouldn't be!
That means that this dude didn't learn how to set-up placing his condiments right in his kitchen. 
That tells me this dude didn't study sushi from Japanese sushi chef or any other professional sushi chef at all.

This guy isn't a sushi chef even!
But the problem is that how can we tell?
There is no test to become a sushi chef.
You don't need a license to kill fish.

He may be a guy just learned How to sushi by a sushi book from Kinokuniya.
So any Asian man can be a sushi chef if you read a sushi book!
Instantly!

The Nigiri was....amateur.
The rice was too sweet, small rice ball.
It was NOT Nigiri. Another Oni-giri sushi. No wonder he turned around. he didn't want to show me because he didn't know how!
Saba was so smelly flavor.
Katsuo was well-done, way over cooked.
That's not Tataki at all FXXXer!
Aji was ......Fxxxin' shit. 
SHIT!
Sushi rice was horribly too sweet. The means that the rice is only good for JiveAssRolls.
I don't know what the FXXX was going on in the place but this place is piece of Crap!

When I got out of the store, my stomach was jiggled and something came up to my mouth.
I didn't throw up. I spit up.
Have you had a funnky feeling when you got something coming up from your stomach after you got a coffee with old milk?
Ugh!
I don't know how many times I spit up after eating sushi in US.
FXXX, help me.
Sustainability? Great! But you gotto know how to prepare the fish.
I think you can learn how to make sushi from a sushi book. 
But the timing of how to prepare fish and good sushi rice is that you must train under professionals.

So, I'd say this.
5 star for All American JiveAssRoll eater who doesn't know what the real good sushi rice is.
But,
1 star for All Authentic Japo-style Sushi eater.

So I give 2 star for good service and clean decor. 
But why should I come back here?
Waste money folks, the chef is fake.
I'll go somewhere else for sure.

Btw, if you like to find out Fake Sushi Chefs, this is my pseudo sushi list.
They are nothing but fake sushi.
http://www.yelp.com/list_details?favorites_list_id=s2kB2rQMnXv63bemRFFo2Q
author: Nobu K.

description:
I'll preface this review by saying I'm the non-sushi sushi eater.  I just can't make myself eat most raw fish, but I do eat some.  So when my husband found this place, and I saw it had a vegetarian sushi menu, I danced the happy dance.

Honestly, I love the concept of sustainability, and I applaud what they're doing.  The fish sushi is good, but not great.  The vegetarian sushi, however, is frackin' awesome.  The reggae roll and ratatouille rolls are fantastic.  Great little Wednesday night 'hey, I don't feel like cooking, let's eat out' place.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Calling sushi "sustainable" is weird to me.  I mean, once you eat it, it's gone right?  It's moved on to sustain *me,* greedy human that I am.  However, I do like the idea of eating species of fish that aren't over-fished, endangered, or that aren't caught using processes that wreak havoc on miles of ocean floor.

Tataki serves only this "sustainable" kind of fish, and I can appreciate that.  Their selections are varied, the fish always tastes good.  I like the miso soup & the Chef's choice sashimi (9 healthy pieces) over rice.  Unfortunately, I've only ever been here for lunch when the Extinguisher roll that everyone raves about is not available.  I'm dying to try it - spicy & flaming, sounds great!

This is a tiny restaurant, so avoid busy times.  It's clean and pleasant, but not exactly cozy and romantic.

Eat here.  You will feel healthy & well-sustained.
author: Ravena F.

description:
Sushi happy hour.
Happy Happy Happy
Char roll = Happy
Sweet Potato Tempura roll = Happy
Spicy Tuna roll = no complaints
Veggie Roll = happy animals
Sangria with Asian fruits = Refreshing
Service = Just OK, a monotone bunch with an unwelcoming feel
author: Po L.

description:
Love this place!
 
I judge a place on many factors:

Cleanliness-- A-  (simple decor & just enough not takeing away from food)

Table service-- B+  (perfectly timing of courses, and water always filled!) 

Cute wait staff-- B+  (adorable and great attention to detail) 

Bathroom-- A+ (one of the nicest and cleanest!! almost as big as my apt.!!) 

Food-- A  (great variety of pairing flavors and beautiful plating)
 
Overall super cute small neighborhood sushi stop where you take your time and enjoy the company of the people you are with. Fish is melt in your mouth fresh, and severed at perfect temperature. Hole in the wall that makes you so happy it exist and look forward to going back. 

Love you Tataki!!
author: Danny B.

description:
Went here with the boyfriend for my bday. A little on the pricier side, but the quality of sushi was great. And it felt good to eat it because I knew that it was sustainable sushi. The fish was really fresh and melts in your mouth. The tataki here is amazing, living up to the name of the place. You can tell they made everything with care, and the plates looked like an art piece.

The service was good, and the chefs were very nice. The server asked if we wanted another beer, and we said, "No, we're good." and she misunderstood and brought us another one. When we told her, she took it off our bill but gave us the beer anyway, which we ended up giving to the chefs. 

The only downfall was that every sushi restaurant we go to, we ask if they have a natto-maki. When we asked here, they hesitated, probably because they don't get asked this, but made us one anyway. They should have just said they didn't have it. The natto-maki turned out to be something very odd....very dry, and not very natto-like. It was probably sitting in the freezer for a long time. I think the sushi chef knew what he was giving us, so he asked us how it was and we truthfully said, "um....it tastes kinda dry and funny." So he took it back and off our bill, and we got tobiko instead, which was very yummy.
author: Emy s.

description:
Yay veggie sushi! As a vegan, when I mention that I like sushi people often stare at me dumbfounded and say "Wait, how can you eat sushi?!" Raw slimy fish is only for us omni kids. Then, I have to explain, "No veggie sushi, silly head." Actually, I feel like I get that with every cuisine. "Wait, you can eat Italian (Mexican, Chinese, Thai, bla) food?! No way!" And yet, if you look over my reviews all of those cuisines are represented. OK, end of vegan rant. 

Anyway, Tataki is one of those awesome sushi places that gives out some good vegan love. It's true if you go to a super authentic place, they like to put fishy sauce or powder in practically everything. It's like salt to them. Anyway, not so at this place. They had a whole separate vegetarian menu, and the waitress did warn me that the miso soup had fish broth in it. Sad day, since I love miso soup, and I especially love the little tiny tofu cubies in it, but it was nice that she knew vegan meant no fish, even in broth form.  

We ended up ordering the vegan cali roll, the mixed veggie roll and the spicy tofuna roll. The first two were really good and fresh and delicious, but the spicy tofuna was by far the best sushi roll I've had in a long time. It had a vaguely oceany flavor with a spiciness that snuck up on you in just the right way. It's hard to describe, so just do yourself a favor and go eat it now. 

Also, as a side note, being a grumpy vegan I don't usually like to sit at the sushi bar, but I did here and it was totally fine. One, the fish was not smelly at all, and two, the creations that were coming out were amazing and very pretty (that is something you don't hear from me very often, meat is  pretty!?) but the brightly colored roe and carefully assembled rolls, some of which came with some flaming stuff on the side were just, well, pretty! The rainbow colors and careful construction of the sushi definitely makes it seem a lot less like meat and a lot more like little works of art. 

Overall, I highly recommend this place to other veggie peeps who find themselves in Pac Heights or don't mind trekking out there for some delicious tofuna rolls!
author: Jeani H.

description:
Every time I have come here I have had a delightful experience AND it makes me feel good that I am eating sustainable sushi.  Its comforting to know that my stomach is doing its part to save the environment. 
I will say that it is pricey but the quality is good.  
Ambience is very low key and its a good place to take someone if you want some privacy.
author: Sarah C.

description:
5 stars for focusing on sustainable seafood.

3 stars for overcooking two of our cooked fish dishes, and cutting other raw dishes weird so there were stringy bits crossing through each bite.

2 stars for a bitchy server.  The owner and the other servers were sweethearts though.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Tataki didn't blow my socks off.  Heck, it didn't even roll them down.  The decor is very "eco" and I like that they're all sustainable and junk, but that's not enough to make a restaurant successful.  Thankfully they spared us the chips and salsa, although I can't imagine why as it seems that other folks dining the same evening got them.

The extinguisher roll will clear up any sinus issues and burn the hell out of your lips, so buyer beware.  It was fantastic and we loved it!
The hamachi was nice and buttery, the tuna just okay, the veggie roll has romaine lettuce in it (?!), and the tataki we had was the most disappointing thing we ordered.  We even waited the longest for it, since despite reading our order back to us, our waitress still didn't get it quite right and we ended up with the nigiri version rather than the tataki.  If you're going to call your restaurant tataki, your tataki had better be slamming me thinks.  We too noticed the really long wait between courses, but with only one sushi chef, it's to be expected.  Prepare yourselves and order some apps if you're starving.  Bring a beefy bank account too, dinner for two of us (two rolls, 3 orders of nigiri, tataki, beer & sake) was over $70.

Summing it all up:
Service was friendly but slow
The idea is a good one
Food was mediocre and EXPENSIVE

Will I come back?  Probably not.  If I'm shelling out this much for nigiri, I'm going to Hama Ko.
author: Jennifer D.

description: This place is a no brain-er 5 star for overall performance when considering all factors.  I highly recommend happy hour.  Only downside is the place is too small and they need to expand to accommodate all the loyal customers because it is popular.
author: Henry B.

description:
For a Monday night, this neighborhood sushi restaurant was busy (in a good way).  We were seated quickly in this small place but all the tables were filled so there seemed to be a manageable vibe.  The waitress was knowledgeable about the sustainable fish choices, made good suggestions and was attentive.  Their prices are standard (little pricey) for sushi but fresh.  

Con:  their fish cuts could have been more generous since their Takaki Tuna dish with jalepenos was over powered by avocado and not enough zip like it is advertised on the menu.

Pro: their have fun some twists to their special rolls like the Extinguisher.  I won't spoil it for you.

A good spot to know about...we will go back.
author: Sue W.

description:
Most people list being faithful as one of the top three essentials in a successful relationship.  I, my friends, am one of those people.  Thus, the mere thought of admitting what I am about to say aches my body and tortures my soul - I have cheated on my beloved Live Sushi Bar.

Why?  Did I feel unloved or unappreciated?  Was it revenge or am I simply following the path of self-destruction?  Well, dear reader, none of the above.  I believe it's my inquisitive and self-indulgent nature to blame.  Such nature adores spicy scallop with minced apple topped with albacore tuna, avocado and 24k gold flakes, which showcased the beauty and delicacy of all things Japanese.  And let us not forget spicy amberjack topped with avocado, habanero masago and hot sauce, which could potentially cause anti-social behavior with a side of aggression and narcissism.  Except for yours truly, naturally.  

So, must I be punished for being human? Must I give up divine scallop with magical gold flakes?  I'll leave my fate in your hands.  But remember, rebuilding trust requires a lot of communication and commitment from both sides - I have made the first move.  Your turn.
author: Tati K.

description:
I like this joint quite a bit, but wouldn't suggest it if you're looking for any semblance of privacy: tight quarters to be sure.

The fish was awesome, and there was all sorts of literature about how clean and green it all was, but I don't pay attention to all that, because I realized long ago that with my genetic make-up I'm not long for this world whatever I do.

If you live in Lower Pacific Heights (isn't that we call the Western Addition now?) this is the best sushi within walking distance.
author: Jason R.

description:
I went several months ago, I remember the sushi being ok, that is not bad, also not great, and more of a novelty with some of the rolls.  People were really impressed with the roll with the flames; it was all wow factor for the eyes, but not for the tastebuds.  I definitely support  what they are doing - eating sustainable fish etc. and it's a good place to go if I'm craving sushi and don't want to deal with driving, parking etc., but not a place that I go to when I want damn good sushi that I salivate for.  

I do have to share one other thing that happened during my visit.  I got locked in the bathroom for a good 20 minutes.  It's a single bathroom for the entire restaurant and I guess they had been having issues with the locking mechanism not unlocking and you can get stuck.  I was a little panicky afraid that I would spend the night in a bathroom.  When I finally got out, I was relieved, but  I was just surprised with the response after one of the guys was able to unlock or take the knob off as it was not a big deal.  They were apologetic, but it would have been nice if they offered a discount, free roll or something for my trouble.  Next time, I'll just hold it until I get home.
author: Miss H.

description:
I had a hard time deciding between 4 stars and 5... But decided to be generous.

I enjoyed this place a great deal. Probably the best sushi I have had in San Francisco. Creative menu, Gorgeous presentation, very very fresh and tasty, moderate prices, nice atmosphere and good service. I can't complain! I am very very picky with my sushi and have VERY high standards.. but this place hit the mark . It's small (about 12 tables).. and the menu is pretty small. But their focus on details and presentation is so lovely.  Everything was just so BEAUTIFUL.
