Seems like people really like to come here, eat, and then sit and chat though.. and due to that, we had a 30 minute wait for a table that was sort of not necessary. Buuuuut, I am also glad that customers like the place enough to want to stick around after the tables have been cleared. That's always a good sign. 

It's not 'cheap' sushi.. Specialty rolls will run you about $12-$15... and regular rolls (philly, california, etc) will run around $8. Our bill for 4 people, came to $90. But, you do get what you pay for... and I am happy to pay a few extra dollars, and wait a few minutes outside, for sushi worth eating. 

Cons- Not good for large groups (its a small place).. and they will not seat groups unless EVERY person is there. Also, bills can only be split across a max of 2 credit cards. All things to keep in mind.

Regardless--- I will definitely be back.
author: Tamara B.

description:
big fat MEH.  sushi for white people.

Even trying to avoid the crazy rolls with craptacular sauces, I had a very mediocre meal.  Even the tataki was MEH.

the test of a good sushi joint is not the "normal" fish like the salmon and maguro.  the tests are the tamago and the saba.  their tamago was made by machine and bought, not hand made by the chef (read: bland, tasteless).  their saba was not oil/salt marinated as it should be, but was served fresh, which made it bland and without the typical complexity.

And all this for about 1.5 times the price I would pay for the mediocre quality.  I'd rather go to Taraval or Noriega Okazuya's and pay half the price for fresh fish.
author: Fong L.

description:
Tataki is one of those places that make you feel like the world is a better place.  Sustainable sushi, beautiful ambiance, great service, very very delicious food...you forget that bad things happen in the world when you take the first bite of the Tataki Deluxe platter...5 different fish, very (and I mean VERY) lightly seared and served up in gorgeous presentation with 5 different sauces.  Each bite was more delicious than that last.  We also ordered the Tuna Poki, this one is also served with three different preparations, the garlic sauce was exquisite. I love that even their nigiri menu changes seasonally.  
The Rolls were good but the stars are for the tataki and poki, and I assume the sashimi is the way to go here.
We are so happy there is finally a sushi place close to home.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Happy Hour specials are amazing here. Half off sushi, I believe. My husband and I have hit up this establishment four times now, for happy hour. It's good sushi. 

Here's my issue:

Each time we've gone, we've ordered all their rolls (maybe five or six?). And each time, they've forgotten about our last one or two rolls. We have to kindly remind them about our remaining food. Seriously, this has happened all four times. WTF? We don't order drinks or any appetizers. We're in and out super quick. How does one forget the order each time? Weird, right?

And, by the way, we have never actually waited around to get our rolls because it gets too busy and they always seem to forget. Seriously. Not joking. 

AND, I really dislike how they serve their water without ice. I've never had a damn ice cube in my water while eating here. They also add a slice of cucumber to the water. Okay...I guess that's cool. I always take mine out because I simply ask for water. Maybe you'll like the lukewarm, cucumber infused water?
author: Hilary A.

description:
Was looking for a new sushi place to try and found this little gem on Yelp.  First thing you'll notice is that it's very easy to miss if you're driving past it.  Along with that the venue is very small, maybe about 10 small tables and a bar that sits four.  They do not take reservations, but if you arrive around the time they open (5:30pm on Monday), there will be no problem getting a table.

What stood out about this sushi place was that it emphasized sustainable fish as one of its competitive advantages.   On every table are little place cards that explain what types of fish are best for the environment and fish population.  The bar also had a small book that went into detail about regions and specific fishing practices; nice little read while you're waiting for your food.

Started off with 10 pieces of hamachi sashimi.  The presentation was quite nice (5 pieces on a plate, 5 pieces rolled up like a flower in a high-ball glass).  The five pieces that were arranged like pedals differed from the other as they were from the belly of the fish.  Both types were extremely fresh and delectable, but the belly portion was smooth as butter.

We ordered two other rolls, the Tataki roll which is a cucumber and avocado roll with 5 different types of seared fish blanketed on top and sprinkled with 5 different colors of tobiko.  This is their signature house roll and is a joy to eat.  

The second roll was the golden state. Spicy scallop and apple inside with albacore tuna, avocado and tobiko on top.  The spicy scallop delivers a nice punch while the apple compliments the taste with a crunchy and tangy flavor.   

Based on the quality of the rolls, the freshness of the fish, the location and venue, I have no choice but to give this place 5 stars.  There was nothing wrong whatsoever.

If you're in the neighborhood and want to give a new sushi place a try, give Tataki a go.
author: Serge S.

description:
WOW this place was good.

came for an impromptu pre-concert dinner the other night with a girlfriend and was pleasantly surprised!

i had yummy miso soup and we split the tuna tataki appetizer, which was HUGE and came with this super good peanut spicy sauce.

we split two rolls (wow, lots of food).  one with spicy tuna and crap on the top, the other was the most spectacular shrimp tempura roll i've ever had.

pretty reasonable prices too, she had sake and i a glass of wine and the bill was only 52$

i'll definintely be returning...perhaps a little earlier in the night (we went at nine) as we were the last in the place when we left and i HATE being in a restaurant when the servers are doing side work.
author: Brooke M.

description:
So, I wasn't quite too impressed about this place. The food was pretty good however the selection was somewhat limited. They had rolls and sushi. I am probably dinging them for that because when I came here with friends, I really wanted a don buri or something. But they didn't. 

The store was on the smaller side. It is good of you want with one or two people. But when you go over 4, it is really hard to get a seat. 

I got the rainbow roll an it was pretty good. I've have had better. It is a trendy sushi place pretty much.
author: Jimmy H.

description: A favorite sushi place! Its small but worth the wait. All the sushi is sustainable and delicious! Best of all, it's not very well known, so it's not much of a scene and truly a good sushi place.
author: Katie M.

description:
I went here with some friends from out of a town and a pretentious "foodie" who wasted little time in labeling himself as a sushi guru.  Fine.  You know everything?  Then order for me, the girl who doesn't like raw fish.

Until recently my idea of eating sushi consisted of baked rolls and udon but I was feeling adventurous.  The fact that this place actually made me enjoy sashimi & nigiri is pretty darn amazing.  Four of us shared a few orders of sashimi, nigiri, and specialty rolls.  Throw in a a lychee cocktail and I was pretty happy.  When the bill came I wasn't as happy b/c this place is pricey for the portion size.

While nothing was completely outstanding/memorable everything was pretty decent.  Oh, did I mention they won't actually serve you 24k gold flakes on the Golden State, because as our waitress admitted (with an extravagant eye roll) that eating gold isn't the best thing to do.
author: Jaime C.

description:
This is arguably one of  the best sushi places I have ever eaten. The rolls were amazing and very creative. The Double-Double and the Spicy Tempura roll were orgasmic. Seriously. Just try it.

Be ready to wait a bit, it's a very small restaurant but it's worth it. The service was amazing--rolls were served one a time and the waitress made sure she brought the next roll as soon as we finished.

And did I mention that it's environmentally friendly?! 

So 5 stars for sushi, atmosphere and service. Quit reading this and go eat there...like right now!
author: Krystle M.

description:
Walked here the other night and found Tataki to be quite a surprise. Recommended by some trustworthy foodies, I had some pretty high expectations and Tataki delivered. The only negative would be the space is too small for the crowd it draws. Clearly more than enough people know of this place, so if you decide to try it, bring your patience. 

The seared scallops on rice are worth coming here alone. The sashimi was excellent and the wait staff was really cool about educating us on where the fish was from and what kind it was. 

I will be back.....especially since its only a 15min walk from mi casa.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
I love Tataki - I met a friend there last night for an early dinner and had a wonderful meal and solid service.  We had the chef choose everything for us and everything was fresh, inventive and absolutely great.  Reasonably priced, too.

This is one of my new favorite sushi spots!
author: Matt S.

description:
This place was amazing!  My new favorite sushi joint in San Francisco.  The fish was delicious and the price completely reasonable.  The place is a bit small but the interior and atmosphere great.  Good for small parties or dates.
Their Happy Hour is also fantastic.  Highly recommend it.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Tataki tastes like tatami.  You know, the straw floor mats.  

The Extinguisher Roll was decent, but everything else, from bland miso soup to awful hamachi tataki would have been regrettable at any price, and with the exorbitant prices and poor service (our order was repeated back to us verbatim and still came out wrong), there is absolutely no excuse for such lousy food.  

They only get a second star for their attention to sustainability, but I will not be going back.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I was planning my husband a small dinner gathering and I had a hard time finding a great place for sushi. It was either Tataki or Koo. I went with Tataki since Koo seemed a little overpriced.

At first, I was too fond of how small the restaurant is since we had 10 people in our party but gradually I found it very comfortable and quaint. The hostess sat us within 5-10 minutes which was fast! Our waiter was amazing! The whole time he catered to our needs with a smile on his face. We were on time for happy hour, which ends at 7pm. Sangria's were oh so delicious! For $4ish, it wasn't so bad. The lychee and strawberries were most definitely marinated in alcohol. More alcohol in the fruit than the drink itself. We also ordered a few sake bombs that were at a reasonable price. We ordered probably 4 or 5 orders of calamari and mussels. Which were also $4.50 for happy hour.

As for our sushi, it was so delicious. We ordered:
Green Dragon
49'er
Double double
Early Bird
Golden State

The 49'er was definitely a treat! The sushi melts in your mouth! I would describe each sushi but that would take too long :] So check out the dinner menu!  We even ordered each sushi maybe twice or three times. Yes, it was that good. Very fresh and delicate to the max! 

As for the dessert, I brought rum cake from Dianda's Italian-American Bakery in the Mission of S.F. My friend told me to be careful since they may charge me for cutting up the cake. So, after the birthday song, they took it to the back to cut it up. it took a long time however we didn't mind :] They sliced strawberries and placed strawberry syrup for each individual slice for a beautiful decor FOR NO ADDITIONAL COST! We were all very impressed. So I asked the waiter to also take a piece :]

The bill came out to be around $350 including sales tax and 18% gratuity. IT WAS WELL WORTH IT!

This place is great! Thank you Tataki for a very pleasant experience.

BTW, the restroom is spotless! I usually rate the cleanliness of the restaurant by its restrooms. And it was IMPRESSIVE!
author: Liezel D.

description:
I went here the other night with a group of friends and we were sat quickly, even thought the place was fairly packed, so the night started out right.

The food was fairly good, the rolls were inventive full of mixed flavors, like spicy tuna with a lemon/avocado dressing to cool it down. Also they had one roll with gold flakes which was kind of fun. 

It was more pricey than the two dollar signs suggest (maybe because of the gold flakes!) but definitely well worth it and I would go back.
author: Marissa C.

description: Very nice sushi place. Not much of an atmosphere though  but we were there for fresh fish and it did not disappoint. I had an ocean salad and sashimi deluxe. Fish was very fresh and a portion was generous. Unfortunately the service was as attentive as I would want although polite.  We were lucky to get a table right away as we walked in. But be prepared to wait.
author: Alex k.

description:
5 Glowing Red Ones.  I've been on the hunt for my *favorite* sushi restaurant in San Francisco and Tataki is the big winner.  The space is romantic, cozy and beautiful.  The presentation is amazing.  The fish is mind-blowingly fresh.  


I must admit, I never knew much about sustainable fish.  As an ex-vegetarian I am interested in knowing where my food comes from, and I guess I preferred not to think about how fish can sit on a dock for 5 days before it's distributed.  The owner of this restaurant sat down, drank some sake with us, and told us a bit about sustainable fish farming.  Don't see your favorite fish on the menu?  There's a reason for that.  I totally support what he's trying to accomplish and you can taste the difference.  

Highly recommended.
author: Kerry D.

description: This place totally lived up to its hype! The sushi was mouth watering delicious. The deluxe sashimi platter beautifally plated a little of everything..The tataki was perfectly done..with a slight smokiness. The place is on the small side..so either go early or expect to wait awhile.
author: Mimi T.

description: I am SO excited to have Tataki only a few blocks away from my house. They have an incredible sushi happy hour and every single roll I've ever eaten there is fresh and delicious. This is a MUST in the City!
author: Lizzie L.

description:
Before coming to this restaurant. i had read some good reviews on Yelp.So we came here tonight to give it a shot. We came here too early, it took us about at least 35 - 40 mins to get the table.

The restaurant by itself is quite small, and a long wait in order to get table even just two of us. when we got seated, took for a while to get a menu..and another 10 mins added up to get our drinks,  we just  ordered a beer and simple a glass of water. 

For the food, I ordered the sashimi regular which 12 pics, it was huge and nice presentation. i also had great seaweed salad, miso soup and some sushi rolls which i enjoyed a lots. I'd say sashimi was pretty good choice cuz it was fresh really. 

But for the price , i'd truly say it's a bit  expensive though cuz i had had a good one in reasonable price before hit to this place. For me, this is more a concept sushi place than a REAL sushi.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: This is a fun little neighborhood spot. It is definitely little- only about 8 tables. We were lucky to come early enough - about 6- to score a table right away on a Saturday. The daily happy hour is a great deal especially for the well-priced drinks. We ordered some rolls off the happy hour menu to start. The spicy tuna roll was very spicy but good. We also got an extinguisher roll and that was definitely our  favorite. Who doesn't love a plate with a little fire? My only complaint is that the waiter was pretty busy and hence I attentive at times and my pet peeve is a water glass that is not refilled. Oh well- we will still be back!!
author: Christy M.

description:
I don't think I've ever reviewed anything in my own neighborhood before, but I feel like I finally found a place that needs it.

Now the subway, and later the subway-sans franchise (can you imagine worse that subway?!?) really filled out this place and brought the neighborhood together. Thankfully, Tataki wasn't a step backwards.

Definitely more upscale than Godzila down the street, with a higher price point to match, but this is definitely a great date spot. Menu is pretty simple, certainly pushing 'chef's choice' type selections and a few pretty tasty/innovative rolls.

Meal started with some chips and salsa. That's a first for me at a sushi bar, but worked quite well. Salsa was delicious. 

I tried, I think, the 'extinguisher' roll, something like that, that has a habanero sauce on it... super spicy. Add some wasabi and get a double punch of spicy. Habanero to burn the tongue, wasabi to clear to sinuses. 

I'll definitely be back. 

(Oh, and the music was a pretty kick ass jazz mix which I was quite fond of. Definitely not elevator music. But it was 10 PM on a thursday, maybe they were kicking it up a notch.)
author: Rhett G.

description: Really cool spot to go with friends.  Their sushi is good (they do a FANTASTIC job on the vegetarian sushi, surprisingly) and nicely plated/presented, though prices are a little steep for what you get.  Perfect if you're looking for a trendy spot with yummy food that's fun to share.
author: Judy L.

description:
Happy hour menu!

I must quickly review this before I forget the yummy things I ate...
This place is definitely small, but nicely decorated for the holidays!  Very much a date place - perfect for an intimate dinner for deux...Per other yelp reviews, we got there early to beat any possible wait time.  My friend and I got there around 6 and were happy to find ourselves in the midst of HAPPPPPPPY HOUR!  J'adore happy hour!  Ends at 7pm - so get in before then.  Plus - they're so green!  I love how they're all about the sustainable fish..they even have a little pamphlet that lists fishes u should eat or avoid...love that I can learn and eat at the same time!

We decided to order a few things off the happy hour menu since they were half their normal price...

1) Kirin-Sangria (?) - delicious!  can't taste any alcohol but still feel the affects- which is always perfect for me...its filled with lychee, kiwi and apple...mmm ($5)
2) Tuna handroll - tuna was really good...($3)
3) Sweet potato tempura roll (?) -  can't recall..didn't quite taste the crunchy tempura I was hoping for...($4.5)

Non-HH Menu:

4) Uni - generally uni is a hit or miss for me...this one was perfect!  The uni was the main reason why we picked this place ..($8)
5) Extinguisher - spicy!  it came out on a flaming plate; pretty much presentation only...($13)
6) Tataki Deluxe - seared sashimi...goodness this was so good!  There was 20 pieces of deliciousness!  Five different fish - each with their own sauce...2 were garlic base and 3 were citrus base...it was awesome! ($30)

Service: our servers were nice; slow at times (I think they were avoiding my friend when she tried to get her attention) but otherwise, we were happy.

I'd come back...but probably for a special occasion - on the pricier side.
author: Julie H.

description: Great place with sustainable sushi. On the smaller side so sometimes it can  be a challenge to get a table. But if you can get here for happy hour sometime you won't be sorry. Only thing is that you definitely don't get full for the amount of money =/ But food with a message is always worth trying.
author: Brad Y.

description:
It is an absolute necessity for me to test out lunch spots when playing hooky from work (been doing that a lot lately, so you'll be reading many "sammi c" reviews... you've been warned).  

Tataki is great!  I was actually heading out to the other local sushi spot, Godzilla, but they were closed.  In my wandering conquest, I stumbled upon Tataki.  A bit more pricey, but I was really craving some sushi.  Let the tasting begin. 

Ambiance was cute.  They really dressed up what little space they were working with.  The lunch menu seemed limited so I just ordered the rolls + chef's choice nigiri combo.  What a great choice!  I loved every single item.  Every bite was more delicious than the last.  The seafood is definitely fresh and melts in your mouth goodness.

I was the only patron there so I thought the service was more than adequate.  The server was nice, attentive, and not all up in my bizness... 

In response to the other post about the service being "unpolished", I think that's a bit snooty.  (I'm just saying, don't hunt me down).  They were very warm people (the server and sushi chef) trying to run a small restaurant, serving up quality, sustainable sushi.  It's just a restaurant in lower pac heights, I don't want the "too cool for school"  type of servers.  To each her own though.
author: Sammi C.

description:
I told my dad that we were going to sushi.  He LOVES sushi, so he was all in.  

I told him that it was sustainable sushi.  He laughed, and didn't know what the hell that was.  

It was a late dinner, so it was busy, and it took us over 40 minutes to get a seat in the small place!!!  We were tired, and hungry, and annoyed that the people who were done, didn't give up their seat readily-even when we were giving them dagger eyes the entire time.

We got seated, and after we ordered, the waitress gave us a free dish of calamari-just for waiting so long.  

The sashimi was AMAZING!!  Not many places have it this good.  It tasted really clean and fresh.  plus, it looked purty too...

The rolls were ok, not all that fancy, and innovative, but it was good enough to satisfy us.

The mochi for dessert was really good...it was fresh made mochi, not that frozen shit with ice cream that other japanese restaurants get from costco.

Yay sustainable sushi! I'd go back
author: Jac T.

description:
I've hesitated to write this review because I don't want toooo many people finding out about this place.  I ate here just last weekend and have already referred three sets of friends - all who came back raving!

Tataki is committed to proving that you can have a full sushi bar on sustainable fish only.  They have the classic Monterey Aquarium sustainable fish cards on every table to remind of the good (green) and bad (yellow & red) lists.  Of course, they are all green.

My two friends and I started with the sashimi platter (Tataki Deluxe - $28) which was tasty and offered up 3 slices each of about 5-6 different fish, each type with their own dipping sauce.

Then, onto the rolls.

We had a recommendation for the Extinguisher Roll ($13) - that does literally come out flaming.  I was into it but it was a bit too spicy for my friends.  My favorite was the 49er Roll ($13) - Arctic char, avocado, with some fresh lemon.  It was melt-in-your-mouth deeelightful.

This place gets 5 stars for:
-Casson, the on-site sustainable fish specialist who chats with each table and educates you on the "comparables"
-Yummy yummy sustainable sushi
-Great ambiance
-Casson says during the week, you'll probably get seated even if you show up at 10pm
-All the praise I've gotten from friends for my hot new find :)
author: Sarah S.

description: Tataki has great Japanese food and a great concept as a restaurant. Sustainable sushi--or at least making their customers aware of what sea life is endangered--is a nice concept. The food here is great, and they have happy hour sushi! Sushi cheaper than usual, which is a major plus. Nice little spot with yummy food--if I lived in SF, it'd definitely be a place I'd frequent pretty often.
author: Ellie W.

description:
I LOVED the sushi here. Fresh, clean sushi.
I had the sashimi and some rolls. I don't think they have too many crazy, "innovative" rolls, but I really appreciate a sushi place with FRESH, RAW fish, and this place definitely did it for me.
Price is not bad either. Great lunch specials.
author: Food L.

description:
There are few things more wonderful than a neighborhood place. You know, where everybody knows your name? (Those who actually know that last phrase, yes, you're dating yourself as am I by using it...) That's kind of what Tataki has become to me. There's the simple part  - like it's a block from my house. And then there's the warmer part - like when I walk in I feel truly welcome. Even before they actually *did* know my name, the greeting upon walking through the door of this cozy little joint was always a warm one.

The other night I stopped by to order some take out. Two of my pals were ensconced at the bar. This evening I wandered in again, and figured it if wasn't crowded I'd hunker down and get some work done ... there was a spot at the end of the bar and so I did.

And when you get welcoming grins from the entire staff that say "we're glad you stayed," well ... now *that* feels good.

The fact that the food is superb and I'm also sipping on one of their signature cocktails (it's called Kin-San-gria, described as "sake meets the fresh fruits of sangria in this refreshing blend of Riesling, strawberry and lychee ... not sure about the refreshing part, but it is tasty and boy is it potent!) is almost icing on the cake.

When you get to Tataki (which you should if you haven't), I may well be perched at the bar ... make sure and say hi. It's that kind of place.
author: Cathy B.

description:
Not a good value and not authentic Japanese. I don't buy this sustainability  BS either. If they were true to that sentiment they would not have maguro on the menu. 
It has decent food and a good small venue but the food was a bit on the pricey side and nobody spoke or was Japanese there.
author: brandon m.

description: Cute small restaurant, attentive staff. Highly overrated sushi. Yes, it's sustainable, however not overly tasty. Edamame was bland, tasted like it was frozen  and thawed in the microwave prior to being served. In any case, we gave it a try based on yelp reviews & needless to say  we were disappointed.
author: Christina P.

description:
wow, the albacore is just AMAZING. it was sooo tender that i hardly needed to chew. the other fish i tried was good as well, but the standout of the night was the albacore. 

the service, on the other hand, was less than stellar. we added a simple nigiri and sashimi order near the end of our meal, and it took almost 20 minutes to arrive. ridiculous! i know it wasn't the server's fault; although i think he did forget to put our order in at first. anyway, i will keep my star rating at 4 for the quality of the fish and hope that the extreme slowness that night was a fluke.
author: Clara K.

description:
This is perhaps my favorite sushi place in SF!  I love their extensive vegetarian menu, and they go beyond the standard avocado roll, cucumber roll, etc. and actually get creative with their veggie dishes.  

The place is intimate, and all the people that work there are nice.  However, this is not the place for a large group of people, (in fact it is best to go with only two of you so you will not have to wait so long for a table).   This is also not the place to go if you are in a rush because sometimes the food takes a while, which makes it great for a date night.  

5 stars for the seaweed salad, 5 stars for their vegetarian menu; 3 stars from my boyfriend who eats fish and likes the restaurant a lot but is not crazy about all the fish that he has eaten there.  4 stars because we love it and keep going back.
author: Simone P.

description: The highlight of Tataki is definitely the super fresh melt-in-your-mouth sashimi and sushi. However, I just wish the pieces could be a bit bigger and I was craving for something extra exotic/unique which was missing from this place. The Sake-Sangria was extraordinary and it was only $5 during happy hour. The staff was friendly and was always filling our tea.  The place is very tiny and parking could be a challenge so make sure you come early.
author: Del S.

description:
SO. GOOD.  Best sushi thus far in the Bay Area. Tried 5 different rolls as well as miso and edamame  apps. Yum, yum, and a sustainable yum. 

I agree with other posters who say the service is a little slow, but it's totally worth it. We sat at the sushi bar and so didn't have to wait as long for a seat or to be served our rolls. 

Great atmosphere too, though cozy with the other tables.
author: Maggie M.

description:
I've never had such fresh sushi in my lifetime, not only was it very good sushi... it was displayed beautifully and came with a good price.

My group had about 5 different rolls so I can say I had enough of a variety to say that the place was good, not just lucky. However, I've forgotten the names of the rolls that I had except for my favorite out of the bunch... the 49er. Get the 49er! It's mix of freshness and just the right amount of lemon squirted on top really did it. The others were good, I remember specifically the one with gold in it and the spicy one.

I'm also glad I took the advise of another yelper to try the green tea cheesecake. Its just a very subtle touch of green tea, but it makes a huge difference and its just... awesome. We also had the mochi but it was just meh...
author: Jason S.

description:
Spotless setting. Clean flavors. Great service. AND sustainable fish!

We just loved this place. The sushi was awesome (albeit a bit untraditional), and all the rolls were beautifully presented. We especially loved the Extinguisher (it comes lit on fire).

Looking forward to our next visit.
author: Abby Z.

description:
I had already bought a chicken caesar wrap at Blue Fog Market,  a block away, but when I noticed that Tataki had opened, I figured that I had to at least try something for takeout.   

My sashimi, sushi, or roll of choice usually includes salmon.  If you are also a fan of salmon, you maybe surprised to not see salmon on the menu.  Instead of salmon, Tataki offers Arctic Char.  In appearance, the Arctic char looked very similar to salmon but its taste was a little different.  I ordered the Arctic char nigiri and an Arctic char roll. At this point I think I still prefer salmon but I would order the Arctic char again.  I enjoyed my Arctic char nigiri and roll.

To get more of an understanding of Arctic Char, I have posted some information from one of my two reliable news sources, Wikipedia.com (AOL News is the other in case your wondering).  According to Wikipedia.com, "Arctic Char is both a freshwater and saltwater fish in the Salmonidae family, native to Arctic, sub-Arctic and alpine lakes and coastal waters.  In Siberia, it is known as golets.  The Arctic char is closely related to both salmon and trout and has many characteristics of both." 

Besides trying a different type of fish, there are other reasons to try Tataki.  As my close friends will tell you,  I like entering and greeting new restaurants as if I'm the mayor welcoming a place to the neighborhood.  If the new restaurant's staff is friendly, there is a good chance I'll be back and recommend to other people. Though I just ordered two small items, the staff welcomed me; thanked me for trying and offered me some tea while I was waiting for my sushi to be prepared.  It was great service!

Another reason to try Tataki is the ambiance inside the place.  Tataki is stylishly decorated and perfect for a group of two or four.  If you ever went to the Subway that was previously in the space now occupied by Tataki, you'll be pleasantly surprised at what a good job Tataki did with the small space.
author: Josh K.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here for his birthday. We wanted to dress up nicely and have a relaxed, romantic atmosphere. We picked the right place. Tataki was exactly what we were looking for. It was a small place, but the lighting and seating was just right for an intimate dinner date. Whether it be with a small group of friends, or an evening for two, this is the place to be! Note: it's not meant to be a dressy restaurant, but we didn't feel out of place in our fancy attire [not like tux and red carpet dress, just not jeans and a skirt with flip flops]

Our first reaction was just with the atmosphere...the food was a whole other story.

The sushi here is fresh and tastes great. The menu wasn't extensive, but considering I'm super indecisive, that was probably for the best. Also, the items they had on the menu (what we had) were fantastic! The Tatori Specialty roll was great, lots of fresh tender fish accompanied with cucumber and avocado. Yumm!

Something that surprised us, was that the Miso Soup was incredible. It sounds really weird to be praising Miso Soup so much...but it was definitely the best we've EVER had. Not like the bland side dish soup you get with maybe one piece of tofu, this was flavorful and had large pieces of seaweed and just enough tofu!

As for dessert, we splurged a bit and tried both desserts. The jello coffee? Great for coffee-lovers, but for us, the texture was too weird. We couldn't get through the whole dish, but if we had a third or fourth, we probably could have. It was just the texture of the dessert that held us back--it tasted great, but squishy coffee chunks? Hmm...

The green tea cheesecake was great! Usually, for me, cheesecake is too sweet, but this was a pleasant balance. Just a note: the green tea flavor is very subtle. 

It was a wonderful evening! We definitely recommend it: it's delicious and pleasant!!

[PS: The bathroom has really cool interior design. Also a weird thing to add.
But seriously.]
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Tataki Ta-takes-forever-to-get-service-i  
After waiting well over an hr when dirty tables sat untouched, we were finally seated. Fortunatly the waiter new how long we had starved and brought out a free appetizer.  Hands down, the Tataki was the game winner. Paradoxicaly, the rolls were at best mediocre but the sashimi more than made up for this.
author: Yen G.

description:
You'll love this place if you're part of the green movement.  

Very good concept.  Food was just *eh...* but i had to give them an extra star b/c they were green.  Went for happy hour.  Food was ok.  Sake Sangria w/strawberries, apples and lychees were the best!!!
author: Nutmeg Y.

description: I just came here with my friend visiting from out of town. The service was great and the food was amazing!! The sushi and sashimi is always so fresh and reasonably price.
author: Marie C.

description:
I was craving sushi again and the places I wanted to go didn't open for lunch. Tataki had good reviews so I thought I'd satisfy my craving. The place is small and features sustainable fish. I ordered the chiarashi - so I could sample a few different fish. They were generous with the types of fish - several slices each of sake, tuna, hotate, tai (I think - I need to figure out what this fish is, it's starting to be on my always order list), ebi, and I think himachi. The fish itself was just OK - the fish had a strange bitter aftertaste and it was a bit dry. And the ebi was tough, chewy, and limp (ick). Koo's fish, in comparison, was moist, plump, and sweet. Maybe the rolls here might be what people come for since many people commented on it, but I judge a sushi place based on the quality and selection of fish. 

And I laughed when I read the comment about the dull wasabi color - bright green artificial powder is preferred? Fresh wasabi isn't bright green :).
author: Cammy H.

description:
I went here for lunch with an Architect colleague and was very impressed with the quality of everything served at this tiny sushi restaurant.  I had the 7 pieces plus a roll lunch which comes with soup or salad also.  My salad was fresh micro greens lightly dressed and it was excellent.  The sushi, was 7 pieces of nigiri sushi and one roll, in my case arctic char and avacado.  Everything was super fresh and flavorful.
I can't wait to try this place out for dinner.  I know it's a 'hot' place to go, but it's worth it!!
author: Ron T.

description:
this is not your average japanese restaurant, granted you'll find your regular california roll here... but i say if you're an adventurer, you need to try the special rolls. it's so different. they serve fish that's out of the norm. different. yummy. fresh. nicely displayed

i am not an alcohol drinker but i saw the waitress serve their sangria to the table next to us... i had no choice but to order it bc it looked SO good and surprise surprise! the taste meets up with the appearance! i think they used japanese wine with lychee, apples and strawberries. check out the photos i posted. 

we ordered:

arctic char carpaccio
pacific sunrise - my fav
golden state
hot potato roll - very spicy and good

ikura nigiri (my fav sushi) - it was really fresh

coffee jello - very rich
green tea cheese cake - very good. make sure to dip in the strawberry sauce they give you

it ended up about $80 or so

get there early, the wait will be long. lots of ppl ordered a sushi with fire. yep! fire! not sure what roll it is but looked interesting.
author: Eliza C.

description:
Three stars for a middle of the road sushi experience, but four stars for Tataki's commitment to preserving the biodiversity our oceans, our health, honoring sustainable fishing practices, and all while respecting the long-standing art of sushi. 

I didn't even know this tiny (!) little spot existed until a friend suggested it for dinner last night. Though the place is certainly small, it's sleek and well designed, both in term of lay-out and decor. The menu is great: concise- highlights what they do best (sometimes I don't even know where to begin with dauntingly long sushi menus), hits all the "favorites" that you'd expect from an SF sushi bar with some original flair thrown in, and for a reasonable price. The rolls them self were fresh and simple, with the quality and flavor of the fish not hidden under snazzy, bling bling ingredients. 

The meal didn't blow my skirt up (although the (literally) flaming "extinguisher" role was a dramatic touch), and the service was nothing worth noting. However, I get the impression that Tataki is consistent in quality and in taking good care of their customers- both things that are key for a local spot. I'd recommend it for a casual, cozy, affordable and environmentally friendly meal.
author: Kat D.

description: I hadn't been in a long time and the food was as great as I remember it. The vegetarian rolls that are often afterthoughts in other restaurants were great.   The service was quick and friendly.  I wish the space was a bit better laid out/warmer, but it's a minor detail compared to the rest.
author: G M.

description:
Big fan. Big, big fan.

See I like to shoot for the stars.  That said it's my goal to try every sushi joint in the city.  Unattainable you say?  Whatever, a girl can dream.

I was given the tip off about this place by a friend and I have to say that my expectations were exceeded: cute ambiance, fresh fish, inventive rolls (other yelpers are right...go for the extinguisher), fun starters (sweet potato crab croquettes were yummy), multiple vegetarian options, great drink selection (try the sake sangria!), and not too bad on the ol' wallet.

Do be prepared for a potential wait, however.  They don't take reservations, but if you get lucky, they might let you call ahead about an hour and put your name on the list (highly suggested).
author: Amanda K.

description:
So, I like to try different sushi restaurants and I've been to this place twice and loved it both times. Tonight I went w/3 girlfriends who loved everything and we shared 7 different rolls: Tataki, Extingisher, Spicy Tempura, 49er, Double Double, Mix It Up and Pacific Sunrise. The service was much better this time than the last time I went.

My favorites were the Extingisher, Spicy Tempura & 49er. 

Least Favorites: The Tataki Roll (I don't like tobiko) Pacific Sunrise (no rise which is odd) and the Double Double.

If you like spicy hot then I would suggest the Extingisher (as long as you dip it in the sauce) and the Spicy Tempura.

I would definitely go back to this place.
author: A M.

description:
This place rocks....

The food is really good--- delicious, fresh tasting sushi.  The presentation is awesome-- they make all their dishes really pretty.  I almost felt bad eating it. They also have a dish that goes on fire.... fire?? WOOO! It's a lil pricey, but I didn't mind since the sushi was soooo good.

The service here is awesome.  Both waiters were really nice and hot, which is a plus ;) 

The only issue I had was the size of the restaurant.  Its very tiny, so they put the tables very close together.... you can hear everyone else's conversation.  I hate that.... oh well 

Overall,  good experience and would def. be back for some sushi
author: Borna H.

description: Ate here for the first time last week. Good Sushi. Had a Rainbow Roll, one pair of Hotate Nigiri, and a grilled-mackerel-skewers appetizer. The total came to twenty-seven dollars. Friendly waiter and waitress, pleasant and professional. I enjoyed the music, hip house.
author: Dan S.

description:
Okay it might not be the most amazing sushi I've ever had but it's pretty darn good, and the sustainable menu makes it all worth it. You must give credit to a restaurant that is brave enough to put the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch pocket guides on each table. 

We ordered mostly from the vegetarian menu and they were all great. Prices for some of the specialty rolls were quite steep but I am a sucker for Japanese restaurants that have a completely separate and sizeable vegatarian menu. The idea of mock meat in sushi weirded me out at first, but the spicy tofuna roll is truly quite awesome and a rare treat for us. We can't seem to figure out what it's made of even after asking the waitress about it (hmph...) but it was a great alternative for spicy tuna.  For the sake of it I also ordered the actual spicy tuna roll and frankly it tasted 90% like the spicy tofuna roll. I don't think I have any reason to get the spicy tuna from Tataki ever again. 

I can't wait to be back.
author: Alfred K.

description: I have eaten here a number of times and this place never fails to satisfy!  I love that they are a "sustainable" sushi place and hope that more restaurant owners follow suit soon!  I have never had a bad meal here, my favorites are Extinguisher, Tataki, Spicy Tuna, and all of the nigiri I have tried here.  Service is always very good as it's a small space and they try to turn over tables as quickly as possible.
author: Jem Q.

description: I've been here a few times. The Happy Hour specials are cheap and the sushi is to die for. The Fire Extinguisher roll is a must! The restaurant is very small, so expect to be sitting on top of the person next to you.
author: Alysha B.

description:
The best sushi I've had in the city.  This is a little sushi shop with seats for maybe 25 including the sushi bar.  You have to squeeze your way into a table, but that is the only complaint I have.  I really like that this place is all about being sustainable in the choices of fish to serve.  It's great for all of the environmentally conscious people and at the same time if you don't care you won't notice a difference in taste from the fish you would normally order.  There is a sustainable replacement for anything you might want without sacrificing quality or taste.  This won't be a cheap night out, but if you're going out for sushi you should not be looking for cheap eats.

Overall,  a great little place to get some eco-friendly sushi at a reasonable price.  Be warned this place is popular so expect a wait almost any night of the week.
author: Thomas J.

description:
As the four stars say above, "Yay! I'm a fan." Seriously. This place rocked. The crunchy spicy tuna roll was fabulous- the tuna was so tender and the spicy sauce had just enough kick without being overwhelming. I really enjoyed the "Early Bird" roll with filet mignon and avocado. My friend ordered the Arctic Char Carpaccio with great results; he was very satisfied. The only, only downside to all of this was that the portion sizes were slightly less than I've come to expect from cheaper sushi spots. Not that that's such a downer, since you come to a place like Tataki for the QUALITY food. However, I'm a fatty and I like big portions. But whatever. 

Come to this charming, tiny little sushi spot for the QUALITY, and the friendly service. And fresh, entirely sustainable fish. 

Eat quality sushi + save the environment = a true San Francisco treat.
author: Anna S.

description:
With a new wave of research and information being updated daily on the state of the oceans and fish, we need more sustainable options for our affluent and intelligent citygoers. Here's one. 

So I was just in India for 6 months and I can honestly say, HOLY COW, another reason not to eat beef!! I came back to a BRAND NEW restaurant in Pac Heights. It's SUSHI!!!! OK, OK, This IS San Francisco who's middle name starts with a capital S and ends in a capital I, I know, another one, right. But this one is so different.

To really appreciate what they have to offer, one needs to be a bit informed on the fish industry, fisheries, ecology, marine biology, have common sense, sprinkled with a bit of moral influence along with a vision for the future of fishies everywhere! 

This is SUPER GUILT-FREE SUSHI! Oh, lemme guess, you had no idea you needed to feel guilty before. Well, allow me to correct that notion, YES, YOU DID. It's not your fault, there are really amazing marketing campaigns out there with fresh and juicy images and polished vocabulary designed to simulate a specified nerve ending and taste bud on your tongue sending a decisive signal to your brain. These ads allude not to the realities of the seafood industry. That's why they get paid the big bucks! Everyone needs a job, and big bucks, but YOU, their demographically projected target, don't have to succumb to being a victim of their grand scheme. 

What I care most about is that there is no Blue Fin Tuna on the menu and Arctic Char is on hand when you need to do something to feel good about yourself, and eat at the same time. Heavy Metals like Mercury is a huge concern in our diet and running the risk of obtaining symptoms of mercuric side effects after years of exposure and accumulation has been showing up in lab results from here to Calcutta. Don't allow yourself to be duped by the machine when there are eateries like this one willing to take the time to do the research for you! 

If we don't make the right choices in SF, how can we expect anyone in places where they elect DOGS as mayors, as they did in Rabbit Hash, Kentucky, (TWICE!) to get the idea? ((DON'T BELIEVE ME, EH:  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rabbit_Hash,_Kentucky))

If you care about your health and want to eat fresh stuff, it's worth the wait, duh. That's as philosophical as I'm getting on this one.

Yours truly,

A Random Avid Eater
author: River W.

description:
A friend of mine recommended this spot, and told me it was a "sustainable alternative" to traditional sushi.  I decided to see if this might be an alternative to my favorite places for fresh fish.

I was quite impressed, as they still had a wide selection of fresh sashimi including special silver salmon, a few kinds of maguro, tai, aji, and suzuki.  All were top notch, as was the spicy scallop handroll, and my friend ordered the "veggie sampler" which was like a vegetarian's dream boat.  They also made up some fresh crab and yam croquettes that were excellent.  Organic sake and decent service that kept my cucumber water glass full.  I'll be back with more friends...

p
author: Pedro B.

description:
Good sushi - fresh and sustainably farmed.  The place is small and the service is good.  It gets crowded, but we arrived a bit before 6 and had no trouble getting seated.

Prices were ok.  Some people said it's expensive, but I found Tataki to be comparable to many other of the higher end sushi spots.  When you order a rainbow roll, you expect it to be a bit more than a California roll!  That said, a bunch of the "more standard" rolls were actually very affordable..and at happy hour, even more so.  

And even better...how about a $4 large Sapporo for happy hour.  Mmmm...beer.
author: Todd S.

description:
I took off a star because yes I understand it is sustainable but salmon is one of my favorites and not seeing it on the menu made me more than a little sad.
Otherwise, the wait is long but the food is worthwhile.
Arctic char is absolutely amazing as is the scallop roll with granny smith apple bits. They have very innovative rolls and when they say something is spicy, it's actually...spicy. The extinguisher roll was no joke. Siracha and spicy mayo teamed up in this tuna-based concoction accompanied by real flames that seared for a good two or three minutes. Pretty cool.
We also got a tataki roll (assorted grilled fish) as well as many a variety of tuna rolls. Five rolls, an appetizer of delicious calamari and two bottles of warm sake = 2 ridiculously full human beings.
Everything is very good and it looks like they boast a sweet happy hour deal so I will definitely be going back!
Just make a mental note that the wait can get long and there only seems to be one waitress but aside from those things this homey establishment is worth checking out.
author: Lianne Z.

description:
This is my first 5 star review.  I haven't been able to find a sushi place that I always want to come back to until I went here.  I found this place on yelp, and since the location was only 4 blocks away.   I decided to check this place out.  

The quality of the fish and the rolls are excellent.  I have to give Kudos to the spicy tuna roll and the rainbow roll.  Those are probably the best rolls I have had in the bay area.   I also had the early bird roll and the 49er, I didn't enjoy them as much. More because they were not my taste, then the qualty of the roll.
author: Linh N.

description:
Mmm, the thought of the albacore tataki reminds me I need to make another visit to Tataki. Their philosophy on serving sustainable sushi is incredibly appealing and very rare amongst SF sushi bars. Most sushi lovers tend to appreciate a wide variety of fresh fish but forget the fact that salmon, for example, isn't in season year round and therefore is creating an exhausting demand for the diminishing supply. Tataki's eco-conscious menu also delivers in quality and taste.

The sashimi was extremely fresh and nicely cut. It included arctic char, maguro and a few other chef's choices I can't recall. The beef carpaccio wasn't my favorite, but pretty tasty nonetheless. I was excited to see they had a sake menu which included a few of my favorites to compliment the delicious menu. I usually go for more simple traditional sushi, without all the fat rolls packed with cream cheese and mangoes, but I had to give their Extinguisher roll a try. (Yes, it was served with a flame) The presentation was clean and creative and the roll itself included a mildly spicy amberjack topped with avocado and masago with a spicy sauce. Simple and delicious! 

For desert, I ordered the green tea cheesecake and sparkling sake. Great finish to an amazing meal. Even though the sake and drinks ran up the bill, overall the quality was definitely worth the price.

Also, the service was the best I've had in quite a while. Our waitress was friendly and timely, despite the fact that it was a busy start to the night. Great service is hard to come by, and having worked as a server myself, I truly appreciate someone who cares for their customers.

Great little sushi bar with a yummy menu and sake to pair. I'll be coming back very very soon. Extended lunch break tomorrow? I think, yes.
author: Coco P.

description:
I really wanted to love tataki since it combines my oxymoronic love of environmental politics and deliciously fresh dead fish, but it did not totally rise to my heady sublime delights.

With the SO in tow, headed there and it looked pretty cute and intimate. nice decor and sustainable ocean eating, great! but for my part, i just ordered two nigiri to try it out (amaebi and artic char), while SO ordered the seared  kanpachi app and the kanpachi roll. came out to 30 already, so we halted early. I mean, i was sated, but i'm done after eating a potato. 

the amaebi was nice, but when i asked the sushi chef for the fried head he looked sadly at the other chef and let me know they had no deep fryer. i sighed too. fried shrimp head is my favorite. they reorged and said they could do a soup instead. the soup came out later, and though it was nice that they tried, it was basically miso soup with the shrimp head in it. I still crunched up everything but the eyes, but...so far. so far from deep fried shrimp head. (although during our conversation back to the car, SO and I discussed: they have a shrimp tempura roll, which means that must be deep fried, which means...!!! was it actually possible to have fried the head?!)

as for the seared kanpachi--i loooove kanpachi, but i felt searing it kinda deadened the taste for me. plus, to serve it with jalapeno was a little much. as overkill, the little fish roe were lost in the flood of sauce. we tried to eat them all, but chopsticks can only do so much.  :'(

i think i'll go back because it was still a very lovely restaurant with some nice nigiri, but i feel like it could have been better.

i miss you, deep fried shrimpie head.
author: Jade L.

description:
had take-out tonight:
Extinguisher roll
Shrimp tempura roll
Seaweed salad

small, cozy, nice decor inside

When I arrived, they seemed confused, didn't have record of my order, but it was cleared up right away. Friendly service.

Sushi take-out is often disappointing 
+ friendly service
+ my meal tonight was better than average - yummy, spicy Extinguisher roll
+ they included free edamame - maybe to makeup for the order confusion?
+ nice presentation overall
- they did not de-vein the shrimp. Poop-shoots gross me out. I know shrimp are the Poop-eaters of the Sea, but I don't want to see/taste/think about consuming their feces. I don't get why chefs don't take the extra step to clean shrimp -- it's easy and the poop/lack of poop really impacts the taste, presentation, and satisfaction of the meal.
author: Tulip F.

description:
My date and I went here on Saturday.  We got there at about 9:30 or 10, so we missed the dinner rush, which was nice.

The waiters were nice.  They seemed to be knowledgeable about the fish. 

I had no clue this was a "sustainable" sushi joint.  I only came here because my friends girl friend recommended it.

Being "sustainable", some of the fish I requested, they obviously did not have.  Which was fine, because there has not been much sushi in my life that I haven't liked (unless it's not fresh of course).   I prefer my sushi either sashimi, nigiri or hand rolls.   Not a big fan of cut rolls as i feel it takes away from enjoying the fish and its texture.

-The pole-caught albacore was delicious and fresh.  Had that nigiri style and a hand roll.

-We ordered several different Nigiri.  I preferred the wild Spanish mackerel to the Atlantic mackerel.  

-Nigiri - pole caught skipjack tuna was tasty.    

-Kodai - wild tai snapper, was delicious.

-the oysters were great, fresh.

I forget what other food we had, but it was all very good and fresh.

I don't really care about the whole sustainable aspect of it, but I will go back based on their fresh fish.  And it being pole caught, i thought was really cool.

We also had some hot sake and beer.

Total cost was only about $75 or so.
author: Jake A.

description:
Still amazing sushi! one of my favorites and still a loyal fan. but there is a decline w/ the new staff members. It seems less personable and much more rigid. i understand you must have a few rules when you are bursting at the seems, but the 2 credit cards per table and the sign for not seating you until your whole party is there is losing the appeal of the neighborhood, very personal gem. remember what made you so successful and don't lose that. 

still love but have had a few recent visits that took the experience down a notch. :(
author: K C.

description: Meh.  To be honest I wasn't terribly impressed.  The rolls were tasty, but small, and expensive considering how small they were.  Spending 25 dollars per person should mean I'm not still kinda hungry when we leave.  Also the waiter was kind of looking down at us for no real apparent reason.  Oh and the max of two credit cards per table, I get it?  But it's still sort of odd.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I really enjoyed dinner here!  The fish was very fresh and a lot of their sushi items had a special flare to them.  

We ordered the extinguisher roll that everyone is raving about. (and for good reason). The wait staff was very attentive and prompt.  It's a very small local restaurant that's charming and cozy.  (great date spot!) 

Meal = Delicious
Sake = Plentiful
Ambiance = Adorable
author: Candice M.

description:
I really like food, and I like eco-friendly food even more. My partner and I ordered the calamari, the sweet potato roll, the arctic char with avocado roll and the extinguisher roll. While nothing negative can be said about the first three items, they weren't anything out of the ordinary. The fish quality was good and fresh, but there was no real personality to the flavor. The extinguisher roll, however, would bring me back to Tataki any day of the week (and not just because my plate was on fire when they served it). It was nice and spicy, with a wonderful texture. Maybe they spend more time on their more expensive special rolls?

Other than food, part of my knocked off star is for service, which was functional (ie- I got my food relatively quickly, my water was refilled without me having to do the waiter hunt), but not impressive. In such an intimate environment as the restaurant's small space, I would have liked a little more personal warmth from the server. He was polite, but I don't think he ever smiled. Food should not be serious! It should be fun.

Regardless of the lack of smiles, I was quite happy after eating that extinguisher roll. It will surely live on as one of the greatest sushi rolls I have ever eaten. And I have eaten a lot of sushi.
author: Shaina 'Occasionally Rahn' K.

description:
In my first foray into being environmentally food conscious, I chose Tataki as the location for a small get together dinner  to catch up with old friends.  I wasn't quite sure what to expect or if many of the dishes that I usually enjoy would be included in the environmentally sustainable list.  But for most of the items that I had wanted, there was something to satisfy my craving.  

I ordered the calamari appetizer, arctic char and avocado roll, amaebi and bluefin toro nigiri.  The calamari was light and crunchy and was served with a bright lemon aioli.  the arctic char was very fresh and paired well with the creamy avocado roll.  Basically a classic, but since it was part of the happy hour menu, was offered at a discounted price.  Score!  The amaebi and toro were also similarly fresh and super sweet tasting, though I wished they would also fry the amaebi head like they do at other restaurants, or at the very least serve the head.  Waste not, want not.  

The service was attentive and courteous though maybe slightly uneven pace-wise.  There would be stretches where was no food, then a ton of dishes would come all at once.  Not necessarily a bad thing, just an observation.  The prices were reasonable for the quality that you get.  The toro was actually pretty well priced considering it's a premium cut of fish, though they did say it was a special.  I wouldn't hesitate to come back again.
author: Gary L.

description:
Yummers!  It was 9:30pm, I was craving for sushi so I yelped to see what is close by.  I saw all the pictures for Tataki that other yelpers took.  I closed shop and ran off to make that 10pm cut off time.

It was a Thursday night and the place was still jamming.  We waited till 10:20 to be seated and we close the place down.

We ordered the Tataki seared deluxe, it was really good.  I like the ponsu sauce best.  We also ordered the raw beef and The Extinguisher, all were out of this world.  Good food and feel food after it,  because it is a sustainable fish place.  Although I am a bit on the fence about arctic char.  I don't think anything can replace salmon.

Staff were great and so were the chefs.  Oh!  The sake sangria is a must try.
author: germaine n.

description:
Probably my new favorite sushi restaurant in SF now.  I really love the sushi happy hour.  My brother lives across the street and wanted to check this place out when I came to visit last weekend.  

Sushi happy hour: 5:30pm - 7pm and most rolls were under $5: 
Sangria was tasty, but couldn't bring myself to drink more than 1
Spicy tuna roll - really good
Char roll - really good 
Crunchy california roll - good 
Sweet Potato Tempura roll - good but a bit chewy
Calamari - I didn't eat it, but my friends and brother LOVED it. It came out really fresh and smelled really good. 

We ordered a 9 piece nigiri, a few of the specials, and some additional cooked rolls...and were all completely SATISFIED with our meal.  Each piece of fish was extremely fresh and the salmon was so smooth and buttery. Yum.  Will definitely come back. 

*Note - my only complaint is that their soy sauce dish is really shallow, so every time you try to pour soy sauce, it splashes all over the place...on you, on the table, on the person next to you.  They should get some real soy sauce dishes!
author: Sylvia I.

description: Nice!  I had kinda given up on finding any sushi place in this area that was worthwhile, but this was a nice find.  It's a little pricey, but the food was definitely enjoyable.
author: Phil J.

description: The "host" is on a power trip, thinks he's the Sushi Nazi or the bouncer at a hot club. Plays games with the waiting list, and if you ask how much longer, you go to the bottom of the list. With that level of arrogance, how could you enjoy the food?
author: Cary F.

description:
Tataki serves only fresh sustainable seafood that will literally light your plate on fire. Yes fire! (read on).

Sashimi Deluxe chef's choice of the day (19 pieces) - $32
* A huge, fresh platter of sashimi. Vegetarian friendly, for "vegetarians"  who "only eat fish and chicken".

49er Roll
Tobiko, avocado topped with arctic char and lemon - $13
* I prefer this with salmon, but since salmon is not in season and Tataki does not serve farmed fish, Arctic char is a nice substitute. 

Extinguisher Roll
Spicy kampachi topped w/avocado, habanero tobiko, hot - $13
* When this comes out the server lights the plate on fire. This looks cool and is an excellent visual aid for this very spicy dish.

Saki
If I remember correctly, Tataki offers a decent selection of both hot and cold saki (mmm unfiltered). For those of you who, like myself, were raised in the United States and still have a tendency to miscalculate when dealing with the metric system please note that a 375ml bottle of saki is not that small when you are the only one at the table drinking it.
author: J F.

description: Try the faux-nagi ($7) - black cod that is prepared like unagi sushi - and the Tataki Roll ($13).
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Small, tiny actually. I go only late night during the week, otherwise, good luck! you'll be waiting for 2 hours. Prices are good, some may consider it pricey, but once you taste the sushi, you forget about the $. Nice staff. 

Fire extinguisher: not only pretty, but so so yummy!
author: Anabelle B.

description:
Outstanding sushi, nigiri and sashimi. Their side dishes are suprisingly good and their rolls are creative (try the Extinguisher Roll). Atomosphere and prices are great-- in fact, I'd argue that they could get a way with charging more considering the quality of the menu.

The service could be much better though... The servers are a little absent minded and tend to also leave empty glasses/dished on the table for quite some time as they bring new dishes-- which is tough because the tables are tiny and then you have no room to manouver. 

We're it not for the service, I'd give them 5 stars!
author: F S.

description:
Okay, So I am not giving this place a 5 star because I did not get the joys of eating at the restaurant, I plan on doing this in the next couple of weeks. So I cannot completely say that this is the best restaurant to go to. 

My friends and I ordered a huge variety of Sushi for New Year's Eve. For the vegetarians (myself included) we ordered:

ratatouille roll (fried eggplant, carrot, zucchini, bell pepper, tempura, topped with minced garlic)

reggae roll (asparagus tempura, cucumber, topped with avocado, tomato and shaved pumpkin)

hot potato roll (sweet potato tempura topped with spicy
tofuna and sweet sauce)

All three of these were AMAZING, these are their specialty rolls and are so good. I could not get enough of them. 

My favorite was the Hot Potato Roll. Typically when I have sushi, I LOVE dunking it into my soysauce/wasabi mixture, but these rolls were so good, I felt I did not even need my fantastic mixture of soysauce/wasabi. 

This place did a great job on take out, pricey yes, BUT I think it's worth it.
author: Parijat T.

description:
This tiny spot is worth the wait. Sustainable sushi is a fascinating and feel-good draw, but what really made the choice for me was the whole section of the menu dedicated to vegetarians. What a thoughtful include, and so useful when you're dining with the less than raw-fish inclined. 
So this place gets 5 stars from me for fantastic wait staff service, a cozy atmosphere, a small but not too small menu, and above all else - melt in your mouth super-fresh and beautifully prepared fish.
author: Nate S.

description: Sustainable sushi?! I had no idea what that meant but thanks to the little phamplet they give you, you get to learn exactly what that means. In a nutshell, you can eat sushi without feeling gulity. I LOVE spicy food so I  tried the spicy crunchy tuna(made with yellow fin instead of the diminishing blue fin tuna),arctic char  roll, and my absolute favorite- the extinguisher. The name says it all, you will need one after eating these rolls of spicy goodness. The best part aside from the taste? They bring the roll with a FIRE going next to it. When do you see sushi rolls on the same plate as fire? The food is awesome, happy hour specials are really good. The sangria is not bad, on the fruit juice side though, only reason I didn't give 5 stars.
author: S K.

description: Tataki is one of the best sushi joints in town. It's small with one waiter and very comfortable, simple atmosphere. There was a little bit of a wait but so worth it. We (party of 3) ordered the sashimi deluxe, tataki deluxe and the nigiri enthusiast . The fish was fresh and the selection was great.  It was a feast of delicious food and we left very satisfied.
author: Camille H.

description: This place is small but nice. Their fish selection is limited due to that they only serve sustainable seafood. So, if you are wanting to order eel or bluefin, you're out of luck. The rolls were just ok. Their tuna tataki was just average as well. The thing that saved them was their calamari. It was on their happy hour menu and probably one of the best calamari I've had. Very seasoned with salt and pepper and a light batter coating with a great dipping sauce. When I go into a sushi bar and sit at a sushi bar, part of the fun is looking at all the fish in the glass case. Well, this case was small with not much in there and the presentation was not pretty at all. I doubt I'd go out of my way to come here. Maybe to get to go an order of calamari only.
author: Tay T.

description: The double double roll is really good. The coffee ice cream is ridiculously good.
author: Khash S.

description:
we eat sushi quite often, and after we found this 'sustainable sushi' place, we were really excited.

overall i'd say that it was just ok. some special rolls were a bit too sweet and saucy. the sashimi is ok but not exceptional by any means. i did love the uni sashimi..

almost 100 dollars spent, i wasn't overly impressed.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Tataki is the new black! We walked in at 7:15 on a Friday, got seated right away and the rest is sushi history. I ordered a Seaweed salad and a sashimi taster which had 5-6 nice, but not too big, slices of maguro, hamachi, and arctic char. My dinner partner ordered the extinguisher and spicy tempura rolls. We shared--that means I ate all mine and helped her with the rolls. Everything was extremely fresh and delicious. Some of the best sushi I have had in the city by far.

The place is very small and is going to be (looks like it already is) a huge hit in the neighborhood, so go early. I am not sure how late they are open, but I think they are a great addition to the restaurants on that block of California. It figures we move out of the neighborhood and in comes some damn good fish.
author: Deborah S.

description:
Tataki had always been on my list of places to go to and randomly I had a chance to stop by recently. It's a tiny place so expect to wait if you come in with a large group (45 minutes for our group of 7). We also happened upon one of the best things I've heard, a happy hour for a sushi bar that extends into Saturday. That's a double bonus! It goes from 5:30-7, 5-7 on the weekend.

I couldn't resist taking advantage of their happy hour so I grabbed a crunchy CA and arctic char with avocado roll, which came in at 4.50. (Hand roll versions are 3, a bit smaller). That alone was actually enough for a dinner, but I felt like I had to sample some of their regular priced wares and I went for a chef's choice of 5 piece nigiri, all of which tasted fantastic. One of my friends also went for the aptly named Extinguisher Roll, which came to our table ablazing. A nice little touch for those who are more adventurous.

Needless to say I like this place I lot. The happy hour prices are fantastic (it gets crowded so get in early so you aren't forced to wait until it's over) and their sushi tastes great. In addition, the place is very much into sustainable seafood, so you won't feel bad environment-wise either eating here. Because of this they serve arctic char instead of salmon, but honestly, they're pretty much the same thing.

Eat up!
author: Roland C.

description:
suuuper GOOD sushi! It's literally right across the street from me. I just moved to pac heights and I am so glad i discovered this spot. Well, I can't take all the credit, I read the reviews through yelp. 

I gave 4 stars because i would rather go to ozumo's then anywhere else in san francisco BUT this place is mad convenient and its not bad, not bad at all. :)

ps. try the mix it? the spicy tuna roll, and the beef carpaccio... delish
author: c g.

description: A nice, classy little sushi restaurant. A little more modern than traditional, but not too sleek and swanky. It's pretty small, space-wise, but intimate and cozy. Service is friendly and attentive. The food was quite good. I love sushi, but am not an extremely knowledgeable connoisseur. I found the rolls to be well-made and tasty though, with a good but not overwhelming menu selection. They definitely get points for their sustainable approach too. A great date restaurant. ;-)
author: Caitlin H.

description:
"Hmmm. You know what this town needs? A sushi restaurant! I mean, there's only 185 sushi places in San Francisco."

That's what I imagined was going through the minds of the owners of Tataki.... BUT!!!! there is a big but here. Tataki is the only sushi place that I know of that claims to be entirely sustainable sushi. In their menu they have a mission statement and they include a reference card for what types of sushi to avoid (at the other 185 restaurants) due to the negative impact on the environment. I was a little bummed because toro, my favorite, was on the "avoid" list. As far as their sushi goes and the prices, it is pretty much standard fare. The location is a quaint and modern spot just a couple of doors down from where I work in Pacific Heights. Being in the industry, sometimes we are able to score some free sushi and who can complain about that? Not me.

BTW. There are actually about 185 sushi restaurants in S.F. I looked it up.
author: Hunter G.

description: Tataki's sushi is really delicious but my reason for the low rating is for how disrespectful the staff can be. The woman working there wouldn't let us pull two tables together and instead of being polite, she decided to yell at us. At the end of our meal we wanted to split the check and when we asked to do that she responded with "No I really can't do that" while slightly rolling her eyes. I thought this was so unnecessary considering many restaurants do this with the check so that really confused me. Even when just walking in, you really receive no greeting or hello. It is really disappointing considering that the food is really good and it has do be viewed lower because of the non-pleasant experience the staff provides.
author: Michala C.

description: The concept of serving sustainable fish is very cool.  However, nothing is cool when poorly executed.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I like it! 

clean, yummy sustainable eats.. Ya, that's what this area needs more of.. Wake-up the neighborhood, cause there ain't much to eat around here.. 
Food, great. 
good lunch deals 
staff cool 
prices, not bad.
author: Dutch B.

description:
I finally was able to check this place out after hearing much about it from my friend, who is such a fan that she is even friends with Tataki on Facebook (yes, the restaurant has its own facebook page...get with the times).  

Anyway, I went with three other people.  We got there early because we knew the place was small, and there was no problem getting seated.

We ordered the cold spinach, seaweed salad, and extinguisher roll to start.  All three were amazing.  Two of us are vegetarians, however, and we were told by the server that there will be a FULL PAGE VEGETARIAN menu next week.  Yay!  The chef offered to make us a couple of the rolls from the NEW menu, and we graciously accepted.

He made us a roll with tons of vegetables in it, that was color coordinated to match the reggae colors of red, yellow, and green.  Oh my god.  Adios, Futomaki, this is my new favorite veggie roll.  Then came what he called Spicy Tofuna, which was VEGAN SPICY TUNA ROLL with tofu.  How awesome is that?!  

We finished everything off with a green tea cheesecake that was delicious.  

All in all, it seems like the trick is to get there early, direct all your questions about what some of the fish are to the servers who are super well informed, and enjoy the amazing food.  Sweet!
author: Christine G.

description: The waiter was not very helpful; however, the chef was very friendly. There is a small menu for special dishes. This is separate from the normal menu so you may want to ask for it.
author: M G.

description: The best sushi I've had in the Bay Area. Right up there with Uzomo ! And the decor is very European, not too fancy but very classy !
author: Zeenat U.

description: It's a quiet, under the radar place, but it serves items you would expect to find at a restaurant of higher scale. The food is fresh and I liked it, but it wasn't impressive. It's a little expensive as well, but they're apparently green, so it's more understandable. It's worth a try.
author: Barrett I.

description:
We came here a couple of months ago...Very good quality fish.    We enjoyed 4 different rolls ( 49er, extinguisher, spicy tempura, golden gate) and all were delectable.    Some of the best that I've had in SF so far.
It is a very small restaurant and I wish it was slightly roomier.  It does feel like your on top of each other... the tables are very close to each other.  However the food certainly makes up for it in my opinion.
Cant wait to come back.
author: Lizete S.

description:
By no means is Tataki the best sushi I have ever had, but it is decent when you are in the mood and it's convenient for me as it's a block from my place. The wait however is not (1 hour on a Wednesday) and the fact that they seat the staff's friends prior to whoever is next on the list is a minus 1 star right there. I don't care how cute the girl is...even if you give her that table first, she's still not going to sleep with you and if she does...ewwwww, be safe! 

The sushi was fresh however I'm not sure how sustainable it was or just a mimic to get peeps in there. It didn't make me sick though! The prices equaled what you got in quantity and quality. If you want cheap sushi that is going to make you sick for days and days, then you are an idiot. 

Also, I don't like how warm they keep the inside of the place. No matter how cold it is outside, sushi restaurants should not be warm!!!! That's another minus 1 star in my book.  It turns me off immediately. But it was clean and the interior was cute 

I wouldn't rush back but it beats Solstice for an evening out with friends or your loved ones. You can actually hear each other and get more food for your money and less douches breathing down your back.
author: Ayrn H.

description:
Wow!  Decided to try this place out and we were delightfully surprised!

Ordered the Sashimi Deluxe platter to start off so we could sample the different nigiri they had.  The white albacore tuna was a slice of heaven.  All the other fish were just clouds to surround that heaven.

You have to try the Double Double.  It's a lightly tempura battered tuna roll with spicy tuna on top. 

Atmosphere was great!  Service was great!  Fish was great!  You get what you pay for!  

I'll be back!
author: John M.

description:
Hm. This place is good, but I've had better sushi. The menu didn't offer much in terms of sushi and sashimi, surprisingly- most of it consisted of appetizers and entrees- but I guess you might like it if the basics are what you're looking for. But I'll definitely go back a second time just in case I missed out on something that would have blown my mind. 

The best thing about this sushi joint was the excellent waitress... she was friendly and knowledgeable about the sake selection. While we waited in the front of the restaurant for a table, she brought us drinks and made sure to check in with us a couple of times. I'm not by any means a sake aficionado, so she brought a couple samples for us to try. Nice!
author: Suzi G.

description:
4.5 stars?  Highly Questionable. 3.5 at best.  I give it 2.

Great, a sustainable menu.  This does not mean good sushi, if anything, there is less selection.  The pieces of sashimi were very fresh but does giving me small piece of fish make our environment healthier, or their sushi joint more eco friendly? Maybe.  I'm all for the environment, but I like fresh, large pieces of Sashimi. It is the food chain baby.

Presentation was great- but skip the b.s. I eat sushi for quality and quantity not for the aesthetic beauty. Go to Muir woods or the Japanese gardens for that.  Maybe if they cut down on the time spent shaving the carrots into flowers, my food would have come faster, thus more customers- equalling more revenue to spend on making my sashimi bigger! ROAR!

Service was good- they pampered us and kept asking how everything was.... i struggled barely bringing forth a grimace, as my stomach growled for bigger pieces!!!!
