In summary, the sashimi was small. Big pieces of sashimi is why i eat sushi if you can't tell.  

If you are a crunchy nut that gets off to eating sustainable food, this is your place. 

I on the other hand will go to Sushi Bistro next time.
author: Peter G.

description: I started this review three weeks ago, but Yelp's stupid policy on using your mobile app to write reviews means I'm finishing it three weeks later, unable to remember any of the details besides what I wrote on the mobile phone at the time. We ate the following: iwana (Arctic char), seared Spanish mackerel (sawara), aji, iwashi (sardine, out), uni, albacore tataki, tuna tataki salad, double-double roll, golden state roll. I remember generally that all of it was outstanding as sushi and sashimi: fresh, tasty, etc. Tataki also has the policy of only using sustainable fish, either wild caught or farmed. So you feel good and it tastes good!
author: Stewart A.

description:
Had lunch there this afternoon with a friend. Great! 

Elegant little sushi house that combines amazing sushi (I had the Califonia and Spicy Tuna roles, miso, and seaweed salad) and business practices around sustainable fishing. 

Loved the article posted on the wall on "The End of Sushi."

I'll be going there again and taking others.
author: Brooks J.

description: I have the utmost respect for these entrepreneurs for creating this masterpiece of a restaurant that simultaneously combines eco-friendliness with delicious. This is not "tree-hugger food": no rubbery tofu or fake fish. It's the real deal.....done smart. Using fish that the Monterrey Aquarium says is not endangered, the chefs integrate creative spices and vegetables very well. You will have a delicious meal, and at the same time promote eco-sensitivity. The $5 drinks during happy hour are also delicious and creative. One negative: the waiter/employee with the ponytail and large framed glasses is obnoxiously rude. Cross your fingers he isn't your waiter.
author: Carla C.

description:
I've been curious for a while, so I decided to drop in for dinner.  The restaurant itself is cute with just a handful of tables.  I also love what the restaurant stands for - green, healthy, sustainable sushi - and appreciate the happy hour specials.  You can get a selection of cut rolls for $4.50 or handrolls for $3.00.  

So why 3 stars?  As Nutmeg Y noted, the food is just *eh.*  I started with a special Albacore nigiri.  My first piece was tough and stringy, the second piece was good, but I didn't really want it after having eaten the first one.  I then had the crunchy spicy tuna roll - it wasn't fried, but was topped with some crunchy thingies.  It also was not particularly spicy.  I then had the Arctic chard and Avocado roll, which was the best item I had, but not worth the drive across town.

I also really didn't like all of the preachy materials everywhere.  I saw at least four brochures telling me what kind of fish I should and should not be eating.  Being sustainable is great, but please don't pontificate while I'm eating. Oh, and its expensive.

I might be back since it's in the 'hood and there was a line of people waiting to get in when I left.
author: She-Ra ..

description: Tiny place that fills up quick. Service is generally ok...sometimes it seems the staff leave tables open a while even though a wait. Sushi is nicely prepared, fresh, good roll variety. Prices are ok, but if you can hit happy hour there are a few deals. Some of the best calamari I've had!
author: Rice C.

description: Sashimi is outstanding - Arctic Char is OUTSTANDING.  Not sure about other posts but our service was Fast and Friendly.  could use a better wine list, but no big deal!
author: Todd G.

description: Intimate little place on California/Divis... and the best sushi I've ever had! It's tiny, so expect to wait for a table, but it's worth the wait... We tried a couple of different rolls and all were so good I couldn't figure out which one I liked best. Highly recommend.
author: Brian S.

description:
Sushi here was solid. Sat at the sushi bar and had mostly nigiri. The fish was fresh, and although the rice was well made, the proportion of rice to fish was much too high. I felt like I was eating rice balls all night. 

The best dish of the evening was aji takaki. I figured, if they're called Takaki, they should have great tataki!! And although it was not on the menu, it was my favorite dish of the evening.
author: tessie n.

description:
Probably the best sushi in Lower Pac Heights. 

I actually was a bit skeptical about the whole "we were the first sustainable sushi restaurant" marketing because I just figured that would raise prices and reduce the range of product they could source.  But it turns out you can enjoy your sushi and know you're not causing the extinction of a species.

A few things to note:
1. Happy hour is pretty solid here, but unfortunately it's just for a subset of rolls, and...
2. I think the best stuff they have here is the sashimi. It's really fresh and consistently tasty. I'll usually go with a friend or two and get the sashimi deluxe.  They usually bring out a standard selection of fish (e.g., arctic char, albacore tuna, scallop, sea bream), and it's decent, but I like to ask for a wider variety and non-traditional items.  Usually they'll have some stuff they can pull out for you if you're adventurous (e.g., mackerel last time was really great) so it can't hurt to ask what else they have that might be special for that day.
3. There's the possibility of a pretty long wait, as others have noted.  Get there, put your name on the list, and if it looks like it'll be a while, just go down the street to Divisadero and grab a drink - there are lots of different types of options (e.g., Solstice, Lion Pub, Fish Bowl).
author: John H.

description:
I feel foolish for not coming here sooner. What a delightful dinner last night with the hubby.

We arrived early and snagged a great little table by the window. Our server was friendly without being overly so and knowledgeable about the menu. She was rather patient since it took us a while to order and we didn't order all at once.

We had, a salmon special (steelhead from Canada I believe) that was melt in you mouth amazing goodness. We had to go for a second round of that. Tuna and Kampachi Nigiri as well. Since my husband loves rolls we also had the 49er (made with artic char, yum), the tempura shrimp and the spicy tuna. I'm off of spicy tuna, it's so hit or miss for me and the tempura shrimp was good but, not nearly as outstanding as the 49er. I would almost always have nigiri over a roll though. The seaweed salad we shared was one of the best I've had in ages. 

We will definitely be coming back.
author: J B.

description:
Love the food and the staff!

The sushi chef was kind enough to cater to my mum's very vegetarian requests. Thank you!
author: A T.

description:
I had to wait close to 2 hours to get dinner here on a Saturday night and they don't take reservations. The problem with this area is that you can't just walk away to another Asian food joint because there aren't any good ones. So minus half a star for that. I wish I could minus 3 stars for the people who see a line out the door but still sit at the tables to chatter but that isn't the restaurant's fault. Just poor upbringing.

Amazing range of vegetarian sushi instead of the usual futomaki. Overall, an excellent fusion Japanese restaurant.

I also managed to have some entertainment for the night. There was a lady sitting at a table in front of mine with her back facing to me. I think she might have had one too many but her tiny little mini skirt rode up half way past her rear end. She also had friends with her who 'didn't' bother to tell her about her mooning situation. So if you're a little bit of a germaphobe and they sit you on the 4 seater table by the door...you might want to wipe the seats down.
author: Jacinta H.

description: We went to Tataki late on a Friday night. I called ahead about 20 mins and they actually had our table ready for us. I was looking for very basic sushi flavors, and while they have many complicated rolls, there are items for those that just like the simple flavors of sushi. The fish was extremely fresh, there was an appetizer special of Tuna Belly (or something) that the waitress recommended, and was right on. The place is definitely reasonably priced for the quality. Highly recommended.
author: Matt R.

description:
After going to the web 2.0 conference, my group decided we wanted sushi. The prices were very reasonable (had enough sushi to fill a somewhat hungry group and 2 bottles of sake for 30 dollars a person including tip) and the food was delicious. The place is very small (and somewhat crowded) and the waitress came by to check on us every so often.

The extinguisher was good. Another great roll was the sweet potatoe roll. Another roll that was great but the name escapes me. There was hot sauce put on the plate like flames and the roll was made of jalapenos and tuna. The dessert was average, we had the green tea cheesecake. A bit too dry for my taste.
author: Paul V.

description:
The food was great - the sushi was fresh and subtle, and the plating was excellent.  It was also great to know that the fish came from appropriately caught and renewable sources, though you do miss some of the sushi classics.   

They do have a long sake menu which is also worth exploring.

I wasn't impressed at all by their desserts - 1 or 2 stars at best - they just didn't seem to have the fight flavor or texture, except for the traditional mochi.

I also didn't like the service - it wasn't bad but our server wasn't really attentive or friendly at all.  I don't think the tiny but overcrowded room really helped either.
author: S C.

description:
Let me just say - i LOVE THIS PLACE! I have only been there once- but I will definitely be going back. I am new to raw fish sushi- finally got the nerve up with a friend who taught me all about it. AND I LOVE SUSHI NOW! So yummy. But everytime I put a piece of himachi (my new favorite) and tuna- all I can think of is how much mercury is going into my body. 

When I found Tataki- I was like OMG. Totally San Francisco to make an environmentally friendly sushi bar. Duh.

So when you walk in, there are Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood/Sushi watch cards all over the place,  for people to look at while eating and take with them when they leave. It tells you which types of sushi are better on the world and on your body. YAY!!!!!!!

I had the "extinguisher" and can be a bit of wimp with super spicy stuff- even though i really like a bit of spice on my food. It was perfect. It came to table with part of the plate on fire. That was rad. Then we had the Sashimi Taster- and everything on it was delicious! We also had this thing with scallops and apples- I wasn't a big fan but my dinner date loved loved loved it. As I am new to raw sushi- I just put it as me learning what I like and don't like. I like spicy and could skip the sweet. oooooohhhh---- the extinguisher. I could have eaten that all night. 

Other than all the WONDERFUL WONDERFUL things i feel and think about this place- there was only one reason I would ever go to another sushi place again. Unfortunately, because of their limitations on what kinds of fish they can serve responsibly - their menu is also relatively limited. It is very important to me to be responsible in my choices about where my food comes from- so this place is definitely going to be on my must go back and often  list.
author: Jill S.

description:
When I came to Tataki, I was immediately concerned about getting my environmentally un-conscious fatty tuna, or Big eye Tuna.

My fears were quickly allayed by the excellent variety of "green" fish that I could eat without feeling like I was raping the ocean.

I started dinner at 8:30pm with the Kumomoto oysters (sp),...fresh, succulent morsels of silky goodness; a touch of green onion with a soy/maybe rice vinegar finish that is such a nice change from the typical lemon/horseradish/cocktail sauce malay.

I had the chefs choice of both Nigiri and Sashimi....both delightful and well priced.  I took a staff recommendation of of a silky, unfiltered, moderately sweet 10 dollar bottle of sake and within 20 minutes, I was feeling pretty warm and appreciative of the friendly and close quartered tables that allowed u to figure out what you would order next....

I followed up with a roll...forgot the name, but it was a spicy tuna roll with a artistic sliver of himachi, wasabi, and sirachi tear.  I am not a roll dude, but i really enjoyed this.... alaht.

The service I received was so hospitable, I almost felt like the lady helping me was enjoying the food as much as I was.   

Good job Tataki!

Warning:   Sushi connoisseurs, please note, you will not get all the typical things u expect from a 4 + start sushi shop.  You have to come here with an open heart and mind to "substitute" your fish of choice with something slightly different.  I have been sushiing up for 20 years and I really enjoyed this experience.  Give it a try!
author: Sam K.

description: I guess the fact that the sushi is "sustainable" is a plus, but I wouldn't be raving about this place if it weren't also the freshest, tastiest, and most well presented sushi I have had.  The spicy tofuna roll, the extinguisher roll, and the "tataki specials" (like sushi tapas) are all superb.  A bit pricey, but worth every penny.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
If you're wondering where to go for sushi tonight. Look no further. Your search is over.
Tataki is pretty much everything I like in a restaurant-

Great staff, comfortable environment, cool design, environmentally conscious, creative menu, and delicious delicious food.

Good for a date or good for a group. The Waitress was amazing. She was running the whole place by herself and still managed to be personal and attentive. Even though it's a bit small, it's comfy.

Be sure to try the Fillet Mignon, Pineapple and Asparagus roll...  trust me, it's goooooood.
author: Cole S.

description:
Seriously- I am  really amazed at how many people still lack the knowledge of good sushi...  Especially in San Francisco.  My wife and I sat at the bar.  I know both the chefs from previously working with them at another sushi bar.  One good and one has no business rolling sushi.  We had ordered Omakase.  My wife ordered a salad off the menu.  How is it a restaurant like this gets good reviews and the salad was horrid. 
When buying spring mix from a box there are a couple of basic rules to apply.  WASH IT!!! WASH IT!!. In cold water and vinegar.  This does two things.  Brings it back to life from the dead, and gets rid of all the dirt, sand and bugs... then pick through it to make sure no slimee lettuce is included. And spin it!!! Seriously if you cant get a simple salad right and skip three simple steps to make your salad at least edible what does this say about your establishment??  Please do not take the spring mix out of the box and throw it in the bowl and dress it!!!!
As far as the sushi, it was ok.
author: Ed M.

description:
I was visiting San Fran staying at a friend's house just down the street.  He had just moved in and didn't know a lot about the area, so we turned to Yelp to find a dinner spot.  What a great find.

I got the mix it up roll, which was great.  My friend also liked his rolls, but I can't speak to the other kinds of food.  Our dessert, green tea cheesecake, was mediocre.  Service was spotty, but it wasn't too awful.  Also, what a great credo for a restaurant!  One star extra just for that.  Very well priced, and we ended up going back for dinner two nights later.
author: Liz A.

description: Very tasty, and as fresh as it gets. Them supporting sustainable fishing is also very nice. A very small place, be ready to wait for your table a long time, but it's worth it (more than 40 mins for a party of 3). Service is nice and friendly. Good ambiance.
author: Maria M.

description:
So, I am torn.  The first experience I had was so so.  The signature roll was way to spicy, even with the warning.

On my last return, I was actually excited the very wide variety of unique nigiri/sashimi options.  The meal was great, except for one complaint.  The nigiri were a bit warm.  Now I dont mean cooked warm, but it was almost as if the chef had held them in his hands too long or had put them on rice that was still a bit warm.  I know its not a major issue, hence still the good rating, but it seemed to take a little away from the fish.
author: Markus S.

description:
4.5 Stars

As a sushi connoisseur, I have indulged in fish of all kinds in many restaurants, in multiple cities, and in a few different countries. Still working to find THE Best sushi is SF, I have slowly but surely been trying the highest rated Japanese restaurants. Tataki did not disappoint. The fish was very fresh (which the most basic necessity), the restaurant was clean, the service was excellent, and the prices were decent. The reason i didn't give Tataki 5 stars was that it just didn't have the WOW! factor. Although, I will be back! Excellent excellent sushi! A perfect "everyday" sushi restaurant in its class, but simply not THE best sushi in SF. My search continues...
author: Matt D.

description:
Seriously, blown away, Never before have I been able to get so many answers about where a fish comes from and how it was farmed/caught. It always frustrates me that I can't know where what I am eating came from. Especially fish. 

Everything was delicious. it was busy but the service was still attentive. This place is going to blow up. And that's a good thing. ALL restaurants should strive to be this ethical and of course, sustainable.  

Happy hour is a steal.
author: Julie H.

description:
I wanted to try a new sushi joint and found Tataki, with its high Yelp ratings, as numero uno on my list to try!  Sustainable sushi?  Ok, yeah, that's important, I guess.  But talk to me about TASTE, baby!  

This place is so good.  I swear, I am not a sushi snob.  I'll eat pretty much anything as long as it doesn't make me sick.  But the food here just TASTES fresher!  The seaweed salad is delicious.  The miso soup is gleefully without that gritty MSG taste.  And the sushi?  Let's just sing a round of "hallelujahs" over the Tataki roll and the Mix it Up roll.  

Really, really good stuff.  

Get there early.  It gets busy...quick.  Let's just say...5:30 on a rainy Saturday and already a packed house.
author: Susan L.

description:
Gem of a sushi restaurant in Pac Heights. Seats less than 40 but that's the way a quality sushi bar should be. Kudos for creating a 100% sustainable sushi menu.

Their tataki selection has some great hits but I would avoid most of the sauces that they recommend pairing each with. The chili oil and garlic sauces are a bit much and cover up the flavors of the fish. Ponzu was enough for all of them.

Nigiri is solid, although I prefer a bit of a firmer texture in my rice with a bit more seasoning and more of the moisture fanned out. Chefs are very friendly and knowledgeable. 

One of my fave places in the city for sushi now!

Recommendations: Tataki sampler, sanma shioyaki, uni, pretty much anything.

Conclusion: Eat well, sleep well.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I tried this place last night with my brother. He and I are definitely sushi aficionados having started at a young age and always been willing to spend for the best. So, after years of the same generic salmon, yellowtail, hamachi, ebi, tombiko, mackerel, combinations I was excited about trying some different fish that was sustainable. 

We arrived for the Happy hour ordered: the two specials, (halibut and fatty albacore),  then off the happy hour menu a veggie roll, spicy tuna roll, and the artic char roll.

Everything was really good and fresh! Especially the specials!! It was so fresh that it had the crisp, but melty quality that is difficult to achieve. The veggie roll was ordered as a filler roll, but was light and tasty. The artic chard was more of a typical salmon, avocado roll that was standard, but guilt-free! The crunchy spicy tuna isn't something i would normally get because I try to avoid tempura at all cost,  but it turned out to be one of my favorites, since it wasn't oily and seemed to form a symbiotic relationship with the tuna.  By far the Nigiri specials were the best! 

For dessert we shared the coffee jello with Kahula--soooo good!! To top it all off we also ordered some unfiltered sake and some beer very reasonably priced. 

We escaped with about a $50 dollar bill for the two of us. So reasonable!

what really placed this place above others was the clean/modern atmosphere, kind people and good service.An additional plus is that everything that everyone else in the room was ordering looked really good too!  I can't wait to go back I am planning on becoming a regular. 

Also there were plenty of Vegetarian and some vegan options on the menu which is also a plus in my book.
author: M B.

description:
Great sushi - fresh, delicious, tasty, all positive adjectives to describe good food

Affordable - go during the happy hour (nightly till 7 p.m.)! Super cheap sushi in price, but high in quality

Great vibe - nice decor, great food presentation, great for a casual date

And to top it all, it's all environmentally friendly seafood!

I love you fish! Thank you for being tasty and my dinner.
author: Bo J.

description: So I'm a regular, or used to be.  Call to order take out.  She says can I place you on hold for one minute.  Ten minutes later I hang up still on hold.  20 minutes later the phone is still busy, they never picked up.  Should be zero stars. Never will go again.
author: P S.

description:
Dude. Dude. DUDE.

BEST EVER. SRSLY.

Everything is *fresh*, with sparkles. Each fish is chosen for *freshness*, sustainability, and low levels of mercury. It's so good! I seriously have to stop myself from licking the plate.

Also, they have a roll that is made of.. steak. Yes, steak, with asparagus and some other stuff. The carnivore in me is simply delighted. But, don't worry about what to order here, you pretty much can't go wrong. Everything is delicious.

ESPECIALLY THE EFFING GREEN TEA CHEESECAKE.

Lastly, they are very affordable for what it is. The portions are spot on, not super huge but definitely not little. The bill for 2 is usually around $60. Also, be sure to use their bathroom while you're here. The mirror is round with a light outlining it, so when you look into it, it gives you spooky alien eyes.

My only disappointment was when I came here for lunch one time. At lunch, their menu is much smaller and not nearly as interesting, although I must stress that it's still really delicious. I guess it's more of a dinner spot anyway.

But still! OMG!
author: Rachel H.

description: Liked the food, however, it is a very small place that plays loud music in the backround that makes you want to get up and leave.  If you are on a date or wish to have a civil conversation then forget it, look for a different restaurant.
author: A A.

description:
Yum! I went to Tataki tonight to explore their new vegetarian menu and I was very pleased. The mixed vegetable salad was huge, with asparagus, orange cherry tomatoes, carrot, and cucumber, along with a generous pile of roasted cashews and an apple dressing quite unlike anything I've ever tasted before. 

I ordered the futomaki and the spicy tofuna roll. The futomaki was very good, and the spicy tofuna roll was terrific. It's cucumber and tofu mixed with something (spicy vegan mayo, I believe, but I can't swear it was vegan) that really made it taste fantastic. I sat at the sushi bar by myself and the sushi chefs were attentive and charming and took the time to answer all my questions. I also asked them to recommend the best fish for a single order of nigiri and they gave me two pieces of kampachi that were buttery-soft and fresh, over some of the best sushi rice I've had in this town.

Their other veggie rolls sound creative and delicious, a real boon for vegetarians who like creative, US-style rolls filled with goodies but are normally confined to futomaki alone for their fix. Unfortunately, most of the other rolls contained various tempura'd veggies, and, since they prepare their veggie tempura in the same oil as their tempura shrimp, and I'm allergic to shrimp, I wasn't able to try any of them.  

I love that they are committed to sustainability. It's high time a sushi place focused on this, since the global fish situation is getting dire. The one drawback was that there was a large party there, and the small restaurant quickly got very loud. But the waitress seemed as annoyed/amused as I was by how loud it was, and struggled her way through the crowd to refill my tea again and again, so I really have no complaints. 

The other thing bummer is they have a delicious sounding coffee jello with kahlua cream for dessert, but they make it with actual gelatin jello! The Japanese are the masters of making jelly-desserts using seaweeds and rice - it's too bad they couldn't make this in a vegetarian version. I had the kinyako mochi which was tasty and beautifully prepared, though I don't think it will become a favorite. Tataki will, though. I will definitely be going back!
author: Scrumptious S.

description:
Sashimi/nigiri - 5 stars
Rolls - 3 stars
Service - 2 stars 

The fish is fresh, but there are a lot of places in the city with fresh fish. Rolls are nothing to write home about. Service sucks. Waiters avoid eye contact at all costs. I am not used to raising my voice to get attention, but I felt that was the only way I could get through. I won't be back.
author: Andre D.

description: I guess the big thing here is that they use sustainable fish. In my opinion, I don't really care. The sushi was really mediocre for the price. The portions were very small. I was really hoping for something better since my girlfriend lives right across the street. We wanted to find a solid sushi option for our monthly rotation. The search continues...
author: Andrew C.

description:
Yum!! It had been a long time since I had gone out for sushi, and instead of Hamano (the usual pick, if we ever went), we chose Tataki.

It was a Friday night at about 6:30 and we found parking easily. We walked in and the place was packed. The server told us to put our names down, but we had to wait 20 minutes. It wasn't that bad, but it is a small place and we were squashed into a corner.

When we finally sat down at the bar and looked at the menu, my mouth was already watering. We ordered a few different rolls and a seaweed salad, which were made right in front of us. It was obvious everything was very fresh. The sushi and salad were simply divine and could not have been better. The prices were also great for the quality.

I would highly recommend this place! The inside is lovely and the food will make you leave happy, guaranteed. A great spot to check out!
author: Catherine L.

description:
Super Fresh sushi.  The extinguisher roll came out with a fire and was super spicy and good. 
The happy hour has a great selection of sushi for half the price. 
I like how they tell you what fish is fresh or farm raised.
author: John c.

description:
Had a great dinner here with a couple friends -- the wait was not bad, even on a Saturday night (about 10 minutes at 9pm).  Serious props as they are really working the sustainable sushi angle - they even have the "safe" list from Monterey Bay Aquarium on the tables. And, the fish is great - super fresh and quality.  They have a range of interesting, creative rolls, including some vegetarian rolls that promise a lot of flavor.

The tuna poke three ways was great -- two of the three ways were awesome, the other was ok.  The nigiri and sashimi were awesome. We did have the roll with the gold, and one os the spicy rolls -- when they say spicy, they mean it! The veggies rolls were not as impressive as I had hoped, but still good.
author: Danielle R.

description: Golden State, 49er, extinguisher and spicy tempura roll are the best. Golden State is my favorite. This place was awesome and I would go back in a heart beat.
author: Melissa O.

description: I came here just yesterday . I had the arctic char roll with avacodo which was very delicious . I also had a few different nigiri and the chefs special nigiri plate which all tasted pretty good . Oh, and their miso soup was very good ... not too salty , not too bland .
author: Eileen L.

description:
best selection of sashimi i've seen in a really long time.  faves:

-tai snapper (todai) - absolute favorite
-barramundi (akame)
-beef carpaccio
-green tea cheese cake (i dont usually like cheesecake but this was good)

not bads:
-extinguisher roll and spicy tuna roll

blah:
-kona kampachi tataki - more like 99%seared, 1% raw and the flavor got drowned out by the ponzu/tobiko sauce and avocado slices
author: Priscilla T.

description: Tataki is by far one of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city.  The sushi is super fresh and I have never been disappointed with anything I've ordered.  They have unique rolls that are so delish!  The sashimi is amazing and I recommend ordering the specials when they're available.  The space is small so if you go during prime time, be prepared to wait, but I promise it is well worth the wait!
author: Keri W.

description: 3 stars because the food and philosophy (?) are both cool.  The service sucks though, at least it did when the hostess gave my table away and tried to play it off by offering us us a smaller and lamer one with a quick wait, saying the people would be out soon (they had just gotten their food and ended up staying for hours drinking, which they have every right to do, but the hostess shouldn't offer it and lie).  It also took forever when it shouldn't have.  The hostess may have been stressed out, it is a small room.  She still lied, though.
author: Jack M.

description:
I really, really appreciate service that doesn't make you feel rushed, even when people are lined up waiting and crammed into a tiny space. Our server was kind, patient, and even walked over the other side of the table to hear me so I didn't have to shout over the big loud guy in the corner. 

Good specialty rolls - the Extinguisher, Pacific Sunrise (no rice), and tempura shrimp. Can't recommend the multi-seaweed salad unless you crave vinegar, which I definitely do not like. 

Good atmosphere, good sushi, good service. If you want cheap sushi, keep walkin' to Japan Town. If you want intimate dining and good sushi without pretension, go here! Makes me wish I still lived in walking distance :(
author: Marina Maven C.

description: We came here for dinner on Friday night and had a good experience. The restaurant itself is very small and does not accept reservations. I loved that they had so many vegetarian options and supported sustainable sushi. They also have a good happy hour (5-7pm) menu if you can get there in time. I got the avocado roll which was good, hard to go wrong, and a specialty reggae roll which was pretty good, wasn't anything to write home about. You have to be patient with their service as there's 2 waitresses who run the place and 2 sushi chefs.
author: H T.

description:
It was great, I dig the sustainable thing, and it becomes a topic of conversation, because there's bound to be someone in your party that wants something, they just don't have. I think that's cool, and the staff is very polite about it. 
The presentation is excellent, and the happy hour makes it all worth while. 
Give it a try, and put your destiny in the Chef's hands and see what they come up with; you won't regret it!
author: Robert L.

description:
Sparkle my Sake!

Ok so, my visit to Tataki starts when my very loud, 8 foot tall best friend (teeheehee) and I walk in, get seated and started to order the entire menu.  Of course, having read and memorized ALL the reviews on Yelp, I started with the Sparkling Sake.  I think I drank about 4 bottles.  I already have an addictive personality and It's just sooooooo good when it touches your lips!!!!  I couldn't help myself!

Double my Double!

As for sushi, we ordered the:

Extinguisher (spicy amberjack topped with avocado, habanero masago, hot sauce)
Reggae Roll (asparagus tempura, cucumber, topped with
avocado, tomato and shaved pumpkin)
Philadelphia Roll (smoked salmon, avocado, cream cheese)
Spicy Tuna Roll
and the Cu da Gra
Double-Double (tempura and spicy tuna sprinkled with
sesame seeds and a few secrets)

We finished up with the mochi and green tea cheesecake.

YUM!  YUM!  YUM! YUM!  YUM!  YUM!

I don't think they can do ANYTHING badly at Tataki!  Everything was sheer perfection on my plate...and in my belly!

The customer service was AWESOME too!
author: Karla F.

description:
I'm still not sure what a 100% sustainable restaurant means, but I'm sure it's a good thing--that and the arctic char sashimi rocked my socks.  Also, try the gold rush roll...apples in sushi with GOLD?!?  soo good!

It's a teeny tiny place, and we arrived around 7:30 with a little bit of a wait, but nothing unbearable.  The place is super lound with a weird ambient music in the background, making it a little hard to hear the person sitting 2 feet away from you (not exactly the restaurant's fault though...).  Do yourself a favor and stop by Tataki if you're in the area- you can't regret it!
author: Dima A.

description:
Absolutely delicious! i definitely second the other reviews with how amazing the vegetarian options are! Try the ratatouille and the spicy tofuna! Absolutely out of this world! They have the typical sweet potato tempura and cucumber but there's definitely creativity to the list! I knocked a star because some of the staff came off  pretty snooty with an ounce of friendliness- not needed in a neighborhood vibe..
tip: they have a great happy hour menu between 4-7, put ur name on the list as the space is very very tiny, but the wait is def worth it!
author: sue c.

description:
Why aren't all sushi restaurants like this?

Only sustainable fish, so you don't feel like you're eating the last goddamn piece of whatever species on the planet.

Awesomely fresh.  Some inventive offerings, but the core is amazing fresh sushi and sashimi.

Small, dark, a bit noisy.

But so much better than all those cheap sushi joints all over town that serve fish from god knows where, sourced god knows how.

Tataki rules!!!
author: tim p.

description: Very small restaurant, probably seats about 20. The food was good, sashimi was fresh. The service was great! The waiter was very nice and attentive. It's more of a locals place, the waiter seemed to know some of the customers, probably regulars.
author: Jennie K.

description:
Love the vibe, the music, the tiny space, and the fresh, delicious ingredients, but Tataki is not without its flaws.

We showed up at around 8:30 on a Friday night and waited nearly 45 minutes for a table for 2. Yes, I was starving by then.

Once seated, the service was good. The menu, while very inviting, did seem to be about 60% tuna/albacore, which I found odd.  We had some oysters to start, which were delicious but one of the four we were served was about the size of a quarter. Umm, thanks. 

The nigiri and rolls were all quite good, although I found the Divisaderoll to be a bit too stuffed with fish. Overall, I really enjoyed dinner. For desert, we shared the matcha cheese cake. Now that was wonderful!
author: Ricki M.

description:
The sushi is awesome! Unfortunately, they do not take reservations, the place is way too small, and the front "desk" (there is a pen and pad to check yourself in when you get there) is awful. People arrive, write their names down, but then don't know what to do next? stand outside? wait for a hostess that never shows up? there is no bar or waiting area, so you have to wait, rain or shine, outside of the restaurant.

They are always busy, and like I said, the sushi is great, but because of the service and the size of the place, it is not worth the hassle. Plenty of other good sushi places to go to in the city. Do not DARE go on a Friday or Saturday night, you'll be highly disappointed once you arrive, not a good start to a weekend.
author: Sandra R.

description:
It is with a heavy heart and no small amount of trepidation that I give my first five-star rating. Alas, I cannot find fault with Tataki. It's the finest sushi experience I've ever had.

Every piece of fish was simply sublime -- as close to melt-in-the-mouth as I can imagine. The rolls were inventive without being obnoxious -- not to mention orgasmically delicious.

The presentation was impeccable. The service, professional: attentive without being intrusive, with each order somehow arriving just after the last one was finished.

The evening's menu looked like this:

Chef's choice sashimi (12 pc) ($19)
Mix-it-up ($11)
Golden State ($15)
Uni ($8)
Aji ($6.5)
Shiro Maguro ($5)
Ebi ($5.5)
Hotate ($6)
Divisadero Roll with tuna ($6.5)
Large Sapporo ($6.5)
Sparkling sake (gratis on account of my companion's birthday)

$105 for two bellies full of sustainably-caught, impossibly fresh, insanely tasty fish? Oh yes. I will be back.

The space is very small (and humid -- a bit of ventilation would have been nice), with only four seats at the bar, maybe seven two-tops and probably another two or three four-tops.The lighting is soft and the music is cool: the perfect ambiance for devouring the magnificence of Tataki's wares. We waited only five minutes on a Saturday at 8 PM. But in hindsight, I would have been willing to wait an hour. Or two.

I literally dreamed about Tataki that night.
author: David B.

description:
Blew our socks off!!!

Very fresh and delicious sushi. Great presentations, excellent service. A fantastic place for a date. Best dining experience we've had in ages. Not to mention, sustainable fish! Is that why the sushi was so delicious? We had the sashimi plate, rainbow rolls, Extinguisher and Sunrise. 

My only complaint is that we did not receive complimentary edamame (other yelpers did) and the mussel appetizer only had two mussels on it. For $6, I expected at least 4 mussels. Other than that, everything was fantastic!

A little spendy for us, ($90 for two people with tip) but totally worth it.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
Great place to go! My new favorite sushi place because it is:

1 Affordable
2 Happy hour?! I was lucky enough to come in at 6:30 and happy hour is 5-7. Tried the crispy cali roll and the artic char. Which brings me to...
3 Arctic Char roll was fabulous. Never had one before, but there is no overly "fishy" taste to it, and it has a great texture.
4 Miso soup was best I had, although nothing to extraordinary. It really is the little things

Cons:
1 Small place, although we sat down right away at 630 on a Tuesday night
2 I don't live in San Francisco...

Go there, get some cheap beers and mixed sake drinks plus eat really good sushi!
author: David G.

description: Seriously delish. Great, quality sushi that is interesting and DELISH. I did take-out and watched the chefs make mine and about 5 other meals in front of me...they are ARTISTS! Yum.
author: Kirsten B.

description: Great veggie options. Good atmosphere. Delicious food. Will come back for more.
author: William B.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants I've ever been to.

We just found this place a couple of weeks ago and have been there 3 times since then. The sushi is incredibly fresh, the prices are very reasonable and the service is excellent.  It is a very small place so for larger groups, expect to wait a bit, but it is totally worth it.
author: Lauren V.

description:
i don't think i've ever had sushi this good. i'm a simple girl, california rolls and spicy tuna rolls are my calling, but coming here was quite the experience. 

i had spent an awesome adventurous day in the city with my boyfriend and our two other friends on a double date of sorts. dinner rolled around and we decided we wanted sushi, this place was brought up and we decided to all check it out, plus it had a "michelin recommended" sticker on the window so we HAD to try it. everything worked out  perfectly, i left completely satisfied! the sushi was amazing, the one roll with the fire on the plate was more deliciousness than my mouth could handle.

go here if you have the chance. it'll blow your mind.
author: Angie L.

description: Food is good, but the main waitress has a sassy, moody demeanor and is very unprofessional.  She needs an attitude adjustment.
author: cristina m.

description: I come eat here at least once a month. It's my favorite sushi place in San Francisco. They have a good variety of sake. The sushi is really well made and the fish always tastes amazing. I have ordered for pick up as well and it's just as great. The only downside is it's quite small so during busy days you usually have to wait a half hour to an hour. The one time we waited an hour they gave us a free appetizer but it's always worth the wait.
author: stephanie w.

description: Arrived before the crowd but worth the wait as many seem to do.  The place is exceptionally small but delicious.  I loved the char carpaccio, green dragon and the brown rice tea.  Also, I appreciate that they are a sustainable sushi restaurant with good service.  I will definitely eat here again!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I'm not hating on Subway, but I am thrilled that it's gone and Tataki has taken its place. I dropped in here last night excited to check it out as it has only been open since Tuesday. I was going to get a few things to go since I was by myself, but there was a seat in the corner and the sushi bar and I figured why not...I'll get the full experience so I can decide if I love it or hate it. 

I agree with the other reviews - the tortilla chips and ceviche/shrimp salsa/whatever is a little strange, but interesting nonetheless. But the fish is outstanding. Whenever I check out a new sushi place, I usually de-virginize my experience by ordering only nigiri on the first visit. Anyone can make a decent roll if you put enough stuff in it, but if the fish isn't fresh the place isn't worth it.

Tataki is definitely worth it.

I asked the sushi chef for a few recommendations and all were excellent. The albacore was melt-in-your-mouth fresh with just a tad of garlic sauce on top. He gave me a hamachi/kampachi combo order and explained the difference - both great with a preference towards the hamachi (a little softer). Arctic char was another recommendation - similar to salmon but darker and less oily - really fresh. I asked about the aji, which he said was on the stronger side of fishy, so he gave me one piece to let me try it out. He was right - it was still good and fresh, but not my favorite. I had more albacore!

They have some really interesting specialties - a lot of tataki (go figure) and the rolls sound really yummy (esp. the extinguisher if you like spicy) so I look forward to checking them out next time.

The sushi chef is really friendly, the service was decent (could have been a little better but it's only been three days!) and the atmosphere is relaxing...very zen...but the place is pretty small. Only about 20 seats and another 4 at the sushi bar.

Tataki is a great addition to Pac Heights and a totally different (and better but more expensive) experience than Osaka, Godzila, Toraya, etc...
author: Kate S.

description:
We were planning on going to our usual neighborhood sushi spot, Godzila, but when we went there there was a long line and for some reason the place just stank.  We decided to look for somewhere else and this place came up in our google search of nearby sushi restaurants.

We decided to take the risk, and I think we came out ahead.  On the plus side, the sushi here is amazing.  The fish is fresh and delicious, the sustainability thing is a nice bonus and the service was just about average.  The only big downside of this place is that the prices are pretty high (-1 star).

I'm planning on going back for another look at the place, just to make sure it's as good as I remember it being.  As other posters have mentioned - the Extinguisher rolls are excellent!
author: Jonah H.

description:
Let me see if this works - read my review on Fuku.  Tataki is Fuku with modern decor and a really friendly staff that communicates clearly.  They serve until 11 most nights.  It is quickly becoming my new favorite for the highest quality fish in SF.  Tataki also serves only the types of seafood that are considered healthy and also sustainable.  Absolutely will not detract from an amazing sushi experience, in fact I found it enhancing.

LET ME ADD TO MY ORIGINAL POSTING - AS EXPECTED I'VE BEEN BACK MANY TIMES ALREADY, AND THEY DO TAKE OUT!
author: Wendy N.

description:
I like that they are very conscious about sustainable fishing and offer alternatives to common fish like yellowtail.  High quality fish, so I recommend the sashimi.  

Nice ambiance but I wish it was a little bigger!  As it gets more popular, walking in and getting a table right away has become more difficult.  The only other downside is that it is on the expensive side.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Yummy, but pricey. More for vegan-lovers. You should read the news articles / reviews by the door while you're waiting, it's quite interesting! .... this restaurant is about "Sustainable Sushi" .. They do not carry some fish here, so don't bother if you want salmon, hamachi/yellowtail or bluefin tuna. They have fish that I have never heard of before. They have a lot of seared dishes and salads. The beef carpaccio was really good and the fish was very fresh. 

Very nice presentation of their dishes. However, the restaurant was very dim and small so I was falling asleep half the time. The tables are also very small ... so be prepared to be squished!
author: Allyson L.

description:
Actually, 3.5 stars. 

If you come here during the weekend, don't be in a rush. The place is tiny, with only 2 sushi chefs and 2 servers. Luckily we were seated right away, but it was a looooong time in between plates. Good if you are with company you like and like to throw back a few cocktails in between, but if you have somewhere to be (as we did), it can be a little bit frustrating when it takes almost 2 hours to get your 5 plates.. 

Anyhoo, you must get the Kin-San-Gria! It's made with Riesling and sake, and soooo delicious! Has apples, strawberries, and lychees - you can't even taste the alcohol, it tastes just like juice! Had driving not been in the picture, I would've had a few more of these! 

Started with the Tuna Tataki which is seared yellowfin tuna with tataki sauce. They serve it with a LOT of fried garlic flakes. I don't know about you, but too much garlic wreaks havoc on my (usually) iron stomach, so I scraped most of mine off. I must say though, you didn't get a whole lot for your money ($13). I guess you pay to have a cleaner conscience? 

Fifteen minutes later, we got the Mix-It-Up, which is a roll with spicy tuna, crab meat, and avocado citrus sauce. Pretty damn tasty. A little spicy, but not too bad. 

Another 15 minutes later, we get the 49er and the Early Bird rolls. The 49er roll is how I define if a place is good or not. This one was okay. They make theirs with arctic char, which is similar to salmon (what most people use). I don't know if it was the fish or the roe, but it was a little fishy.. The Early Bird was a success. But how can you go wrong when there's filet mignon on your sushi?!.. Rolls are pretty big too. 

Last on the list was the faux-nagi nigiri (black cod), which we had to remind our waitress to get. Ten minutes later it came out. It was okay. They charred it, but you could really taste it, which I wasn't too into. Other than that, it tasted a lot like butterfish or waloo. 

All in all, it was good, but not great. Would have been better had the service been faster, but what can you do?
author: Vera H.

description: This was AMAZING sushi! My only complaint was the hour long wait :( Otherwise though this was some of the best sushi - the plate lit on fire was also very entertaining!
author: Simona M.

description: Takes forever to get in, but if you have the time, it's worth it.  The rolls are incredibly delicious and unique, but be prepared to fork over a decent chunk of change.  I recommend the Fire Extinguisher roll...it actually comes to your table with the plate partially on fire!
author: Erin B.

description:
This place is just "OK."  

Most people give extra stars for the whole sustainability thing, which I think is great, but it doesn't make Tataki a 4+ star sushi house.  Especially when it increases the prices and limits your sushi choices...

We had:
Miso soup - just okay (I like my tofu chunks big!)
Tuna Poke 3 ways - way too much sauce, hard to eat in tiny bits
Regular Sashimi Plate - small peices of fish, way too much time spent on presentation
Uni - $8
Golden State Roll - HIGHLIGHT of the night - really delicious!

Bottom line, this place is just OK.  

For a $$ sushi place (even though I have certainly not tried them all) go to Sushi Bistro.  Or for the really good stuff at $$$, go to Kabuto AS!
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
So disappointing!

The albacore was rubbery and the rolls were tiny! The overall quality of the fish was medicore at best. You can find better quality fish at whole foods and pay the same.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Oh, I love Tataki! It's delicious, guilt-free sushi. I used to always order salmon and eel when I went out for sushi (I'm not very adventurous) but here they have none because there's no good sustainable version of either (that I know of) so instead we ate a bunch of stuff we might not otherwise and it was all delicious. The faux-nagi was so good I might go back and just get several orders of that!
The wait is long, but there are bars near by so you can grab a drink before dinner.
author: Kely G.

description: Since going here for the first time about 3 weeks ago, I've returned once per week. I've never done that anywhere else in the city, period. I'm ruined for all other sushi. Enough said.
author: Shoshana D.

description: After a long play date in the city for our anniversary, we came here for dinner and absolutely loved it. The place is a little small and the service is just okay but the food definitely made up for it all. We ordered the sashimi deluxe and seriously thought we were in sashimi heaven. Scallop was so fresh, the other fish were like melting in my mouth. It sucked that they don't serve salmon however their substitution for salmon was really good. We also ordered the extinguisher roll which was really yummie. The plating was really nice and interesting that I haven't seen at other places. Overall, this was an amazing experience and definitely recommend this place to everyone =).
author: Huyen N.

description: My friend and I came here after checking out all of the yelp reviews, and everyone was right..this place rocks.  When I arrived I was only planning on getting one thing...but that quickly changed. We ended up ordering an assortment of rolls and everything was delicious!  If you go during happy hour they also lower the prices on some of the dishes, and the sangria and beer is pretty cheap! Unfortunately the weekend before I lost my ID at a wedding so I wasn't able to try the sangria, but it sure looked tasty.  As soon as I get my new ID i'm heading back here to check that out, once I get a taste i'll update my post.  Don't miss out, this place is definitely worth trying out.
author: Shannon M.

description: Loved the premise behind sustainable fish.  The "extinguisher", "mix it up" and (can't remember the name now) but it had steak instead of fish which rocked and their desserts were even really nice.  I loved the recommendation on the "sparkling sake" which really was a treat.  I just wish they were a little bigger and a bit more room (cramped and small) and a little more atmosphere.  Nice quiet place to eat if you're into your partner and just want to relax.
author: Lynn A.

description:
3.5 stars to be exact.

The place is cute, nice decor, friendly staff. They even give you a little card that explains sustainable seafood. 

The quality of food was above average, but nothing mind blowing.
The Extinguisher was good, I didn't find it as spicy as some yelpers claim.
I enjoyed the tuna tataki salad & the baked mussels. Love amaebi, but was sad that they didn't fry up the heads and serve them to me.
My favorite was the arctic char carpaccio. Yum.
The kampachi tataki was okay, the flavors of the fish seemed hidden; it reminded me of the hamachi + grapefruit carpaccio at Anzu (which btw is delicious). 
I definitely give them credit for their efforts towards sustainable seafood. However in the end, I say 3.5 stars because I would choose Kabuto over this place. BUT, it's likely that I will come back here again.
author: lisa m.

description:
I really wanted to give them a great review because I appreciate the sustainable seafood idea, and that whole eco friendly theme.

1 star for the great warm decor + pretty bathroom, 1 star for the effort, 1 star for the food quality that's justified by the price. Their uni was very good, for $9 a pair.

But no sorry, 1 star less for not quite there feel, and 1 star less for the very "unpolished" server and her service. This place is very very close to be the hidden gem that everybody talks about, but they have to execute the whole business on the spot.

I suggest that they get more refined servers, not the kind you find at the neighborhood dive sushi bar. 

Also the arctic char that they call "iwana" in Japanese, it is not iwana. Iwana is a char fish, but it's a white fresh water only fish, not the one they serve that look like salmon. I was skeptical that this was iwana, because it didn't taste like what I ate in Japan when I was little.

We might go back there just to support the cause, but this restaurant doesn't live up to the 4 1/2 stars on yelp yet.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
Before Tataki my neighborhood suffered a drought of decent food options.  But when this place came it filled a long standing void of excellent sushi restaurants.  Now I go to this place at least once a week.

My recommendations for food:

I tend to avoid the namesake dishes (i.e any of the tataki's).  I don't find them nearly as good as the rolls or the nigiri that they have available.  

My favorite rolls are: the Extinguisher, Spicy Tempura, and the 49er roll.  But I've tried them all and they are pretty special.  

For nigiri i would ask what special fish they have in and order that.  It'll be extremely fresh and delicious at the same time (two attributes highly sought after in all sushi restaurants)

If you're stuck for a suggestion I would just leave yourself in the care of Raymond at the sushi bar.  He'll make sure you leave absolutely satisfied.
author: Peter C.

description:
The sushi "rainbow" here is the best one I've ever had. 

I came this small place with my friend on Sunday afternoon. The restaurant is so small than I expected. Fortunately we got the last small table near the window, otherwise we had to wait outside for more than 20 mins like the customers who came a little bit later than us. We ordered an appetizer, 6 pcs sashimi and 3 kinds of sushi. (He had most of these food :) I always eat like a bird) All of the food are so yummy especially the sushi rainbow. it is topped with 5 different kind of fishes. good looking, good taste. The waitress was nice too. We spent a great time here.
author: sarah w.

description: I went here with a friend of mine about a week ago. I am a huge sushi fan but I am always skeptical when I go try another sushi place. I was very surprised as to how amazing this place was. It was a very small establishment but it felt right. The wait staff was friendly and knowledgable of the menu. The menu was small but where Tataki lacks in option it makes up for in big taste. Wonderful sushi combinations that would normally be mild and somewhat tasteless are livened up by many delicious sauces. Overall I say that if you are staying in SF and you like sushi then go to Tataki!
author: zelda z.

description: i am a huge fan of this place. i have been visiting san francisco for a month for business and have gone to this place on a weekly basis. great sushi rolls and great service. hard to get seating at times since it is a small place but definitely worth the wait. big fan.
author: Anish P.

description: Excellent rolls! Definitely recommend the 'mix-it-up' and 'double-double' rolls. The 'extinguisher' and 'tataki roll' were good as well. I was very intrigued by the sustainable fish philosophy and despite the seemingly limited number of fish options, I didn't even miss the salmon! We also tried the reggae roll - it looked much better than it tasted. Great presentation of all the rolls. I'd go back.
author: Shweta V.

description: nothing suprised. Just like another sushi restaurant in japantown. The price is ok though, and evironment is cute.
author: Carol X.

description:
One star for creativity. Be aware they have a limited many so your stuck with same sushi with a different name on the menu!!!!
One page if sushi WTF
Don't understand why it has a high rating. Yelps rating duped me when I was in search for REAL tasty suhi. Philly ole was good butte arctic char was not good. Not heated sushi. How organic can suhi get. Not Tate and the tattaki was suggested by the waiter but te food had no taste. Looked great. I guess the food would be good if I drank. Very disappointed and not really a Japanese influenced sushi joint. 
Really really disappointed. BewaRE no hot foods and all they use is arctic char to replace salmon, this has no taste. Philly role is your best bet. Pricing is too much for food that taste like nothing but a decorative IKea sushi plate.
As you can see I rarely yelp but this place was misleading with it's high starts. Usually I trust yelp but this piss me off. In search of good suhi and it's not hard to find it but a place that charges a lot and make organi sushi, come on sushi is organic!!!! Rip off. Go here for the drink bc it would make anything they make good.
Will never go here again.
Lesson learned and money wasted.
author: jr j.

description:
I have been extremely loyal to Zushi Puzzle over the years and on my first visit to Tataki for a lunch break at work over a year ago I left unimpressed.  I am glad that a year later I decided to give it a second chance.   My second visit to Tataki during dinner hours was completely different and unexpectedly delicious.  

The only drawback to this place is that it is tiny.  Although, this is not such a bad thing if you come during less popular hours and It does create for a much more personal atmosphere.

Other than that, service is good and food comes out in a timely manner.
The fish is very, very fresh and I appreciate their endorsement of sustainable fish.  In fact it provided me with some education on exactly which fish are okay to eat and which ones are overfished.  I also ended up trying (and loving) some fish I probably wouldn't have thought to order at other sushi places.

Zushi, I am sorry to say it, but you've got some serious competition now.   My favorite roll:  The 49er roll  (masago/avocado roll topped with artic char and lemon)  Mmmmm.  Also the amberjack special roll was off the charts.
author: Brenna C.

description:
The lady heard about this place and then looked it up on yelp. The "eco-friendly" part caught our attention so we decided to give this place a shot on Friday night. If you go on a weekend, be prepared to wait a bit, we waited about 45 minutes. The place is small, but warm and cozy, even though it was small we didn't feel like we were rubbing elbows with other tables. 

For drinks to start, I ordered the House Sake and she ordered the sake-sangria special. Hers was much better! They used fresh fruit and it was very flavorful. The House Sake was just...House sake. 

For appetizer we got Fried calamari. This was one of the best I've ever had. It was light, crispy and not overly salty like some other places. The sauce that came with it was also very good, I'd describe it as a cross between thousand island and spicy mustard sauce. +1 for the Fried Calamari. 

The Sushi: We got the spicy shrimp tempura roll and a Early Bird Roll. The Spicy tempura was good, and quite spicy the way I had hoped. It is spicy tuna, shrimp tempura, a jalapeno slice and some vegetables. I liked it alot, but I probably would not get it again, mainly because as good as it is, it was nothing special.

The Early Bird roll was much better! seared Fillet Mignon with avacado and fresh pineapple. It doesn't sound like it would work, but it did. The fillet Mignon was soft but not mushy, and was seared perfectly ( cooked on the outside, pretty rare on the inside)  The meat seemed to melt in our mouths. Best Sushi roll we've had in awhile! Definately will order this again.

Service was great, everything came in a friendly and timely fashion (it helps that it is a small restaurant). Overall it was a great experience. Its a great date place, or group place.
author: Justin J.

description:
I loved the sashimi and nigiri (especially the faux-nagi!) at Tataki - very fresh, very tasty alternatives to your typical sushi experience. I also tried two of the tatakis (atlantic char - pretty good; a hamachi/avacado type dish - not good) as well as a roll (the extinguisher - just okay). 

The decor of the place is cute/small/quaint - a good place for a casual date night. The pricing is reasonable - under $150 for two including a large bottle of sake. 

I'll definitely come back and just stick to the basics - they were delightful.
author: Jana M.

description: cucumbers in my water?!! Whhhhhhaaaaaaaatttttt.  yeah that was kinda cool...The sushi is fantastic.  This place made me think about sushi for a week.  We showed up at like 10 pm and it was phenomenal, everything.  And the cool part was we ordered a lot because we were hungry and the waiter was nice enough to hold off on a few orders because he knew it was a lot of food.  Cool place, good food, nice people.
author: christopher h.

description:
incredibly fresh and affordable with a focus on the fish, not on ridiculous sauces and bullshit (though they have a modest number of these if that's your thing)

come early or expect to spend a solid hour exploring lower pac heights or watching others eat.  it's a small place with a slow pace, and if you choose to wait you'll find yourself hurling hateful thoughts at the people who slowly lift...each...piece...of...sushi.

it's absolutely worth it though - this is my favorite sushi place in san francisco.  get a couple of the regular sashimi samplers (they're somehow cheaper per-piece than the larger deluxe ones) and just let them pick for you.  the emphasis on sustainable fishing is a boon for the greenies and for lovers of variety, since you end up with a unique assortment every time.
author: Justin B.

description:
disappointing. out of the approximately 8 types of fish in our deluxe sashimi platter, only 2 were really fresh. 1 was completely inedible. uncaring and unfriendly servers. 

i would give it 2 stars if i was not a fan of sustainability.
author: Yevi A.

description:
I would have easily given it 4 stars, but unfortunately, this place has been "discovered", which immediately has put it in the overrated list. This little, cozy restaurant was a real gem - fresh sushi, quiet location, simple but inventive menu. 

Then the crowds arrived. Now, any time you drive by, there's a crowd outside - a sure sign of an overhyped SF eatery, such as Burma Superstar or Pork Store Cafe. So, it's time to expose Tataki's few but noticeable drawbacks. 
First, the place is tiny, so if you bring a date here, be prepared to share your conversation with neighbours to your left and to your right. There's barely a space between the miniature tables for the waitress to squeeze by. 
Second, the staff is, well, not very Japanese. Waiting staff is just plain boring American, and the chefs are, I believe Chinese, although I could be mistaken. And to be honest, I am tired of Chinese and Korean owned sushi restaurants in San Francisco. I mean, it's not like opening another Chow Fun take out. 
Finally, even though the quality of fish is generally good, there's just a tad much focus on its sustainability rather than taste. I don't really want a lecture on fish ecology during a sushi dinner. 
But overall, it really is too bad this place has become more popular than it can handle to be.
author: Evg R.

description:
We love sushi, have been eating for 40 years, and always on the look out for a good affordable sushi bar.   Good fresh fish is expensive, so we understand why good sushi will never be cheap.   We were delighted when Tataki opened up on California St, only two blocks from our house.   We've eaten there a few times, and although crowded, the sushi is good.  Rolls vary from good to ordinary.   We order takeout from them often and have always been happy with it.

Lat night (Sunday, 5/26) we took a friend to eat at Tataki.   The music was very loud, with an overwhelming beat.   It was nearly impossible to talk without shouting.   We asked the waitress if she could turn down the music, and she gave us a strange, not very welcoming look.   But she did turn down the music a bit.   A few minutes later it seemed to get louder again, so we asked one of the guys behind the counter if he could either change the music to something less jarring or turn it down.   He seemed surprised, but did turn it down somewhat.   The music, at any level, was not at all relaxing.    It seems likely that this is no accident.   Loud, discordant music, can cause tables to turn over more quickly.   So the bad tude and the loud music kills it for us for an eat in.   Will still get their takeout, but sure won't be eating there again.   None of the owners were there Sunday, so not sure if it is the staff's preference or the owners' orders for loud music.  Why does a small restaurant even play music?    Are the owners acting out their aggression?
author: Ian B.

description:
i have to say i was really impressed with this place.  the service was friendly and attentive and the rolls were delicious.  that albacore tataki nigiri will definitely be repeated on my next visit.  i even enjoyed my riesling/sake sangria.  

i think this will be my go to place for when i want something a little more playful than ino...there are times when i just want some good rolls and a nice fruity drink and this is where you will find me getting exactly that.  

last but not least -- i'm also a fan of guilt-free sushi consumption!
author: ML ..

description: Great sushi and a great happy hour. Perfect local sushi spot.
author: Will B.

description: Small and intimate... Long wait on a given day but well worth it. Delish.....
author: BENADICK F.

description:
Tataki is totally delicious. They put asparagus in their salads and what an anomaly that is! Their salads are to die for.

But... the salads aren't as good as the sushi, which is super buttery. Don't get the mix-it-up unless you are comfortable with the surprise of having your mouth go numb from habanero sauce.

But really...the sustainable fish is delicious, particularly the arctic char, which is a fabulous alternative to salmon.

BTW, our server Christine was great and gets wicked hotness points. Very great at refilling the water, too. Also, she was really helpful with explaining the kinds of fish they offer.
author: C C.

description: one of the best sushi places i've been to. The freshness alone is enough to bring u back. Rolls are meticulously put together. Seemed each and every plate could have been photographed for the cover of a food magazine. Only downfall: place is so teeny! Have to wait 4ever for a tiny table! Come on the cusp of starvation so that by the time you are seated, you will be ready to get your grub on :).
author: Rebecca S.

description: I live in Long Beach, CA visited San Fran. for a few days and happened upon Tataki. This was over a year ago, I have searched and searched all over Long beach and surrounding cities to find a sushi place that can hold ranks against Tataki, none that I have visited come CLOSE to the quality of Tataki. I have contemplated moving to San Fran. just so I can eat here on a reg. basis...
author: Dan K.

description: Vegetarian's have always gotten the shaft when it comes to sushi...until Tataki! If you're looking for suggestions I recommend the reggae and/or ratatouille rolls. Tataki also has a happy hour everyday from 5-7pm with some super fab roll and drink specials (but don't bother going unless you get there by 5pm). Their white wine/sake sangria with lychee is superb if you're into that kind of thing. As others have mentioned, it is small so if you do have to wait, go to Solstice next door and enjoy some tasty beverages (Solstice also has half off bottles of wine on Monday). Tataki, you dazzle me.
author: Ami V.

description: MMmmmm, Tataki never lets me down.  This place is one of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF.  Delicious rolls and great salads, I always order the spicy tempura roll....the sliced jalapenos on top is my favorite .  A nice, cozy spot in Pacific Heights....sometimes there is a wait, but I just go next door to Solstice and have a drink to kill time.  :)
author: Jana S.

description: So I had high hopes based on Yelp reviews, but they could not live up to the hype.  So my boyfriend and I showed up tonight at about 5:45 and dutifully added our name to the wait list (all names above ours were crossed off, as though already seated).  After a ten minute wait, a table opened up that we thought would/should be ours.  But no....they gave it to a couple that appeared a few minutes before being seated and who were clearly well known 'regulars.'. Strike one.  An additional ten minutes later, we are finally seated.  We order the extinguisher and "crunchy" spice tuna roll.  They come fairly quickly, although each separated by at least five minutes (serving us at different times).  They are "okay," but know that their crunchy spicy tuna roll is NOT tempura battered...they have 'tempura flakes' only.  The extinguisher had some spice, but was pretty mild by my standards.  The sushi, for it's prices and the wait, was mediocre at best.  I've had far larger portions and much more tasty sushi in San Luis Obispo county.  Strike two.  Not feeling full so far, we ordered a spicy tempura roll.  After waiting twenty minutes (without food or even a check in or apology by the waitress), we ask for our bill.  She says, "we're slicing your roll now.". We say, no, we'd like the check.  Still no apology.  Strike three.  I would expect better from a San Francisco establishment, but now know I will get FAR better in my home territory.  This place is just a bunch of hype.  I won't be back.
author: Lisa S.

description:
1. Craving sushi/japanese food
2. Go to Tataki and pray for decent parking (or take a cab/bus)
3. Sign up on the waiting list - no reservations and yes, there will be a wait
4. Go next door to Solstice to lubricate your tummy for dinner
5. After about a 20-30 min wait (on a Saturday), take a seat at one of the 10 tables or sushi bar
6. Sit back, browse the nice and simple menu, order some sake 
7. Expect a little while for the food to come out, but enjoy the pleasant, clean, slightly "cool" vibe of Tataki
8. Dig in. Katsuo Tataki was recommended and pretty decent if you like seared fish ($11 for about 5 slices). Nigiri was very decent although there was a little too much rice. If you want hamachi or salmon, it may not be on the menu but try one of the other raw fish options ($5/2 pieces on ave).
9. Keep the house sake flowing ($6) while you finish off with a roll (golden gate roll for $15 - spicy scallops with seared albacore on the outside).
10. Walk out of Tataki feeling satisfied. Good quality food and quality atmopshere.

Would I go again? Sure, if I were in the area but Kazu is still #1 in my book. For a nicer dinner experience (which is not why you go to Kazu), Tataki isn't a bad choice at all.
author: Deann M.

description: Pretty average place...I wouldnt recommend it but I wouldnt say it was a bad place either. very small...the food comes in very very small portions so i guess its good for an appetizer joint, so basically its perfect if you just want to have a light meal with some drinks and have a nice chat with someone...and want to be green and save the planet...cuz this place is 'sustainable'...meaning....they like to be sustaining...yeah...
author: Viet N.

description:
This small little restaurant is a great local spot if you live in the neighborhood. We went to Tataki last night for the first time after seeing reviews on Yelp. I have to admit. The sushi was fabulous. I can't say that it gets much better than this!

The one thing I do have to comment on is the service. While everyone is VERY friendly in the restaurant, it takes a very long time to get served. So if you are looking for a sushi spot that is super speedy, this isn't your place, however if you have the time to sit down, relax and have some killer sushi... Then you have come to the right spot!
author: Meredith B.

description:
sushi experience 1: meh... 
sushi experience 2: omg I love this stuff
sushi experience 3: screw the fancy rolls, this Tataki stuff is phenomenal 

I will still down an entire bowl of edamame before sushi, but I have graduated to the good stuff!

I love how quaint this place is, makes you feel cozy... although I felt a little more uncomfortable with my chopsticks seeing as how everyone could see me failing miserably.. I swear my clumsy fingers will get it eventually. 

On top of the amazing sushi they also have their own take on Sangria, made with Sake and lyche. 

We sat at the bar, and I found myself in a daze watching the chefs dominate those rolls so fast! :) Same blank stare I used to make when a little kid, staring at the TV.. Only this was much more personal. 

This is a great place for a small group, or a romantic little date. I would say don't bring more than 3 friends with you! The wait is worth it! 

Recommendation: Do not come here for a first date, everyone can hear your entire conversation, and we find it amusing when your awkward first date convo revolves around twitter and what tin foil tastes like...
author: Hailey P.

description: All you can ask for these days in a sushi spot, their fish is fresh and sustainable ......the wait staff is too cool for school, and a hand selected list of songs from someones i pod is playing. worth checkin out for sure!!!!
author: Ruca R.

description: I've been to tataki several times over the years.  I think it's terrific.  I had several pieces of nigiri that were quite memorable.  I love the rolls here as well.  very pleasant dining experience.
author: ari b.

description:
i wanna say to every delectable morsel in SF---yeahh... i totally tasted that...*wink wink nod nod* ohhh yeah~ (^_~)
this sustainable sushi was so delicious and creative!! 1 of my favorite places so far! i even loved the music! i loved that it was small and unassuming, not some colossal look-at-me restaurant filled with look-at-me ppl. everything was perfect from the hipster waiter right down to the cucumber water! i had the extinguisher sushi below. so funny seeing ppl not used to eating spicy food sweat and fan their faces as they frantically flag down the waiter~! :D 

my dessert was amazing, too--strawberry mochi with fuji apples drizzled with hot swirly fudge! next time i'll try the green tea cheesecake...;b
author: gookgette c.

description:
Sustainable sushi.  Finally, environmentally friendly food is becoming mainstream.  Fish is seasonal, people.  Farming fish is very tricky to do in a way that doesn't hurt the environment.  Farmed salmon is terrible.  Wild salmon is fine (and tastes better) but only available in summer (may - sept).  Arctic char is farmed sustainably and makes a lovely sashimi.  I've never seen it in a sushi restaurant before Tataki.  

The food here is beautiful, inside and out.  Gorgeous presentation, excellent sashimi.  I had the chef's choice which was divine.  The mackerel was so good it was like toro.  The uni took me to the sea it came from.  

Open your mind and try new things.  You will be rewarded at Tataki.
author: Janet S.

description: Excellent, fresh, sustainable sushi.  Knowledgeable, helpful staff.  Reasonable prices.  Small seating area and popular for good reason, so plan on grabbing a drink down the street after you put your name in.  Dont worry, its worth the wait.
author: T H.

description: Wow, even the deserts were awesome. A small, welcoming, neighborhood place with high quality and wide variety of sushi dishes.
author: Igal P.

description: Tiny place but if you can get in, service was fine, prices are fine dining, but a good date place.
author: Micah P.

description:
Based on all the hype I was expecting something fancy, or at least memorable, but this turned out to be just a normal, sleepy neighborhood sushi joint.

We tried the Golden State roll and several nigiri. The only thing that really stood out for me was the arctic char (iwana): this was the first time I had heard of it. At Tataki it was presented as a feel-good alternative to salmon, but in any case it was fantastic.

I'm not sure I'll return to Tataki, but I will definitely look for arctic char the next time I go out for sushi.
author: Matt B.

description:
I think the fish here is really great.  The rolls were tasty and the sashimi was very good quality.

The service was just ok and SUPER slow.  We ended up cancelling part of our order because we lost our appetite after waiting forever for the first couple rolls.
author: Luci B.

description: I love this place. It is a great combination of neighborhood, delicious, and creative. It isn't either too cool for school, or too dive-y, it is just right.
author: Deb J.

description: I've only been to Tataki once, and keep meaning to go back (but one of my other favorite places is closer, which deters me) but it still deserves a glowing review. I went for lunch and got the chirashi, and it was delicious. In fact, I keep dreaming about the char, and desperately want more of it. Delicious, and makes you feel good, too, since it's sustainable.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Unbelievable sushi!  It was one of the best sushi meals I've ever had.  The fish was soft, fresh, and oh so tasty.  It's cute inside and they played a mix of good music as well.  The wait and the service are the drawbacks - it's a tiny place with only two waiters and two chefs.  We're definitely going back.
author: Denise G.

description: Delicious! This intimate and modern sushi place has a fantastic happy hour menu Sunday- Saturday from 5:00-7:00.  There's a relatively small but tasty menu:  arctic char & avocado roll, crunchy spicy tuna, sweet potato tempura, California roll, and a couple of more.  Hand rolls are $4.50.  Also, calamari and sake-sangria are part of the menu at $5.  Personally, I like the seaweed salad.  Just the right crunchy texture with a sweet flavor.  On most nights, there is a small crowd waiting outside.  You can go during peak hours or head there a little early to take advantage of fewer people and the better prices.
author: Krista C.

description:
