i really liked the concept.  the food execution was really good too.  however, the space and service hold tataki back.  the hostess was nice and allowed us to put our names down as we waited for other members of our party to show up.  she also allowed us to go about rather than wait near the area.  by the time we got back out table was waiting for us.  after that though our service was spotty and almost unfriendly.

our waitress, while putting on a smile, didn't seem like she really wanted to help out much.  she offered suggestions and i suppose for the veggie end of the table she was a bit more helpful.

for drinks, we got some nigori sake which was pretty darn good and the ladies got some of the house sangria which was very un-sangria like but very refreshing.

we started w/ one arctic char roll and one sweet potato roll.  the artic char roll was really nice and the fish was very buttery and smooth.  i didn't have the sweet potato roll but heard it was good.

on the veggie end of the table, the ratatouille roll and some custom made rolls that i can't remember were.  all rolls were liked especially the ratatouille roll.  i had a bite and it was a nicely constructed and flavored roll w/ great texture.  on the fish side, we got the chef's nigiri platter (had stuff like amberjack, arctic char, skipjack, scallop, mackerel,  etc.), the extinguisher, tataki, double-double and spicy tofuna rolls.  all were good and the fish was really fresh and delicious.  the nigiri special was my favorite w/ the double-double being my second favorite.  the spicy tofuna was weird though.

we did get dessert and got one of each!  the mochi ice cream was very disappointing as was the green tea cheesecake.  the ice cream's mochi layer wasn't soft or chewy and the green tea cheesecake tasted like well cheese.  the regular mochi and the coffee jello were good especially the mochi.  the coffee jello while good was missing a punch to it.

overall, a good eating experience but the service was blah.  next time i'll sit at the bar to get some one-on-one time w/ the chef.
author: Swarup B.

description: This is one of the best sushi bars I've ever been too! I really enjoyed the Tuna sashimi and Tataki Rolls.  The place is small and crowded, so pick a good time to come.
author: Daniel L.

description: The definition of a 5 star restaurant and probably my new favorite sushi place in the city Tataki gets extra points in my book for their practice in serving fish garnered through only sustainable fishing techniques. The servers and chefs are friendly (one of the chefs saw me eating raw wasabi and challenged me to eat the fresh stuff, my mouth burned, my eyes watered and we shared a laugh) and make you feel really welcome at their restaurant. Only hangup is that the place is pretty small so come early and expect to wait a little bit. Aside from that this place is rockin.
author: Tommy P.

description: After discovering sushi in Hawaii, we went to Tataki ( 4 adults and a baby )  to further discover the art if sushi. And we loved it! Of course you have to wait in the san Francisco cold for some time but the wait was definitely worth it! The food is very good with a fairly large variety of sushi, the waitress was nice with us, trying to make the life of the baby easier... Recommended!
author: Yann M.

description:
My boyfriend and I recently went here on a day trip to SF. Parking wasn't bad to my surprise. Since it was after 6, parking was free and about 50 feet from the restaurant. We walked up and it was extremely small and every table was filled. If driving on the rode, you wouldn't even notice the restaurant. Since it was so small, I felt hesitant but my boyfriend put our name on the waiting list while I used the bathroom. The bathroom was very clean but a challenge to get to considering the small space between tables. I looked for other sushi places near by and then our name was called. I decided to give the place a chance and I'm so happy I did!! We had a delicious experience! We got the rainbow roll, the golden state, the extinguisher, the baked mussels for an appetizer, and a glass of Chardonnay. The mussels were wonderful. My boyfriend did find a very small crab (dead and cooked) which must of made residence in the mussel. It did not gross me out because it reflected the freshness of the mussels but he said the crab was hard and if he had bitten it, it could have hurt his teeth. The Chardonnay was quite tasty and the waiter was very helpful in helping me select the right wine. All of our rolls were fantastic. The golden state have apple in it which I was very skeptical about but it was AMAZING. They flavor their tobiko in different things such as habanero and yuzu which adds for a wonderful decoration and taste. The price was pretty food for SF, nothing over the top or very cheap. The extinguisher is their most popular roll and once you taste it, you know why-it has quite a kick and comes with a side of FIRE. I kid you not, they bring the plate to you and it has fire on it. A truly unique decoration I doubt I will see anywhere else. The only thing about this experience that I was not the biggest fan of was how the waiter always seemed so surprised and perhaps even judgmental when we ordered all of the food we did. My boyfriend and I are frequent sushi eaters and we can put it away, so to speak. 

Finding sushi in SF is a hard task because there are so many places to choose from. But I know that my boyfriend and I will be back here again!
author: Jacquie F.

description: good stuff...cute little place.  good rolls- reminds me of the good places that have lots of sauce like ponzu on sashimi that is slightly seared......that arctic char is tasty.   they have a hanero that was spicy and good.
author: Rob C.

description: Mom read about the restaurant in her Chinese paper a few days ago and is dying to try the place out.  So, armed with the knowledge that they can only seat up to 20 people and that it's a popular place, we got there at 4:45 today to wait for their opening at 5pm.  When we were finally seated , we were delighted to discover that they have a Happy Hour menu on the weekend as well.  So, we ordered with abandon: 2 appetizers, 2 rolls, 2 nigiris, a sashimi platter and sake.  Needless to say, we were quite stuffed and had to take some home.  Everything was superb!  The only thing I didn't like as much was their salmon on their sashimi plate.  They didn't have the flavor that I've come to associate with raw salmon sashimi (slightly sweet and subtlely oily taste).  Perhaps it's a matter of where the fish came from?...  Anyway, a minor quibble.  I would definitely go back without a doubt!
author: Yvette F.

description: Went here as a party of four, just in time for happy hour.  $3 beers and $4 handrolls or maki.  You can really fill up on good, fresh fish here.  We had sake, beer, many rolls and edamame and walked out of there completely full for ~$30 each.  Not bad at all! The rice is nicely cooked and flavored and not too hard or soft.  Our server was very sweet and accomodating.  I will definitely return!
author: Shelley T.

description:
This place is amazing, especially for their commitment to serving only sustainably harvested seafood, for our guilt free sushi pleasure! 

The menu is creative, and I've always enjoyed the beautiful presentation, the freshness, and the flavors of the different rolls and nigiri selections. I've had great service here, very friendly and efficient. 

I like especially the Golden State Roll with spicy bay scallops, green apples, topped with seared albacore, avocado and edible gold flakes. Also the Reggae Roll is delicious, with asparagus tempura, with avocado, tomatoes and pumpkin. Last time I tried the albacore toro, so buttery, and the seared black cod, with a lovely smoky delicate flavor. 

I will be back soon!
author: Jazzin' B.

description: Great sangria! Unlike most, they use a Reisling so it's sweeter than most white wine sangrias AND at only 5 bucks a pop during their happy hour special, well that just makes me happy. Weekday evenings are rarely overcrowded and it's local so that's always a plus, can't say it's my favorite sushi stop but as others have stated they use sustainable methods to harvest their fish. So help save our earth by eating at Tataki or just go because the happy hour is hard to top.
author: Kat R.

description: 4.5 stars. Quite possibly the best sushi I have ever had. Sustainable and amazingly fresh. Reasonably priced for what you get. You have to go! (but don't steal my table)
author: Kari B.

description:
The sushi here is very, very good. The menu is a little limited, but understandably so since they only serve sustainable seafood. I went here on a Monday and the place was almost full. Our waiter was a little forgetful--I had to ask twice for our appetizer--but the restaurant was so small it was easy to get his attention. Once I reminded him he brought it right away. 

I will definitely be back whenever I'm craving sushi.
author: Lizzie S.

description: I really like this place! I'm a student at Drew College Preparatory, which is like half a block away from Tataki, and my best friend LOVES Japanese food and especially Tataki, so we would always, literally almost every single day we would go there for lunch. It has been 4 years now and we still go there frequently, their quality improves every year. I love their rolls, like California, Shrimp Tempura, and a lot others, and I also love the beef udon. Highly recommend it for people who likes Jap food!
author: CaRol L.

description:
OMG, this place is sooo good! Ambience is stellar, Gretchen was incredible and the food was delicious. AND, if for no other reason, go for the green tea cheesecake.

Holy moly!
author: Heather G.

description:
Tataki has a very warm ambience.  The waiters were very friendly.  The food was tasty and not overly expensive. They have a great theme going on in regards to their attention to the environmental commitment.  They only use fish caught using fishing methods that does not harm the environment.  I thought that it was pretty cool although it means that they don't have the more common fish found in other sushi restaurants.  
On the downside, their dessert menu is VERY limited.  Overall a decent place to try.
author: Victor K.

description: So overrated, and the customer service wasn't that great. I like the ambiance, but it wasn't anything special.
author: Sarah A.

description: Sustainable sushi and lots of vegetarian/vegan options? AND a daily happy hour from 5-7pm (including weekends)? I'll definitely be coming here often. Cozy, good service and great food. My new favorite sushi place in the city.
author: Tamara M.

description: Great fish, willing to modify (I have allergies to wheat and soy), sustainable fish (friendly for the environment), relaxing environment
author: Sara B.

description: This place is awesome, which explains why I've had to wait about 45 minutes every time I go there. The fish is fresh and the prices are reasonable. Get the tataki combo, which is 5 different types of seared fish, each with its own dipping sauce. They are all about sustainable fish, which is a plus, because I want to be eating sushi when I'm older and can afford to eat it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
author: Peter H.

description: So, the adventure of touring San Francisco ended here. Its definitely a local's place. The restaurant has a limited amount of seating, nestled in a small, quite neighborhood. Waited approximately 10 minds to be seated. Service was moderate, there was only one server for the entire restaurant, and two sushi chefs. We ordered the Tataki special..? Can't remember the name of the dish.... blame it on the alchohol... it was 4 pieces of 5 different fishes served with their own designated sauces to compliment the fish. It was good, I was starving and I ate everything, minus the leaf the fish was sitting on two seconds earlier. For good measure we ordered a roll called the extinguisher. The salt on the plate was on fire.... I missed it... oh well, a picture will suffice. It was good, but not great... We were still hungry so we ordered another roll... This one was deep friend with tempura in it. It was good, but not great. To be honest, I found that was my opinion for the entire restaurant. Good, but not great. I've tried a good amount of sea food and sushi in my life. I liked how small and quaint it was however the food didn't hold up for me.
author: JJ O.

description: 4 stars for food. 0 stars for service/friendliness. The hostess chick was rude! Had dinner here last night, August 15 and have been before so i was aware of the lack of tables due to size of restaurant which is fine but the way they handle the waiting list is retarded.  We didnt want to take up space at doorway and creepishly stare at people while they enjoy their sushi so we sat down at Bistro SF next door for a glass of wine. I got up to check where they were on the list every 3 sips of wine so we wouldnt miss our turn.  Finally, I noticed they had crossed off/sat the person above us on list so I thought yay we are next. I went up to the hostess chick to let her know we are next door closing our tab and we are ready to be seated.  When we came back 3 minutes later she sat people at our table! All she could say, very rudely "well you werent standing here". Um excuse me but you either suffer from memory loss or pure stupidity because I just spoke to you 2 minutes ago.  All she could say is "well you should have been standing here." We waited 30 minutes patiently for a table, stayed out of their way but checked back every five minutes.  What a rude place. Good sushi but there are tons of great sushi places in SF so I will take my business else where.
author: nicole s.

description: Best sushi I have ever had and the guys behind the bar are so nice. The sashimi is so fresh and melts in your mouth. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jeni Z.

description: I LOOOOVE the sushi here. The fish is fresh and that's important to me when eating sashimi.  I always get the rainbow roll and a few of the other specialty rolls. The crab croquettes were delicious as well.  The only thing I didn't like were the oysters that left a fishy taste in my mouth (def not worth $2.50 an oyster), but everything else I loved.
author: H. A.

description:
we have been going back to tataki pretty frequently lately.  it's still right across the street, and if we get there early enough, we don't have to wait for a table with all the hipsters in the street.   also i have a bit of neighborhood pride from seeing this place go from a subway to a failing sandwich/ice cream shop to the sustainable sushi wonderland it is today.

we finally were able to taste the vegan cali roll and the spicy tofuna roll and i am so in love.  the tofuna is my favorite but that doesn't mean the cali roll isn't amazing.  i still can't give 5 stars since anything battered (like the sweet potato croquettes, which sound amazing) still has egg in it, and the miso soup is not vegetarian, but it is no longer on the veggie menu and the vegan items are CLEARLY marked so i have no real qualms with this place, besides the fact that it is so delicious (and so expensive) that my tataki habit is getting to be somewhat of a problem for my wallet.
author: kate s.

description: Amazing place for sashimi.  I would give it five stars only if it was a bit easier to get a seat.  I love their commitment to sustainable fishing and appreciate the ability to try new types of sashimi (such as artic char) that you don't get to try at the more traditional japanese places.
author: Sarah K.

description: I want to give this place a bed review just so that no on else knows about it but... I can not do that to Tataki.. Happy Hour is awesome, food is awesome, service is amazing, atmosphere is the best.. I love the Spicy Tuna and the Tataki Roll, it gives you a little taste of everything yummy yummy!
author: Deidre B.

description: It is a bit pricy sushi place. The sushi is definitely good but I cannot say it is the best. Service was also nice. Spicy tampura was good, tuna roll was  regular one...
author: Ali E.

description: Just been here once - had a pretty mainstream experience. Fish was fresh and good but service lacked a little... perhaps it was just too busy? Good for them at least...
author: Jakob B.

description: Best Small Sushi Place in SF. Period. I have yet to have better sushi. Service was great. decor was traditional and modern. Space was super cozy but charming and intimate enough to be date worthy or small gathering worthy. Don't bring a party bigger than a 6 top, i would suggest. Every table was adorned with little Marine Fisheries Safe Fishing Practices List AND they gave out little lists of the fish with high/med/low mercury content for those interested in keeping their brain intact during this lifetime. Good stuff.
author: Jordan S.

description: I'm not really a sushi dude but I could eat here on the regular! This place is small but warm and cozy. They don't take reservations so you might have to wait for a table. Its worth the wait though. The food was very good, the cold sake was also great! They have a separate vegetarian menu so an excellent sushi joint for veggies! Friendly attentive staff and fast service. Another plus for me is they are open till 10:30pm instead of 9pm like most restaurants. Not cheap but worth the money and very good! Love the reggae rolls.
author: Cue A.

description: Delicious sushi!!  The happy hour special is a great deal.  Crunch spicy tuna rolls, crunchy california rolls.  Their sangria is delicious w/riesling & lychee fruit!  I want to go back here again and try more rolls!
author: Kristina P.

description:
Tataki was an absolute delight from start to finish. We were greeted by a courteous and friendly server who sat us promptly in the window seat. While on the tiny side, this cozy restaurant made a great use of its space. The track lighting above was modern and tasteful and the bathroom was alarmingly cool with tiled walls and a stylish square sink. 

While I'm not an environmental activist, it was refreshing to discover that Tataki supports sustainable-sourced seafood. An enlightening  pamphlet on the table, sponsored by the Monterey Bay Aquarium, informed us which seafood to avoid. 

The calamari, lightly seasoned with salt and pepper and served with an unique dipping sauce, was the perfect appetizer. For the main course we ordered the Reggae roll (warm asparagus tempura, avocado and pumpkin), Philadelphia roll, and Tuna roll with avocado and masago. All were melt-in-your-mouth delicious and the presentation was exceptional.

This place is really special. So far, the best sushi experience I've had in San Francisco.
author: David P.

description: Our server, Evan, gets 5 stars! On a busy Friday night, I would expect the server to be on the move but Evan took his time with us to educate us on sustainable sushi and the most eco-friendly options on the menu. His smooth, calm composure fit in perfectly with the whole vibe and objective of the place. Tataki lost a star due to the wait. Who knows how long we were standing out there - maybe 30 minutes? We couldn't take the chilly breeze any longer so we popped in next door for wine - probably another 20 or so minutes. We should have gone with the wine from the beginning so take note and don't be a fool. Evan will hold your table until you come back.
author: Susan L.

description: All around awesome! Everything we got was amazing. Although we did order way to much food. The special rolls are huge! Happy hour from 5-7 has some great deals on rolls and other appetizers. Its impressive that their environmental concern has been featured on NPR etc too..
author: K A.

description: really small and disappointing selection of rolls. the ingredients were all high quality and fresh, so i guess you get what you pay for. tiny restaurant but very clean and friendly atmosphere. dunno when id come back here again, but i wouldnt be opposed to it either
author: Stephanie C.

description: Definitely a popular place. Long line. Long wait. A bit overrated though. Any true diehard sushi fan knows you can get a whole lot better for a much better price. The atmosphere was nice & cozy I guess. Wish the slices were thicker and better quality.
author: Patrick K.

description: the tatakis and calamari were delicious. small place with good quality food. but there weren't many sushi choices.
author: Ebru T.

description: Yay!  They've added more rolls and now have HAPPY HOUR!  My current faves are the extinguisher roll and  the mix it up roll.  I've noticed it's gotten much more busy in here lately.  Even though I want them to be successful so they stay in business, I like being able to walk in & get a table right away.  I want it all.  ::sigh::
author: Rosie F.

description: You'd think you would pay for sustainable sushi either in quality or money, but neither is the case. Especially at happy hour, this joint is inexpensive and definitely quality. It does get crowded later in the night, which makes it less enjoyable, but at happy hour I can recommend without reservations. Not restaurant reservations, my own reservations about recommendations. You get it.
author: Colin T.

description: Absolutely delighted by this gem of a Japanese restaurant. We LOVE fresh sushi, and the sushi specials here (including a buttery toro tuna belly) were spectacular. Service was professional and prompt, very informative yet not overly attentive and chatty. Ambience is cozy and uplifted, with a sweet neighbor-hoody vibe.  Each dish had us exclaiming "YUM!", including the regular standbys like seaweed salad and cold tofu with a bonito sauce. Even an a la carte bowl of rice was a stand-out. Sake was excellent also, and we are sake lovers!
author: Anne Kerry F.

description:
I too really enjoyed this place. Tried to hit Zushi but it was (as usual) an hour and half wait. Sooo.... I hopped on Yelp in search of the perfect meal that that would give me tingles when I were to reminisce of that night.

I find Tataki.

What I loved about Tataki:
- There's Bamboo everywhere. Why is this important, you ask? Because it's a Japanese restaurant that tauts itself as being in support of sustainable fish. In the meantime, they also seem to be in full support of sustainable materials in general, because bamboo grows like wildfire. I can appreciate that. 
- I went to the bathroom first. I LOVE THE BATHROOM. You know how you can tell that a restaurant puts thought into the design of their space by how lovely the bathroom is? Yeah well whoever put this tiny retreat together did a fine job. I love the sink. Love how the tiles glisten depending on your vantage like they are abalone shells.
- The whole sustainable fish idea is pretty cool. Sustainable fish is generally farm-raised. Every table has information on what fish are good to eat and which to avoid.
- Sake list is pretty extensive and surprisingly well-priced. You can definitely stretch your dollar there when it comes to liquor consumption.
- Uni was AMAZING last night... if you are looking for that perfect moment to introduce your palate to the greatness that is a wonderful bite of fresh Uni, here and now are the place and time. Santa Barbara Uni. I'll have to remember that... there is a wonderful caramel sweetness about good uni. Uber Yum.
- Preparation was thoughtful. We didn't eat a lot, but we did eat enough Nigiri to know that the chef put thought into the aesthetics of each cut. 
- Definitely get yourself some Hotate. Scallops were some of the better I've ever had... anywhere.
- They serve you cucumber infused ice water. mm..
- General ambiance: fantastic. Very friendly staff, great recommendations, gave you the space you needed and weren't overly pushy on turning tables (maybe because it wasn't full).
- They played great music. 

What I didn't particularly enjoy about Tataki:
- Wasn't a big fan of the wasabi they offered. It was dry and brittle.
- The sake bottle was glass and had that hole for ice... great idea but it drips everywhere when you touch the thing. I would have preferred another bottle.
- The more expensive sakes seemed to have more thoughtful descriptions. I just thought that was interesting.
- General variety of fish offered was not as great as other restaurants. This could be both good and bad I suppose... I guess when you know what you are good at you stick with it?

Overall, I will definitely be back. I really enjoyed the experience.
author: Annie T.

description: This place is great for a fresh taste of sushi. My favorite roll is the tataki roll. I will definitely go back
author: CT D.

description: This is one of the best sushi spots in the City. And they're sustainable, so I feel like I'm doing something good while stuffing myself full of sushi! They have a great veggie sushi menu. The ratatouille is one of the best rolls I've had anywhere, ever. Literally. The hot potato roll is awesome too. It's a tiny little space, so there can be a long wait for a table. That's why we usually call in for takeout, which is always just as fresh and yummy.
author: Natalie N.

description: The more I go, the more I love this place. We invaded them with the toddlers (us and two other friends) at happy hour time a couple of weeks ago and they were very nice about it. The food was excellent and a great value. Happy hour runs from 5:30pm to 6:30pm.
author: Elsa T.

description:
this place is the size of my studio. if your party is more than 4 people, well. you should feel like an asshole. (my party had 5.) 

prior to coming here, I assumed "vegan sushi" consists of rice wrapped around some julienne cucumber and carrots, with a schmudge of avocadoodoo and a slap in the face. This place took me in, hungry and cold, and showed me the world of ratatouille rolls, vagan california rolls, and other awesomenesses. None of them tasted remotely healthy or authentic, but positively delicious to my slaggy monsanto-honed palate. 

go there to kick off your vegan lifestyle. wash those indulgent little morsels down with saki.  Next week, you'll tackle that wheatgrass shot and go to the gym, but tonight, you learn what vegan sushi could be.
author: Lynn T.

description: I have nothing clever to say about this place. I ate here with my really hot female friend and mainly just tried to keep my eyes on the food instead of her boobs.
author: Jay S.

description: Excellent meal, large vegetarian selection & friendly wait staff. Be prepared to wait as it is small but well worth it!
author: Dan K.

description:
We had a great time.. We were first in the door, so no waiting, but it filled up very quickly... 

The server was very helpful and gave us some pointers since we hadnt had sustainable sushi before.. The best by far was the "double decker" roll.. The quality of the fish was top notch..
author: J G.

description: Oh, wow - so I guess you all have discovered this place, huh?  We went last night and it was totally packed.  Our waitress said that they've been very busy lately.  Good!  This place deserves to be successful.
author: DD B.

description: I would have to say that this is one of the best sushi places in town.  A little neighborhood gem that is always consistent.  =)
author: Suz L.

description:
Highly reccomend the Fire Extinguisher (which comes out on a firey plate) and the 49'er role- topped off with sake sangria- so yummmmy.

Tight on cash- happy hour will cut your sushi bill in half

p.s. all of the fish Tatki uses is sustainable along with the design of the restaurant
author: Crys C.

description:
Love this place! Tataki encompasses all that I like in a SF restaurant. If you're seeking great food, friendly service and a unique atmosphere in a small space, Tataki delivers!

The sashimi was incredibly fresh, seaweed salad flavorful and light, rolls were creative and wonderfly presented, and sake...awesome and "potent!" 

When we arrived around 7pm we thought the place was packed, but packed was not until later around 8:30pm when there was a crowd outside the door waiting.

Tataki is a must if you are in Pac Heights! Get there early, they have a happy hour menu before 7pm anyway!!!
author: Matt K.

description:
Not only sustainable (and as a side note also avoids most of the health issues of mercury and PCB's in big fish), but wonderful, fresh sushi.  We've taken friends from out of town and all have been impressed.   For our weekly sushi fix, we stay in the neighborhood and order vegetarian, but this is the place we come for fish.  

In terms of classics, the calamari tempura appetizer was surprisingly good, as was the spicy tuna roll.  We really enjoyed trying the arctic char carpaccio and the smoked fish sampler from the specials section.  They don't take reservations, but the list is clearly posted and moves fairly fast.
author: Laura C.

description: I'm not sure what my husband and I were expecting, but I thought everything was pretty normal.  The rolls were interesting, yes, and I get the part about eating sustainable fish, but I just didn't think the more-ethical fish was particularly fresh.  The albacore tuna was powdery tasting.  Seating is tight, but we were lucky and got seated immediately.  The waiters were a bit stand-offish and impatient-like, but not exactly rude.  Just won't return next time.
author: Marcellina T.

description: By far, this is the tastiest Japanese restaurant in san francisco. I came here once for the first time because me and my friend were craving for japanese food. Since this was the closest Japanese restaurant from where we were located, we just hopped in and tried this place out. the sashimi are awesome! VERY FRESH with great textures. Sushies are awesome too because they're paired up with interesting sauces too. But this is a typical place for small parties no greater than 4 especially during happy hours (3-7pm?). Great place for party of 2s. RECOMMENDATION: Though Sashimi Delux is more on the pricier price, IT'S A MUST HAVE! SOOO GOOD!! Share it with a friend!
author: Eudora Z.

description:
A couple of weeks ago, had one night in San Francisco during a very short business trip. Colleague and I were on the hunt for a good sushi place and picked Tataki based on Yelp reviews.

Wow. Thank you to everyone who has recommended Tataki. Was fantastic. Very tasty sushi, nicely presented. Wide-ranging selection beyond the usual. Sustainability focus much appreciated. Service was wonderful. Atmosphere was perfect.

Sushi places back home don't compare. Very much looking forward to the chance to stop in at Tataki next time in San Francisco.
author: A B.

description:
I just want to say that Nobu K.'s review below is completely misleading. I went to Tataki last night as it has become one of my favorite sushi restaurants, and I had a long discussion with the waitress about Nobu's Yelp review. I had not read the review yet, but as she described it it was full of hate and anger. Her description was accurate.

Nobu K. should get his facts straight. He claims that the chefs are not trained, and that is flat out wrong. Although they may be from Hong Kong, they are formally trained.

The sushi is excellent. The service is friendly. The atmosphere is modern and intimate. I could care less if they serve me cold water, even if that is not customary in Japan. 

This is probably not a traditional sushi restaurant, but I don't know that it claims to be completely traditional. There is a huge variety of sushi restaurants in San Francisco, and they all have their place. These guys are doing a great job bringing sustainability to sushi, and they should be commended for that.

Clearly Nobu K. is pretty much alone in his review. Almost all other reviewers give Tataki increadibly high marks. If you click on the link Nobu K. provides of his other reviews of sushi restaurants, you can see that he is a very hateful person. All his reviews are filled with swearing and racist remarks. I wish you could flag a user on Yelp.
author: Elana W.

description: I've gone to Tataki for lunch and they have an awesome lunch menu, which runs about $11.  Yes a bit pricey for lunch, but the sashimi is soooooo good. Splurge and enjoy.
author: Me Like Good Food S.

description: I really have to admire what Tataki is trying to do here. Sustainable sushi is definitely something we all need to be encouraging. It just makes me so sad that all the best stuff happens to be on the Toxic 5 list. I love hamachi, sake, unagi and maguro! Sadly though I don't think Tataki has managed to quite replicate the delicious flavors of those particular fish. I tried the arctic char, the kanpachi, the California roll and the 49er roll. The only one that really replicated the richness of non-sustainable sushi. It's clear they use quality ingredients but I even felt like the seasoning on the rice was off. I will continue to support Tataki because I think what they are doing is important but I hope I just ate there on an off night and next time it's as great as everyone has been saying.
author: Cathy T.

description: Really good as far as sushi goes! We decided to check Tataki out on a recent visit back to San Francisco. Wish this place was open when I lived in Pac Heights, because I really enjoyed it (and can't believe it used to be a Subway location!). Although a bit on the small side, the place is very cozy and a bit more upscale than the typical neighborhood sushi spot. We ordered a variety of rolls (spicy tuna... yum!) and some sashimi, all of which were very fresh and delicious.
author: Chris B.

description: Very good, and their sustainability ethic led to different tastes than other sushi places I've been to. I wouldn't put them at the top of my sushi list, but the food was quite excellent. Definitely worth going again, but I don't know that I'd go out of my way to go there in particular.
author: Doug B.

description: Not the best sushi I have ever had but it comes close. The sustainable fish theme is a good differentiator and place the itself is quiet and clean, if not a little cramped. I have no idea why it is so hot in there so don't dress warmly. The Tataki specials are great for those seeking something other than rolls and they have a wide variety of sake. They also have lots of vegetarian options. Don't forget to try the Green Tea Cheesecake.
author: Kiran G.

description:
First date my bf and I went on as a live in couple to...
It was such a romantic walk
A nice 30 minute wait while we talked and cuddled outside on the bench.
And what a nice dinner!!  I had a glass of red wine and he had a soju type of mai tai(kinda bland )
This place is environmentally aware and educates you on the type of fish they use, the kind you should eat and not eat to prevent extinction and inhumane farming.
The rolls we ordered were delicous and amazing!!  Melt in your mouth good ,.. I think one was called the extinguisher.. spicy but not over powerring!  I cannot get over how good their fish was!  Very fresh!  We also tried the Tataki ofcourse! That was to die for as well.
One roll looked like it may have had nuts on it and my bf is very allergic.. so we asked a waitor to find out and he never ended up back.. that was mildly irritating.  annoying.  
Our regular server was great, though(really sweet girl that felt terrible about our wait)
The dessert was out of this world!!  Green Tea cheesecake!!  I had to take lil bites to savor each morsel! Holy Moly I had to be rolled out!  I am so happy we live so close to such a great suchi place!!  yay!!  A great date indeed!!
author: blair k.

description: I really do think this is now the best sushi in the City. All the fish is sustainable, everything tastes so fresh, and the owners and staff are so nice. Even their house sake is good. I almost dont want to write this review because I'm worried that people will start to crowd my favorite neighborhood place, but I think the word is already out.
author: Jenica M.

description: The sushi here was good.  They have a lot of spicy sushi options, which I am a fan of.  Definitely worth a try.  I cannot remember the names of the rolls I tried, but you can probably figure it out by looking for the spicier rolls on the menu.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I agree with a previous yelper: The idea behind Tataki gets 5 stars.  I have carried around a Sustainable Seafood Watch card for many years now, but it is very unpractical to use it, especially at a Japanese Restaurant.  How many times are you going to make a waitress run back and find out if your salmon was farmed or from Washington or from somewhere else!? So the fact that they make all the sustainable choices for you is amazing.  
However, we had to wait almost 1 hour for rolls (we were already seated!!) that weren't even that tasty!! Also, the price was a little too high, especially for the measely amount of fish they serve.  
So, 1 star knocked off for super duper crazy slow service and 1 more knocked off for the rolls being kinda blah.
author: Jacqueline T.

description: Meh. I've had MUCH MUCH better sushi and service. This place is small...we were one of two couples in the entire restaurant and we still had to wait way too long for our initial appetizer/roll. I have no reason to go back here (other than mayyybe the eco-friendly aspect)...
author: Camille R.

description:
Bottom Line:  The food is 5 stars and the service is 2 stars

I 've been to all of the so called best sushi restaurants in SF including Ozumo & Sushi Groove.  The food at Tataki is every bit as good as those place but the service simply sucks .  The host  accidently skipped our name on the list and didnt even apologize.  The food is slow and the waiters are flighty and not well informed about the food
author: Jeff S.

description: The sushi were pretty good, but it doesn't justify the pricing!  I've had sushi that are equivalent to Tataki, but cost about 30% less!  $6.00 for a California Roll???  A wee bit steep.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
My all-time favorite here is the chirashi, and they don't serve it for dinner.

I tried rolls and tataki deluxe and was disappointed at the quality and upset how expensive it is. Will stick with the chirashi.
author: Amy C.

description:
I am not usually compelled to ever write reviews, but my group's experience at Tataki was disappointing enough to finally write one.  There were five of us in our party so the 25 minute wait was expected and not a problem. What was a problem was waiting that long for a table big enough for five and then being given a table that was only for four.  I didn't think that was going to be a problem since the fifth person could have just sat on the end. That lasted half a minute before we were told to get out of the server's way and squeeze three people on to one side of this very small table.  Apparently that still wasn't good enough so the other server kicked my chair as she passed.  Instead of receiving an apology she stared me down and made sure I knew our five-person group was an inconvenience. I don't know if she was having a bad day or not but she definitely made us not have an enjoyable experience. 

I realize service can be hit or miss at many restaurants so I will say that the food was good and the concept was interesting.  I definitely have never eaten sushi while listening to the Notorious B.I.G. If SF wasn't such a big city with so many restaurants to choose from I might be compelled to give them a second try, but too bad for them that isn't the case.
author: Erik Z.

description:
Tonight they caught me on my "explorer" mood.

I was thinking: real salad is lettuce and dressing. Not lettuce, tomatoes, tuna, apples, nuts, raisins, etc. But then... such a "salad" is good too!
So let's go for some non-sushi "sushi".
And it was pretty good indeed.

I was pleased by the explosive taste of their new-wave california-style sushi. If you're a sushi purist, this is not for you. I would say I am, but again, tonight I appreciated the creativity of their rolls and their carpaccios.

Definitely a "go-back".
author: Peppe R.

description:
OHHHHHH Tataki! A former Subway location never looked so good!

I heart you so! And the waiters recognize me, which is a sure-fire sign I am here quite often.

I don't crave specific sushi rolls quite often - but now that I have tasted the deliciously spicy Extinguisher Roll, and the 49er Roll, and the Tataki roll, and the Double Double Roll....and the.... you probably get my point-
This is for sure my favorite sushi restaurant in the city!

And between you and me...I don't miss the fish they don't serve here either. As this is a sustainable sushi joint, they do not serve salmon and unagi. (bleehhh unagi) 

Lunch menu is abbreviated here since it is so close to a school that gets hit at lunch....but you still can't go wrong with anything that has the artic char in it!

PS-- Don't try showing up with your group of 8 - - it is an old Subway for goodness sakes! Big parties should avoid this joint, as it is rather cramped quarters for groups of more than 4.
author: Erin C.

description: 2 out of 3 rolls were awesome (crunchy spicy tuna and double double). The third was still pretty good (mix it up). Missing some standard items due to 'sustainability' issues. Reasonable price. Definitely will be back.
author: Jeremy M.

description: I've been looking for a good sushi place in my hood for a while. This place fits the bill. It's really small, so get there early to get a table. I live close so I usually order to go and bring it home. The spicy tuna rolls are great, but I'm not that adventurous when it comes to sushi, so I can't intelligently opine on the rest of the menu.
author: Josh G.

description: I love sushi, especially cheap happy hour sushi.  Really fresh fish. Love the crunchy rolls.  Cons:  the restaurant is small and parking is hard to find, so you have to get there early to avoid a long wait.
author: angela t.

description: The most conscious sushi place I've found in the city. I was impressed that they only serve sustainably caught fish. Try the jalepeno roll- it's ridiculous! They also have the best vegetarian menu I've seen at a sushi place and a great sake menu as well. Small place and no reservations, so try to get there earlier rather than later. Yum.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Tataki is not a sushi restaurant, it's a social experiment to see if San Franciscans are dumb enough to pay $30 to eat Americanized, "sustainable sushi".  Unfortunately I failed.

After ordering drinks I felt my stomach sink like a rock.  Our waitress mentioned in her sermon on sustainability that they wouldn't be serving yellowtail, salmon or eel.  I've been to Catholic churches so I'm familiar with religions requiring abstinence.  Yet, this felt like the equivalent of In-And-Out Burger deciding not to carry hamburger, fries, ketchup and buns.  She'd prohibited my order in total and I felt like a dirty enviro-sinner.

Luckily there was still chance for redemption.   She went on to mention that I could order their "sustainable" alternatives for the salmon and yellowtail.  I started to wonder if these alternatives would be "sustainable" if all sushi shops used them, but was distracted by feelings of benevolence and acceptance.

The miso soup came first.  It clearly had too little salt and no fish stock, I'm guessing to keep vegetarians happy.  Sorry vegetarians, Japanese food is not meant for you.  The rolls themselves weren't bad, but they were all spicy which is often the mark of a Korean sushi chef.   The fish were very watery, appearing to have been frozen.  They also forgot the "sushi" in "sushi rice", there was no taste of vinegar.

The decor was very soothing and the staff was very welcoming.  I would say that the service was very good but I kept feeling a bit like I was dining in the center of a "Stress Test" encampment.  On the way out they even tried to force some sustainability pamphlets on me--no thanks Environmentologists!

If you're thinking of eating here for good sushi please look at the number of 3 and 4 star reviews that give bonus stars for "sustainability" or being "eco-friendly".
author: David R.

description:
Being a vegetarian, sushi is never my first pick when it comes to choosing a place to go eat. Tataki has changed my view forever!

Hands down, the best vegetarian sushi I have ever had. The service is great and they are very helpful with recomedations.

If you are a fan of sweet potatoes-I recommend that roll. The ratatouille and Regge roll are my other favorites. 

The ambiance is nice and the sake selection is also great.  There is always a wait, so I recommend going early, putting your name on the list and going next door for drinks.
author: Avani S.

description: The arctic char carpaccio has to be one of the best things I've ever had the pleasure of putting in my mouth. So fresh. So yummy. I'll be back for more.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I went again last night and it was even better then before... this place may hold the spot as my favorite sushi restaurant in SF. yum! My friend and i sat at the bar and the men making the sushi were so fun to watch and to joke with.. they have some really awesome rolls, many on fire and all with amazing presentation. I give it a 10. also try the mochi ice cream.. almost as good as Bubbies in Hawaii which is a huge compliment!
author: Barbara C.

description: Well...just got back from eating here with four friends and I must say, this is by far, the best sushi ive had...ever. The service was great, the fish was fresh, the prices were great (for sustainable sushi) and the atmosphere was perfect. We purchased many of the specialty rolls and some char and tempura rolls and they were perfect. I dont know what else to say other than this place was worth every cent. Five of us paid 96 bucks and we were all very satisfied. Will go back for sure.
author: Franky G.

description: We really liked the ambiance, but the food was only so-so, mainly because it did not feel like we were getting good value.  The tataki sampler was tasty but not enough fish for $30.  Otherwise, the rolls we ordered were nice, especially the extinguisher role.  Overall, this place seemed like a place I'd go for a quick sushi night out, but is not a can't miss destination.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Great sushi, great service. Small place, but when we went (late on a Wednesday evening) we had no trouble walking in. The Tataki roll is excellent.
author: Ryan K.

description: Both owners Raymond and Kin are pioneers at combining out-of-this-world sushi with sustainable practices. It's awesome to know that the owners are choosing fish that's low in mercury, local, and even promoting vegetarian options for a Sushi restaurant. I recently read a pretty cool background story about Tataki and their partnership with Fishwise and the Monterey Bay Aquarium to preserve eco-friendly practices - http://sfrecess.com/tataki-422
author: Edwin F.

description:
I was absolutely ecstatic when I found out a sushi restaurant was opening in my building. And this one more than lives up to my expectations!

The edamame is always perfectly done here and both the Seaweed Salad and Garden Salad are excellent starters.

The 'Extinguisher Roll' is not to be missed! It has the perfect amount of slow heat. This roll keeps me coming back for more. The 'Tataki Roll' is also excellent with a nice combination of seafood present.

There is a nice selection of Vegetarian rolls and the 'Philadelphia Roll' is a nice alternative for smoked salmon aficionados.

The ambiance is excellent and the servers are wonderful! 5 Stars!
author: Julian L.

description: Tataki was delicious, cute space and the food presentation was delightful.  I love that they pay mind to good sustainability practices and only include responsibly-fished items on their menu.  I will definitely go back for more yummy sushiness.
author: oh em g.

description: My boyfriend had heard about Tataki during a program on NPR because of their sustainable sushi slant, and telling me that is all it took to pique my interest. I was in a party of 3 on a Saturday night, where this small sushi restaurant was packed. When we finally got a table, I ordered the Extinguisher from the Specialty Rolls section of the menu. The roll is composed of spicy amberjack topped with avocado, habanero masago, and hot sauce. The plate included about 8 pieces, which was filling enough for me, and featured a small dune of lemon salt set ablaze. Yes, there was fire on the plate. The roll was quite spicy, but I liked it a lot. I believe my dining mates were similarly impressed with their selections. Tataki, you will be seeing me again. Oh, and +5 for the sustainability slant!
author: Ben D.

description: You'll want to bring your patience. The benefits of waiting for the delight that you will experience at Tataki are unlimited. Come as early as Happy Hour where you'll have the opportunity to consume discounted beverages and succulent sushi. My favorite dish is not included in the Happy Hour menu, however if you can handle a seriously hottt dish, I highly recommend the Spicy Tempura. This place is sizzlin' hot.
author: Jasmine W.

description: Tataki gets 5 stars for good service, good food and totally guilt free dining. I'm not too adventurous yet with my sushi eating, so I had a rainbow roll, shrimp tempura roll, california roll and and arctic char roll. All were quite good. The shrimp and crab here had some really good flavor. The happy hour rolls were really a good deal too. The fact that everything served is completely sustainable is fantastic. I would totally go here again.
author: Erik S.

description:
let's say one thing first.. this place is TINY! probably fits about 30-35 covers but it is more along the lines of cozy rather than cramped. The food to note is nothing too crazy nor out of the ordinary, however, let me say this the quality of the fish is pretty amazing. Tataki's major marketing point of focus is the use of sustainable seafood that provides an alternative to your usual seafood selections that the "other" places usually do not prefer to give piece of mind to. This sustainability not only helps with the prevention of over farming in certain areas of the world that is causing harm to the local eco-system. Now let me tell you, i'm not a rookie sushi go-er i'm actually quite the fanatic and i hold japanese food and sushi very close to my heart and It could just be me, personally, but somehow it seems like the quality and taste of the fish here is simply heavenly (maybe i just came in on a good day right after purchase but HEY who knows!) All in all, this place is definitely worth trying ATLEAST once.. then you can go back to your normal fav. 

Ahh yes one more thing before i forget.. prices are about normal - above normal considering the quality
author: Timothy W.

description: This place was that' bomb diggity. the freshest,  most melt in your mouthiest sushi I have tasted in a while. They don't have much salmon on their menu, but never fear. The waitress explained to us that they use some other kind of sustainable fish ( the name escapes me) that tastes very similar to salmon. We tried it and it was wonderful. I absolutely could not tell that it wasn't salmon. The space is very small and rather cramped though with an upscale feel, but the food is to die for. Very impressed by the reasonable happy hour prices!  I will be back without a doubt...
author: Susannah S.

description: I REALLY, really, really wanted to like this place for a multitude of reasons.  Unfortunately, it totally let me down....for a multitude of reasons.  Check out http://youngbrokegreen.blogspot.com/2009/07/restaurant-review-tataki.html for my entire review, if you're interested.
author: Dale M.

description: Yum. Really good sushi. I have been looking for a new sushi place close to my place for the after work cravings. I found it! Went here on my first weekend in San Francisco. BIG ROLLS. I wouldn't order more tha n3  to split with a friend unless you're really hungry. Spicy Tuna and California Rolls were amazing. Definitely heading back.
author: Kristin M.

description: I've been here about 20-30 times, although this place isn't cheap, it's definitely worth it. The arctic char and 7 piece nigiri combo is always a hit! Plus you get miso soup or salad to go with that! The sushi is always well-prepared, and another thing that comes in very handy is that the waiters will give you your order first if you mention that you're in a hurry. Again, the only downside is that it's expensive, especially the dessert. But a great lunch spot overall!
author: Igor B.

description: I loved sitting down and seeing a flyer on the table from the Monterey Bay Aquarium about what fish to eat and not.  Not that I will follow ALL of the suggestions (my future kids don't need to know how delicious shrimp are), but it was cool to see it.  Everything we got was fantastic.  We even had order envy from delicious and beautifully arranged plates going to our neighbors.  The Tataki rolls and dishes certainly rock the hizzouse.  As do the Tuna Poke and the specialty rolls.  I"m already thinking of recruiting newbies for a return trip real soon!
author: Chard M.

description:
The sushi at Tataki is amazing! The extinguisher is my favorite roll and it comes out with a flame on the plate which adds some excitement. It's a very small place - maybe 10 tables - so maybe not the best place for a group bigger than 4 people. 

Highy recommended.
author: Allie G.

description: Stopped by here for lunch on a whim one day.  Wasn't impressed with the service - the place was not busy but it still took a long time to order and then get my order.  Headed home - and then about 30 minutes later, I had to run to the bathroom.  Guess I got some bad sushi...
author: Bobbi C.

description: this place was AMAZING!! I've been searching for a place with an amazing spicy tuna roll (my favorite) and they have it! We also got a rainbow roll which was just as beautiful as it was delicious, and a mix it up- which confused us all because it was sweet at first and then spicy. We were wishing we had ordered the extinguisher, because it comes out on fire, but it's a good reason to go back!
author: Sara R.

description: Well....I went here for my birthday dinner because Koo was closed.  It got such great reviews here, so I tried it.  I guess it's great because they have lots of info about sustainable fishing and they only serve sustainably harvested fish.  The Oysters were very fresh (yum) and the Norwegian Saba Nigiri was great.  But over-all, I wasn't too excited about this.  Our server was in a bad mood or something and well, when it comes to sushi, I've had better. I'm not sure if I've had better that was environmentally friendly, so like I said, I appreciated that.  But.....I was not really blown away by the creations of the chef....I've had better.
author: Lanie W.

description:
Would have given them 3 stars based on quality of sushi alone. Its solid, but nothing spectacular. However, the fact that it's environmentally sustainable and that they play good music makes it a 4 for me. It's also has a really small and cozy ambiance that adds to it's charm. Good spot to take out-of-towners.

Favorite is the fire roll - it's a got a nice kick and the presentation is pretty cool with the flame volcano on the plate.
author: Charles M.

description: Good sushi. Friendly service. Not going to wow you. Straight up quality though. Live close and will definitely be back.
author: Christopher T.

description:
Absolutely fabulous. Exceedingly fresh, simple, delicious sushi. Super nice staff. They routinely waive corkage when I bring champagne. 

Sure, it's a little small. But who cares. Just get there early.
author: Max B.

description:
liked the atmosphere.  almost all the fish was super fresh.  the arctic char and kanpachi were especially good.  the specialty rolls were very tasty and well made.  

there were problems with the 'flow' of food.  we sat way too long without anything on our table at one point, then got a bunch of things all at once.  keep it coming chef, even if it's one item at a time!

the bill was higher than average, but worth it for the overall quality.
author: Alfredo I.

description:
Well, let me just say this from a selfish, personal perspective..if you do NOT go here, then all the better for me.  From a very true perspective, if you do NOT go here, you are out of your mind.  My wife, of 48 hours now,  found this true gem right here on Yelp.  Reading the reviews something did not add up, but it was intriguing.  How can you have 4 1/2 stars with a low $$ rating and serve top quality sushi?  Let me tell you how.  After reading the menu, I had to ask our incredibly knowledgable server Gretchen " I see everything on the menu is either line caught or totally sustainable.  How in the world can you do this at this price point?"  Without going into detail, our conversation summed up to this....a true love and belief in the food, technique and seasonality without making you think that what you are paying for or about to experience is going to make you feel like you just gave up your savings or money market account.
From the unique baked mussels, the sparking, yes sparking, Sake, to the incredible green tea cheesecake, there was not a moment where we did not look at each other and just know that we were experiencing something extremely special.
Every person in this very comfortable, very quaint location believed and UNDERSTOOD exactly what they were creating and serving.  Each dish was so different, so bright in their flavors that we found ourselves looking at the menu asking "OK, what next?"  Because we had so many courses we could not try everthing but we did the next best thing, we looked at the menu and discussed what we would have next time we returned.  It was that special.
Service was fantastic.  Beyond knowledgable, very attentive.  The chefs and owners (one in the same) work behind a small 4 seat sushi bar and create beautiful and intriguing dishes.
We will be back many times.  We have found a new place to share with our friends.  Hopefully you will try it as well, you will be so pleased.
author: Lizza M.

description:
food 5; service 5; value 4

Super fresh sushi and super friendly service.  definitely worth many repeat trips.

try the artic char with avocado - yummy!
author: Stacy N.

description:
It is so nice to be able to go eat fish and not have to ask if the fish is farmed, etc.  Everything they serve is sustainable and they meet the Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch guidelines.

This is a great small sushi restaurant with very nice staff, especially the chefs one of whom I think is an owner.  The food is great, the rolls are a good size but not the huge ones you can't get in your mouth that fill you up on rice.  Do be ready to eat things that may be different from your usual picks.  You wont find Unagi (which we shouldn't be eating at this point) and Salmon is hit and miss depending on a supply that meets their standards.  However they have good substitutes for both.  They make a Faux Nagi with black cod that is great and use Arctic Char in place of Salmon at times.

This place is awesome!
author: telo s.

description:
amazing fish
great service
sustainable
creative and beautiful presentation
very affordable
author: renee j.

description:
Sustainable sushi.  With the recently announced salmon ban, it is easy to see the importance of sustainable sushi and on that point alone I am a big Tataki fan.  

There are other reasons that this is my new neighborhood sushi spot though... the "Sashimi Regular" is a fantastic array of VERY tasty sashimi.  I've also had several rolls and other menu items.  The food at this restaurant is put together with thought.  I love it!  

The service is friendly and fast, yet timed nicely... at dinner with my fiance, we ordered several items and everything came out slowly enough that we could enjoy one dish before another was set down on the table (not the norm at other neighborhood sushi restaurants).  I agree with other yelpers mentioning great ambiance... this tiny restaurant used to be a Subway?  You would never know -- the interior is so cozy, yet not cramped.  

One review mentions speed, and at this point there are 2 sushi chefs working at a time as well as a few servers.  Nothing was slow, and all tables (except one) were full.  Looking around the room, I felt like the service was probably prompt for everyone else too =).

Also of note is price... this restaurant serves sustainable fish.  To spell it out for you, that means that they are paying more, and putting in more effort to bring us the freshest, yummiest, and most environmentally friendly fish out there!  How great is that!?  I love it.  I am willing to pay a dollar more per item to get great, healthy, better for me and definitely tastier fish.  Definitely!  

With all of that said, I guess the one thing I would change is the sign... not that I am complaining, but I want there to be more curb appeal =).  I want everyone in the neighborhood to see the restaurant and make it their go-to sushi spot too!  =)
author: Sara S.

description:
There is fault with those reviews that rate this "mediocre".   It's fresh, sustainable fish with flair.  A small place that has a handful of tables and two sushi chefs.  There was a long wait...but headed next door for a drink at Solstice.  Started with Calamari (on the house due to the wait....points for service).  I recommend these rolls:

1) Artic Char with Avocado
2) Double Double
3) Early Bird- filet mignon w/asparagus
4) Extinguisher- spicy role on a flaming plate

Sushi rolls ranged from $6-7 for basics and $11-15 for specials.  There is a happy hour!
author: around town e.

description: Fresh! Fresh! Good environment/ambience. Good music. Good service. Nice cute spot..worth the $$. My bf and I usually eat sushi once a week in TX/CA..we would definitely  come back and recommend this place to friends/family : )
author: Lisa R.

description:
Went with a friend from LA and we can both say that Tataki has some of the best sashimi we have ever eaten. The staple sashimi: salmon, tuna, and albacore was tender (almost like butter) and delicious. The rest of the fish selection was unique and tasty.

As for the rest of the experience, the sake selection was good and had some interesting flavors. The waiters were friendly and professional.

The price was reasonable considering the quality of the fish. We ordered the 20 piece sashimi platter for $36 with a bowl of rice.

The place itself is a bit small, but cozy and inviting. The only issue I had was that there wasn't much space to wait inside. We had to stand outside (luckily the weather wasn't cold).
author: Abhik P.

description: This place is awesome. The freshest fish. Arctic char and albacore are amazing. Highly recommend the sashime regular.
author: Amanda V.

description: Sushi without the guilt!  Amazingly fresh and delicious.  Great staff, friendly and helpful.  I love it.  We try to make it here once a month, even though we live across the bay!
author: Zorba Z.

description: Cute little place in a neighborhood always in need of more restaurants - mine! Love what they're doing as far as sustainable fish. Easy place to walk in, at this point anyway, and on a weeknight at least, and easily get a table for a last-minute dinner out. Thought the fish tasted really fresh, the extinguisher roll was fun since the plate came out on fire, and the sake was good. Pricing seemed reasonable enough for fresh fish. The restaurant could do to (1) dim their lighting a bit - at 10pm it felt like broad daylight! and (2) improve their service. We had to flag people down to order more and to get the bill. Nothing phenomenal but a good addition to the hood with good food ethics.
author: Sarah R.

description: I wanted to like Tataki more than I did.  I'll give it points for having good fish and kind of creative rolls and being a cute little spot.  I'll dock it points for having most of the same fish as any other sushi spot.  Carrying arctic char instead of salmon does not make you sustainable.  Plenty of other sushi restaurants carry artic char and little if anything on the AVOID list and they don't claim anything special.  I'll also dock points for value.  The sashimi sampler we had was over $30 and it didn't even begin to fill us up.  And all the special rolls are all $11 and over?  Plus they're all super tiny.  We didn't get any drinks and  2 people still spent over $60 without tip and left hungry.  Since Tataki isn't in my neighborhood I doubt I'll be back much, if at all, but it may be a good option if you happen to be in the area.
author: M M.

description: Some of the sushi was rubbery and hard to chew... and it wasn't tako (octopus)!!! Although, shrimp tempura roll was excellent. Went for lunch - might be better quality fish at dinner.
author: Anita S.

description: Short but sweet: This is some of the best sushi and sake I've ever had, and it's affordable! We used to come here every week and the staff is great.
author: Sai Y.

description: I wandered in one afternoon looking for a light lunch and was very pleased....I had a two roll meal with salad that was excellent.  Both of the rolls that I had were inventive with fish I don't normally see on menus, Artic Char and another one....some sort of jack, both were tasty.  I will be back..highly recommend lunch for no crowds and great prices!
author: Brye L.

description: Excellent. The fish was incredibly fresh, very creative, and perhaps best of all sustainable!  It's so wonderful to see people taking the lead in living, and eating sustainably.  Add to that incredible sushi, a great vibe and people who truly care about the environment and it can't get much better!
author: Amy P.

description: excellent sushi. as many vegan/vegetarian options as there are fish options and although i do not eat fish i admire that they line catch all their fish. i think this is the best sushi i have ever had! and cute waitstaff!
author: Meghan B.

description: Very cool place that specializes in sustainable sushi. I didn't have their fancier rolls because I wasn't really trying to impress anybody, but if you are on a date, i would suggest you go for the extinguisher roll! It has a live flame!!! On the other hand, I got the spicy tuna roll (which was actually pretty spicy), futomaki roll, and the philadelphia roll. The venue is pretty small but cozy. I really enjoyed eating here and savored the sushi while I could. What a great find!
author: Dave Y.

description: Yes, there was a long wait, but we showed up with 6 people at 8:30 on a Saturday night, so what did we expect?  AND they gave us an order of fried calamari on the house for the wait (which was delicious, by the way, and we'd definitely order that).  This place is a treat with delicious sushi, sustainable fish, and interesting rolls.  Definitely try the Artic Char and the Extinguisher rolls.  The service was great, prices reasonable, and a cute little cozy atmosphere.  I will definitely be coming back here!  (Just saw Laura F.'s review--we were there together, but she beat me to the punch with her review).   We also saw the sashimi baskets and regretted not ordering one of those.
author: Sara B.

description: very tasty sushi -- especially the fire extinguisher role which actually comes out on fire.  The only issues are the place is very small so the wait can be long and the food is a bit expensive.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Though I have long known about Tataki, I finally dragged myself across town for a visit last night.  This will not be the last time I make the trek.  Not only is the sushi mind-blowingly good, I didn't leave feeling guilty about the number of endangered species I had just consumed.  And, unlike so many other organic, sustainable, environmentally friendly options, the cost is no more than any other sushi restaurant I have been to in the city.  My partner and I had sake, an appetizer, three special rolls, and nigiri for under $50.00.

So good.  In so many ways.
author: Stella B.

description: I had nigiri of Halibut, Mackeral, and Tuna, each of wish was very good.  I also had a happy hour roll of avocado and char, which was mediocre.  The other happy hour roll (that my wife got) was spicy california roll was very good...actually had some spice.  The place is a 'sustainable' sushi place, but its not super green themed...just a normal sushi place.  I would definitely come back.
author: Jason S.

description: I came here for one of my first dates, and it had a nice ambiance.  Sushi is good, service is good, and I recommend for anyone trying to make a good impression on a date. I would come back again.
author: tianyu c.

description: Enjoyable in every way.  The space, service, sushi and saki were all above average.  I will return.
author: Teri K.

description:
I heard about this sushi place and finally tried it yesterday.  I like the idea of using only sustainable fish..well..give them credit for at least puttting effort to save Nemo. Food was great overall. However, they put too much source on some of the sushi rolls which overwhelmed the fresh taste of fish. 2 people spent $90 only got us half full. Went to King of Thai for second around right after.

3 stars for food and 1 for the effort
author: gary t.

description:
I was pretty impressed - this is one of the better sushi restaurants I've been to in San Francisco.  Everything is so good, there's no need to even touch any soy sauce.  

We had:
1) Miso Soup - delicious, not sure why, but better than other misos.  
2) Edamame - normal, but I've had better.  
3) Arctic Char Carpaccio - the high recommendation from other yelpers is deserved.  This was impressive.  
4) 4 oysters - I've had much better.  I guess the lesson is - don't go to a sushi restaurant to get oysters.  
5) Sashimi Taster - there is a zero percent chance of me returning to this restaurant and not getting this dish (unless they remove it from the menu) - the fish just tasted perfectly fresh.  
6) Extinguisher Roll - great spice, very tasty, but I was mildly (ha) let down because it wasn't as amazing as other yelpers made it out to be.  
7) Spicy Tempura Roll - this was the best surprise of the meal.  Wow - that is some delicious food.  Loved the jalapenos on top.  
8) Golden State Roll - very creative and very tasty.  I liked the touch of apple.  
9) Coffee Jello - not good.  No one liked this.  Sorry, but it's true.  
10) Green Tea Cheesecake - pretty good, but not jaw-dropping.  I guess you really don't go to a sushi restaurant for the dessert.  

Overall, great experience.  Quality of sushi is well above average.  I'll be back for sure.  The wait is long, but that's not a point against the restaurant.  That just means it's good.
author: Luke P.

description: this has been one of my favorite hot spot for lunch. the sushi are fresh, salad is refreshing and the staff are totally awesome!!!
author: Tess C.

description: If you have kids do not dare to walk in as you will not only  get the worse  service.  I happen to visit friends that live close by.  The server had nasty attitude, and so did the rest of the staff.  There was nothing Japanese in that place.  we got part of the food before our drinks, we had o ask 10 times for Ginger and got it when we were all done.  The Tuna was so bad like it was attacked with salt to avoid the bad taste of old fish. over-all this small nasty place full of attitude and bad food that is way over priced will never ever see our face again.  This was the first and very last time I will ever visit there nor will my friends....I guess it is a good thing I work for the food critics back at home in LA....good luck staying open after I share my thought or two.  My advice to you go eat at CPK as we did after paying $70 for nasty food. people who have no skills of customer service.
author: Sharon B.

description: I kept running across this place on yelp and kept meaning to try it, and I'm glad I did.  I read that the place is small and always packed, so we got there early on a Friday night, a little after 6:00 pm, and there was no wait and a few empty tables.  We even caught the happy hour menu, which goes until 7:00 pm if I remember correctly (cheaper rolls and alcohol, etc.).  We tried the poke, which comes in three different flavors (all three were great), and tried various rolls.  The fish was soft and fresh and the service was great.  the only downside was that we were sitted in a middle table close to the tables on either side of us, and could hear our neighbor's conversations a little too well.  I would come back for sure!
author: Andie A.

description:
Delicious.  The menu is innovative, the service is great and best of all, the fish is fresh and sustainable.

I've been a few times and each time have been really happy with what we ordered.  The crab croquette (sweet potato was a nice touch) and the Tataki roll were fantastic!  The extinguisher was another favorite, though be prepared for the heat as it's spicy.

It can get crowed although the wait isn't very long and the food is worth it.
author: Sam M.

description:
A very nice dinner experience.

Service was wonderful from a numerous, professional, and kind staff that oversees a rather small restaurant.

Some of the sushi items were really high quality: the scallop and sea urchin in particular.

The nigiri items generally were very good, though selection was limited in some respects.

I really enjoyed the Extinguisher roll.

The dissapointment largely related to the shiro maguro tataki.  The fish itself was good, but he "tataki" theme was really missed by simply serving the fish sliced on a plate with sauce on the side.  So, Tataki missed on its rendition of tataki--which really ought not to happen.

However, the service quality and ingredient quality still rank high.  A really fair rating would be 4 and a half, but that is not an option.  So, giving the benefit to the very charming waitress, make it a 5.
author: Richard P.

description: I went today for lunch and it was really mixed experience.  I so wanted to  support and love this place, you know, sustainable sushi and all that.  Their heart is in the right place.  But actually the chirashi bowl (with 7 pieces of raw fish over rice for $16) was totally mediocre at best...Most of the fish was tasteless, not bad per se, just tasteless. I've actually never had such tasteless fish before.  Weird.   One of the chef's had unaccountably given me the evil eye when I walked in so i wondered if he had used their worst fish dregs when he made it.  Or maybe I just got them on a bad day.  Even tho it was adorable inside, and my waiter was sweet and accomodating, I won't be back.  There's about 10 other sushi bars in the Bay Area much, much  better for the money.  Just order sustainably at those.  And when I got back to my car I had a  $50 ticket for street cleaning, but, hey,  I can't blame that part on the evil chef, even if i want to.
author: T S.

description: Sustainable sushi as a concept is great. The resulting sushi is ok. I would say the best from this restaurant is the  vegetarian sushi, which is really good for a place that also serves fish. So if you are in a night out with veg and non-vegs, this place can please everyone to an extent. I would have given it four stars for this. But, service here has always been a problem. We have been here four times, and always had problems getting a table (i.e. out of order wait list), the server was rude to a few in our table a couple of times, and food wait can be long. Enjoy appetizers if you plan to come here. The waiting time outside is not so bad, compared to any good sushi in SF or East Bay.
author: RR R.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday. This place is so tiny compared to the sushi places in Reno. We came here on Friday, it was super packed and had to put our names on a list. We were waiting outside and noticed the people that came after us had gotten seated first. Once we got seated it took them so long to help us, but as soon as we got the sushi, I must say it was the BEST sushi I have ever had. Although this is a little pricey compared to all you can eat sushi back in Reno, it was def. worth it. 

Food- Five Stars 
Customer Service- One Star
author: Nicole H.

description:
its actually been a long time since i wrote a review, but im VERY passionate about how good this restaurant is, so im literally writing this review right after i got home from tataki. 

i first heard about tataki when i was at the california academy of sciences happy hour, where the exec chef at tataki was demonstrating how to cook with sustainable seafood/sushi, something i basically had zero understanding about. what the hell is sustainable sushi?? 

the more i found out about sustainable sushi, the more i realized how awesome this place is. if u are passionate about doing ur part in eco-friendly stuff, this is ur place. at this restaurant i read about how they fish bluefin tuna, where they use long poles with hooks all over them, and sometimes they catch random fish they dont want, or turtles, or other sea life that just become collateral damage when fishing bluefin tuna. hence, they dont serve bluefin tuna. i also learned about how eel farming is so crappy for the environment, so they also do not serve that as well. instead, they serve this other kind of fish (forgot what the name was, but on the menu its called faux-nagi) with a similar texture blowtorched to the same color as eel, with the same greasy sauce on top of it, and i could honestly barely tell the difference. if anything, it tasted BETTER than regular unagi. all dishes i tried here were SO delicious. highly recommend  the double decker (i think thats what the roll is called), tataki roll, and rainbow roll, all sustainable sushi, mostly with fish that is farmed in tanks, and not in wetlands. wetlands is where the junk and toxins from the farms can flow into the ocean. u should skip the dessert there - ice cream mochi and green tea cheesecake isnt really anything to rave about like their sustainable sushi, but for their noble cause in being eco-friendly, this place is still 5 stars in my eyes. 

u should definitely expect a long wait on friday and saturday nites, from the time they open up to when they close. my friend and i got to tataki at 10:15pm on saturday night, and we waited about 30 min - every seat was taken. the service was so friendly - the lady came over and asked us if we wanted some edamame while we waited, which i thought was so nice. highly recommend this place. i'm peeved i didnt hear about this earlier!
author: Angie K.

description: Fantastic sushi, great prices, and environmentally responsible at the same time!  What more can you ask?  I will definitely be back!
author: Debbie M.

description: After walking by and seeing this place packed day by day, husband and I finally hit up the happy hour.  I started with the sangria which was delicious and had lychee in it too! We ordered the crab croquettes, which we could've done without, some happy hour specials and the golden gate roll.  The golden gate was something a little different than I've had in the past, so I'll note that.  The taste and and texture of everything together was really unique, and I enjoyed every bite.  The other more notable was the artic char roll.  It was really fresh the day we went in my opinion, and they really pack a lot of sashimi in.  I had no idea about eating responsibly when it came to sushi, so I really appreciated that about this place.
