It even had a little pamphlet on the table about what types of fish to eat, where they are caught and how you can determine whether or not they're eco-friendly.  Living in this neighborhood we'll probably go back often.
author: Jen T.

description: I had no idea that sustainable sushi existed as a concept (and I was veering away from going out for sushi altogether). I am delighted to have found this place via a Green Zebra coupon, and I will definitely be back. They have done the analysis of sustainable/safe or not for you - it can be very confusing, as the same fish in a different ocean, or caught in a nastier way, may have a different rating. In addition to reducing the guilt some of us have about how our tastes have been messing with the oceans, this place is delicious. And they have happy hour rolls in the early evening, such that going out could be very reasonable.
author: Ati C.

description: very tasty fish but terrible service. of the four things we ordered, the waiter forgot two, on two separate occasions. it was 10pm on a monday and the place was virtually empty, so the busy excuse doesn't count.
author: who k.

description: I am pretty picky about my sushi and this place definitely makes my taste buds happy!  It is a very small place with only a few tables, very intimate which is sometimes really nice (no loud, clanking noises of large restaurants).  The extinguisher is sooo yummy!! It's pretty spicy and comes with a baby fire on your plate (yes, an actual fire).  The prices are pretty good, especially sushi, which is always a more expensive dinner.  The service is great, very tentative to your needs.  Kiera is the best!  If you're ever cruising around SF, hit this place up!
author: Shawn L.

description:
quite an interesting place in the neighborhood.
good for group of 2-4, or even by yourself. the Tataki's tataki isn't bad but just not very tradition, it's good for ppl who wants to try something new. 
over all the dishes are good and fresh, especially the environment would make you stay longer, good for dating and drinks.
 they actually open till late nite, this is something unexpected
author: Mile W.

description:
Tataki is a great addition to the area. It's so good that Sushi Rock isn't even an option anymore. 

I'm so excited to see something good go into that spot. Let's make sure that this place sticks around.

Try the Tataki roll, the beef carpaccio tataki or the Extinguisher roll. All delicious.
author: David S.

description:
we went here because of the other reviews and its more or less in the neighborhood....we loved the sustainable fish consciousness  and the food was great, very efficient pleasant waitress..the food was not only delicious but beautiful to look at too...the restaurant is small and simple and clearly popular.

We'll be back for sure..and next time will try the bar and watch the two chefs at work....we love seeing the food prepared and we ate quite a bit and had beer  and a 'kin-sangria' --a mix of riesling, fresh fruit and lychee..not too sweet... and only spent about $55.....We did go early and they have some great deals for 'happy hour.'
author: katharine k.

description: Best spicy scallop hand rolls ever!!!!!
author: likes t.

description: this was possibly the best sushi i have ever had in sf- the rolls are distinct and fresh, and who doesnt want to eat fresh, organic and sustainable sushi? you cant make a reso here, and it it is quite small, so we had to wait about 30 mins- but well worth it. thy also have great sake for pretty cheap. we tried 7 different rolls and i loved all of them- cant wait to come back here soon!
author: Emmie B.

description: I've been here 2x and each time was incredible.  Amazing food, very creative items on the menu, I love the small-ish vibe of the joint.  You have to be prepared to wait though - the place is tiny and the line for a table can be long.  I just chalk that up to part of the experience.
author: Christin A.

description: This is, hands down, the best sushi place I've been to in the past 5 years.  The only negatives are how tiny the place is, and how they don't take reservations.  We sat at the bar, which has convenient purse hooks underneath.  They also have a coat rack near the bathroom.  We had the artic char carpaccio, which had a very slight fishy taste compared to the other dishes, but was nonetheless good.  The extinguisher roll was great on presentation, a bit too spicy in flavor - it covered up the taste of the fish.  The albacore nigiri melts in your mouth, the wahoo nigiri was extremely fresh, and the divisaderoll is delicious and a great deal at $6.  Skip the spicy tuna roll, it's overpriced for an "ok" roll.  The specialty drink, kin-sangria, was light and fruity, and absolutely delicious.  The mochi is good - overpriced, but that's any restaurant.  Service was good.  Overall, I really enjoyed the fact that they're conscious of sustainable fishing, and the quality was great!
author: Lyn Y.

description:
A couple of girlfriends and I went here for dinner on a Sunday. The restaurant is small and we had to wait for a table big enough to fit 3. (It was actually 2 individual tables pushed together.) They have a sign at the entrance announcing that parties have to be completely present in order to be seated. Parties of 2 got seated pretty quickly though.

I started off with the miso soup. This could be a positive or negative but it was bland. I don't feel like I have salty taste but I had to add more soy sauce into my soup. We then all shared the beef carpaccio. I didn't think that this dish was flavorful at all. A friend recommended it and that's why I ordered it. The taste of the meat reminded me of the rare beef that is used in Vietnamese Pho Noodle soup. This dish also came out after some of our rolls even though we told the waiter that we wanted it as our started. I guess I just don't understand why raw meat with some sauce on the sides would take longer than fancy sushi rolls. I also had the Mix It Up roll. I am not a fan of fish but I wanted to give this roll a try. I would say that the crab meat on top overpowered the dish. All I tasted from each bite was spicy crab meat. So I guess for me, it was a good dish because I didn't have to taste the tuna. 

My friends had the Hot Potato roll. They felt like it was a good veggie roll. The spicy tofuna was an interesting taste. I'm not a big vegetable person so I didn't really like the roll; it was kinda "weird" and nothing special. They also had 5 pieces of nigiri and said that it was really fresh fish. 

Overall, I feel that this restaurant was overpriced and provided average tasting food.
author: Jennifer C.

description: More recent visits to this restaurant have yielded inconsistent results. One time my Kampachi roll was a bit on the "mushy" side and tasted not so fresh.  While i love the idea of sustainable fish, I think quality has gone down since it opened.  There is also only very limited items available during lunch.  They took off the chicken teriyaki from the lunch menu.
author: N c.

description:
Got take out this evening and was very impressed with quality of sushi (and relieved to see compostable packaging!). 

Will order again soon...
author: Margaret M.

description: Yummy organic sushi at great prices! I was a little bummed that they didn't have salmon on the menu, but when I learned that it is because they use sustainable practices and do not serve any fish that are endangered or over fished/farmed, I was totally OK with no salmon! the rolls are very tasty, they have great vegetarian/vegan options and the fish they do serve is fresh and delicious. It can get very busy as it is a small place, but getting to listen to old school hip hop on the outdoor speakers while waiting made the long line worth it!
author: denise s.

description: Amazing! As a non-seafood eater, trips to sushi restaurants are usually a drag. avocado or cucumber roll, salad, miso soup, maybe veggie tempura... but Tataki has total changed my opinion of going out for sushi. They have an entire page of vegetarian sushi and non-sushi items, and they also had some sushi with steak! I had a ratatouille roll, which was tempura veggies wrapped up in a roll, and it was one of the best things i have ever tasted. I also had the steak, avocado, cucumber roll, which was pretty tasty. The service was attentive and prices were reasonable. We had about a 15 minute wait on a wednesday night -- which was completely reasonable considering how good this food is!
author: rachel s.

description: Guilt-free sushi - how can you not love that?  They have great lunch and happy hour specials.  Service is a little slow, but the sushi makes up for it.  Lychee sangria doesn't hurt either.
author: C L.

description: delicious! fresh sushi all the time. not a lot to offer on menu. but makes the best out of it. maintains sustainable seafood. good call with the extinction of species. parking some what hard to find.
author: Sarah O.

description: yes, i am a fan. and would recommend this place. fish was fresh, no fishy fish. and absolutely loved the happy hour prices! great salmon handroll! yummy greentea cheesecake. would go back! but the place is very small. so, go early or something!
author: Sasa S.

description: The food was good but I would hardly call the price reasonable.  We left hungry with a large bill to show for it.  I thought the waitress was very odd and cold and I guess service means a great deal to me.  She never once asked how things were and when we tried to wave to her politely to obtain more food, she seemed genuinely annoyed and expressed it with her odd demeanor.  I wouldn't bother going back again.  I'm sick of paying expensive prices for service that is cold and impersonal.
author: S.C. H.

description: AMAZING sushi, SO fresh! Great Happy Hour and it's always nice to know what kind of fish you're getting! Highly reccomended!
author: Luba R.

description: Ehh, won't be returning. Great moral premise about sustainable fish and all, if you don't mind being slapped across the face with it, and then eating sub par fish. The chefs sashimi platter is always a good acid test of fish and had some questionably oily cuts. One hardcore sushi fan that will not be returning to Tataki for a third roll (of the dice) and side of moral superiority upside the head.
author: R D.

description: The food was excellent! We had to wait 1hour but it was worth it! It is not a five because we paid too much -for example  the sangria was $7.5 for a really small glass!!
author: Joana R.

description: This was one of the best sushi experiences of my life. Maybe *the* best, since I felt comfortable knowing that the fish was sustainable and carefully researched and chosen. Kudos to the owners! I stopped eating sushi earlier this year as I learned more about fishing practices, overfishing, the impact on other sea life, etc.  Oh, it's hard trying to care about the world! Anyway, on top of the awesome philosophy of the place, the sushi was absolutely delicious, melt in your mouth good! I went with two recovering vegetarians who had never had non-vegetarian sushi before, and my sister's friend who knows a ton about sustainable fish. It was so exciting being able to order without constantly checking the Monterey Seafood Watch guide (which they did have out on every table, awesome! The sushi one comes out on Oct 22). We had the Golden State (scallops and apples - awesome!), the Extinguisher (spicy and delicious, and the plate comes on fire!), and skipjack, prawn and black cod nigiri. My friends had the Reggae, Veggie Philly and Tataki Rolls, and we traded a few pieces here and there. Everything was fantastic. Our waitress was not only super nice and totally on top of things, she also was totally informed and had an answer for every question we asked about the fish. I seriously am going to go here all the time. I missed sushi so much, and I'm so happy to be able to have it again!
author: Janet G.

description: The first truly sustainable sushi restaurant in North America! Val's colleague from MIIS sources all the fish, he also works for a non-profit dedicated to sustainable seafood. I had a few firsts when I went, which was the Uni (sea urchin) and pickled jellyfish salad. I actually liked the jellyfish, which is good since it will be about the only thing we have left to eat from the oceans in about 30 years unless we do something drastic to reduce overfishing. The Uni tasted like gritty condensed seawater...not my favorite, but I didn't nearly vomit like one of our friends that came along with us. I probably won't order Uni again voluntarily. The other 99% of our meal was full of amazing fish that took us on a journey of sustainability throughout the world's oceans. Everything we had (aside from the Uni, which is personal taste) was absolutely delicious and about as fresh as possible. The Sake was also amazing, we had several different varieties, and our server was a sake sommelier so we were in good hands as she described the subtleties of each of the sakes was tasted. This is an amazing place that I highly recommend, especially if you are genuinely concerned about the future of the oceans, our food supply, and sustainability. If you want to know what ocean going creatures are ok to eat, please take a minute to download the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Guide at: http://www.mbayaq.org/cr/SeafoodWatch.asp
author: Michael M.

description: Sustainable sushi! Brilliant AND tasty. Definitely talk to the servers about the menu. ALL San Francisco Sushi restaurants should get on board and follow suit. A must try sushi restaurant!
author: Nikki T.

description: Out of this world quality and creativity!!!  Place is not a college sake bomb spot, but rather a fantastic contemporary ultra high quality sushi experience.
author: Tory P.

description: So, I think it is only appropriate that Tataki is my first review on Yelp.  This small, intimate sushi restaurant is the real deal.  I have actually never had fresher fish served and I have been to dozens of them.  Its a little pricier than the average spot, but you are paying for delicous food that is raised and farmed in a sustainable way.  Yes, some restaurants tout their sustainablblity hallmark, but Tataki is 100% genuine about their efforts toward this worthy cause.  I even over heard one of the owners mentioned that "we're going to put jelly fish on the menu so that customers ask why we serve it and we will respond by saying that if we are not careful, we will all be eating jelly fish in the years to come b/c that will be the only thing left to eat in the ocean."  The owner is very passionate, genuine and happy to please.  He not only knows how to hire terrific sushi chefs, run a restaurant, and find the best/freshest fish he also seems to be a really good guy and is some one I am more than happy to give my money to.  I recommend this place for couples or some groups (4 max.).  The restaurant is simply too small for anything larger than that.  I was impressed all around by the food, presentation and friendly staff.  This is restaurant is 100% attitude-free, no egos what-so-ever.  I took my girlfriend last weekend for her birthday and I would recommend this place to other couples or very small groups (4 max.).  They do not take reservations and that may be my only complaint of the evening.  I wish Tataki the best of luck, we need more restaurants and people like them.
author: Jeff L.

description: Wow was this place disappointing. I don't know what sushi the rest of you reviewers had, and i don't want to believe that sustainable = awful, but the fish was not fresh, and none of the specialty rolls were anything other than average fish with gimmicky garnish like sweet sauces, tobiko, roe, or a small flame to distract your taste buds from the mediocrity underneath. I won't be coming back.
author: EZ R.

description: The attitude of the waiters in this place ranges from mildly annoying to infuriating.  Our waiter was just rude.  I have been here 3 times and service is always a problem.  We waited about 10 minutes and were the only ones waiting. No one suggested having a drink or even told us how long it would be.  When we were seated, the food came in piecemeal. The sushi was generally good but not great, same quality as Godzilla for twice the price.  The albacore was cut way too thick for sashimi and it was a not a good value.  They always try to make up for quality by making things even spicier and it rarely works.  I asked if they use real crab on a roll when I ordered and he said yes. Then we get some kind of chopped crab salad dollop on top of the roll (with hot sauce of course to make you forget about the fact it is not whole crab meat).  Wine is priced by the full glass and served in a shot glass.  It is frustrating to pay $10 for a glass of wine and get a 3 oz. portion.
author: Z A.

description: As someone who likes high quality fish and companies focused on environmental sustainability I can enthusiastically recommend Tataki.  I've only been once but greatly enjoyed my food.  I got my standard- miso soup, seaweed salad and spicy tuna roll (hot sauce version, hold the mayo).  The miso was flavorful, the tuna was sweet and the seaweed salad was good as well.  The venue is small so if you're going with a group you may have to wait a bit for a table.  That said, it's well worth it.
author: Aaron P.

description: Went in right when happy hour started, so there was no wait.  Nice small restaurant with quality fish. Got the 9 piece nigiri and every piece of fish I got was so fresh. My favorite there was the amaebi! It was so good, I had to get another piece! The fried calamari on the happy hour menu was also very good too. Had the right amount of spice on it and was probably the best I've had.
author: Jonathan M.

description: GREAT sushi!  Love the Early Bird roll.  Slow service
author: Caroline Y.

description:
i feel torn about tataki. i felt like some things on the menu were excellent and others very mediocre. i found some of the nigiri to be very bland and there was too much rice. but the rolls were good (divisadero and rainbow)... but i think that a sushi restaruant that is too focused on rolls tends to be mediocre. and i hated the hour wait. 

good things? cheap!! if value matters, then this place fits the bill. great, awesomely clean bathroom. i think it may be the nicest restaurant bathroom i've ever been to (minus hotel restaurants). the uni was pretty darn good as well. plus it's a super close walk to my apt.

overall, it's a good place that will fill you up. if you're a  sushi officionado- then it's a pass. head to sebo.
author: Eliza K.

description: The fish literally MELTS in your mouth. Yes, like butter. The sustainability factor is certainly an added perk. Went there for lunch yesterday and I will certainly be going back very soon. Food aside, the place is intimate but tastefully decorated with a modern twist...even the restroom has some good decorative flavor to it.
author: Evelyn R.

description: Thinking about the sushi from this place is making my mouth water.  Everything was really fresh.  I've never had black cod, aji mackeral, or char.  They were all excellent.  Will definitely come back and eat here again.
author: A M.

description: We live in the neighborhood and have supported this sushi since they opened. Their popularity is a testament to their good sushi but unfortunately the good sushi does not outweigh their rude staff. After spending almost $50 on sushi they wouldn't even give us soy sauce to go. There are too many good sushi places in this city to be abused by rude staff. I won't be going back here again!
author: Michelle L.

description: My bedroom is bigger than this!! Well what can you expect from a restaurant located in SF.  Okay so the place is tiny, the decor is nice, and the place is intimate,  They managed to have sushi bar to seat 4 people. The tables are tiny and I felt like I'd knock every thing down if I moved a muscle.  This place literally fits like 25-30 people.  I figured service would be better but the waitress took forever to take our order and when she did she suprised me by not writing my order down on a check and guess what she missed one of our orders.  And I told her I wanted to cancel it since the food did not really give me any reason to keep it coming. The amount of food compared to the price was not equvilent because taste was not there. They did not once ask if everything was okay? I would not go here again. I order the fried calamari which was dired and not succulent and does not melt in your mouth like others I've had.  The seafood salad was tiny and I didn't really dig the vinegar dressing. The MIX IT UP was a traditional spicy tuna roll with an addition of crab meat on top. Nothing special for $12 bucks. A otal tab of about $30 bucks with tip.
author: dave c.

description: This place is great.  Unusual, but awesome sushi.  Get there before 7 and they have a really great happy hour as well - drinks and sushi.  The staff seemed nice and well informed, and the price was very reasonable considering the quality.  Only downside is that it's retardedly small and they don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait.
author: Gregorio S.

description: This new neighborhood spot was good enough for me to start a yelp account! I live down the street and since they opened, (2 or 3 weeks ago?) I have been twice. Inventive and delicious roles, and the seared fish dishes make it unique. Great service and cute ambiance. Godzilla down the street was my go to place for a long time but I found my new neighborhood spot, this is leaps and bounds better. Yum.
author: Lauren Q.

description: After reading so many rave reviews, and since the restaurant was in our neighborhood, my hubby and I thought we should try it out.  We thought it was okay, but nothing to write home about.  The rolls were overseasoned with either too much spicy sauce or mustard-vinagarette that you could hardly taste the raw fish at all.  The sushi rice was a little too mushy and wet.  The amaebi nigiri, however, was one of the best I've had in SF.  I wouldn't mind going back again but to order just the nigiri.
author: C L.

description: Some of the freshest, most delicious sushi in San Francisco.  Like the idea that they are thoughtful in selecting sustainable seafood only.  The fauxnagi made with artic char was so good, we ordered a second helping.  49er roll was super.  The only thing we didn't like was the way they served the sake -- in a very cute carafe with an open ice cube compartment on the side -- once the is melted, the water sloshed out.  But the sake was excellent.
author: mickey t.

description: YUM!!  And it's guilt free because they make sure you're not eating anything endangered.  The place is very intimate (read small) but totally hip atmosphere.
author: A N.

description:
went here with my mom and aunt before cabbing to the post street theater to see burn the floor...the show was alright, but the sushi at tataki we are still talking about.  

first impression doesn't do much - we honestly had a talk about going somewhere else when we saw the outside...its just tiny and unimpressive looking, but we are glad we stuck with our original plan and trusted the yelpers, because our meal was great.  definitely don't miss out on this place and when you go order the sangria, they put reisling and leche in it.  YUM!!!
author: Karen M.

description: Great place. Reluctant to rave too much because it is a small place and I want to go back. Very friendly staff and the sushi is fantastic. Not a huge premium for sustainably caught fish--so eat away and feel socially conscious.  Nicely done Tataki!
author: Ty G.

description: Loved it! Solid sushi, with a newer feel/sustainable twist. Very mellow atmosphere and great service. We asked questions about the sake and got knowledgeable answers, that showed a bit of study on the servers part. Sashimi plate comes in 3 sizes, good for choice. All the fish was fresh and well displayed. Not too pricey for what we got; $52 for ocean salad, medium sashimi plate (3 slices of 4 kids of fish), spicy tuna, California roll and a bottle of sake. I am excited to try happy hour, which looks fab, and they have a really well dome vegetarian menu for those so inclined.
author: Caitlin S.

description: went there on a Monday night and were seated very quickly. the decor is really nice and welcoming. some of the nicest and most informed staff Ive ever dealt with. everyone there has a passion for what there doing and it shows. My girlfriend a vegan felt right at home they have many great options. the double double roll is off the hook and the vegan reggae roll was great too and im not vegan so there you go.  If you go there be sure to try the ocean salad and ask your server to recommend some sake for the first time in my life ive enjoyed sake rather than the usual Sapporo . this place is a must for any sushi enthusiast and if your vegan all the better.
author: dan m.

description: There were some interesting creations here with Kampachi and Arctic Char.... not a very "traditional" place, but enticing nonetheless. I'm going to give this place a 4 and go back again!
author: Shwin S.

description: Four of us ate here on Saturday night and it was delicious!  I'm not a sushi connoisseur, but i certainly appreciate unique, fresh sushi, and this is probably my favorite that i've tried in the city.  They have a lot of spicy rolls with a unique twist.  They also have a whole list of vegetarian rolls that were unique and looked delicious as well.  We will definitely be going back.  It's small and they don't take reservations, so we had to wait about 20 minutes to sit - not too bad for a saturday night though.
author: Suzanna J.

description:
best place to get sushi in SF so far :)

coming back from 2 years in Japan i have to admit i'm spoiled when it comes to sushi. but this place is great for an american sushi place!  the pieces of fish are a lot smaller but i can't really complain too much.  the service was fantastic (went on Halloween nite... finally getting around to reviewing!) and the food was delicious.  

We went with the nigiri sampler...? i forgot what it was called but the server asked us what types of fish we liked and the chef selected fish to our tastes! it was amazing.  he got everything just right.  the fish that they served was so soft and just melted in my mouth.  i have to say it was the best restaurant experence ive had since moving back to america. 

the decor is really cute too... since we went on halloween the 2 chefs were dressed as batman and joker. its a really small place but we were seated right away and our server made sure we had everything we needed.

tataki u guys are the best!
author: S T.

description: wow! that may have been the best fish i have ever eaten! the arctic char was unbelievable as was the cod, salmon, tuna...everything was delish. i am usually a sashimi and very basic rolls only type but we had some of their specialty rolls and they were fabulous! one had spicy scallops inside  with apples that was amazing (golden state). they even had wheat free soy sauce on hand for me! actually, the only thing i didn't like was baked mackeral on skewers, it was too fishy for me but my brother and his friend both liked it.  it was a friday night so we did wait but they gave us warm tea to sip on the bench outside while my brother tried to explain the ins and outs of investment banking to me, a poor dumb scientist with no clue.
author: celiac j.

description:
overall, best sushi spot in the city. surrriously. ingredients are fresh, sustainably sourced, and beautifully presented. check out the reggae roll and the extinguisher. and don't forget a side of the croquettes! yum. 

only thing i would change is the location. this place should be closer to my house. ;)
author: melinda h.

description: i think i'm going to refer to this place as a 'convenient truth' because it's an eco-conscious restaurant that would make Al Gore proud. i couldn't get enough of the spicy 'tofuna' roll. by far, one of my favorite sushi places in the city. next time Al's in town, i know exactly where to go for dinner.
author: kirti p.

description: Loved this place: delicious sushi, wonderful presentation, and amazing sake.
author: Anastasia V.

description: Came here on a whim as Godzilla sushi down the street had a long wait.  Initially drawn to the faux bamboo menu frames and the roll that was being served to the table by the door had fire coming from it which seemed pretty cool.  After a somewhat long wait our food made it to the table and was quite good.  I recommend the spicy tempura roll which comes on another very eye pleasing plate.  Overall a fairly good experience.  Despite the quiet and dim atmosphere, the food was great.
author: Shane L.

description: My girlfriend and I went to Tataki on a Saturday night and after seeing the place from the car I expected that we would have to wait 30 min (this restaurant is literally a whole in the wall, only bad part is the limited seating). However, there were two tables open and two seats at the bar so we sat at the bar and greatly appreciated the friendliness and warm smiles from the  two sushi chefs behind the counter. The sushi rolls and appetizers at this restaurant are very original and detail oriented. The chefs use different colored fish eggs and lemon peels on assorted rolls to add color and just that extra hint of flavor. I would recommend ordering the house roll, Tataki roll, delicious and very different! Also, I would recommend the V.I.P. roll, its not on the menu but it is absolutely delectable and involves the chef slightly torching the fish. For an appetizer try the Ahi Tuna Poke,  fresh raw ahi tuna assortments with three different flavors topped with flavor infused fish eggs, something I have never seen before. Great place, very homey yet hip with a very friendly environment. What makes this sushi restaurant break the boundary between mediocre and excellent is that all the fish comes from sustainable sources and is environmentally safe.
author: Alex G.

description: This place is GREAT. Especially the Staff. New Happy Hour menu is outstanding just what the neighborhood needs. Excellent all around!
author: Steve S.

description: I live right down the street and was a bit dubious about a new sushi place opening up, given how many others are in the area, but this was a pleasant surprise.  The place has nice decor, great staff, and very fresh fish, all with the added benefit of priding itself on a sustainable menu.    The prices are very reasonable too.  Will definitely be going back here.
author: Brian S.

description: normally as a vegetarian, i feel like sushi places have limited selection for me.  at tataki, not only was there a whole vegetarian menu, but everything was delicious!  plus my husband, who is not vegetarian, loved the fish too.  and even though we went on friday night, since we were there relatively early (6pm) we were seated right away, and the service was very efficient.  overall, we were very happy.
author: Raga K.

description: if i could give a jillion stars i would. i love LOVE love this place, it is a bit small, but for sure worth it.  the owner is so cool, and smart.  they offer AMAZING GLUTEN FREE options, if you ask they can make anything g/f or put sauces on the side.  BEST SUSHI IN THE CITY, HANDS DOWN
author: Jess L.

description: the best veggie sushi menu ever!! you gotta have the tofuna roll and reggae roll. we wanted to try them all, but we weren't that hungry, can't wait to go back! the specialty rolls took some time, but the preso was amazing! loved it!!
author: bhavna p.
